reviews.review: A hidden jewel. This gem is a must see for anyone interested in the history of Rome. 2,000years of history carefully & lovingly brought to life with a light show highlighting the features and recreating this amazing villa right in the heart of Rome. This is the second visit for us to the domus Romane as we were blown away the first time. We will be visiting here on every trip as we enjoy the presentation so much Please note that it is recommended to buy tickets before visiting Rome as the tours are limited numbers (12 in each group I think) and book well in advance (Be sure to book tour in right language)The highlight for me is the mossiac which is remarkably well preserved an then filled with lighting display to show the beauty of the floor.The staff are friendly welcoming and helpful It is a superb example of a first class visitor attraction in Rome & well worth a visit

Very engaging. We all enjoyed this..including our 9 year old son. Really good to see an archaeological site being so well set up to engage the minds of young and old, and take us back in time to sit in the frigidarium..even if in our mind. Highly recommended.

The Best We Have Been To.... This is one of the best experiences we have had in our month in Europe. If you are into history and any form of archeology, then this should be on your list.The museum entrance is right beside the Trajan Column and you head underneath the Palazzo Valentini where the desire to build an underground car park in 1998 discovered the ruins of two Roman mansions beneath the foundations.The museum was opened over the ruins in 2010. Walking underground on the glass floor through the actual ruins and with recreation through multimedia is a fantastic hour an a half experience.You do need to book as they have specific English speaking tour times and you cannot go without a tour.For 27 Euro for a couple, this is an absolute must see!

Unexpected treasure. It was part of our tour group and I wasn't at all sure what to expect, but it was a terrific multi-media presentation in the ruins of an ancient Roman house. Nothing that hasn't been said already. If you are prone to vertigo, you might be uncomfortable on the glass walkways, but if not, the experience is well worth it.

A don't miss hidden gem. The buried remains of the 4th century home of a wealthy Roman recently uncovered below the Palazzo Venezia near the Victor Emmanuel II monument. An outstanding multi-media presentation showing actual ruins and 3-D images of what the room/building must have looked like originally. This tour was better than the Roman Forum or the Palatine Hills in its presentation and information.

facnitating experience setting a new benchmark for archeological sites. In 1998 under a 16th century Renaissance building in Piazza Venezia in front of the Traian column they found the ruins of two magnificent roman villas of the 3rd century AD The museum was opened in 2010 and it is unique since they manage to recreate via visual effects how the villas looked like in their good old times and how their owners were living among spas and banquets. the effects are extraordinary, the narrative is excellent and the ruins themselves have some extraordinary artifacts.The guided tour of approximately 90m must be booked in advance and obviously you must choose the language you want the tour in. the entrance of the museum is on the rear of the building in front of the Traian column oversseing fori imperiali. be there a few minutes ahead of the scheduled start.unlike some of the comments I read, I found the staff very kind, polite and professional. a friend of mine was late, they kept his ticket at the front desk and escorted him downstairs upon his arrival.the tour may not be recommended if you suffer from vertigo or have impaired vision. you walk in the dark over glass floors laid over the ruins. beamers suddenly lit up the ruins and visual effects complement them to provide an idea of how they looked like. the glass floors may be uncomfortable for those suffering from vertigo. the visit is good for young children.

dont go if you have vertigo. While interesting from an archeological perspective,themulti sensory experience is a bit overwhelming. The sudden shifts in the floor and lighting can have the same kind of effect as strobe lights.Our guide was not happy at leading an English speaking group as was evident by his responses to questions. There was a diabetic man in our group who needed some water and the guide was very nasty about assisting him. They also stop in an area to buy souvenirs for about 10 minutes where you are almost forced to purchase something. This s about 20 minutes before the tour is ended. Normally this would be after a tour in a gift shop but the obviously want you to be a captive audience

Unique & fascinating experience!. Who would guess that underneath a Renaissance palace are the ruins of one of the largest private homes of ancient Rome??The ruins were uncovered in 1998 and archaeologists have found more and more of the foundations of this ancient structure since then.What is unique are the visual effects they produce OVER the ruins to show what the rooms may have looked like and that made it come alive.....from the beautiful mosaic floors to all the grand columns, etc. Second best to being in Pompeii!

Great experience!. More of an experience to see how they lived back in the day, than an actual museum with artifacts, but I thought that was what made it so unique. Even our young child stayed interested. We were careful to get tickets for the English speaking tour.

Excellent little museum. Last year before going to Rome i read a report from a man who had stayed in a small b& b in Rome and the owner had told him to visit this museum as it normally gets missed off of peoples itineraries.I did and have been telling people to go every since each time i am in Rome.It really is a good place to go look it up

Surprisingly Interesting.. Went here on a suggestion from our Hotel (Armony Suites) friend, Luca. We had absolutely no idea what we were going to see. In the end, the 90+ minutes really was worth it. Located right in front of the Trajan Column, the entrance was a little difficult to find but after that all went well. Guided, audio, in English for our group, tour took us underground to view 1st and 4th century roman excavations, findings, re-creations. Really amazing archaeological work. Nice connections made to modern times and yet helped you to build an appreciation for the Roman time period, and then the Renaissance thereafter. Very educational and enlightening.

Subterranean Sensation. Recommended by a friendly Italian tour guide - who showed us round the Colosseum and The Vatican - this fascinating insight into Rome's history and culture is quite tricky to find, thus missed by too many visitors. We went in a party of four adults and four children 8-16 and all were enthralled by the guide's narration, aided by stunning visual presentations which transported us beneath the surface of this wonderful city. The tour lasted around 90 minutes and was very inexpensive. A must-do, but booking essential as parties are limited.

Amazing experience, but not for kids!. My husband and I went here expecting to be walked around some old ruins. The narration and computer regeneration effects they have are fantastic. The tour took close to 2 hours, and included a 30-minute video about Trajan's Column. I wouldn't recommend this for young kids, because it is dark and there aren't any places to sit, bathrooms, or quiet areas to access during your tour.

I'd like to give 5* but I can't. The visit itself is very informative and you can see the remains of ancient Roman houses. The projections really help you understand how it was back then.The only problem is the size of the group. The rooms are small and it’s a bit awkward trying to move around. There are times when you won’t be able to see everything because of other people. When we arrived, there were four people missing in our group and it made a huge difference.

Super interesting tour. We were pleasantly surprised how interesting this tour of an underground archeological site was. Combination of video, audio and light show did a good job of portraying 4th century Roman life.

A must see atraction in Rome. It was an interactive, attractive and really enjoyable tour in Rome, where we could see hear, and imagine lives of ancient Romans. Historic details were presented with great care and weren't boring at all.

Interesting, but not what I expected.. Two years ago, a hotel staff recommended this a a great place to see mosaics found underground Rome. We weren't able to go then, but on this return trip made it there. We tried to go on three separate occsissions before we were able to get in. I know you can make a reservation and pay in advance, but I refuse to pay the extra booking fee if I walk in the door and make a reservation. So, the staff were neutral- not overly helpful, and friendly, but not rude. I expected to be able to see some ancient mosaics, which I did, but it is sort of a "story". About how the ancient Romans lived as you go through different parts of an excavated home. The ruins are below you - there is a glass floor- but the multi media program makes it hard to really envision how the whole place came together because you are essentially in the car with only certain points being described spotlighted. It he multi media story was neat, but I would have liked to see the whole area lit up so that I could get a full picture of how it looked. It is also narrated by a recording, and the tour guide just ushers you from place to place to go along with the recording. The tour guide does describe some neat artifacts in the museum, but you are rushed through and can't take your time to look around at everything. The information at the end about Trajan's column was very. Interesting. I came back and did some more reading about Trajan after that. Overall, it was fine, and interesting, but I needed more time to just look around and understand myself how this all fit together. Not a must see in Rome, but if you have time it is interesting. Also, no photos are allowed so you need to use your memory!

Absolute must see!. When you've seen all the ruins of the forum and colosseum, you must do this tour. It brings it all alive. An hour and a half of fascinating insight into Roman life with multimedia effects ending with a very special grand finale. So glad we fitted this into our itinerary. It is up there on our favourite bits of Rome list.
The first attration after Colosseum. For me this was the second attraction in Rome I liked. Impressive. Me and my partner really enjoyed. But you should book in advance, we stayed one hour to get in.

Absolutely fascinating!. If you are looking for ancient history this is the place for you! Instead of just yet another pile of rocks, this is a "multimedia museum". Prebook to a session in your language. You are led around the ruins of the house, pointing out important aspects and projections give an idea if what it was like in its splendor. It is fantastic to get perspective and context for information. BRILLIANT.

Fascinating visit. This visit takes you down through layers of Roman history to the remains of a large house from ancient Rome, parts of which are surprising well preserved. Where they are not, a light show using computer graphics is used to re-imagine them. This is all very well done and the visit is a good introduction to other Roman remains. One of our group was initially somewhat nervous about walking on the glass floor that covers much of the site, but soon got used to it. The tour ends at the base of Trajan's column and there is a short film about this. This was OK, but not really connected to the house itself, so it seemed like a bit of a time-filling add-on.

A must!. Booked this not really knowing what to expect. Our guide was a little hard to understand, but this didn't matter as there was video & audio guide. The experience was amazing. You start by walking down underground, which is lovely on a hot day, and walking on a large glass floor. This is then lit to reveal excavated ruins of 2 roman villas. You pass from room to room, reavealing more rooms, baths and courtyards. There is a lot to see and well worth visiting. One of the best sites we visited while in Rome!

Good start before exploring Forum. I liked it. The group was small. Visionaries were wonderful and helped to imagine how Romans lived centuries ago. I would recommend this place. The only minus - when you see it, you understand that Rome has been built on ruins. It's really pity.I'd like to see everything what we have under Rome. However, it's nearly impossible due to new buildings.

Interesting tour of ruins unearthed beneath a more modern Palazzo. This is an indoor attraction, walking on clear/see through flooring over excavated ruins of an ancient Domus. Very interesting, but pales in comparison to the ruins of Pompeii. Great to see if you won't see any other large excavated sites.
Okay - but too long, dark and not really a lot to see. Certainly it helps recreate what a house might have looked like - but too long and hard to find. Go to a museum or Pompeii instead

You don't need to imagine how Rome used to look anymore!. What a cool place!!! you get to go underneath the buildings and visit excavations of old Roman villas. Not only you get to see what's underneath the city but thanks to an amazing technological hologram type show you see the images of the reconstruction of the place right in front of your eyes. Not to mentioned this is indoors so you get a break from the heat in the summer! My kids loved it!

Hidden gem. It is the second time my husband and I have done this tour. We thoroughly enjoyed it. Although there is a guide taking you around to view discoveries made during an excavation, the narration is done using video/audio guides. Something that would improve this tour is if the guide was more receptive to answering questions about what is being viewed.

one of the best attraction in rome. It was really good experience . it was build on the old roman house and you were standing on glass the whole tour and the house was under your feet which was very cool. In the tour with help of projectors it is described how the romans lived in this place. Really worth the money.

Very Cool. We booked in advance for a tour in English. Wow! I love archeology so the light show bringing it all to life was great. It was cool in the heat of the day and the finale with an explanation of the relief on Trajan's Column was much easier than trying to decipher at the museum.Well worth the money.... Good for interested kids too.

One of our Rome Highlights!. I can't say enough good things about this experience. It is a small group guided tour so get your tickets before you leave for Rome. The site is undoubtedly the home of a significant Roman figure in history as part of it sits on the very temple of Trajan itself just a stones throw from his column. A column contained in the site is the largest ever found in Rome, larger than the columns of the Pantheon! The ruins three floors below ground level are visible through glass flooring and enhanced by multimedia projections that give you a vivid idea of their original appearance. This was once the home of someone very important and extraordinarily wealthy. If you want a special memory of your trip to Rome, don't miss this!

Ancient Roman Town House. This immersive multimedia walking tour leads the visitor on clear glass floors, from room to room, above the remains of a patrician Roman house discovered under the Palazzo Valentini. Well-designed projections accompany the informative, dramatic narrative and background music, illuminating the rooms and describing daily life in ancient Rome as reflected in the domestic architecture of the period. The tour is a good complement to the public spaces exemplified in the ruins of the Imperial Forums and the Colosseum on the street level above. The concluding illustrated description of the helical frieze around Trajan's Column brings to life in extraordinary detail Trajan's victory over the Dacians.

Time Travel at its best. Book online well in advance, they allow only a small amount of people at a time, and not all tours are in English. It is an amazing holigramatic reconstruction of life in ancient Rome. These villas were discovered thanks to the excavations taking place to build the third metro line. A journey in the past, feeling you are a ghost from the future, or surronded by shadow of a past which appears at present. A must see.

Up-close look at archeology. We were a bit skeptical about this tour, but decided to book anyway. We're glad we did! The tour provided an unusual, very interesting perspective on the ruins that lie beneath the streets of Rome. There is a see-through floor over the ruins and as the narrator talks, the areas that he is talking about are lit up. At the end of the presentation in each room, there is a light display that shows how the room might have looked during the Roman era. It was great to be able to walk over the ruins instead of viewing them from the side which is the normal viewing perspective. You visit various areas of the house and see baths, mosaics, living areas, staircases, etc. Near the end of the tour, there is a video about Trajan's column that tells the story that is carved on that monument. I wouldn't rate this a "must-see" attraction, but if you are spending a few days in Rome, it's well worth a visit. Our children (ages 10 and 12) enjoyed it too! Be sure to book it in advance.

Enjoyed this . We visited this attraction based on TA reviews. I prebooked my English tour for 1:30 before I left the UK to ensure our entry. My family ( 2adults & 2 kids age 7 and 9) really enjoyed it. Having spent the week trying to imagine what the ruins we were seeing might have looked once like, it was great seeing the light impressions of what the houses were once like. The staff at the attraction weren't overly friendly and your guide doesn't speak to you, it is all automated and recorded. I think it is a little on the expensive side but group sizes are small so still worth doing. Ending the tour at the base of Trajans column after an explanation of the "comic strip" was super ( though you can't get outside to see it, just look through a metal gate).

Incredible multi media presentation. See this exhibit in Rome. The multi media prsesentation is amazing. It is offered in different languages too. Honestly, the web site does not do it justice.The history lying beneath Rome is as incredible as what is at street level. Book your visit time .. You won't be disappointed!

Fascinating. Our travel agent told us about the Domus Romane, which was not open the last time we were in Rome, and it was a good tip. It was especially interesting to learn about the process of discovering and uncovering these archeological treasures which remain buried under the streets of Rome.
Astonishing!. This is a must see in Rome! Completely astonishing! especially if you are into archeology. Make sure to book in advance since the groups are limited on 15 people

Domus Romane failed effort. Online, I bought two tickets for 8/1 2:00 pm presentation of Domus Romane. We arrived early at 12:00 to pick up our tickets, and were surprised when we were told we missed our 9:30 slot. I am confident that I booked the 2:00 slot since English tours were 1:30, 2:00 and 2:30. I had tried the 2:30 first and that was not available. I then went to 2:00 and was happy to see the "Avanti" button to proceed with the order. The hotel desk attendant had printed the confirmation for us, and I did try to double check the info "date/ora lun 1/08/16 0.00. I commented to my husband that they didn't note the time. The entire confirmation info was printed in Italian, and we don't read Italian. I didn't realize at the time, that a bit further down there was printed another selection which said 9:30. So -- upon arrival early for our tour, we were informed that there was nothing Domus Romane could do for us. They took no responsibility and did not even acknowledge the possibility of a computer error. They insisted that this could not be possible and said nothing could be done. I understand that the tours were limited in number of people; however, I was very unhappy with the attitude and unhelpful manner in which we were treated.
Well worth a visit. Once you get over walking on the glass floor, it is a stunning site. Don't miss this one, well worth the entrance price.

Don't Rely on Website for Tour Times. Before I left on my Rome vacation I checked on the website for English tour times: there are only 3 a day (in the middle of the day, when all good Italians are having their long lunch)... and many of them were already booked. However, when I showed up, the people at the front desk told me that lots of tours were added at the last minute.. and in fact there was plenty of room in the 11 a.m. tour (not listed on their website).I highly recommend trying to get in. It's a 90 minute tour. The first hour walks you over the remains of several Roman houses... just beware, it's a little disconcerting to walk on a clear, glass floor. The last half hour covers Trajan's Column and when the tour is finished, you are looking straight out at the column. (In fact the tour office for this attraction is in the half-circle of buildings facing Trajan's Column.On the tour I attended there was a couple with a stroller. It's doable, but just know that you are going to have to carry the stroller up/down several flights of stairs if you do this.Good to know: this attraction is open on Monday, when many things in Rome are closed.

A multi-media exploration of an ancient Roman palace. This multi-media tour is very unique, the group is led from room to room, as you are standing on glass floors above the original historic floors below which are illuminated with projected images and lights. You definitely need to book in advance.

visit a roman villa. innovative lighting by laser and some great remains uncovered gives a real sense of the scale and beauty of a roman villa. lots of information from the guide but no freedom wander at all and no photo's

Highlight of the week. Fabulous tour of the Roman and Venetian palace remains. The whole tour comes to life with virtual representations of what was there originally supported by the actual building remains. Ending with a fabulous view of the Trajan column. Thoroughly enjoyed every minute and would recommend highly.

Unique experience. We have been on this tour on two separate trips to Rome and enjoyed both visits. Second time with our 14 year old boys. Your walk on a glass floor above the remains of what was an ancient villa overlooking Trajan's column. Augmented reality shows you what the house looked like during Roman times. A hidden gem in Rome and a must see attraction!

Roman Houses brought to life. We stumbled on this museum by chance one evening we couldn`t get into a concert in Via Nazionale. Not far from Piazza Venezia this palace is the entrance to a fascinating system of underground passageways into which one enters to encounter a visual extravaganza recreating the Roman House unearthed during renovations. Not for the faint-hearted who don`t like standing on plate glass with nothing apparently below. But well lit and well guided with those who bring the rooms to life. The piece de resistance is at the end of the tour when you emerge in a basement room from which you can see the base of Trajan`s column - a different perspective on this incredible piece of monumental architecture.

Wonderful experience for all levels. We did this tour today. It was incredible, truly a hidden gem. Good for families. We had two teenagers and they enjoyed watching the joining of technologies to take a glimpse into the past.

Interesting and entertaining-light and laser show. This was recommended by our B&B. We have been to Rome several times but this was a very interesting and entertaining attraction. The glass floors do take some getting used to but after that it is great to see Rome lit up and the narration was also informative. I would recommend this for the adults and older children. A little bit of Disney to the theme.... Hats off to Luca for the recommendation and thanks for scheduling this in the afternoon given the July heat!!!

Just a bad customer experience. In the interests of being balanced, I have reviewed this place very highly before, however this time around I experienced some bad customer service that left a bitter taste.Having booked to see this attraction, and this time taking my kids, I was hit by a delay on my flight to Rome. No one's fault, these things happen, but I was 2 hours later than planned. By the time I got to this attraction I had missed my slot.Despite providing all the evidence to prove my story was genuine they would not let us in, they would not allow us to come back another day, and they would not issue a refund. In fact when I asked to speak to the Manager she could not have cared less.€60 down the drain. Thanks for nothing you miserable devils!

Favorite. I highly recommend to visit this site. When I asked my kids what was their favorite thing in Italy, they loved this place! It is a great thing to do in the afternoon as it has AC. It is really cool to step on the glass floors and slowly see ancient ruins lit up dramatically beneath you. We went there around 1:00 and were able to get a guided tour for the 3:00pm time slot. It was really neat to see an underground ancient ruin and to learn about Trajan's obelisk and market. The Roma pass works there.

Highly interesting. Very interesting prevention of a Roman house from the late empire period using multi-media. Also, the tour covers Trajan's column. Note that the visit must be done with a tour so plan ahead on timing. Worth the time, which is a 90 min tour.It's also a nice respite from the heat of Rome as it is inside and underground.

When your running out of things to see...maybe.. This is 'ruins meets Disney' were you see the caverns of a Palazzo and Baths. Laser and lighting show is used to dramatize the pre-recorded tour. For me this was a waste of my time...but for the next guy, who knows? You can miss seeing a lot if your not first up to the small tight areas being featured. The guide did not manage the group well so many times the lights would go out before everyone in our group got a chance to get a look at what was being featured.

Very captivating experience. A must see. Shows how high roller Romans lived 2000 years ago. Lots of interesting objects and excavations overlaid with projectors for an interactive display so you're taken back in time. A must in Rome.

Ancient Rome brought to life!. This was a great place to visit. The ruins themselves were amazing but when they added the special effects it was like seeing Rome as it once was. Obviously there was quite a lot of guesswork-'this might have been' etc-but it was all believable and well done. The mini lecture on Trajan's column was worth the money by itself. You MUST book this site in advance (easily done on the website) because although there are sometimes places available on the day, we saw a lot of disappointed people being turned away. Having a Rome Card does not guarentee entry-you still have to book.

Don't miss this museum!. I found this museum after a Google search on what to do in Rome on Mondays and was super happy I did! The website said that they were sold out for the day but I went to the office across from Trajan's Column and was able to get tickets later in the day. They only do a few smaller groups divided by language each day. It is AMAZING! All of the intact architecture and the use of lighting to understand what an ancient roman villa looked like was pretty cool. One of the best museums I've ever been to!

Spectacular. Our local hosts recommended this as we've seen all the big sites more than once. First - you MUST have reservations. Limited to a group of 15. English only.This was first rate. It gave you a real sense of what they have uncovered and what it means. It was almost like Disney helped in developing this tour. You will not be disappointed.Cost is 13.5 Euros.

The Best!!. Been to Rome many times. Were told about this by a friend. Did not really know what it was until we entered. Loved it. Go at dusk to see a fantastic view of the Trajan column at the end of the tour. Very informative!

Unique experience in Rome. We enjoyed the Domus Romane very much. It is dark and cool because it is underground, which was a great thing to do in the middle of a summer day of touring. Very interesting look at ancient Roman homes using high tech displays. Also learned a lot about the process archaeologists go through when making their discoveries. They also teach you about Trajan's column and forum which are next door.

A bit long..... For about an hour and a half we wandered around an old roman house under the Palazzo Valentino. It is by guided tour only. It was quite something to be down there amongst all the history, but I found it went on a bit too long, though in it's defence, I did have a bit of a hangover, and it didn't help that most of it is done on glass floors, which can be a bit disorientating...There are light shows and a sonorous disembodied voice, and its all a bit Disney, but I think they did it all very well. Certainly worth a visit on a hot day...

Perfecto! Best museum visit in a very long time. This was one of the coolest exhibits I have seen anywhere in the world. It was long and very informative. It used new technology in a way that truly took you back to a Roman villa under ground. We were still raving about the exhibit over dinner. It was enchanting and the tour group wasn't large. After many visits to Rome I am so happy to have found this gem as something new to rave about.

Excellent tour of ancient Roman villa. We thought this tour was fascinating. Much of the tour involves walking on glass floors above the ruins of two Roman villas, which allows you to see the ruins up close. In addition, the use of video re-creations of the villa and lighting to highlights specific items of interest really helped us to learn about how wealthy Romans lived back in the day and how the site was being excavated. There was a guide with us, who was knowledgeable and answered our questions. Definitely worthwhile.

Better last time. We booked a tour at the last minute and it seemed like they were booking as many people as wanted the English tour. Everything in the tour was now automated with preset audio. All the personal guide said was "come this way." There were too many people in our tour. We could not get a good view of what the commentary was pointing out. There were a number of people in our group who did not speak English so they were speaking very loudly to their companions in their language explaining what was going on - very disconcerting.We have taken this tour twice before and I am certain this will be our last tour. The entrance has change to a door that is directly across from Trajan's Column, which the narrative on the tour goes in to in very minute detail about, which was very interesting. The tour takes 1 1/2 hours.

Very cool, a must see. We found this on trip advisor and then stumbled by the building the next day. We lucked out and got on the last tour of the day. It was really interesting and well done. Special lighting recreated the spaces which helped with visualizing how it once looked. The tour is 90 minutes and is mostly by recording so you don't have to worry about a bad tour guide. The dark rooms can be a bit disorienting at first but you get used to it and there is a guide to move you through the spaces.

Cool tour of ancient Roman villa ruins beneath current buildings. Interesting tour of ruins discovered in 2005 beneath the 16th century Palazzo Valentini. The ruins of the different parts of the villa, pillars, mosaics and artifacts can be seen underneath a glass floor. There are visual effects in each room and a video presentation. The tour exceeded my expectations. You'll pass through a small gift shop at the end of the tour.. Worthwhile!

Great way to spend the day!!. The tour is 90 minutes long; Monica P , our tour guide knows well what She is Talking about.! You are not allowed to Take photos and reservation online/ phone is needed if you Want to enter! Don't forget this cause you can not Enter otherwise. The Palazzo Valentini is near the V Emanuelle and Trajan Forum and vis-a-vis Wax Museum... It is my second time in rome, mu second time at this Museum, Buț definitely not the last time!! I really reccomend it!

A journey to the Roman past. The museum is excellent, it is an interactive expirience and everything is done with lights and projections. We walked over glass floor so the excavations were visible and the projections over them renedered the beauty of this nobleman's houses as they appeared in Roman era. The guided visit lasted for one and a half hour, but time flew, it was so interesting. I would reccomend this museum to everyone who wants to know more about the everyday life in ancient Rome. The ticket was 13,50 euros and it was well worth it.

Roman Ruins with a Guide. Definitely reservations. And if you were glasses where the lenses darken while you are in the sun, step inside for awhile before the tour begins.It took me awhile to trust where I was stepping. It is dark and you are walking on a glass floor. But after a bit it all felt perfectly natural.The ruins of a home of a wealthy Roman are directly underneath. The area they are discussing lights up, so you can understand better. It is an excellent way of letting people see the excavations without compromising them. Very ingenious and well worth doing.

Not to be missed. Although the ruins give you a sense of the scale and sophistication of ancient Rome, this is the only venue to recreate the domestic life of Rome. You walk on glass floors above the excavated remnants of the home of a wealthy Roman family, with an excellent narration. The rooms are illuminated and recreated with outstanding and innovative graphics and projections, integrating the surviving components, including mosaics, frescoes and other objects.

Simply amazing. Due to lack of planning on my part, many attractions in Rome were unavailable to me since it takes days or weeks of advanced planning to get a slot. Rome has become much busier than my trip many years ago.But fear not because the Domus Romane only sells tickets for the day of - so as long as you go early enough you can generally find tickets. We hit the office around noon and were able to grab slots at 6:30pm.And was it money well spent. The attraction is first rate - the quality of the ruins is amazing and they've done a great job setting it up for viewing, along with interesting AV effects to show how it might have looked. There is also one of the best descriptions of the story carved into the Traiana column outside.

Off the Beaten Track Excavations!. Limited entry and an almost-undiscovered status means that Palazzo Valentini is an awesome small group tour of an excavated villa near Trajan's column. Book in advance! They use a light and video show to bring the villa ruins to life in front of you, and the presentation is extremely interesting. Well worth the admission price - but the freaky part was walking on the glass floor looing at the excavations below you.

Amazing. We attended a friends wedding at the forum and the grooms mother recommended this museum and we are so pleased we visited. It is amazing. You get a real insight into what Ancient Rome was like. With clever use of computer graphics, it enhances what has already been preserved. Sound effects enhance the visit further, so for those with little imagination, it must be phenomenal. The tour takes about an hour and a half. The English speaking guide controlled the audio visuals more than speaking English herself! There are toilets available as well as lockers to leave your bags and umbrellas. There is a small shop for trinkets and souvenirs. It cost €24 for two of us and we were really lucky to be able to access the next tour which ran in the next ten minutes. The grooms mum said you could buy tickets online, which is probably a sensible thing to do, we were lucky with timings! We loved this experience.

Very interesting!. This place was great - different way of looking at Roman ruins! We learnt a lot. Make sure you book in advance and turn up on time! We saw quite a few people walk in wanting to book in for that day but they were fully booked and these people left disappointed. We also saw a couple turn up late (half an hour) and they missed out on half of their tour. It is the kind of place where you have to be with the group as you move through different rooms and different lights shine on things in time with the information given, so you do need to be with the group.
Domus Romane. If you're in Roma you should spend a couple of hours in this amazing "Palazzo". Underground you can see a part of an ancient roman villa a "Domus" and much more. Enjoy.

Excellent site, spoilt by the guides. A thoroughly well thought out and we'll presented domus, spoilt by the rude and completely uninterested guide that accompanies you around the domus. We went in with a group and we're told to follow our guide. There was no introduction or explanation, we were simply ushered quickly through each room. So quick that we didn't even see the contents of the first 4 rooms! Beware that rooms are completely dark when you walk in, the light up as various elements are explained. At one point our entire group was plunged into darkness without warning, with the guide simply shouting to walk forwards. Several of the group walked into stone walls! A very good visual presentation, throughly spoilt by the guide.

A piece of breathtaking history. A recent and fascinating excavation unveiled the remains of an ancient Roman villa ("domus"), situated under the Palazzo Valentini, close to Colosseum and Forum Romanum. Execellent tour with really exquisite narrration in English. It is a truly beautiful site that shows remains of mosaics, wall-decorations, bas-reliefs, and the thermea and calidarium of wealthy families at the peak of Roman power. History of over 2,000 years ago comes alive via multimedia elements that make a visit a breathtaking experience.

very dissapointing and dangerous for people with less than perfect eyesight. by the time we battled through the queue in the shop and had got all our rucksacks stored in the lockers we were behind schedule. But the "show" started exactly on the scheduled time. Non one explained that we would have to miss the first couple of rooms which only show hypocaust anyway. Instead we were plunged into an unlit room with a distant voice calling this way. They had no torch to show people the way, so we ended up with our party split across three or four unlit rooms with no idea of where they were meant to go. quite a dangerous situation. Staff were very unhelpful. If you must go, the moral is - arrive early and push to the front of the queue if you have a pre-booked slot - and store your bags first.

Experience ancient Rome (with a sometimes hokey audio guide). Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini is a great way to not only see the ruins of an ancient Roman house but also to experience what that house would have looked like in its prime. You go from room to room, first seeing the ruins and then looking at virtual reconstructions of the same area while a voiceover explains what you're observing. Overall it's a very cool site, but the audio guide (played on speakers not on a personal device) was a bit silly and dumbed down at times. In addition, the size of the groups makes it difficult for everyone to see a particular thing at one time. And there's no hanging back once the audio finishes because you're hurried on to the next room and the virtual reconstruction is turned off. That said, while these issues detracted from our enjoyment of the site, we are still glad we visited. No photography is allowed of the archeological site.

The BEST ruins in all of Rome!. Finally a place that actually explains what it is you are seeing. This tour offers EXCELLENT English speaking narration of exactly what you are looking at.If you want to understand how Rome was built and a peek at understanding ancient Roman life this is the place for you. Very well presented, very interesting, and not too long.Why the other "major" attractions in Rome aren't presented like this is beyond me.If you go to one museum in Rome, make it this one!

Ancient Rome becomes alive!. Through the use of multimedia/light/sounds, an ancient Roman villa becomes alive: you can see where the family entertained, bathed, strolled... you can find out what happened to the villa afterwards as well as see an animated version of Trajan's column. A gem of a visit and highly recommended for children.
Great educational experience . Surprising underground experience. A fascinating mix of archeology and graphic arts. We loved the video explaining the Trajan column.

Worth a visit. This place was interesting and presented well. However do plan your trip in advance as it is guided tours only and they did not have any English tours on the day we had planned to go, and ended up rescheduling. It possibly goes on a little long at the end, but is still really worth a visit and is recommended.

New approach to displaying an archeological site. This is the ruins of an imperial era building under a building in the center of Rome. It does a great job of using technology to make the ruins more understandable. You go down stairs to spaces excavated under Palazzo Valentini. Once you are at the ruins you walk on glass panels above the ruins while lights point out elements and a recording explains them. This is done in small tour groups, otherwise you wouldn't be able to see. You do have to move around at times to see the various items under your feet, but it gets easier as you get the hang of how it all works. They also use computer generated visualizations to show you what the building would have looked like at the time. This is really helpful to understand what you are seeing. Doing it while you are still in the room looking at the ruins makes it all much easier to understand.There are a few caveats. There are stairs going down to the site and back up again. Some of the stairs and a lot of the slots are glass. So you are walking on glass in a fairly dark space with the uneven ruins below lit up. It took a while for my head to get comfortable walking on a largely invisible surface above the ruins. But the floor in these areas is perfectly flat so it is very safe, no tripping hazards. Eventually I got used to it.One issue that should be fixed is timing. There are a few places where the recording doesn't allow enough time for the whole group to get to the next room, so the people in back miss part of the presentation. It's just a minute or two, but annoying if it's you in the back.It's also fairly expensive at $10 € each. But it was a large investment to create the framing and glass panels for the tour and the computer rendering and displays. They are then running small groups, so they can't be making much at doing it.All in all I think it points the way for new ways to present archeological sites.If you have seen the major sites in Rome and love archeology, make a reservation, and go see this.

Superlative experience. Despite arriving 15 minutes late for our reservation due to our confusion about a Metro location, we were welcomed by the staff and personally escorted to the ruins below. At first we felt great disorientation in walking over glass floors in the dark, but we adjusted quickly. The holographic projections and computer modeling to explain the ruins of the Roman villa were exceptionally well done. As a bonus, the presentation on Trajan's Column at the end, isolating vignettes through spotlighting, was so much better than my art history class on the subject many years ago. Bravi to all the clever archaeologists who made this great experience possible.

Cool Roman case. The remains of a Roman Senators house just of the Forums.I good example of how the other half lived in Rome.If you like underground ruins you will love this one. High tech displays and reconstructions.next to Trajan's Column.

Perfect for History buffs!. If you are into history then this is the thing for you! It is a very well done audio-visual walk through an ancient Roman house. The tour is good for all ages and I've done it with different groups that have come to visit me (high school students, college students, family, and groups of adults) and everyone seems to love it. I've done the tour 6+ times and have not gotten tired of it. Although it does wax cheesy at the end of the house tour, it makes up for that in the presentation of Trajan's Column. Truly a fascinating tour and a must see for history buffs!

Enjoyable. Through multi-media presentation you really get a feel for what it was like to be among the upper class in ancient Rome. You see the ruins and then the building in transformed through lights ans sound. You also get a view of Trajan's column. Part of the Rome Pass for discounted or free admission
Underground ancient Rome. I was told to go there. If you have time is not far from Colosseum and not so crowded. I will suggest a tour to anyone

Only Three Tours a Day in English: book well ahead of time. Tours in English are only given in English at 1:30, 2 pm and 2:30. I'm looking at tours 6 weeks from now, and already two of those tour times are not available because they've been booked up. If you really want to see this in the summer, it seems advisable to pay the extra booking 1.50 fee to get a spot, rather than just hoping for the best on the day you show up.

How to add value to history!!. Domus romane were found below the beautiful palazzo Valentini, in Piazza Venezia. The place is very beautiful and gives you the idea of the magnificence of richest’ houses in Roman times. The best thing is the tour, performed with lights, sounds and videos that really enables the visitor to imagine how wonderful all of that was at the time.

Fascinating. We visited on a recommendation of our host in Rome and are very pleased we could get tickets. The display of artefacts combined with the multimedia presentation really brought it to life and we learnt a lot.

Spectacular guided vist. Dramatic and educational guided visits to an excavated late Roman building. The light show and vertiginous glass floors are entertaining but seem like overkill for what, by Roman standards, is a rather modest discovery.

Unforgetable experience. This is a hided museum close to the forum that allows you to know how did the rich families live in Rome in the pastel. With modern holographic lights and a nice staff you go back in time and has the most cool history class in an hour and a half. Its totally worth it

Wonderful view of history with ancient house ruins. We took the 1 hour tour of these ancient ruins of a large home (palace) in the heart of Rome..quite interesting and worth the visit if you have been to Rome before and seen the major sites

Will give you the visual understanding of ruins that so many other ruins don't. Having been to the Baths of Diocletian and Caracalla, and seen many other excavations in the basement of museums, I was a bit disappointed with how difficult it is to look at very small amounts of archeological remains and imagine these rocks as being some 10ft high, splendid structure. I honestly think it takes a trained eye to be able to look at these and see something more than what's there. But this is the issue that Palazzo Valentini deals with; they take the ruins and they 'draw' the missing bits on (with lights), so you can genuinely SEE what it would have looked like in its hay day. If this can't be done so easily, then they show you a video of what it would have been like, like a 'virtual tour'. And just when you think it's ending a little prematurely, they then give a detailed explanation of Trajan and his column (which sits right out front of the palazzo) which gives you a nice new understanding of an important monument that you'll probably pass several times during your stay in Rome. I really recommend this tour.

Only guided tours. Had to wait 3 hours to get in. Not mentioned on website . Only guided tours. Had to wait 3 hours to get in. Not mentioned on website. That's poor information, hence low raring for wasting my time going there

Learn about the lifestyle of the rich (and famous?) in ancient Rome. Domus Romane is described as a "multi-media museum." You will walk on a glass floor under which are the remains of a home from the time of Imperial Rome. There are projections on top of the excavation so that you can see what it might have looked like at the time. in the There are recorded tours in English that your must reserve in advance. Fascinating experience.

Amazing animated experience. This ancient Roman Domus dating to the 4th century had all the amenities of today's rich and famous, with a private spa including jacuzzi, sauna, frigidarium, pool, exercise area and relax area, and spacious rooms equipped with all sorts of luxuries. Fantastic tour with films that show how the house would have looked like in the days it was lived in, and how the archeologists were able to piece together the details of the findings. Instructive, intelligent, fun and great for kids.

This could be brilliant but.... The opportunity to view the excavations of a luxurious Roman villa, as well as view Hadrian's column and get to hear the story it tells, should be a highlight of a visit to Rome's historical area. The multimedia presentation is slick and engaging and the excavations are extensive and quite well-preserved. The reasons I haven't rated this attraction more highly are:-the lack of guidance, engagement or any enthusiasm at all from our guide. She wasn't interested in answering any questions and merely took us from one section to the next in a robotic manner. She didn't introduce herself, give any introduction to what we were about to see or explain how we would move through the space.-Our group of about 12 was too large for the small space in some areas of the exhibit, which made it difficult for everyone to see the highlighted areas.- Some of the explanations in the pre-recorded presentation & video could have been more concise.

When people tell me they're going to Rome, I say "Go to this place". When you see how they present this archeological magic, you'll wonder why you haven't seen this done anyplace else. It was mesmerizing. If you have one day in Rome, I'd spend ~90 minutes of it here.

Highlight of Rome trip!. This underground attraction allows you to imagine what Rome looked like centuries ago. Multimedia presentations bring the ruins to life. See Rome from a whole new perspective.

Fun, but physically demanding. This was a very well done program and very enjoyable to see. The only issues I had were that there are a lot of stairs, walking, and standing which was not listed ahead of time. You are on your feet for the majority of the two hours. I have mobility issues so this was something of a challenge and I would not have visited without checking for accommodations. If your tour is large you also often have to try to find a place to see the areas being spoken of, so if you walk slowly then you can find yourself unable to see past the others, and there are no places to sit and rest throughout. There is also a video at the end that was a bit dull, though full of interesting information. Unfortunately it was more than 20 minutes long, and most of the children in our group got very anxious at being made to sit quiet to watch a documentary.If you are an able-bodied adult, it is a really fun way to spend some time, but if you have any mobility issues or young children I wouldn't recommend it.

Amazing must see. Again, another marvel tucked away in Rome, surrounded by shops, restaraunts & busy streets! So glad we found it though & it's well worth doing. It can be a bit disconcerting at first as you are walking on glass flooring which is several feet above the original Roman street below. Absolutely fascinating & I would recommend everyone to go see it.

Not what I was expecting, it was better!. I'd heard about this tour but hadn't done much reading up on it so wasn't sure what to expect. The explanations, visuals and special effects make this a very unique and interesting experience. I would say though that I could have done without the last 20 minutes. Sitting down in the dark watching a run down of the column depictions didn't add to the experience, it should end on a high.

Impressively Presented. First booked stop in Rome After seeing some reviews that stated to do this tour first to better appreciate other ruins. Glad we did. Amazing site and collection. My mom has vertigo and we were all a bit jet lagged so the experience left us all slightly dizzy. Took a minute to adjust to viewing a 'museum' beneath a glass floor. Never saw anyone comment that the last piece has you going through WWII bomb shelter doors with a major focus on and outdoor view of Trajan's Column. A must see!

No time, and no light, to actually look at things properly. Bring a torch!. The site itself is extremely interesting and worth a visit, but it's a shame that the multi-media tour is so poorly designed. Only those items that the voice-from-above focuses on are lit, and only for very short moments, so if you are in a group of more than 3-5 people, those a bit behind are likely not to be able to see much, as the spot-lights will have moved on to illuminate the next item before they managed to have seen the earlier one (BRING YOUR OWN TORCH :-)). Big downer also that there is no time (and no light) to look at things in your own time. And we weren't given *any* time at all to look at the exhibits they have in their small museum rooms. Seems they want to rush the tourists through very quickly.

Fabulously done visit to a wealthy Roman residence. This is an essential visit to anyone interested in getting a glimpse of how the wealthy lived in Rome. Buried for long under a more recent palace, the municipal authorities should be commended for restoring the site and introducing innovative modern enhancements, like 3D rendering on the old walls, to bring to life what was surely an amazing mansion in the heart of Imperial Rome. Highly recommended for people who have been to Rome often and have already visited all the big sites. This will bring you to the next level of experiencing Rome.

Incredibly well done.. Makes Roman archeology understandable for tourists. A must see for those who have a passion for Roman history. Great displays beneath glass flooring. Greatly explained by a recordered voice and highlighted by light sketchings. Unbelievable that people ignored ancient structures in the late middle ages and renaissance.

A true gem - by far the best museum experience in Rome. Far less known amid the abundance of historical places to check in Rome, this place is truly amazing. Very well preserved ruins and artifacts are complemented by excellent multimedia projections. All other famous tourist traps (the Colosseum, the Roman Forum etc.) pale in comparison to this place.

An incredible experience.. This was probably our favourite historical experience throughout our Italian holiday. It truly captivated all of us and brought ancient Roman civilisation to life. We'd spent a long hot day in the Colosseum and had booked a 4pm slot. We were a little concerned that the children wouldn't make it (ages 11, 8, 6 and 3), but they loved it. The combination of the lighting, the visuals, the sounds and the excellent narration completely recreated life in and around this beautiful palace beneath a palace. The 3yr didn't quite make it through the movie at the end, but the rest of us were completely enthralled. We would highly highly recommend. Do not visit Rome without a visit to the Domus. Thank you for an incredible experience.

The Roman age under the floors of a city Palace. The 90 minutes guided tour under Palazzo Valentino was really an experience. With light, sound and video the history of the daily life in the Roman age were made live. Absolutely recommended. The guided tours are in different languages at different times. Pop in in the morning and buy your ticket for an afternoon tour before going to Colloseum.

Do not visit Rome without seeing this!. This is one of the best history style tours I have ever done. Often they can be long and laborious if you are not a history buff but this one is far from it, it is so well done and engaging for people with all levels of interest.These underground ruins beneath this 16th-century palazzo in the heart of Rome are amazing as it recreates the ancient rooms of an imperial-era villas using multi-media lights and commentary that makes it easy to understand and imagine how these spectacular homes would have once been.Only recently found and restored there is still evidence of the mosaic floors, saunas, baths, ovens, columns and many grand structure. Many walls are still intact and the parts that are not are re-created right before you eyes. You walk over the ruins on a glass floor giving the best vantage point to fully appreciate the spectacle. I HIGHLY recommend this tour when it Rome, it is right near the Colosseum and an absolute cracker!

If you love Roman archeology, don't miss this. A great experience this audiovisually guided tour in a Roman domus only open for the public since a few years.
Booking (in a language you understand) is absolutely required.

Simply superb. I would recommend this to anyone- from the young children to seniors.I am told in summer you need to book well in advance- the tour takes 12 people at a time and each tour is in one language- german, french, italian & english tours are available.The re-creation of a Roman villa was stunning.This must be one of the best 12€ I spent in Rome!
Most avances tour on ancient Rome ever!. Absolutely lovely tour underground with projections, light shows and narrative! Love it. Not fitted for people who are too afraid of heights.

Must visit. We were recommended this by friends who live in Rome and it was undoubtedly the highlight of our trip! I've been to Rome before so wanted something a bit different. This modern and informative site definitely gave a different perspective to the ruins of two luxury villas found buried under a central renaissance building. The tour really brought the archaeological site to life and made this much more fun and educational than most sites. I'm sure my children would have loved it had they been with us.

Great combination of old architecture and 3D technology, very difficult to find the place. It was very difficult to find the place. There are no banners, no signs nearby and we almost missed our reservation because we couldn't find it.The tour is nice, except that if you are from Romania, the guide doesn't even notices you, while he is explaining and showing things to everyone else.The combination between old architecture and 3D technology is amazing and is worth the trouble.

Absolutely Fantastic. Up there with the Colosseum as a must see. This 90 minute tour is fascinating takig you through the various areas of the origin1st century AD villa. Walk along a raised glass floor as the artefacts below you are illuminated and revealed. Lots of accompanying media, informative and really well put together. Would recommend without hesitation
Wonderful experience extremely well done.. Great effects bring the story of this Roman villa to life in a very informative manner. Best experience of our trip to Rome.

One of the best thing in Rome. This tour is key to understand the changes the city experienced throughout the years. The tour takes you below street level in the ruins of a former luxurious house that was changed many times over. It includes virtual reconstitution of many elements and rooms. The problem is that the tour is by appointment only. We had to do it in Spanish to squeeze in our travel plan. Spectacular still.

Great activity . The tour was an exciting unearthed houses with recreation on top of existing ruins. A hidden gem underneath the city. The tour is an absolute must see. Warning the tour has glass flooring and narrow spaces.

Incredibile view into Roman opulence . This was recommended by a local and what treat and surprise! You visit an underground archeology site which is a Roman mansion discovered in only 2010. The remains and the audio visual displays are unbelievable... A truly unmissable attraction in the historic centre.

One of the few surviving fragments of the real life of the Romans!. One of the few surviving fragments of the real life of the Romans! The color purple, "Pompeian" is known for style,paintings on mythological subjects,even special temperature and humidity retain impressions.

Intresting Place also for children. We tried to book our visit through the Internet without success. Not only that but the site said that all tickets were sold out. Never the less we went there and there was no problem to buy ticket to the Tour in English that was due in 20 minutes. It was interesting tour because it shows you how the Romans lived at that time. We recommend the tour.

Informative!. I really enjoyed this tour. You explore these excavated areas room by room, looking through clear glass floors. Projections are overlaid to show what the ruins would've looked like. You also get to see some of the excavated pieces up close in a mini gallery area. Only suggestion: Book tickets a couple of days ahead so you can get a time slot that works with your schedule.

Archaeological underground tour. A fascinating tour under the city hall where they have excavated the remains of elite Roman houses adjacent to the forums. You walk on glass floors over the remains of the rooms, with an audio visual presentation, but the coordination of lighting and audio could be better. We found it via Trip Advisor and weren't disappointed. Booked all online the But when we found the entrance - discretely signed at the entrance to city hall, and were sent to sit in rows of chairs in a meeting room, we wondered what we had booked for! It's not exactly well publicised or promoted, no guide book, no leaflets.There is a second part to the tour which would be better shortened allowing longer in each of the excavated rooms, allowing the lights to be on for longer on the amazing excavation below your feet.

WOW! A must see..... I highly recommend this tour, it visually shows how an upperclass citizen lived in ancient Rome. I heard about Le Domus Romane from a Rick Steves guide while attending a class on ancient Rome.

So much potential but badly presented. Such a shame. This should be amazing, the site they have excavated is impressive. They have uncovered some Roman baths and houses. Unfortunately the multimedia presentation is dreadful. The lights go on and off to quickly so you can't always see and the voice over starts in the next room before everyone has managed to get through from the room before. The guide was clearly bored, not surprised as she was just there to shepherd us around. I see so many people loved it which is great, just wish we had.

A surprise dig in the heart of Rome. Our host recommended this hidden gem in the heart of Rome. We were pleasantly surprised by this extensive archeological dig under a large civic building. The entrance took a while to find although it was right in front of us all the time. Small unobtrusive signs on a very large building marked the door. Once in, you must wait for the tour to begin at your designated time. Silent ushers steered us through a labyrinth of glassed floored chambers beneath the palazzo where we followed an impressive multimedia and lighting demonstration walking us through ancient roman mansions and baths and other surprises within spitting distance of the base of Trajan's Column. If you are classical studies geek or want to experience ruins from a novel perspective - this site is a must see in Rome. Don't miss it.

Brings the ruins to life. We took our two boys (11 & 14) here after doing many of the other historical sites in Rome. They were in the "not more old ruined stuff" frame of mind, but they actually really liked this, I think because they could make sense of the ruins and could get a picture of what Ancient Rome was like. Projected effects were really well done. It is a little long at 1 1/2 hours - there seemed to be endless rooms - but you can't say you don't get your money's worth. The illustration/narration of Trajan's column was great, but we had a giggle when after about 10 mins of listening to the story and Trajan conquering all, we found out there was still half the column to go! (Apparently he had to conquer them all over again.)Tricky to find, but well worth hunting out. With Il Vittoriano behind you, walk to the end of Piazza Venezia and turn down the street on the right (Via Cesare Battistini - stay on the RHS footpath). You soon come across a building called the Prefettura. There are two signs out the front advertising the Domus Romane. Go through the little door to the right. Make sure you book online in advance to get a spot and in the right language. You can pick up tickets there if you have your confirmation number, so no need to print.Worth the effort!

A New Look At Ruins. Those smart techies came up with a great way to peak the imagination of what it would be like to walk into an ancient Roman home. They change the bare stones to lovely mosaics before your eyes. You must have a timed entry, since the tours on the glass floor above the ruins have capacity limits and have information given in a schedule language for each timeslot. My one tip - be brave and take that first step onto the glass floor - it is definitely very sturdy, but that first step seemed scary to me.

Excellent presentation. This is a very contemporary look at a large Roman villa excavated in the heart of Rome. Glass floors and projected images bring to life this ancient house. The audio visual explanation of Trajan's Column was outstanding.

Ancient City of Rome Comes to Life. What a nice surprise. We were able to make reservations for the English speaking tour. Started out slowly but wow! The underground multimedia show was amazing. Loved the story/history brought to life on Trajan's Column, the dwellings, and neighborhood. The entrance is from the Roman Public Office - Provincia.
Serviced by bus lines 40 and 64.

The future of museums!. We booked tickets at the last minute so were only able to find space at the end of the day on an Italian language tour. Even though we only understood perhaps a quarter of what was said, it was still well worth it. If you can though, best to book a few days in advance to ensure you get a tour in your language at a convenient time. Tour groups are kept small for a reason -- space is tight, but it also make it an intimate and special tour. The guides will describe this as 'multimedia', but that is an overused term that understates just how brilliantly done the exhibition is blending the existing art and architecture with sounds and sights that make this a truly memorable experience. It is not glitzy or Disneyfied, just extremely effective and ca[tivating -- both informative and eye opening. There is a wonderful There are many blurbs in recent guidebooks but it would hae been nice to find out more about the details since they whizzed us through the gift shop in the middle of the tour without really letting us pause to be able to find a more detailed book on this site and the wider context. If you can dig up the very accessible research article by Napoli and Baldassarri from June 2015 in Frontiers of Architectural Research they conclude by claiming that 'we have implemented a prototype of a third-millennium museum' and indeed they have. A very special place to visit and hopefully we will see more such efforts to help give all ages new insights into the past without trampling all over it and thereby preserving it for future generations.

Unique Experience. At first glance the Domus Romane seems suspiciously overpriced however in hindsight after my visit I can only say it was worth every penny. I have not visited a historical landmark that has been so successful in bringing history back to life. The tour was fantastic, the video unusually interesting and the view of Trajan's Forum at the end a magnificent sight. Definitely 5 stars.

Fantastic multimedia show made history come alive. Really well done, both the multimedia show and the exhibition. A little bit too long maybe, one and a half hour with a pause in the gift shop (!) half way in. Our group of 10 was perfect, any more would ruin the experience since some of the rooms are tiny and you tend to block each others view. Make sure you pre-order on the website.

Could be a great attraction, but too hard to see. Although I love the idea of this -- seeing an ancient Roman house underground with lights through a glass floor (!) -- it wasn't very well executed. The lights don't stay on for very long so you spend a very long time in the dark listening to the taped tour. They are talking about the house but you are only able to view it for a short time. Also, they divert into talking about Trajan's column (because the house would have been nearby) which seemed a little strange and also makes the tour go on (in the dark) about 30 minutes longer than is it should have.

Roman Ruins below Your Feet. The curators have very cleverly built glass walkways over the ruins of a Roman house that is being excavated. Through use of lights, lasers, projected images and sounds they show you the layers of history underfoot. It really helps you visualize the layers of buildings on top of buildings that makes up the Rome of today. One caution- if you have trouble seeing in low light, it can be a bit tricky walking across glass walkways in very low light. Available with a tour guide only, best to book in advance over the Internet. Now that the Domus Aurea site is closed, this is an excellent substitute!
interesting building. an interesting old building housing an art exhibition, but a lot of steps to climb, still worth the effort

Amazing experience not only for history lovers. Relatively new attraction, definitely worthy to see. With help of lights and technology this museum helps visitors to imagine the life of the past. Our 8 years old child enjoyed it too.

Hidden Treasure. This tour is a fantastic experience and brings to light the lifestyles and architecture of the patrician class of Romans. You need to book tickets in advance via the internet and book into a tour in your chosen language. Do allow time to find the address, please note that this is housed in the building called "Provincia" and is pretty much north of Trajan's column. There is alot of standing involved, so best to be relatively fresh for the tour. Our teenagers were quite weary after a hectic day visiting the Roman Forum and the Colesseum, and i think they would gave enjoyed this more had they not been so tired. There is a great lunch bar across the road worth a stop.

A secret that you can't miss. Not a well know spot in Rome. A fantastic place that you cannot miss. Better buy tickets in the Internet and choose the language/hour of the tour since it is guided only.

Brilliant. Totally different experience. This is only available with reservations and it takes you on a guided tour over some recently excavated Roman ruins. The tour tells you all about Rome, Roman life and history. Really well organised and it uses modern technology really well. it's inside so I recommend you do it on a cold or rainy day. It takes less than 2 hours. Not to be missed

Unique viewpoint of Roman architecture. This is a unique viewpoint of Roman architecture. We went on the tour in Dec 2015 with reservations, which are required. We made our reservations through the hotel once we arrived in Rome. We didn’t have any issue reserving a tour for later the same day.The most amazing part of the tour is when they project images on the ruins to recreate the house as it was hundreds of years ago. They obviously spent a good deal of time on the accuracy and scope of the projections – a few even took my breath away.The first part of the tour is amazing, although I did have some difficulty following the narration at times. The narrator would reference things “as we saw before in the XX room/architectural feature”, but I lost track of the rooms and architectural names because we were shuffled back and forth between rooms. We visited a couple of rooms multiple times which only added to my confusion. I’d recommend paying close attention to the names so you don’t have the same issue.The second part of the tour is about an entirely different topic. The first half was focused on the ruins we were actually visiting. The second half is about Trajan’s column, which took me about 15 minutes to figure out. I would have liked a brief note of the topic change; without that introduction, I wasted time trying to figure out how the new narration connected to the ruins we had just toured.The second half of the tour seemed to drag a little bit. There is a 20 minute detailed video about the scenes on Trajan’s column and what each represents. This was fairly interesting for about 10 minutes, but then I started to get antsy. I have the patience of a 9 year old, though, so you may not have this issue. My husband said it was fascinating.The last feature of the tour made up for the second half – they take you to a gate where you can view Trajan’s column from a totally new, close-up angle. This was an unexpected delight.Overall, the tour is amazing and you should put it on your list of things to see in Rome.

Slightly kitsch, but an informative experience!. If you're not into heavy-duty visits to the Casa da Augusto or the Museo Nazionale, then this is an excellent way to get an impression of what the interior of a Roman house might have looked like. The excellent AV presentation gives a good (if speculative!) idea of what might have been beneath the present building, before subsequent eras filled it all in and built on top.

Little known gem. Kinda hard to find but it is centrally located with places to eat nearby. We were 10 min late for our tour and they took us right in. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and the group was just the right size. Great value for the price and close to other sites that may be on your list.

Excellent virtual tour, average staff. This location was near impossible for my family to find. Eventually, we gave up and asked a police officer for assistance, who directed us to a somewhat nondescript building, inside of which the ticket booth and entrance were located. The staff at the desk were not very friendly, and actively avoided engaging with us. However, this proved not to be much of a problem as the tour was virtual, with an interesting use of lighting and special effects to help recreate parts of the damaged building. This was an unexpected gem of our tour to Rome and definitely recommend the tour, despite the staffing.

Under the new villa .... Right in the center, near Piazza Venezia, under a new structure, an ancient world taking shape, an impressive light and sound presentation.Reservations are required (preferably in place) in small instruction groups.Interesting and worth a visit

Poor staff. I made reservations here and the site itself is interesting.The staff did not have proper turnover and was poorly trained. My family arrived 15 minutes earlier and asked if I have arrived yet, they said no. When I came in and I inquired if someone was looking for me, they said they cannot help me.They were not busy during this time but seems uninterested in everything other than finishing their shift schedule

Nice virtual tour!. This is quite an unknown museum but has one of the nicest tours with lots of virtual projections to emphasize the difference between the ruins you see and how it used to be. Worth your money and don't miss this one!

Very interesting and well done.. This is great for school age children on up. Very nicely arranged and provides a very good idea about how an ancient Roman villa in Italy was set up. My wife was a little psyched out by the glass floors, but they're very solid and not really a concern. It's also a cool place on a warm day.

Wheelchair accessible-excellent interactive experince. Thoroughly enjoyed this experience today Informative and visual display of life in a 4th century Roman Domnus.Wheelchair access to whole of display Very helpful staff take wheelchair participant and companion down/up a couple of lifts to reach all areas .Lift is compact but suitable for a standard size wheelchair. There are no steps to negotiate in interactive ares. Group sizes are small ?20 in ours The wheelchair user and companion are free too. Although dark at times the areas are totally level and safe.

best 12 Euros spent in Rome. Rome history revealed through archaeology and multimedia. One great 2 hours show. Book in advance. Only small groups allowed. Only with guide. Different hours for different languages. You will not forget this.

Just go. Don't miss it. One of the highlights of our visit to Rome.. Not too expensive, but you do need to book ahead as it seems always sold out. Especially so you can be sure to get tickets for the English tour. Following another traveler's advice, we took this tour on our first full day in Rome, which helped us understand other villas, homes, and ruins we saw later. This is not like any other site or museum you've ever been to. 90min approx. Really great!.
Best museum experience. This is really a must place to go when visiting Rome. No other museum in Rome will present you the roman culture like this one. The entire experience is immersive.

One of the highlights of our trip!. This museum is really wonderful, it truly was one of the highlights of our trip. We have been to Rome a few times and were looking for something a little different and off the beaten path. We made reservations and were pleasantly surprised when we found the group to be small, maybe only 10 people. The guide was great and enthusiastic. Its a long tour so be prepared. It was nice that they didn't rush us through. This was a couple years ago and there were FAR fewer reviews on here then there are now so maybe its popularity has soared and it will be really busy, just make a reservation and you should be good to go! Have fun :) P.S. this is a GREAT escape from the Rome heat when it is hot day outside.

Fantastic!. This tour was fantastic and the use of glass floors and lighting just brought the ruins to life. It was a little disconcerting at first to step on glass floors but soon got use to it. Lovely to see the base of Trajan's column as an extra at the end!
Must visit!. Book in advance and you will not regret visiting this place! You go underground and walk on glass looking down at the ancient remains! A lovely experience!

Best understanding of ancient roman's houses and lives. Excellent visit, full of interesting information about rich Romans life's and houses. Ground floor are from glass so you can see under your feet parts of house and streets. In the same time there is a film depicting how the house should have looked at that time.
