Last part of tour is presenting house surroundings in Trajan's time and the story of Trajan's column.Tours are in different languages and start at scheduled hours. One tour takes 90 minutes. You can reserve your tickets in advance by phone and pay on place (13,50 euro). For us was difficult to find the palace entrance without knowing in advance the place and address, so we lost first 10 minutes of tour. I liked it so much that I will do it again anytime.

Well worth it!. Visited this exhibit on a rainy afternoon with three teenagers - what a great 90 minutes! Amazing explanation of ancient roman homes with visual effects over authentic ruins. The curators did a great job of bringing ruins back to life! Really impressive, educational and entertaining.

A unique experience. Not only does this recently excavated site have wonderful things to show, it has a unique multi-media presentation unlike any other to highlight them. Parts of two ancient Roman houses, with tantalizing, well-explained details have been uncovered beneath a renaissance building. A story that may be quite common in Rome, but this one stands above the rest. Don't miss it.

Great place to visit. If you are interested in archaeology and gaining an understanding of what Rome looked like in its heyday, then you have to see this. They use good old fashion archaeological techniques to preserve and record what was found and light technology to give it's visitors a clear vision of the past. It's a must see!

Stunning!. this place is definitely worth the visit. it's very well organized. tours only. it shows the remnants of two roman houses (of somebody who was very well off, maybe a senator) and the history of the traiani column. best to make a reservation beforehand.
Amazing. I don't want to say too much so I don't ruin the surprise but for 12 euros you get 1,5 very informative and entertaining hours.

Just go. After vaticano and spietro the next thing that you have to see.i can not really explain to you...all the museum has to be like this.next generation of guide tour.i can not explain to you .we reserve with 15euro through ticketone with15euro and we collect from the entrance of domus

A great museum. This is so good. Most people go and see ruins but these are ruins with a twist. A recent discovery of a 4thC Roman home, below a 16thC palazzo, right beside the Forum.It is brought to life using light and sound and slides so you really get a feel of what the house would have been like. Very clever and one of my favourite visits on this trip to Rome

Brings history to life. This was the second visit I have made to the Domus Romane and I just love it! Time flew by so quickly because the whole experience was so interesting and informative. I would recommend this for families as there were a number of (beautifully behaved) children on our English speaking tour and they seemed to love it

Time travel is not science fiction!. By far the best place i visited in Rome last week. The Domus is preserved very well and the light and laser projections actually bring it to life, which actually gave me goosebumps a few times. The background sound effects and story telling were excellent too.

"A Must See" Experience a Palazzo in all its Beauty!". This was our second trip to Rome and we had already seen most of the major sights. Or so I thought. This is one of the "Best" things we have ever done in Rome. I recommend booking ahead. There are various tour times and languages throughout the day. The tour takes you back in time to see the splendor of one of the finest palazzos of its day. Complete with sauna, swimming pool, heated and cooled rooms, exquisite mosaic floors, etc. Glass flooring has been installed above the archeological work allowing you to transport yourself into the midst of the building in its former glory days. Great for all families, excellent tour guides provided as part of the visit.

Not worth it if the tour is not in your language. This may be really great, and I think it could be, but we followed the mandatory tour in Italian, thinking we could get something out of the experience that others rave about. Not the case. Only go if you can fully understand the tour guide. May not be suitable for young children. Mine could not handle it and found it quite boring. (Granted, there was a language problem).

Amazing opportunity to see history come to life.. The Palazzo if located right next to Trajan's column and was built in the 1600s on top of a Roman house (domus) which was begun in the 1st century and added onto through the 4th century. You walk above the excavation on thick glass so that you can see everything without doing damage.

Our favourite tour in Rome. We only went to this museum because of the rave reviews on tripadvisor. We were thoroughly amazed with how they presented the tour. It's a must see in Rome. The museum is somewhat hard to find at first, but keep walking into the squared courtyard and you should find the entrance on your left. We were lucky to get a tour time, but we recommend you book ahead of time since they only take maybe no more than 30 people in each time. Also, the entire tour was about 1.5 hour from what I remember.
Well done museum.. Would highly recommend this museum. Very well done. All glass floors that you walk on, while looking at ruins from almost 2000 years ago, that were recently found.

Amazing tour/show: one of the best explained archaeological sites anywhere.. One of Rome's best little secrets. This tour/sound and light show leads you through a fascinating and complex archaeological site right in the middle of Rome and helps you understand all its layers and history. Really fun and interesting (and available in English or Italian, not sure about other languages).

A must see when in Rome. Went here with someone who was making a fourth trip to Rome, who had not previously been or heard of Domus. His surprise only added to the enjoyment, as this visual show was both entertaining and enlightening. While parts seem to be geared for families, the entire experience is one that should be on your list. Advice- get your tickets in advance, and then be on time, as it is highly scheduled.

very interesting and a welcome change from the usual. went here on our last morning in Rome, having gone around what seemed every museum, ruin and piazza, initially we found the staff a bit stern, we had to come back after trying to book a tour the day before, but it turns out its really popular and I would recommend trying to book rather than turning up like we did. initially its a bit daunting, having to walk over glass steps and floors in rather dark conditions, but we all soon settled into it and had a very interesting tour, looking at the well preserved remains of the palace. the addition of the extra information about Trajans monument and the supposed temple was very interesting to us, and threw some more light on the amazing structure.would recommend, but not for people who don't like glass floors!!

Fun place to visit with kids. Very well organised visit; the displays with "special effects" are very good at keeping kids interested without feeling fake. Gives an excellent overview of daily life in a wealthy Roman household. I would recommend especially to families.

Amazing 2nd Century Bath / House Museum. I visited here using the Roma pass one morning, an absolutely incredible museum. I would strongly recommend this to anyone - entry to the museum is by tour only. The guided tour takes about 1.5 hours and is accompanied with a light show and audio tour. You will receive an amazing insight into the luxury of what the building would have been to live in, how it was decorated, the destruction that occurred, and modern day excavations. I would strongly recommend this to anyone travelling to Rome.

Very interesting and well done! Would have been better if I had researched it first.. We did the English language tour, since I was sure my Italian wouldn't be up to the task. It was quite good, but raised more questions than it answered and even though our guide spoke some English, we weren't able between us to communicate well enough. So do your research first, and then have a lovely time!

Amazing experience unlike anything else!. This magical tour recreated life in a luxury villa in Ancient Rome with the clever use of lighting-- you are moving room to room observing the rooms as they light up beneath your feet (through the thick, clear floor panels)! Make your reservations in advance! This tour was one of the highlights of our time, especially for our teen and pre-teen kids (but we adults were also fascinated and amazed)!

Sets a New HIGH Bar for Archeological Museums. The is a 90 minute multimedia tour over the recently uncovered ruins of two 4th century AD Roman homes. You walk on glass floors looking down at the ruins and hear an interesting recorded description while projections are shown on what remains of the house so that you can visualize what it might have looked like. The end result is that you get a much better idea of how people of the time lived and how they built their houses. It's hard to describe, but fascinating!Book in advance because this is a popular attraction, tour groups are small and tours in English are only given at certain times of the day. This place can be a little hard to find. If you have a tourist map of Rome, look for Trajan's Column - the Palazzo Valentini is the building just north of it, enter on the very busy street on the north end of the building.If you go to Rome, don't miss this!

Le Domus Romane. We are not big fans of museums generally but this was amazing. Fantastic use of glass floors, lighting and projections made this a unique experience. It's actually very difficult to explain how clever it is. We pre-booked before we left home (on a recommendation) and suggest you make this one of the first things on your itinerary in Rome as it gives a fuller picture to the ancient monuments you inevitably see as you tour the sights during your stay.
A lot to see. Leave yourself plenty of time. This can be an all day attraction. There is so much to see. Amazing works of all kind of aart.

The sensation of looking through the floor takes some getting used to. Once we found this site (through a courtyard of an imposing looking government building) we had to wait a bit for the next tour. It began with walking down a flight of glass stairs to get to the lower level. I must say this took quite a bit of getting used to as it seemed as though we would continue falling. As the narration led us from "room" to "room" (the remains of them being beneath the glass flooring) lights would shine on the various areas being narrated. It gave an interesting picture of life in an upper class early Roman house. The mosaic floors were truly beautiful. We also got to go down a narrow passage and observe the obelisk outside from a distinctly unique perspective. I probably liked this tour more than my husband who got pretty bored with it after an hour or so.

Great View of How Romans Lived. Very well produced showcase of excavation of ancient residence. Small groups. You are escorted by a tour guide. Must make reservations in advance. We visited in October and I know when we got there it was sold out for the day.

Before you visit anything antique else, do go here, with your pupils or kids!. Near the Forum Romanum, under the office building of the Province of Rome, a few years ago a Roman house was found back. It must have been an important and rich family who has lived there for the house and its decorations are very impressive. I won't give away more surprises, but I strongly recommend you to go there, with your kids or pupils, for here you are able to see how the house looked like and how the life in and around was, for by a very honest and realistic performance the rests are brought back to life, are reconstructed so that you can see for yourself. After having visited this house you will be much more able to imagine the ancient city in its architecture and life. Book the visit online. The tour takes 90 minutes and is worth every penny!

Amazing place for antiquity lovers!. Palazzo Valentini makes use of modern technology to bring to life the interiors of a 4th century AD Roman domus and its surroundings. An amazing trip into the past, through the underground chambers of the palace.Visiting in October, I was lucky to accidentally arrive 10 min. before an English tour at 10 AM (as you can only watch the display with a group) and still get a ticket, but I would otherwise recommend booking the attraction through the website. I know they offer tours in Italian, English and French, but perhaps other languages are also available. The tour lasts for about 90 min.The palazzo is well worth a visit and there is a surprise at the end of the display!

Recommended by locals. We were told to go here by locals who said it was not well known. It was very well done. Really explains how Romans lived. It is similar to the underground roman remains in Barcelona, Spain and Coimbra, Portugal, but better because of the multimedia presentation.

Welcome 21st century approach to archaeological tours. We travelled to Rome as a family of 3 (8 year old daughter) and really enjoyed the Palazzo Valentini experience. It is a continuing excavation of 2 homes from Roman times. The tour itself is limited to 15 people per group so apart from one section that is very tight, one doesn't feel crowded or feel like one is missing out on seeing things. Booking is made online or by phone and unlike others, we found the process very simple and seamless. We arrived as instructed, 30 mins prior to the tour and collected our tickets that had been booked by phone the week prior. We were using the Roma Pass so when booking, we were only required to give our name to secure a booking. We were then given a reference number and then we collected the tickets.The tour is conducted mainly in the dark and narrated by a recorded story teller. We had a guide but her role was to direct us to where to walk next and to stop people wandering off. I asked her a couple of questions and she politely and knowledgeably answered.There are a few things to be aware of. As the tour is conducted mainly in the dark and as you walk on clear toughened perspex that you see the ruins through, many of the older members of our tour group struggled. There was quite a bit of nervousness and very slow and shaky walking and clinging to the railings which meant if you were stuck behind someone struggling, it was very frustrating as the narration started before you got there. This could be resolved if slower people walked at the back of the group but as is often the case, the nervous and shaky people always wanted to be near the front so everyone else got a bit frustrated.One other thing that was a bit annoying was that the sites beneath were revealed in bit parts to fit in with the narration. So the group would walk into a room in the dark and would stay in the dark while the narration took place and then 'taa-daaa' the great reveal would illuminate one section of the floor and then it would go dark again for some more narration in the dark until the next 'taa-daaa' moment when the next bit would be illuminated. This resulted to way too much standing in the pitch darkness waiting for the bit to be revealed. Too much emphasis on overdramatic 'the big reveal' moment to the detriment of the actual time we could see the site. It was like some overly dramatic designer thought it would be more exciting to have 'the big reveal' moments but over looked the fact that it left people standing in the dark for half the journey. Sometimes we just felt like it would be a lot less annoying to have the whole area illuminated at once so you could see how it fitted together more (rather that see an illuminated column base....darkness.....illuminated helmet.....darkness......illuminated bit of wall.....).Contrary to one other reviewer who did not like the supposition and 'possible' look of the place prior to it's destruction, we found this aspect is what held it apart from other tourist attractions. The recreations were of course created with some deal of creative supposition but not stupid, hollywood make believe. It was all recreated from the pieces found and knowledge gained from other sites from the same era. And the recreations brought a whole new dimension to our ability to imagine what the place really would have looked.All in all, well worth going to and a welcome addition to the other more traditional sites.

Amazing - must to visit!. We have been in Rome tens of times, but first time visited here. This is really worth visiting. In 90 minutes you will learn much about ancient Rome and new techniques was used in presentations very well.Only challange is, you must buy tickets in advance. Or you may ask tours for same day there and if you lucky you may buy tickets on the entrance desk, but usualle they are sold out.

Pedagogical. I really enjoyed the visit. Visiting the ruins of the Roman Forum, I feel it sometimes hard to realize how it was. The visit of this Domus is very well explained and the different features of the place are recreated with lights. It's a guided tour and you need to book it in advance, however, i would really recommend it if you're not specialized in roman history (otherwise it is probably oversimplified)

excellent multimedia and historical excavation exhibited. The place used to be an ancient bath of a huge residence, and through the centuries the house was built over and over again, layer above layers. The visit together with the multimedia projection makes the visitor feels like going through a 3D movie. There are beautiful restored mosaics, and through the glass floor one can actually see the actual ruins. The last part is a very good video about the Trajan's Column (Colonna Traiana) which stands right outside the palace.I highly recommend visiting this place. It's timed visit at different time of the day, and available in a few languages (you may call them to check). The tour will last slightly less than 2 hours. I went there on a late-Oct Saturday morning 9:15am to buy the ticket of 1:30pm entry.

A Hidden Gem among Rome's many gems. This is a MUST SEE book through hotel as spaces are limited 12 only on each tourYou enter through a fairly non descript entrance to walk on a glass floor over the excavated remains of a wealthy Roman residence which was on 2 floors some of the rarest finds have been unearthed here but the best is yet to come when the graphics & light show give you an incredible visualisation of what this residence was really like DO NOT MISS OUT ON THIS AMAZING TOUR STEPPING BACK IN TIME 2000 YEARSHistory was never this good when I was a kid
Amazing. Awesome audio visual presentation. Gives you excellent insight into the ruins. Highly recommend. Good for a rainy day.

Amazing effects and great atmosphere . Despite looking quant on the outside some real effort was put into the experience. The vast majority of the floor was glass allowing fantastic views of the ruins below this was further supplemented with nice lighting and visual effects making a good well rounded and most importantly interesting experience

Visual effects bring history to life. The projectors, sounds and video at the end really brought the history to life. I'd recommend this on your second day in Rome because afterward I appreciated the ruins much more after attending. It's a must-see.

Connecting Past to Present. A very engaging combination of archaeology and high tech. You'll walk on acrylic pathways over excavated remains of a luxury house, guided by professional voice over explaining what you're seeing. Video projections help you 'see' what the mosaic floors and painted walls looked like in their original glory. The tour is being extended as the digging continues, uncovering important pieces of this remarkable ancient neighbourhood.

You can't leave Rome before you visit here. This has to be one of the most fascinating things to do in Rome. You need to book ahead especially if you want an English speaking guide/tour. It isn't expensive for what you get. Have never had Roman ruins explained in such a fantastic way before that helps you to understand what life must have been like. Rome has so much to offer that you could almost become blasé about yet another Roman ruin that is until you Le Domus Romane. Don't leave Rome until you have seen it.

One of a kind museum experience. This is a must see museum when in Rome. Our private tour guide at the Vatican highly recommended it and I'm glad he did. They only allow 15 persons/ tour which lasts about an hour. Best to show up and purchase tickets in advance for English tours. You may have to return later in the day for the tour.You are essentially walking on a glass ceiling of a 200 AD Roman Senator's luxury villa, looking down into his pool, sauna, kitchen etc. The engineering is amazing and the marble and mosaic floors are exceptionally preserved. The excavation is much more complete than the Forum. One of the most memorable stops of our trip.

The way ruins should be viewed. This is one of the best tours I did in Rome. You go underground and walk on glass looking down at ancient remains. They use a light show to demonstrate what the rooms once looked like and there is a video at the end that explains the story of Trojan's column. Inexpensive and worthwhile museum!

Excellent visit. A quite spectacular tour takes you some 2 centuries back in time to a luxurious Roman Domus. Very interesting - only downside was a less than expiring tour guide - even though by far most of the tour is recorded material.

Fantastic (if you can get a booking!). Well worth it, very modern approach -multimedia, lights, glass floors .... Not a typical museum at all, you can't wander around! It's all positive though we loved this museum.It's an old Palazzo which they found by excavation and the wonders that lie beneath are truly wonders. They bring the place to life, you go 25 ft underground (not a cave or tunnel don't worry!) and everything they found is 'as is' but they erected a glass ramp so you walk above the various rooms. I can't recommend this highly enough you really see and understand how the rich lived back then. The amazing things they discovered when the ruins of this Palazzo were uncovered are all there you move from room to room all on glass ramps with everything lit up in turn and various short explanations both in voice and voice and film.The Palazo was ruined by an earthquake and buried, built on top of and on top again and hence only excavated down recently - everything preserved what an experience! GO!Trouble is booking a ticket for you language tour... English is scarce need to book well in advance. We had Roma Pass cost €8 concession entry and tour combined asked our hotel to phone and they reserved. We paid when we picked up the tickets at the Museum. If you are booking online it seemed to be €13.50 no option to select Romapass discount, you should only pay €8. You have to take tour can't self guide here no option to do that allowed.It's a huge Municipal building official looking quite hard to work out that it's the Museum inside as well. Very cheap coffee shop inside, great coffee only €1.00! Lots of office people eating nice looking inexpensive food, the coffee shop is attached to the Municipal but open to all and great value!

Don't leave Rome without seeing this. In order to understand what Rome is about it is extremely useful to go underground, which is where a large of the ancient city still is. This wonderfully entertaining audiovisual journey will delight you while teaching you how to "read" Rome's complex urban layout. Once you come out of the daylight you will see the city with different eyes. The masterful videomapping technology rmakes the monuments come alive, and Piero Angela's descriptions in the audioguide are superb. A must see for Romans and visitors alike.
A Must Do!!!. Others describe it well. Perhaps 1 of the top 3 or 4 places to visit. Guides aren't too helpful or knowledgable...This could be improved.
Wonderfull!!!. Wonderfull experience inside the ancient Rome! You can walk inside an ancient domus with your family! One off the best thing you can look in Rome!!!!

Interesting at times. Booked this attraction as it had a high rating and the weather forecast was rain, it was very interesting at times however I felt it went on for far too long, unless the weather is really bad I wouldn't suggest going as there are better things to see in Rome

Fascinating history of Rome. We took a tour of Domus Romane - other than having a hard Tim finding it, it was a wonderful tour. It consists of one home and the excavations that have unearthed amazing artifacts of both imperial and Renaissance Rome. Definitely worth seeing!

if you are interested in how the real Romans lived this is a great tour. Highly recommended. Book online first.If you are interested in how the real Romans lived this is a great tour, the detail is amazing. The Palazzo is hard to find though, so get there early. The only sour note was the attitude of the 'guide', who clearly had better things to do and we were all too scared to ask questions relating the the tour - which is a shame.

A Glimpse into the Past. We really enjoyed the 2 hour tour of the archaeological dig that exposed the ruins on a Roman villa. Modern technology is employed to allow you to visualize what the interior may have once appeared. Highly recommend but be prepared to walk over glass floors to see the ruins beneath you.

Bringing ancient Rome to life. Travel under a renaissance palace and discover archaeological remains of a roman house. Walk on a glass floor over the remains of rooms such as hot and cold rooms, a gymnasium and pool, and see mosaic floors and artefacts. The media recreations of the house, projected on the walls, bring this house to life. Book in advance as only small groups can enter at a time. Memorable.

Must go, especially if you only have one day. Wasn't so sure about this when my hubby picked this up on travel advisor. It was definitely worth it. An hour and a half, with clear explanation of an excavated ancient roman house, and the stories carved on the Trojan column. This was newly excavated in 2011 and only opened for a few years. In fact they are still excavating other parts.

This is a must!. I wasn't sure about this when I first went through the doorway. But as soon as I was underground, Rome did come to life. I felt like a Roman myself walking among their corridors. I was mesmerised by the beautiful, well-kept remains. This is simply a must visit, you can really get a grip of how people (the rich) lived. I would go again! This is actually an interactive museum and you can only enjoy it fully if you start from the very beginning. When we went, we missed 2 minutes!!! I do wonder what I missed in those 2 minutes as the rooms which I missed were pitch black and could not see a thing. So make sure you go from the start and simply follow the light ;)

Rome comes to life under this fabulous Palazzo. Book your place in advance, you can do it over the internet. And you are in for a treat. It is a video/light tour that really builds up the excavations. I found it riveting and really helped me understand and make sense of the ruins below my feet.

The other reviewers are right!. This place has received many positive reviews and we can see why. It is a remarkable experience in which the past is brought to life by tremendous visual effects and helpful commentaries.
It is quite a long tour but it never gets boring. This is living history of the best kind.

Worthwhile tour.. Tour of this underground dig of a Roman villa and parts of Trajans column was wonderful.good English commentary and-explanations as well as 3 d projections made this a very worthwhile experience.
Artifacts found as well as later finds discarded on top of villa as new buildings built were very interesting. Highly recommended if you're into Roman history and or archaelogy.

The Best attraktion in Rome!. I was blown away by this place. Amazing - no less. When you leave, you'll have a whole other - and so much better - understanding of how Ancient Rome were. Can't recommend this place enough!

Well worth the visit. I read about this museum on Trip Advisor prior to my vacation and saw the great reviews. It definitely lived up to my high expectations. The tour is an hour and a half and you need to schedule a time. Even if your not a big museum goer, you will love this one! Only about 12 Euros. A must see for sure!

A Trip Back In Time. Palazzo Valentini is a 20,000 square foot complex with two 4th century AD patrician villas and the remains of a private thermal bath in the heart of Imperial Rome. You really get a great sense of Roman life as it was lived almost 1,700 years ago. There are tons of mosaics, fountains and frescoes to enjoy.
Wow !. Fascinating palace which I highly recommend to visit. It is a historical beauty with opulent architecture.

A most vivid presentation of Roman history. The tour takes you through a stunning series of state of the art video projections which are used to reconstruct how an ancient senator's villa looked and by the end of it vistors get to see a close ups of Trajan's Column in 3D complete with a genuine storytelling which makes the bas reliefs come to life.Overall the tour lasts for about an hour and a half, and it's definitely worth booking (which I belive greatly increases your chances of visiting at a desired hour).The visit can also be linked to visits at Palazzo Venezia or Il Vittoriano due to its proximity.

One of our favorite places in Rome. We LOVED this unique and creative peek into the everyday life of ancient Romans. We walked over glass to see ruins of ancient homes, and we loved the rest of the tour too.

A modern look through Ancient Rome. Great entertainment!. You proceed underground to the domus which is effectively an archeological site which has been cleverly presented with the use of glass floors so you can see down to the Domus below. The world of technology and lighting help to bring the history to life and the whole experience was thrilling and educational at the same time. My wife and I both loved it!

Don't leave Rome untill you see it. The owner of our apartment told us we can not leave Rome without seeing the Palazzo Valentini and you know what, he was right!!It's not what you would expect, you walk into the first room onto a glass floor "which is a little weird at first you feel like you're going to fall through" and then the lights come on under the floor to reveal the villa, WOW absolutely amazing, all of the ruins have been left as they have been excavated no restoration word has been done, so you're seeing it as it was left all those years ago. This was one of the best attractions in Rome, not to be missed No photos allowed tho

Speachless! Digital experience in the ruins of a Roman villa!. We did not know what to expect, it wasn't "advertised" well enough - but wow!! Walking on glass floors looking down on the ruins of probably the best preserved Roman villa from the years ~ 0-400 AD below a renessance palace was stunning in itself. Then add digital effects and lighting with explanations and you get a spectacular experience. This is Tourism 2.0! This is the future of Tourism. Well done Rome Tourism!Tip: You go in groups (small groups, 10 pax), scheduled at different times, so make sure to plan your visit.

Discovering the past in a very modern way. It is a very new Roman attraction that You absolutely must see if You love the antiquity. You will have the opportunity to visit the ancient house even more completed that there are in Pompei. Besides You can get familiar with the history and iconology with the Traian's column. I do reccommend!

A hidden gem - must do!. I can't add much new, but this is a GEM of a tour. We went to Pompei a few days after this tour and had such a better experience because of it. The digital projections are really well done - not hokey at all, but really help you envision what life was like for Roman citizens living here two thousand years ago. Really amazing information, and truly felt like the future of archaeological museums. A must do!
Wonderful experience!!!. This was one of the best events we experienced in Italy. The video effects made a very wonderful show. Be sure to go and have a great time wish we did.

Amazing combination of history and technology.. The domus is an old Roman house where visitors can really see how rich Roman houses used to look. The project includes ruins, but also light projections which add on the ruins and help understand what the house must have looked like in the 4th century AD.

Fantastic exhibit but the guide was a sour note. A must-see attraction that helps you understand the richness of the history right under your feet. You'll need to book in advance but it is well worth the effort. I must say, though, that our guide gave off a curt, rude, "bored to death" attitude that took away from the marvels surrounding us. I can't give this a 5-star review because of this. Hopefully, The Domus Romane Museum will do something to improve the quality of service provided by their guides.

A hidden gem - a must stop when in Rome. This is the perfect intro into ancient Rome. The multimedia tour starts on street level & takes you down three stories to a hidden roman villa. The lights and special effects set the scene for all other ruins you may visit - and definitely helped us imagine what we were looking at!
Excellent . Well worth a visit. Very interesting and the effects are done very well to add to the educational message but also being very vivid. A must see I'm Roma

Glass Floors Reveal Ancient Roman Home. Fascinating and interesting tour of an Roman dwelling that was unearthed. We took this tour before seeing any of the sights of Rome because we wanted to have a better understanding of what the ancient homes looked like. Not only did we come away with an appreciation of the skill and beauty of these homes, it helped us finish the picture in our minds whenever we saw some ancient ruins. Learning about the history of Trajan's Column was also interesting and gave us a better understanding of other Arches that we later saw as we toured the area. Well worth the time. Definitely do it as one of the first sights. It does make the rest of your sightseeing more enjoyable.

Worth looking for. Difficult to find and only limited tickets for an English tour but a must see if you can. The site is interesting and the video projections make it so much more interesting. Read the other reviews to make sure you know where it is and vista a few days ahead to sort out tickets.

Now and then. I was blown away by the effective use of technology in a well structured and guided walk through.
I'm always interested in how buildings and monuments originally looked.
Every crew member behind the whole experience deserves a congratulations.
If you do this you won't be disappointed.

Definitely worth doing. This place is relatively new and wasn't mentioned in any of our guidebooks but we read about it on TripAdvisor and were happy that we did! We booked our tour in advance; so far as I could tell this had to be done by phone since we were using the Roman Pass. It was an expensive phone call from the US! It seems like most of their tours (and English are only a couple per day) sell out, though, so we had to do it for the 4 of us to see the museum. We arrived about 10 minutes before our tour time, and the front staff weren't incredibly helpful. They gave us our tickets but didn't really answer questions other than to tell us to wait outside (in a very hot courtyard). Oh, and the domus is not easy to find - we wandered around for a while until we found the entrance (past some guards that let us through once we said we had this tour scheduled) so make sure you leave plenty of time to get there.Once our tour started, the guide took us down stairs and into the rooms of the museum. (It was much cooler down there, a nice benefit!) The museum consists of several rooms of two ancient Roman villas, probably owned by a senator or other very wealthy individual. The great value of the tour is in the lights and projections that they use to outline what they're talking about and also recreate what the villa may have looked like. There are also some fine mosaics to view and information about archaeology and excavation. Overall we all really enjoyed it - even my teenagers were interested. The last portion of the tour is information, including a movie, about Trajan's column, which is nearby. This portion wasn't as interesting, in our opinion, although it was nice to learn a little about the history of the column and its depictions.This attraction is a great introduction to Rome and its history and archaeology. We were glad that it was one of the first places we visited in the city.
Absoloutly fantastic . One of the best places you visit in Rome. You will enjoy the place with the great explanation of the ancient Rome. Totally amazed. Highly recomended

Must do for any history buff in Rome. Although I did enjoy viewing the forum ruins in Rome, I sometimes felt that I was just looking at rock and struggled to imagine how it would of been during the Roman Time.This is where this museum really comes into it's own and offers a unique experience in Rome. It initially takes you onto the site of two luxurious roman villas underground and helps bring the villa's to life with the use of glass viewing screens below your feet, light projections and a good description.The final part offered a detailed explanation about Trojan's column, explaining the story behind the columns origin and the story carved upon it. We were then led to a viewing platform on level with the Column which offered a closer experience and view than you can usually see walking past. This left me in awe & the story behind the carving ensured I stopped and stared at the column every time I walked past. This was easily the highlight of the tour and potentially worth the admission fee alone, as it brought Trojan's column to life and gave a great insight. However I felt that the tour was overcrowded at times and this resulted in you being squeezed into rooms and not always being able to see the artefacts properly. When describing what we could see, a cgi video would often show how it would of looked like in roman times. Although this was initially interesting. I felt at times it was slightly over the top and went into too much detail as it was often describing things about the villa's that were guesswork. This seemed to be a view shared with the rest of the tour. I felt that the customer service provided by the staff could of been improved, when entering the museum and walking to the reception we were faced with employees who didn't seem overly happy to see us and along with the rest of the tour we were told to wait outside in the blistering heat. I saw no reason why we couldn't wait in the museum itself. Although being accompanied on the your by an employee, all of the detail was provided by a voice over through the speakers. admittedly easier for the museum, I felt this lacked a personal touch and prevented the real opportunities to make a connection with the your guide and feel comfortable to ask questions.Overall I feel that this is a must for any history fans visiting Rome as it offers a unique experience and insight into how the Romans lived and gives great detail behind trojan's column.

Barely mentioned but a must do!. This museum is a great view into the excavation of a Roman senators residence, augmented by a fantástic áudio vídeo experience. It is part of the Rome Pass but please remember the tours are limited in size and they are in different languages throughout the day só you need to plan when you arrive there. We loved it and you shouldn't miss it!

Best thing to do that no one knows about. Book this in advance and you won't regret it! When your done being overwhelmed by Rome's beauty, food and people, you will relish this treat of learning in a fun and comfortable setting that does all the work for you !
Rome's sample. Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini is a clear example of Roman atmosphere. When your are there, you find yourselves in the destruction of the history.

Worth searching out. This barely gets a mention in the guide books and isn't very obvious when you get there but it's one of the best attractions in RomeFirstly you need to book online in advance. The website isn't particularly clear and I ended up with a booking for the wrong date by mistake with no refund. However I did manage to get another booking for the right date. Generally English tours seemed to be in the afternoon and only 2 or 3 a day taking about 20. It is in the Palazzo Valentini which is the seat of the regional government just off the Piazza Venezia. The building is set back from the road and you need to go through the arch to the door on the left of the inner square. There's a small coffe shop and loos beside itSo what exactly is it? It's a tour of the layers of archaeology under the Palazzio. As well as showing bits of the remains from various dates it makes good use of lighting effects to reconstruct how the area might have looked. There are also short films giving more background including a particularly good one about Trajan's columnIt lasts about an hour and a half and was varied and interesting throughout. I was a bit wary that it might be light on content and a bit 'Disney-ish' but it wasn't and had a range of material which would interest people who know virtually nothing about Rome and others who had a more in depth knowledge

People need to hear about this!. I talked to a few people about their recent trips to Rome, and they either never heard of this or it didn't get short listed. Too bad for them because they really missed an amazing state of the art presentation of an ancient Roman home. Not only to you get to walk over the ruin and admire it through the plexi glass floor, but there are light projections working in conjunction with the narration that bring the ruin to life. Also, the presentation at the end about Trajan's Column was very informative and it complemented the exhibit nicely. I am glad to see this finally featured in 3 Days in Rome.

Great exhibit. We normally get bored of exhibits / museums, but this one kept our attention the whole time. It really brought Ancient Rome to life.
Also, great explanation of Trajan's Column. That alone was worth it.
Had no problem booking in the same day we wanted to visit during peak travel season.

Layers of rome. Rome is what you see ... Plus another couple of layers below your feetIn palazzo Valentini they've created an interesting reconstruction of 2 roman villas (Domus ) which parts have been found below and around Trajan's ColumnYou will walk on thick glass above the excavations and what is not visible anymore will be made real to your eyes through lights And computer graphics projection allowing you to picture how the Domus probably were back in their time of splendor Even teenagers were interested !

Thecno projections to show you more. It is a interesting way to view the scavations. It use tecnology projections to show how was the place. Really interesting.You have to pay about 13 Euros. You can buy in advanced by the site.
Don't miss this in Rome. One must not miss this extraordinary place. It is not widely advertised but it shows ancient buildings and how each room was used. HI Tech combined with ancient enviroment.

Hard to find - but great experience. This is a really undersold attraction in Rome. Was not even in our guide and we only visited because it was open on Monday, unlike many other attractions. The tour is excellent, really well done and extremely clear. If you want to get a really great idea of how to reconstruct the lives of the ancient Romans from the archaeology then this is the place. Excellent for children, although those younger than 8 or 9 may get bored. Be sure to check ahead for the time of your tour in your language and don't be put off by the feeling that you are walking into some local government office at the entrance, it is very much worth it.

Amazing tour - best experience in Rome!. What a place! The tour and quality of supporting AV technology was really first class. And you could blink an eye in that part of Rome and completely overlook it. Visit at all costs! - it's covered by the Roma pass, you have to prebook but this can mean coming back after lunch. Tour groups are small and our guide was very knowledgeable and professional. All in all a fascinating - no amazing insight into the high end of 3rd century Roman life.

#1 in Rome. If you're interested in Roman architecture, Roman life, anything Roman at all, then this is the place to visit, contrary to one review I read the website is so simple and makes it clear in which language your tour is for, I seriously don't know how someone got confused with this, I know because the time I wanted was a French tour so I had to go for a later one, not hard at all. Anyway, the tour itself is amazing, it's a blend of Roman architecture deep in the foundations of a current Roman building mixed with state of the art technology and projections filling in any gaps and bringing the villa back to its former glory, absolutely worth doing and worth booking early

Fascinating Place!. What an absolutely fascinating place – not at all what you would expect. This tour is great for all ages (unless you are afraid of the dark) . Reservations are a must for this exhibit – you can order your tickets in advance on the internet. This tour takes approximately 1 ½ hours, so plan accordingly. Going below the Palazzo Valentini, which has been the seat of the Provincia of Rome since 1873, is like walking into another world. These excavations were rediscovered in 2007. You are led down a series of steps by your guide – it is dimly lit which adds to the mystery of where you are going and what are you going to see. You enter a room that is quite scary at first – they should explain in advance that you are standing on a glass floor. The guide explains the room below, which is lit in different places, shows you what it looks like now, and then they overlay it with special lighting and shows you what it looked like then. You go thru a series of rooms like this. The rooms come alive thru modern technology. You finish the tour gazing upon Trajan’s Column. We only wish there were fewer people on our tour and that there were places to sit down in each room – a lot of standing.

Great surprise . Had a great time checking out this tour. Very unique and provides some rich history of the area, the visuals are a great addition. Not sure if we caught it at the right time but showed up around noon with no reservations and got in to the 12:30 english tour. Would definitely recommend to anyone visiting Rome especially if you have children.

Be very careful when making your reservation. My review is not so much about the actual site, more about the process to get into it. This attraction was so highly rated on Tripadvisor that when I began planning my family's two week trip to Italy a year ago, the Domus was on my radar. After reading the reviews and the attraction's website, I knew that you had to make reservations for entry. NOWHERE on the website was it made clear that this is a guided tour offered in different languages at different times, so I assumed (incorrectly) that it was similar to the Borghese Gallery, where admission is limited to a specific number of people at a specific time, but your tour is self-guided. In preparation for our trip I made dozens of reservations at dozens of sites across Italy so that we could get in to things we wanted to see and/or avoid waiting in line, and several of those reservations were for tours in English (and it was made clear that the attraction had a tour and was not self-guided). I made our reservations for the Domus at a specified time, not realizing that the reservation was for a tour in Italian. By the time we realized the situation, we could not make any changes, the English tours were sold out, and the people at the front desk of the Domus were not particularly interested in helping us find a solution. We went ahead and went on the tour, hoping we could figure out enough of what was going on to make it interesting, but there is nothing intuitive about the information being shared, most of it is just a narration that we were unable to understand. After about an hour, we managed to slip away from the tour and exit. I am sure the tour is very neat if you can understand what they are saying, but be very careful when you make you reservation that you make it for a tour given in the language you want.

Best Place in Rome. The light show was immensely cool, especially how they restored the mosaic on the floor. This was definitely my favorite place in Rome. Don't expect to get in right away though. They'll tell you when you should come back for a tour in your language.

Unique tour limited opening time during the week. The excavation of a Roman villa with full explanation by an audio in each room. You walk on a glass like material with the archaeological activity and finds beneath you. A very unique tour and one that should be at the top of anyones list

My Kids Hated Everything in Rome Except THIS. Even with all the positive reviews I wasn't prepared for how cool this experience was. Talk about history coming alive--it was Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous, Ancient Roman Style. You basically walk through an archeological excavation of a Roman mansion--instead of a guide telling you stories that try to help you imagine what was once there, each room has a projector and lights and narration to literally show you what was once there. I wish more sites in Rome had the funding to do something like this. My 10 and 7 year olds moaned and complained about everything we did in Rome but this blew their little minds. Even the adults in our group were ooohing and aaahing. Leave this for the end of your trip, because nothing can compare. Well worth the cost of admission.

Amazing way to bring history to life!. We visited here with our 2 sons aged 8 and 5. Using light and video it really brought the Roman history to life and was a fabulous way to visualise the building as it must have been once. This museum is actually a tour and lasts 1.5 to 2 hours. The museum was hard to find (needs more signs on the street) and we did not know until we got there that you were supposed to pre book a visit (didn't say on the website). However, we were extremely lucky that an English tour was about to start and we had a really amazing visit. It also explains the Trajan Column in a lot of detail. If we hadn't been able to get straight on this tour by luck, our review would have been very different! We need more museum experiences like this.

Didn't know what to expect. But really glad we did do it!Words can't describe this experience... Technology used together with ancient ruins are a great combo. Who would have known.Thumbs up, will recommend this to others.

Outstanding experience. See a first century Roman house as it must gsve been - in splendour! Walking through the excavated ruins of a huge house of a clearly very rich family, the tour incorporates very clever audio-visual effects to bring the home and lifestyle almost to life. Booking is required as groups are kept small. Highly recommended!

Helps visualize ruins. It is always hard to visualize what ruins looked like no matter how well preserved but the tour and technology really made the ruins come alive for us. The description of Trajan's column and then seeing it in real life was also a great touch.

A fantastic experience. The tour brought this ancient Roman domus back to life - the use of technology to enhance the experience was genius. We could almost feel the presence of our ancient Roman ancestors. We enjoyed the opportunity to learn more about Trajan's Column and to see it up-close too. Highly recommend this experience.

Glad we did it. We learned a lot from this. You see a lot of ruins in Rome and this at first seemed like it could be more of the same but they present it in a really unique way and i am glad we did it. Towards the end it really changed gears to talk about Trajan and we got a little confused, as we had no idea who he was. But we were able to piece it together later.

Brilliant!. Totally recommend seeing this - tickets can be purchased on the day or online in advance. We had to wait 2hrs for our slot but it was well worth it.The museum uses projections and lighting in combination with the ruins to recreate a Roman Villa as well as other ruins. The way in which this is done really brings to life what you are seeing and makes the whole experience fantastic. Tours take 90 minutes including the obligatory stop at the gift shop before concluding with the story of Trajan's column (fascinating in it's own right).

Amazing! . Simply amazing! Any history interested people can not miss this!! Big wow! We had just been talking about, after we had been to forum Romano, how nice it would be to get a better feeling of how the Roman Empire looked, instead of imagining by looking at stones as rubble. Here you really get a feeling of how wealthy Romans lived
Excellent. Best visit in Rome for kids and adults - 6,18,21 year old all thought was brilliant. Hadn't pre-booked got on tour 30 mins after arriving.

An Incredible Journey Back In Time.. This subterranean exhibit is a partial physical reconstruction and graphic projection enhanced gem. The home of an unknown patrician, this palace was destroyed in an earthquake and ensuing fire, burying timelessness moments from the ancient Roman past that one could only image - until now.

Absolutely worth it. Impressive, we were glad we booked this tour and enjoyed it.It was nice to see not just the ruins but to really be able to imagine how this place looked like hundreds of years ago.

Fab. Don't forget to bookA great piece of archaeology. I don't need to say anything about it as it's said very well in other reviews.Staff kindly added a tour for us and then got 4 more people on it. You can't go in without a tourA very small percentage of it is a bit cheesy but it's well worth 12 Euros.You are seeing part of an on going excavation and can feel that you are

Impressive. Make an appointment to visit this Domus which is so nicely presented by the guide with the help of 3D completion.I was dreaming of living in old times in this Domus. I was amazed by the beautiful mosaics. It recently opened to the public and I want to go back on my next trip.

Great for kids. All of my kids (6,8,teenager) enjoyed it, but especially my Lego-building 8 yr old. The video before the tour was very interesting and surprisingly kept their attention as well. There was no availability for an English tour on the website but when I called they were able to get us on one that wasnt listed. The guide did a great job. And of course it was a nice break to go underground during a hot day.
Hidden Gem. Incredible multimedia display. My brother is in the event business and was very impressed. Small groups, great narration. Can't believe more people don't know about this.

A bit of a disappointment.... Booked this based on TA reviews...and its the one thing we did in Rome that I could have done without. It was very interesting to see the remains and the light/video recreations, but the tour was a little long and got a little boring. My husband actually fell asleep during the part about Trajans Column. I also agree with other TA reviewers in reporting that the employees there were less than helpful and didn't seem to care about much.

Fascinating for history buffs. First thing - you must book well ahead in peak season. It was easy to do online, but the English language tours only had 2 vacant spots in the week ahead when I tried. It is not expensive.It is the remains of 2 large private homes from time of the height of the Roman Empire. You walk above it on a glass floor, and on first glance it is not really impressive, but with your guide's explanation and clever highlighting it all comes to life. There are also some new discoveries they talk about, and an amazing explanation of the carvings on Trajan's column.I'm not sure if this would appeal to everyone, but my companion and I thought it was great.

Remarkable. Our large family group, including seniors and young children, absolutely loved this attraction. When you first enter, it is quite dark and unsettling, as the floor is transparent, but you can't quite tell what's underneath your feet. But once the light-show begins, it is difficult not to feel transported back in time. The archaeological value here is incredible, as the ruins are excellently preserved and displayed in a historically valuable context. The staff are great also - my seven year-old dropped his hat while looking over one of the elevated walkways. Since it had fallen into an archaeologically sensitive area, one of the archaeologists on staff had to go to retrieve it, which they did without hesitation. Admittedly, it was funny to see a modern ballcap at the bottom of an excavated ancient Roman house. Reservations for this attraction are required, and its best to get there a bit early. Its easy to find, very close to Piazza Venezia. We got a pleasant surprise at the end with an incomparable close-up viewing of Trajan's Column.

One of the undertated highlights of Rome. Beneath the Palazzo Valentini are the ruins of one of the largest villas found in Rome. This tour is a 90 minute multi sensory experience using light, sound and projections to bring the house to life. You need to book the tour in advance for your appropriate language, although we just dropped in by chance and an English tour had only just started so we went straight in without booking (and boy is it dark joining this way). All the floors are strengthened glass so you walk directly over the ruins. The audio commentary tells informative and interesting stories about each room, and spotlights pick up each area, with computer enhanced lighting emphasising each subject matter. The real magic comes when the projections transform each rooms ruins into a visualization of the original rooms before your eyes, projected onto the walls. Its like watching a time lapse video of the room being built. Walking round the rooms last about an hour, then you go into a small theatre where they tell the story of Hadrians column. The actual carvings on the column itself are like the worlds first cartoon strip, however you can't follow their story viewing the real thing. This film tells that story by following the carvings and picking out particular people and events (in pseudo 3D). At the end you are taken to a ground level view directly below the real column. One of the most unexpected experiences whilst in Rome and wholeheartedly recommended as a must visit.

Cool!. My teenage son thought this was awesome! It is fun to walk on top of a glass floor and see the ruins. They light up the artifacts and have a clear recorded description of everything you see. They keep it to a small group so it is easy to see. There is a guide who walks you from area to area and leads you thought the entire tour. It is air-conditioned and a nice treat to get out of the heat! I would do this again!

Worth a visit to this unique exhibit. There is a lot of "underground Rome" to choose from, and this attraction is both fascinating and memorable. The combination of excavations and the simulated multimedia reimagining of the houses really works. Although at times it felt a bit long, I would have liked to spend more time in the small museum at the end of tour (they whisked us to the shop and presentation of Trajan's Column). Booking in advance is essential, as each group is limited to 10 (I booked about a week before).

Entertaining But Too Long. Thankfully it's rare that I disagree with fellow reviewers. Le Domus, while entertaining and informative, should NOT be the 10th most popular attraction in Rome. It's about 85% video recreations and supposition and while that's the point it just goes on and on and on. I run triathlons but by the end my back was sore and I was ready to flee. Too many videos showing what it "might have looked like". Then, when I thought it was over they launch into a separate and equally lengthy segment on Trajan's Column....at one point a video narrates the sequence of events illustrated on the column and when they get to a part where the narrator says...NOW WE ARE HALF OF THE WAY DONE I wanted to scream. Throw in the fact that it's staffed by sullen teens that ooze boredom and contempt? I wouldn't recommend it unless you've been to Rome many times and you're running out of fresh ideas. For what it's worth, my wife really enjoyed it...

Fascinating experience.. My wife, 25 year old daughter & I went to this attraction 2 days ago, and it is well worth a visit. You must be able to spend about 90 minutes, as it is an accompanied tour, and there is a fair bit of walking inside. However we all felt that it was worth the time. The scale of the remains is amazing, as it is the largest private villa yet found in Rome. The soundtrack is very informative, and the lighting effects and visuals bring the past alive. The ending, where they explain the story of the diagrams on Hadrian's Column, is especially intriguing. You need to book before your visit, but we turned up early afternoon and got in for 18:30 the same day. We only had 3 days in Rome, but it was one of the highlights of the visit for my daughter.
Amazing. A fairly new attraction different to the usual Rome attractions - would definitely recommend as worth a visit. Remember to book first as it can be difficult to get in.

Fantastic modern representation of archaeological site. Hard to find located inside the courtyard of a Rome council building. 90 minute multimedia tour of an excavated Roman villa. The way they present the site is modern and engaging. The use of lights and visual reconstructions really bring the scale and grandeur of Roman villas to life. Make sure you book in advance!

Unique, Fun and Informative. This museum is actually a kind of multi-media experience combining the ruins of a Roman home with holographic enhancements of what the home would have looked like based on the remains of the ruins. You actually walk above the ruins on clear glass flooring and descend down to different levels. Our teen aged daughter who enjoys history was captivated, but even some younger more "active" children in our group were held by the overall presentation of the attraction. This is definitely good for kids. One note of caution: older people or those with a disability may have a bit more trouble getting around the exhibit. Should I get back to Rome again, I would do this tour again. Highly recommended.

Amazing!!! One of our favorites in Rome!!!. This museum is very special! You will get a very good picture of how it was living in this house. First you go see what archaeologists have unearthed then they will visualized how it looked once upon a time with a fantastic play of light.Very interesting and amazing.I will recomend this museum to everyone!!Well spent money!!
Very interesting. This place is a beautiful marriage of ancient Rome and modern technology. It really brings the past to life. Very much worth visiting.

Life In Ancient Time. For a small entrance fee, you entered into a time machine. It takes you through the underground remains of a 4th century home which was rebuilt in the 16th century. Fabulous multimedia is used to recreate how it was like to live in the beautiful Palazzo Valentini. You walked on see-through glass floors in the dark and could see the ruins below, which was quite an experience and actually made you want to hold on to something for safety. The rooms and building were projected in completion form on the walls as they looked historically. The best 12 euros I spent in my entire trip to Italy.

Fabulous video recreation of Roman history amid artifacts. This was a great tour of a fascinating set of "archaeological remains of ancient Roman houses." What was exceptional was their animated video recreation of what the rooms looked like. It was almost liked being there! Be sure to book in advance and book the tour in your native language. I goofed and we could not rebook into an English tour. But the guide was kind enough to occasionally translate for us. This should be on your must see list in Rome if you are into history!
A superb insight into Roman Life. This is a good tour but make sure you book before going. We ended up on a French speaking tour because that was the only one available - not ideal!

Fascinating and worth every minute. This is an actual archaeological site where lighting, projected image, and video is used to complete or accentuate ruins that are in remarkable condition. Most of the ruins are from the interior of a palazzo 2000 years old, however there are also interesting 16th century objects found during excavation. I would recommend doing this tour before checking out the forum. It's a great way to get an idea of scale and that makes a difference when you are staring at the ruins of the forum and palatine.You can only do this by being a part of the tour, and because the tour starts in the building housing Rome's municipal government, there aren't many places to hang out and have a spritz if you get to the tour early. This was really liked by parents and teens. As an added bonus, you get to see the base of Trajan's column, and you get to see a very well done recounting of the story depicted in the bas-relief spiraling up the column.

Very cool, make sure you book in advance!. Something 'new' in Rome for me and really worth going!!! It provides a glimpse of how a rich Roman family lived 2000 years ago. The idea that they were so far with what they could do/make/come up with and that all this knowledge just disappeared is unbelievable.

Brought us back in time. This is a very interesting attraction in Rome and it enables the visitor to get away from Rome's big crowds. The narration really gave us a good idea of how things were back then and the ruins are very well preserved. You should reserve a day or two in advance.
Great for kids.. Wonderful experience and extremely popular with kids. Ours were aged 9 and 11 and loved it. Makes ancient Rome come to life.
time machine. It's really like a time machine...back in the roman empire inside e real domus! visit it but remember to book ;)

Brought history to life. We visited the Domus with our two children (aged 6 and 11) who were first a bit unsettled by walking on a glass floor (so you can see the ruins underneath) but who were then quickly fascinated by the way the narrated tour explained what it all was. The light and sound effects really brought history back to life in a way that walking through the other historical sites does not, and later during our vacation (for example, in Pompeii) we found ourselves relating back to what we learned while at the Domus. It made it a lot easier to imagine what it may have looked like. The latest addition to the tour is a movie and a look at the column outside. It was nice to learn about the meaning of it, as well, as we had passed it several times already and were unaware of the historical significance. Like others were saying, there is very limited interaction with the staff, but if you know going in that they are really not so much "tour guides" (with limited English) but staff to take you from room to room and hit the right buttons, you will not be disappointed. There are only a few English tours per day, so reserve your spots early. Best way to get your tickets is through ticketone.it. Here is the direct link: http://www.ticketone.it/biglietti.html?affiliate=ITT&doc=artistPages%2Ftickets&fun=artist&action=tickets&erid=648606&includeOnlybookable=false&x10=1&x11=domusClick on the day and buy your ticket (make sure it's one of the 2 or 3 English tours ("Inglese") at 1:30, 2, or 2:30pm) and choose full price tickets ("intero") or reduced ("ridotto") for people 65+ and children 6-17 (see: http://www.palazzovalentini.it/info.php?lang=eng)

Enlightning. This is a mixture of a museum and a show. It consists of an excavated site with a home ( domus) from the middle ages and then on top of that house the remains of a renaissance home. The laser and projections help you to imagine what these homes would have looked like in their prime. It was very informative and enlightning. There was practically no introduction and you were immediately put in a room and the show begun. The guide told us ( the ones who were in the front of the line) that we are going to see 2 homes. She didn't speak english well and questions or clarification were not invited. Also if you reach early there is no where to wait other than an independent cafeteria nearby so you would have to purchase something to be able to sit there. The staff were not particularly accomodating and when we arrived 30 mins before the show we were told that we have to wait outside and we can return 2 minutes before our appointed time.My husband considered this attraction the highlight of his visit to Rome. I would recommend it. It is not crowded and it is air conditioned which alone sets it apart from the other attractions in Rome.

Wasn't Our Thing. Somewhat interesting tour with good historical information. The guide was hard to understand and not terribly engaged, the sound equipment felt sterile and had problems 1/2 way through the tour and all of the plexiglass took away from the experience. I understand how the area needs to be protected, but it felt very contrived. The 4 of us struggled with how this has rated so high.

Very interesting visit. From my point of view, the visit in Domus Romano is must. I am surprising, that till now this place isn't most popular. Order tickets online and came to see wonderful things. It is amazing!

One of my favourites in Rome. Of course, when in Rome you must see the Colosseum and all the other sights that Rome is famous for. This place however is a real treat. Prepare to step back in time as you walk through these cleverly reconstructed ancient Roman villas and find out who lived there and all sorts of other history of the villas.I would definitely recommend this as an alternative to some of the more popular things in Rome. Really impressive!
didn't live up to reviews. It was a very nicely constructed museum, but the tour was underwhelming and the tour guide annoying.

away from the crowds. the domus will give you a good impression of the ancient roman houses. a great place to visit when the weather isn´t at its best.also step into the nearby churches, they are great.

By far the best tour in Rome. This place is a miracle in the craziness of tourist packed Rome. An audiovisual show which takes place below Rome in several recently excavated villas, so many surprises and beauty. A must see.

High-tech treat!. This place is hidden away; walk into the courtyard of the office building behind the sign and look for the ticket office. It's not cheap, and you have to take a guided tour. Ask when an English tour is offered. But it's worth it. They take you through an archaeological dig which has had a glass floor put over it, so you see the ruins below your feet! Lights come on to highlight the features that are being explained, and other lights "draw" in the missing parts. It is a very cool, new way to explaining ruins to people. At the end, you get a ground-level peek at the Column of Trajan. One of the coolest things I've done in Rome.
Ancient Rome starts to live. Difficult to explain what you see. Just try it. We were very impressed! Light and laser projections show the living in ancient rom.

Tough to Find but Worth It!. We were really challenged trying to find the building that day..........talked to many people in the immediate area and they had no idea what we were looking for. Since we didn't have a smart phone we were determined to find it and finally stumbled upon it. The attraction is well worth the trouble. The amount of work to create the show is impressive. The blend of lighting, projection, narration and staging is brilliant. You will not be disappointed.

Terrible attitude of the receptionists. When my partner and I arrived and asked the staff about the availability of the tour, the guy and the girl at the reception appeared to be very indifferent and look annoyed. I particularly don't understand the eye rolling of the guy when he saw us. Tourists to them were more like headache and their attitude were they can't be bothered at all. They kept repeating themselves that the next tour was at 3 so we said "ok we will take the tour AT 3 plz." Then they gave us a ugly look and said the tour is not for free with exaggerate gestures. Both of us speak perfect English and we've been to a lot world class tourist attractions. No one had turned us away the way they did. We decided to leave at the end and I will for sure write to the person in charge about this unhappy incident. We have no idea why they have to be so rude.
The place was amazing; the staff not so much.. Nothing much else to say: the place was amazing; the staff not so much. Worth seeing despite the uninterested staff.

Interesting but rushed.... The archaeological excavation underneath a government building is displayed in a multi-media presentation that is interesting and informative. Unfortunately, the staff appears to be 'going through the motions'; as a result, we were rushed through by a disinterested tour guide. The significance of the find itself is breathtaking, and I would recommend it highly to all who have an interest in viewing and understanding privileged life in Ancient Rome.

A must do in Rome. We'd heard this place was good from one of the locals and we weren't disappointed. The tour takes you down under Palazzo Valentini and uses an interactive recreation of the ruins to explain what the ruins would of originally looked like. You need to book in advance and its not particularly well advertised or signposted but don't let that put you off.

An intimate look into Ancient Rome. We booked a visit after finding out about this attraction after our arrival in Rome. We are very pleased that we did. You walk above the remains of a home of a wealthy Roman. The use of lights and lasers brought the ruins to life in what appears to be a realistic recreation of the house. My only criticism is that I found the plexiglass floors, and some steps, to be a little disorienting but certainly not a show stopper. A must see.

Bored staff?. Good introduction to the history of ancient Rome, particularly for families. However the staff appeared bored and disinterested during the tour and we would have appreciated more time to look at the exhibits. No refreshments available.

Interesting Presentation. Went on a recommendation. Limited (15) tours set times on language offered. Building is an old residence of they believe a senator or someone of some opulence. You walk on a clear floor, so to see the ruins & treasures beneath & they surround you with animated 3-D reconstruction as to what it may have looked like in in decadence. Only 1 1/2 hr, so easy to fit it in & in central location.

It's more than a little cheesy but also really interesting. This is a tour of sorts through parts of two ancient Roman villas that have been found underneath a local building in the middle of modern Rome right near Trajan's Column. I say "of sorts" because the actual guide is an audiovisual experience triggered as you move through the space by a person who comes along with you (and seemed very hot and bored during our tour!). The actual villas are totally fascinating and the mosaics will really wow you. But the presentation is cheesy, you get rushed through what seemed like really interesting displays of coins, ceramics, and other things that have been found there, and the person accompanying you really isn't prepared to answer questions. The last half hour was devoted to a really interesting video about Trajan's Column that seemed totally irrelevant to the tour but definitely made me interested in Trajan and his campaign against the Dacians. A couple things to note. There is a lot of walking and stair climbing and not a lot of places to sit so definitely not something for people with limited mobility. The tour groups themselves are small and in different languages so it seems like a good idea to get a ticket in advance; I did it on-line through their website and came with a confirmation number. Finally, the place is a little hard to find as it's off the interior courtyard of a working building. If you're unsure, I'm adding a picture of the place you enter.

Superb balance between sensitive technology and ancient site.. Well organised and insightful tour. Plate glass allows views of the excavations which are brought to life by the careful use of lighting, virtual reconstruction and recorded narrative. The 90 minutes of the tour flew by. Excellent value. A pity that booking site is only in Italian- take care! The address/ map on Tripadvisor is misleading although it comes from the Museum's own website. The entrance is on Via IV Novembre, 119/A, through the Prefettura Di Roma in the Palazzo Valentini. As another reviewer has suggested, google a picture of the Palazzo Valentini and you will recognise it with ease.

Fascinating!. We took our history loving 8 year old granddaughter to Rome . She loved this attraction, it was informative, fascinating and kept her interest for the one and a half hours it took to look around the remains of the roman villa found underneath the Palazzo Valentini. Glass floors over the remains and reconstructions of how it would have looked were brilliant. It is essential to book a tour in english before you go, but that was easy to do on their website. This was the highlight of our granddaughters visit to Rome, much better than the childrens tour of the Colosseum.
Quite interesting. This tour brings the ruins to life with 3D projection to "rebuild" what once was. Make your reservations in advance as each tour group is small and only some are in English.

Visit me first!. To understand Rome, his magnificent history, the lifestyle of your past citizens you have to visit this wonderful archaeological site placed just close imperial forums near piazza Venezia in the center of Rome.The guided tour last 1 hr and half, can be followed in Italian, English, Spanish, French and perhaps Portuguese.For information and to book your visit you can see at: www.palazzovalentini.it.I'm roman (Romanus sum, civis), I'm 52 and I started to visit Rome when I was child.During my life I visited a lot of roman archeoligical and artistic sites but none like this.This site was opened to visiting only five years ago.I visited today (June 7, 2015) the "domus romanae" (roman houses) and I say that it was the beautiful visit I made in a roman archaeological site.A young guide drove us in many ambients of the two houses: in each ambient there is a detailed description with spotlight and virtual reconstructions; from domestic thermal bath with "calidarium" (a sort of sauna), "tepidarium" (a poll with lukewarm water) and "frigidarium" (a cold water pool) to the big halls to receive hosts.
