Also aspect of medieval and renaissance life are treated because this two houses ware find under a big roman palace (Palazzo Valentini).A special moment is devoted to the Traian Column: a virtual reconstruction of low reliefs drove us in the history of battles leaded by the emperor Traian.After 1 hour and half we exit very satisfied of visiting this nice place.I strongly suggest all non-romans to visit this place first: Colosseum, Roman Forum, Saint Peter can wait two hours. It will be more suggestive to visit these places imaging all things you have seen in the Palazzo Valentini.

Brilliant . By far the best museum we visited in rome. Can't believe the amazing artefacts they've uncovered and they highlight them so well with the lighting and descriptions. The guided tour only has a limited number of places which is great as it's not overly crowded. Some of the rooms aren't huge so only having a few people was a bonus. Absolutely worth a visit when in rome. The guided tour takes an hour and a half to complete so worth it to get out of the midday heat! Also worth mentioning is the restaurant on the other side of the museum (it's all related to the museum). We went for lunch before we visited the museum. Food was really good, not an enormous menu but the food served was delicious. We both had the pasta with tomato and mozzarella. We also had a bottle of water, a beer and a fruit juice. I think it cost around €30 in total.

History brought to life!. This was without doubt my absolute favourite tour in Rome. We found out about it from looking at things to do in Rome on trip advisor, and booked our tickets online by following the link to Domus Romane website. It really did bring history to life, recreating parts of the house with stunning visual effects which you see directly below you, as you walk on a suspended glass floor above. This made the tour very easy to understand. Another favourite part was when they took you from the underground area to a door which when opened brought you face to face with the base of Trajans column, and as you look to the top the scale of it is even more impressive. I thought it was excellent value for money and would highly recommend this tour.

A must see in Rome. When you're planning your visit to Rome, you automatically think of the Colosseum, Trevi Fountain and the Vatican. However, in my opinion, this trumps them all. Situated in the heart of Imperial Rome, just off Via del Corso, it may be unassuming from the exterior as a renaissance Palazzo. I urge you to book onto a tour of the museum in your required language and it is covered by the Roma Pass (however the full price tickets are 12 euros and is a bargain in my opinion). You go under the palazzo to walk on a glass walkway suspended above excavations of an ancient Roman Domus. The recreations in light shows and the information given is both incredibly informative, but also breath taking in the way they depict how the domus might have looked in all its glory. The next part of the tour focuses on the magnificent Trajan's column (located at the rear of the Palazzo) and the archaeological finds including the columns from the speculative location of Trajan's temple. A short video takes you through the carvings on Trajan's column depicting the Dacian conquest. Cannot recommend this place enough, a real hidden gem and an excellent excuse to get out of the scorching Roman sun.
No more boring old ruins. Sometimes you just long for a fresh presentation in a museum and here it is, lights, action, colour, music. Room for improvement, bit it sure beats many other Roman museums.

Great visuals of history. Great visual tour that brings the ancient ruins to life and puts them into context. Great tour for all with an interest in Roman history and day to day lives of Romans. Also a very unique view of Trajan's Column from the bottom up - not available to the public! Tour actually takes you under the streets and buildings of modern day Rome.

Hands down the best museum. Stop reading and go. Now. Seriously, do it.If you can't get tickets on the website, get there early (we got there at 09:15), and you can snag some. What an amazing presentation of some beautiful Roman ruins. Do. Not. Miss.

Best 1.5 hour tour in Rome. Unique tour that captures an ancient Roman villa and takes you thru the villa on a multi-media tour. Particularly good for those of us with short attention spans as the tour is only 1.5 hours, and the use of lighting and video makes the tour very real life. Only gripe is you have to book well in advance and the english tours are limited to the afternoons. Otherwise highly recommend.

Different type of attraction merging old with new!. A great attraction for just 13 Euro - mixed the old, 4th century ruins with laser technology. Also topped off the tour with a short film taking visitors through all the major scenes of Trajan's column, just next door. Great value for money.Make sure when booking you have clicked the 'English tab' and then make sure you book an English tour. Otherwise it would be meaningless to you unless you speak Italian. I booked an Italian one by mistake so wasted that money (my own stupidity I know). To find: Stand in the grass of Piazza Venezia with back to the monument to Victor Emmanual. Walk to the street which runs in front. Turn right onto it. Second or third building on right hand side (yellowish in colour with two sculptures on globe-like balls in front.) Go through into court yard and doors on left with signs.

Quite an unusual experience. This attraction deserves its excellent rating. The excavations come to life with a very well designed presentation and documentary. An additional aspect of this attraction is that the ancient Roman villa passages join up with a WWII concrete bunker.

Fascinating use of light and audio. A 90 minute trip through the remains of a 5th century villa which was probably destroyed in an earthquake, filled in with rubble and built over with the construction of the Palazzo Valentini. The tour ends with an interesting video of the scenes of the Trajan column which is right next door, one of whose giant surrounding columns fell into the ruin. The floor you will walk on is an experience in itself.

Vacation. This was spectacular. Only 15 people in each tour and only a few tours per day per language It is an actual archeological dig enhanced with visual technology to show original an now Plan ahead and don't miss it.
recommended. reservation needed because the groups of visitors consist of few persons.luxure multimedia presentation of ancient roman residence with notable monuments.

Le Domus. This tour of Le Domus was extremely interesting and well presented. It gives you a look at ancient rome you do not get anywhere else. I found the your to be amazing, and quite the find. If you are interested in seeing ancient Roman artifacts, this is the tour to take. Plan ahead a make a reservation.
Great 3D projection. Beautifully restored excavated houses and enhanced by 3D superimposed images of what they must have looked like when they were occupied.

Hidden Gem! Don't Miss this!. Around the corner from the Piazza Venizia and a bit hard to find but worth the effort. This is an original Roman villa and wonderful tour. The floors are glass and you walk over newly discovered walls and floors, mosaics and frame of this once noble house! Great experience. Tours in 4 languages.

Very Intereting. Everyone that comes to Rome should visit the Pallazzo Valentini. The visit is very well organized, explained by a well known writer ( Alberto Angela) and interesting to understand how the Roman houses were built.Beware not to use high heals as most of the floor is made of glass. Do not loose this opportunity, is unique!

Way ahead of most of the other stuff in Rome. There are a lot of archeological sites in Rome, but they tend to be underdeveloped - this is an example of things done right. The tour does a great job of using technology to provide contextual data and enrich your exposure to the remaining fabric by showing you what it looked like in its prime. Strongly recommended!

Good, but nothing spectacular . The tour itself was quite entertaining, but staff weren't the best. I went and booked the tour early being told there was only so many tickets. Suffice to say there were more there than they said. They also picked me out to check my ticket several times for some reason. We also had to coincidentally wait around for a while in the shop while we waited for the tour ahead to move on. Towards the end it is a long video, which I nearly fell asleep in admittedly. Compared to Rome's other attractions I would say it is a little overpriced and as mentioned above staff could be better.
Archaeological ruins bought to life by modern technology. Very good experience. Interesting ruins which are easy to understand with the unique presentation using lighting and sound.

Unfair to Roma Pass holders. We had Roma pass and bought the discounted tickets on line. However, when we picked up our tickets, we were asked to pay the difference between the discounted and regular ticket at 4 Euros per ticket. The explanation was we couldn't get discounted ticket on line; we were supposed to call. We couldn't have known that but the staff didn't care.The tour itself was ok using imaging technology. For 13.50 Euros person, it wasn't worth it, especially if you've been to Pompeii or other ruin sites.

Different. This place gives you a different perspective on ruins and shows you what they might have been like hundreds of years ago. It was very dark as they kept turning all the lights off then only illuminating parts of the old building. Almost like a haunted house feeling. After half an hour or so though I felt like we were just looking at the same floor and designs over and over and I was trying not to fall asleep because it was so dark. I should've spent the money on a delicious Italian dinner or a few gelato.

Not to be missed!. I discovered this tour on Tripadvisor when reading through things to do in Rome. I'm amazed that its not more well known! For the price (12 euro approx) it was more than worth the value. Like the previous reviews have said, you are guided through an excavation of a GENUINE Ancent Roman House!!! This house was built upon during Renaissance times but so much of the original parts of the house has been uncovered, and they use projections and videos to help you imagine the rest. This is an absolute must-see for anyone visiting Rome. Its amazing to think that the tiles you can see are around 2000 years old! Pre-booking is essential!

amazing!. 2 roman villa ruins that have been unearthed and you can walk above them on a glass floor.Spaces are limited to small parties so you need to prebook.There is a spoken guide throughout explaining everything and reconstructions on the walls showing how the villasmay have looked in their entirety.12 euros per adult for a 90 minute tour, superb value for money

Nice to visit. Since we are not all experts, this visit was great, considering that the light effects make it easy for visitors to clearly spot remains of the Domus (i.e. palace) and special projections evokes the original look of the rooms, pools etc. Once a day there is a tour in English. You have to find it on the map, since in the Tourist Office they did not know where it is situated, although our friend speaks excellent Italian.

Must visit this museum. This was a one of a kind experience. I'm so glad we took it. Warning, you really must make reservations or you probably will not get in. Do it! You see the actual ruins of a Domus through a plexiglass floor, and then you see holographic lighting that finishes the picture to what it would have been like. It's absolutely amazing! This was probably my favorite experience in Roma!
A room with a view. Wonderful exhibit of an ancient Roman villa. The visuals really help to bring it to life. Better than average tour. Really liked the explanation and visuals of Triano's Column.

A slice of ancient Roman life. We happened upon this after seeing the positive reviews here. I can confirm the reviews are warranted. The tour had two parts - the first 60 minutes was about the Domus and showed the excavated ruins along with light show driven reconstructions. The second 30 minutes was about the Trajan column and did a retelling of the story carved into it. All extremely interesting and well done. And great value as well. Easily accessible next to Piazza Venezia.

Unmissable. This wonderful exhibit really brings an ancient villa to life. You walk on glass floors above the excavated baths and living areas and computer modelling and projections help you see what the villa looked like. There are portions of marble flooring still in place as well as a beautiful mosaic floor that had been in an adjacent building and was cut in half when the present palazzo was constructed. There is even a section of a Roman road with an explanation of how they were constructed as well as a film documentary explaining the story on Trajan's column. I highly recommend this museum, one of the best I have seen.

Worth a Visit!. Don't want to share my whole experience because if you visit you will definitely enjoy this museum! The glass that you stand on took a little time to get used to, but its great to hear the stories with the english tour while lights and effects show what bits are being talked about. It takes 90 mins in total and would recommend it.
Wow . Where in Italy things doesn't work very well, this the opposite. Great place. Don't miss it. the domus is amazing.

Don’t miss this tour!. We wondered in many places why Italy’s greatest ancient attractions lack so much love in the presentation. Often audio guides are hard to follow, maps are outdated, and many sites could easily be greatly enhanced by just placing more and better descriptive signs with some more drawings. Palazzo Valentini was the opposite and is an outstanding example how cool a guided tour can be made with modern tools. The tour leads you through multiple rooms of a ancient roman villa which was excavated below Palazzo Valentini. Most of the time you are walking on a glass floor above the excavation. An audio guide gives a description of the rooms which is accompanied by projectors that highlight what is currently explained, e.g. explains technical details, draws pictures of how it could have looked in the past or completes broken mosaics. This is really well done, improves understanding and drives imagination. In the end there is a video about the Trajan column which is beside Palazzo Valentini. The tour is also perfect for children, the children with us in the tour enjoyed it completely.The tour starts regularly, is limited to 15 people and tickets should be reserved / bought in advance. Some people say it is hard to find and we also missed it the first time because we just went for the house number, which was hard to find. You can find it easily on Google Maps first by searching for “Palazzo Valentini”. The entrance is located at “Via IV Novembre” (between “Via dei Fornari” and “Via di Sant’Eufemia”, directly across the wax museum “Museo delle Cere”).Coordinates: 41.896701, 12.483725

Interesting and well designed. Very interesting, especialy for history and archeology buffs, very well designed technicaly, but a little less in terms of story-structure.Childern under 12 (at least) will probably not appreciate.

Very Interesting. Very interesting and well put together. Great mix of actual ruins of a Roman home and computer animated layovers to fill in gaps. Booked online with no issues. And yes, it was difficult to find due to a lack of signage on the exterior of the building. (I think they have signs now) Wandering somewhat aimlessly in the area for about 15 minutes made us brave or frustrated enough to venture into the courtyard of the building where the office is. One plus was the "secret view" of Trajan's Column.

If I could give it a 6 stars I would. I was completely blown away by the uniqueness of this experience. It is difficult to convey to you what this was like but it held me in awe from the beginning to the end 90 minutes later. This exhibit was built right over an excavation of a wealthy prominent Roman's home. There are steel girders positioned over the excavation that support the glass flooring that you stand on. You get this feeling of being suspended in the air. A PBS quality narration mixed with music play over a theatre level sound system accented with computer driven projectors that highlight the excavations as the script plays out. What is so clever is that the projectors can throw out virtual 3-D like graphics over the ruins to help you visualized what the room could have looked like 5 centuries ago. Toward the end of the program there is a 15 min movie explaining the detailed historical carvings on a huge Roman column. It was a short history lesson that adults will find captivating but children will not so much. At the end there is an inspiring surprise viewing. This exhibit is really tricky to find. We looked for this and then stumbled upon it. It is way past a corridor in a government looking building. They certainly need better signs out front. It's on that 14 Novembre street right across from a wax museum. Regular fee is 12 Euros and it is given in different languages at different times of the day.

Must-do in Rome. I found this attraction on Tripadvisor and now I found out why it rated so highly! This is a must if you visit Rome, besides the more known monuments such as the colosseum and the forum Romanum you should visit this place. it gives you a different insight on Rome and it's history. Perfect for couples with children.

Incredible experience. This is an excavation of a large Roman house underneath a government type building. The floors of the modern building are plexiglass and walking on them is really disorienting, but ultimately a great deal of fun (kids would love it). The tour is escorted and has videos running to show how areas would have looked and a brief film in the middle of the tour gives you a chance to sit down and re-orient yourself (I think they planned it this way because the plexiglass 'experience' can becoming daunting if it were for a long period of time). As another reviewer said, it is a little hard to find, but if you use the street number and don't get intimidated by walking into what appears to be a government building straight through to the courtyard you will be well rewarded! You can make on-line reservations for tours in your language of choice, which I would recommend.

A very interesting site - but watch your confirmation email carefully. We visited this site in early April. The archeology mix with technology demonstrates the wonders of ancient Roman life with a modern twist that allowed us to clearly see what life was like for this well off Roman family. One 2 minute technology presentation (a short part of the overall tour) did not work when we were there. The one major issue we had was booking through the internet. On the internet, I booked the date and time that fit our schedule after double and triple checking the correct date due to the use of the European date/month/year protocol. We received a confirmation email that I admit I did not check. When we arrived on the date I signed up for on the internet (March 30), the staff informed us the date we booked was actually (February 22) one full month before I ever traveled to Rome. While there was space three hours later (which we ended up taking even though it caused us to miss other activities) we had to pay a second time despite our protests to the contrary. If this only happened to me, then I would not write this type of review. However, when we showed up for the later tour, the staff was in the middle of an argument with other patrons who experience the exact same issue - they were told their booking was earlier than they traveled as well. I offer a word to help others avoid similar problems - double and triple check your booking - and any confirmation emails.

English tours sell out early so book in advance. Most comprehensive tour at an archeological sight in Rome and it utilizes audiovisual technology to convey the original architecture and design of the buildings/rooms.

Book Ahead. More than 3 days in advance and you will be left with the scraps of the limited 15 group size?
Massive surprise at the end of the tour

Multi media time travel to a roman home. What a find! A 90 min guide round ruins which are brought to life by fantastic multi media. Really is worth doing, as the technology is so well done. It transforms the ruins into how they would have looked as a house, the lighting and video are excellent. Different from anything else I have seen. The place is hard to find, so make sure you have the address. Also you must pre book, the groups are small as the isn't much room.

Incredible Museum. If you at all interested in the history of Rome and what life was like in ancient Rome, I recommend you go. This is so much more than a museum. They walk you through the ruins of an ancient Roman house and show you virtually what it would have looked like, when certain pieces are missing. They explain so much and my friend and I were highly impressed. I could explain it all, but then it might ruin the fun. Go online to their website and book a tour for the next available time in your language and you will have a great hour and a half and wont be disappointed.

Very entertaining. If you wish to see Rome in its old regal and charm, then this is the place to head. This exhibition utilizes the remains of an old roman building so it gives a credibility and authenticity to the whole tour and added to that they use modern technology and 3D narration skill to bring this entire building to life and for you to see as if it still is an active ground. Well worth the price and long queue.

Impressive. It's an old house of a rich man and a public bath that has been digged out under the ruins. Sounds interesting? Maybe not.But the interesting part is how they present it. You walk on glass floor on top of the diggings. When you walk around (with guide) they have used lights and conputer technic to show and simulate how things originally might have looked - and that is where impressive comes in. It was cool - sometimes 3D, some times 2D - but it was very convinsing - it did make a huge impression of the ancient time and how Things once were.It's hard to discribe further and no Pictures are allowed. But - it takes 1,5 hours, cost 12 Euro - and it's really a fun place to visit. Very recommendable
Unmissable. Unmissable, make sure you book on line and collect tickets from the booking office. Brilliantly presented and fascinating to see.
Inside and outside. Informative, but I expected more. I really liked the view from the outside, but inside many tourists. Most of the rooms are very close.

The only one modern museum about ancient Rome. A truly must do, after the Fori and the Colosseo, Palazzo Valentini worths a lot as you can enjoy with your children a 3D reconstruction about and insidie real ancient Imperial Roman luxury houses ruins. A rare modern museum in Rome, with discovery digs always in progress, and an exclusive view of The Colonna Traiana (and a nice exhaustive video at the end!).
unforgettable multimedia underground experience. unforgettable multimedia underground experience in a wonderful reinassance palazzo with 3d graphic and real art mixing up together in a perfect way

Very interesting palazzo. Went here on trip advisor recommendation, and we were not disappointed. Gives a whole different perspective on Roman life by bringing the building to life. The only difficulty was the length of time in each room. We had a large party and by the time all had exited one room, the presentation in the next room was well under way. That aside, would definitely recommend.
Imagine how the Romans lived two millenia ago. Very enlightning multimedia show. You get a really good impression of how a Roman domus must have looked like 2000 years ago.

Interesting and different museum tour. After having been to several museums/sights displaying statues & paintings, we found Le Domus Romane to be a refreshingly different style of tour. Much of the 'magic' of the tour involves dark rooms (so beware if you are not a fan of the dark or have small children) with sections illuminated/computer-generated reconstructions, which beautifully demonstrate how these 2 homes would have looked in their heyday (which spans several Centuries). The tour lasted 1 and a half hours, which for us was a good length and had much to offer, including glass floors which enabled you to see the original features of the buildings whilst preserving these ancient structures. Thoroughly enjoyable! Would recommend to friends visiting Rome.

Amazing house brilliantly presented. The Domus Romane is a house that has been excavated and then preserved. There must be 100s of ruins around Rome and plenty of opportunities to wander amongst them, but the way this house is presented is just breathtaking. You stand on glass floors (pretty disorientating at first) whilst a (very thorough) voiceover guides you around the rooms of the house, and lighting cleverly highlights portions of the ruins to help you visualise the home as it was in Roman times. At its best, the lighting "rebuilds" the rooms, offering what static museum exhibitions can't - the chance to really imagine yourself in a Roman home. The second part of the tour describes Trajan's Column, ending with an up-close glimpse of the column itself.On the day we visited, it was pouring with rain, so this was a perfect indoor activity, but I'd urge anyone with an interest in the Romans to visit.
very nice. The Palazzo Valentini or Palazzo Imperiali built in 1873 , in Rome, close to , Piazza Venezia. is State Province Building

Travel back in time in a way you have never experienced before. A fascinating experience where we travelled back in time, seeing ruins come to life. Clearly a lot of thought has been put into this. Strongly recommended for children aged 9 and above as they can clearly see the connection between excavated ruins and what life was really like.

Not to be missed. An absolute highlight. I say no more, the experience will speak for itself. Numbers on each tour are necessarily limited - about 12 on the English 2.30pm - so do book in advance. Visited as a couple but this would really appeal to families with historically inquisitive children.
so cool, worth it. Such a high quality experience. all put together and presented in a way that makes it interaction with the viewer as unique as it comes.

Great museum experience. This was a really interesting and engaging museum experience, well worth the 12 Euro entrance fee. We pre-booked the English tour online. Underneath a public building (very close to the Victor Emmanuel Monument) are the archaeological remains of a wealthy Roman house. The excavation is viewed through a glass floor and it is bought to life through the use of modern technology and special effects to recreate how it would have been. As it offers tours in many languages we wondered why the artefact labels and display boards are only in Italian? The tour ends with a film about the Trajan Column, which is directly behind the museum. A visit is highly recommended and really makes you appreciate all the work that goes into an archaeological dig.

Once in a lifetime opportunity!. This places takes you back to ancient Rome. The guide takes you back to the beginning of Rome, how everything was built and how modern Rome is built under another city. I am writing this review now because I just finished Reading an academic article about Ancient Rome and it was due to this visit, that I was able to visualize everything the article said.

One of the best museums in Rome and very little known. This museum is one of the most interesting Roman museums in the entire city, yet it is barely known to Americans. You will need a reservation (tickets can be purchased on line), but you will see a fourth century AD Roman villa built under a Renaissance palazzo (Palazzo Valentini is now the office of the region of Lazio right in Piazza Venezia). Computers and lasers recreate the interiors of the museum, and it is really spectacular, one of the most interesting things you can see in Rome. By all means see this museum--you even see a bomb shelter down in the subterranean depths of the villa from WWII. I have been coming to Rome since 1962, and this is one of the most fascinating things I have seen here.

This is a great place to visit. I agree entirely with Ronil, this place is a great place to visit and not well known. It is 12€ entry and the tour takes about 1.5 hrs. In March I was able to rock up at 12.30 and book into the 2pm English tour. I found this much better in many respects than the Museo dei Fori Imperiali which was 14€ entry. The Domus enabled me to really be able to imagine what the house and lifestyle may have been like.

Different experience. This is hard to describe any better than those who have already posted here. It felt like a real privilege to be given access to this site of history. Having visited the Forum the previous day, this was a great complimentary trip which gave an in site into the life of the ancient Romans and into the work of our present day archaeologists. NB You must book in advance especially for the few English tours there are per day. AND don't visit if you are unhappy in the dark.

For those who want to travel back into the past!. I took the English tour, but there are tours in several languages. The whole tour is done over a glass floor through which you can see the old remains of an ancient home, which was destroyed (probably during an earthquake) and built over throughout the years. They use lights and lasers to recreate the place the way it was and it's truly amazing! I really felt like I was looking into the past. After the tour you get to watch a movie that shows the stories of the Trajan Column, which you cannot possibly appreciate in the same way just looking at it from the outside. It's like a comic strip, showing the conquests of the Roman emperor and it's pretty cool when you see the details narrated in the movie. This place is still kinda new so not many people know about it and that's a shame because it's really great! Unfortunately they don't allow photos inside due to copyrights...

You can't miss this place. One unknow surprise at heart of rome. Inside a public building ( in fact in the underground) an amazing house of the Roman era, with great special effects. In the end, a surprise from the II world war.

Excellent place to visit. I would highly recommend visiting this attraction while in Rome.Its amazing what you see beneath you, roman baths, a home, a road, staircase, mosaic floors, a monument and statues plus more.What i love the most is the technology they use which creates you a picture of how the roman home would looked back in the day and really helps you to visualise it all.

very interesting visit. It was a real surprise visiting the ancient Domus in Valentini Palace, a very special place to discover in Rome to understand the power and the ability of Romans in building houses and thermal baths. Amazing multimedial effects help visitors to imagine life in the Roman Empire periods. Absolutely to see!

You feel like you're back in time!!!. This was an extremely interactive and wonderful experience. If you ever wished that you could see all the Roman buildings back in their glory days then you have to come to this tour! You walk through what was once an opulent house and through new technology it can be recreated for you in front of your eyes. The best thing ever! High recommended!!!

A time travel experience. Palazzo Valentini was really one of the highlights of our visit to Rome. It made understanding ruins so much more accessible to the lay person. We used the Roma Passes to get a free entrance to the attraction. We had phoned a couple of weeks earlier to reserve places for the 2pm English tour of the archaeological remains of a 4th century Roman house. There are just a couple of English tours in a day. So they fill up really fast. We loved seeing the sound and light show that recreated the 4th century home over the ruins. The kids (aged 10, 7) found this really awesome. This was followed by a half an hour movie on the making of the Trajan Column, which the kids found boring. The lady sitting next to me and I both nodded off for a few minutes. The tour ended with viewing the Trajan Column right outside the backdoor of the palazzo, which is quite amazing. Those travelling with kids may want to know there is a very nice toyshop next door, Little Big Town.

An exciting tour. The tour through LE DOUMS ROMANE, that are underneath Palazzo Valentini, was one of the most exciting visits I have had so far. An excellent presentation, with computer animation as well as with holographic one, makes the past times appear in front of you. Within the tour, there is a video presentation describing the bas relief of Trajan's column,too.The sight is open for public on 2010. Worth seeing!

Unique and Intimate Tour. Our family including our two kids, 12 and 10, really enjoyed our time on this tour. Reservations are required, as the tour is limited to about 16 people per tour and English tours are provided only during select times during the day. The organization responsible for this sight has done a stellar job in providing participants to quite literally view the past. It is a class act! In addition, we really enjoyed the "bonus" education given on Trajan's column (which is in the "backyard" of the Piazza Valentini.)

Excellent and enjoyable experience. Visited with my 2 children (6 and 10) - they and I were entranced for the whole experience / tour. I thoroughly recommend visiting Le Domus Romane - one of the most enjoyable, well-organised and informative experiences we had in Rome. As well of the joy of experiencing a virtual reconstruction of a Roman villa, I particularly enjoyed the commentary on Trajan's Column. Thank you.

Setting the benchmark for historical museums.... As a family of four we loved our recent visit to Rome and thought the Colloseum, Forum, Vatican Museum, Sistine Chapel, Pantheon, St Peters etc.. were simply breathtaking. However, this attraction is head and shoulders the best value for money you will ever spend in Rome. It is a 90 minute long, visually interactive tour walking over the excavated ruins of an ancient Roman house. The ruins are seen underfoot through glass floors throughout the tour with computer generated images bringing the place back to life. The group we were in consisted of only 10 people so it provides perfect space and time to marvel at the ingenuity of the ancient Romans. This is not advertised particularly well and the tour (they alternate between English & Italian) has to be booked in advance. It cost 40 EURO for 2 adults and 2 children (under 17) but is worth every cent. So pleased we visited (thanks to Trip Advisor reviews) as it finished our wonderful 4 day trip to Rome off perfectly. ******

best view of ancient Rome ever. The computer-enhanced view of an ancient Roman house with wonderful guides is a must-see in Rome and very convenient to the Forum and Colosseum. The glass-floor presentation is perfect for an above-ground view.

beyond my expectation. great use of science and technology to help use understand history. A few things to note1) bookings required in advance2) Roma pass is acceptable 3) no photography, but the imagines are well captured in my mind

Entertaining. With innovative layout and usage of effects they have created wonderful surroundings to experience the ancient Rome like never before. They have literally resurrected this ancient villa to tell the stories and livelihood of ages back from now. The tricky part is getting the ticket and the guided tour in your language and once that is effectively done, this is the best interactive experience you can have.

Great for all ages...but website lies. The spouse and I--both middle-aged adults--thoroughly enjoyed this. Great dramatic presentation, well worth our time and money. Note that you won't be able to take pictures inside.One caveat: the website said there would be English language tours at 1, 1:30, 2 and 2:30. We were traveling in the off-season, so we did not pre-book for flexibility. We arrived at the site just before 2, and were told there was no English language tour at 2:30. Check carefully when booking in advance!

Best 90 minutes you will spend in rome. Definitely worth a visit but book in advance as they only take 12-15 people each half hour and you can choose language. Amazing trip back to 100 ad, great computer graphics and commentary.Been to rome loads of times but this was one of the best history finds.

The BEST thing to see in Rome! You will not be sorry you went. 6 stars!. I had never heard of this tourist attraction until I purchased the Roma Pass for my trip to Rome in October 2013. At the time, it was one of the places you could visit with the Roma Pass although sadly, on a quick search today, this seems to no longer be the case. This restored Roman villa located under a government building in the heart of Rome took my breath away. I am obsessed with Ancient Rome and visiting this attraction was like stepping back in time. The Forum, Palatine Hill and Colosseum, whilst fascinating, can sometimes start to look much like each other because there is not much left but stone. Not at this place. As you move through the remains of the villa, you walk on a glass floor suspended above the ruins of the villa. Lights are turned on at various times to highlight different parts of the villa and when the lights were turned on to show part of a collapsed staircase, I almost stopped breathing. The decorations and colour of the staircase were so vibrant, almost as if the owners had just stepped out and the staircase had just collapsed. There were excavated household items and even food. It was a magical and spine tingling experience. The photographs do not do justice to this place and nothing will prepare you for how amazing the experience will be. I cannot recommend it highly enough and you can bet that I will be back here next time I go to Rome. Tip for kids and any other member of the family too bored and not wanting to go - there is a large toy store practically right next door!

New but fantastic tourist attraction. Palazzo Valentini will surprise you. However, limited entry, only guided tours, so make sure you ask for the timing for the guided tours in your language. The exhibition is done in a wonderful way. A recently discovered villa, relives to its beauty with the help of multimedia techniques. At the end, the story of Trajanus column is presented in an interesting movie. Highly recommended !

Stunningly brilliant concept. Three years ago I stumbled on Domus Romane almost by accident because I had to walk past it from Hotel Evezia to P. Venezia. I was so delighted that I returned later the same week. I shall be in Rome again in April and I intend to visit it again. The use of glass flooring to show the rediscovered remains of the domus, and the use of computer technology to extend the reality into a vision of how it was eighteen centuries ago is wonderful. The simulated helicopter flight over ancient Rome is cream on the cake.

Truly worth the price. One of the most inspirational experiences you can have in Rome is this one. The enlightment and audio effects are interesting. You can buy the ticket online but I recall that it is 1.5€ cheaper when purchased from the building itself. Enjoy the tour!

A glimpse into the past. This place is well worth a visit, particularly if you are short of time. It really does give a glimpse into what life may have been like.
It is exhibited so well, don't forget to stay for the movie at the end, we missed it because we were not told about it, fortunately we can go back.

A hidden gem. I would never of visited this house if it wasn't for tripadvisor (thank you). Not well advertised in Rome and easy to walk past it (in fact we did). 12 Euros per person, best to book in advance, we booked as we walked past it in the morning. tours on every half hour around lunch time and last for 1.5 hours. As people said very strange walking on the glass over the old roman ruins. We preferred this house to visiting the roman forum. Guide very informative. A clever use of multi media to show you how the house once was. However, the 20 - 30 minute video at the end a bit long (dozed off)!!
Loved the modern spin on an ancient villa. Excellent multimedia presentation about an ancient villa. Very concise. Wonderful time. Brings to life the way people lived 2000 years ago.

Great way to get a sense of the "real" ancient Rome. Went to see this on my last day at the end of 2 weeks in Rome. It was a fun way to end my trip and would have been great to see earlier on as well. It's a fascinating project and a perfect way to visualize how all those chunks of marble ones sees lying everywhere, actually would have fit together! Definitely a must see, even if you have only a few days!
an amazing project. we liked everything even breathtaking,but it became a real challenge walking in darkness...we managed and enjoyed it!!!
Very cool!. Informative, interesting, nice effects, "real world" attraction. The glass floor let you see the excavations.

A town under the town. If you want to visualize the wealth of history in Rome, you should visit that event. With the help of technology (light projections, excavations), you will spend an hour under the modern city, and you will be taken back in time, at the time of the classical Roman Empire.

Brilliant multimedia exhibition. We had a private tour as there were only two of us for the pre-booked time slot. It was great. This is the best use of excavation site I have ever seen. It was wonderful to see the old room to come alive through the projection and music. Wonderful, truly wonderful, I was amazed by the cleverness of it all. Just great, make sure to book ahead.

Highly recommended. The tour is a brilliant way of bringing to life how Romans lived and how buildings were built and used. The glass floors really make you feel as if you are getting a behind the scenes tour. It is also an great introduction to archeology. Our 10 year old said it was second only to the Colosseum in his review of our holiday in Rome.Tip: I prebooked our tour from England.
A real gem. A beautilfull computer aided restauration of a Roman house with bath next to the Trajan column. Gives a great insight of how the Romans lived.

Captivating!. This "easy to miss" gem was truly an unbelievable experience! Based upon the reviews on Tripadvisor's for Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini, we decided to visit the Historic Museum. We were not disappointed.If you are interested in Roman history and its rich and amazing architecture; this is the place! The tours begins in darkness. But it leads one to the light through the ruins with such beauty, delight and fascination! With the music, narration, lighting and the wonderful world of technology, the tour leads your imagination to the beautiful and modern world of Rome. We were so mesmerized by the tour, we hardly took any photos. Truly amazing! Don't miss out!! Be sure to book on-line or arrive early for the tour...if you miss out on the first minutes of the tour, there's no re-entry.

Very nice museum with virtual reproduction. It is a really interessting museum with virtual effects. You learn a lot about ancient roman houses. But book your tour in advance - it is always very crowded

Very clever. This tour brings ancient Rome to life. You are literally walking over excavated ruins and being given a first hand experience of how wealthy Romans lived, it is amazing. We bought our tickets online in advance, booking an exact time, and there were only 5 of us on our tour, so you won't be crowded or feel like you are missing something. The only reason I am giving a rating of 4 and not 5 is the movie towards the end. I think that it goes for just a bit too long - they could condense it and still provide all the info you need for the last part of the tour. This attraction should be on every list of must-sees in Rome.

Exellent presentation. Presentation is very unusual and made by high technology .Palazzo itself is the part of history. By the way, always busy. Highly recommended to make reservation as early as you can

Fantastic experience. Just off Piazza Venezia, and perhaps a little difficult to spot, it's opposite the Wax museum. Inventive museum. Helps you experience living in Ancient Rome. Looking in to the extensive ruins through the glass floor is fantastic
Don't Miss out. Need tickets in advance but do not miss out on this awesome multi-media experience. And surprise at the end.

Nice surprise. Having been to Rome three times, we decided to look for something other than the main attractions. This attraction is well worth the visit. Great way of showing an example of a Roman Villa. The multimedia exhibition is an amazing method of showing how the Roman elite lived. Put this on your list along with the main attractions. The bonus close up view of Trajan's Column is a nice end to the tour.PS - if you're early for the next tour in your language, try the café beside the ticket booth for cheap and excellent coffee.

Nothing like it anywhere. This is a tourist attraction unlike anything you have ever seen. They were doing some foundation work under City Hall and found an ancient Roman Villa that was unknown of.The genius of this is how they take you on a tour of it. They replaced the roof of the villa with glass so you walk on top of the rooms. It is really unbelievable.There is also a huge surprise at the end of the tour which I will not spoil but this is a really cool thing to do especially if the weather is not too good outside.DougtheLebaneseguy

Don't miss!!!. Likely one of the best places to visit to learn about Ancient Rome. Fantastic 3d reproductions that overlays projections over the ruins. Great infomative audio and video tours. I was absolutely amazed by it and would recommend it to everyone. Reservations was very easy to make online and received tickets via email. Check online ahead of time. Right now in the. Holiday season the place has indeed runout of seats for days, but make sure not to miss this amazing spot. Right around the corner from Venice Square.

Fascinating. We took a cab from the Pantheon for $20 in heavy rain to this catacomb. We literally were the only two there. We had a private tour as a result. Best $16 we spent all trip. This was my favorite sight we saw in our 10 day trip.
Brings ruins to life. The tour gave me a new appreciation of the past life of the ruins being clearly thoroughly researched. Digital media was used very well.

3D Projections of ancient Rome. If you like roman history, archaeology and/or ancient architecture - go!
This is an underground tour in an archaeological dig site, converted into a professional, beautiful and interesting attraction.
Booking in advance is recommended, since the different (set) tour hours run in different languages, and it's impossible to enter without a tour.
Layers of Roman history. This dwelling has layers from ancient Rome and Middle Ages under building - very well shown & explained.

Another don't miss!. We did this one after visiting a great number of ruins and I'm reAlly glad we did. This museum is one of a kind and helps you jell it all together where you can finally visualize how it was like to live then. The images are now imprinted in my memory. It's a light show, a live diaporama, a laser show.... One or all of these that rebuilds over the ruins the villa as it was then. After this experience, it's much easier to reconstruct the scenes when you visit other ruins. Anyway, that's how it worked for me. I would not do it upon my arrival however, I'd plan smack in the middle of my trip. Enjoy!
Luxurious Roman villa. Wonderful display of ruins of villa, enhanced for visitor with lighting to show what the rooms looked like 1800 years ago!

Well set out, interesting to visit. Once again found on tripadvisor. We were pleasantly surprised at how well set out and informative this place was. A good introduction to Rome and the archaeology of it.

Fantastic but you need to know where to go.... We are seasoned and matured travelers and were in Rome for a week, our 5th or 6th trip to Rome. We love history, art, etc. and this site was just fantastic. It is suitable for young or old, novice or experienced. Since many reviews already covered what it is, let me offer 3 practical items. 1. The location indicated in the map at the offitical website is either wrong or confusing. Here is how you get there. The entrance is east of piazza Venezia--about 50 yards--on the only big road where buses run (40, 64, etc.). You will see a small sign on the sidewalk and you enter the courtyard of a municipal building. You will find the ticket counter and the entrace to the left of the courtyard (as you enter). 2. English tours (90 minutes) are available every day at 1:30, 2:00, and 2:30. Booking online was very easy--13:50 euros each. The site is covered by the Roma Pass. You probably need to go to the site to use your Roma Pass for ticketing, however. 3. Walking on glass took us a while (about 10 minutes) to get use to. Just keep this in mind so you would shorten your adjustment time.

A great tour of an ancient home. This is an unexpected delight of a tour. As you walk through an ancient underground home, beneath one of Rome's current palazzos overhead narration fills in the history of the place, while special effects, etc bring it back to life in all of it's glory....not to be missed!

A must to understand the history and importance of Roman civilasation. Very intersting exhibiltion on old houses just under the palazzo and probably also of the palace of Trajan . Very well done , not to be missed . Prebooking is a must

Different and well worth it. Great place, you learn about Roman life, and get to see an interesting excavation site through the glass floor. Book in advance, guided tours in small groups, also interesting for children. (do not go if you are afraid of darkness)

PROFESSIONAL & AMAZING. We have been to Rome 5 times now - first time here. It is an amazing experience - really recreates what the archaelogists have achieved and helps you to imagine how the wealthier Romans lived. the multi-media presentation was outstanding. The groups are small and it was wonderful to walk through an area taking you to the bottom of Trajan's column with a great up close view of it. I am really grateful that TripAdvisor highlighted this otherwise we may not have heard about it. Great to take a group of History students here! Photos not allowed - but worth it anyway.

History Comes Alive with Technology. Through a high-tech light show, the remains of this aristocratic ancient Roman house are reconstructed right before your eyes, and often right under your feet. Using the archaeological remains of mosaic floors, frescoes and marble revetment, the house is restored to its former glory as you move through several rooms, including the family's private baths. The tour ends with a reconstruction of Trajan's Market which is right next door to the house. You get to look out through a doorway upon Trajan's Column, which looms large due to its proximity. This was my third time taking this tour and I am always fascinated. As other reviewers mentioned, advance tickets are recommended, especially for English tours. A small snack bar with minimal seating and restrooms are in the courtyard which is the entrance to the tour.

A secret place open for the asking. Here you can visit a mix of an ancient Roman villa with renaissance interferences, all explained masterly with audio and vide installations accompanying you all the way through the underground of the Palazzo

Unique museum. Our son is studying in Rome and saw this museum as part of his classwork. He suggested we see it when we went to Rome to visit him. There are only a few slots available each day so book early. It was such a different kind of experience and we definitely recommend it to friends and family traveling to Rome. You actually get to walk above an ancient house and peer down into it while the history of the location is explained.

Very impressive!. Domus Romane provides a fascinating and unique look into an ancient Roman home. It really provided an amazing glimpse into the daily lives of the wealthy ancient Romans. The floors here are glass and built above the ruins, so that you are standing directly above the areas that are being described. Particular areas are highlighted with spotlights so that you know exactly which areas the commentary is focusing on at any given time. I highly recommend a visit. A few things worth noting: You must book tickets for this in advance, especially if you require an English-language tour. Also, you use this as one of the two free admissions covered by a Roma Pass, but you still must book in advance and you MUST mention the Roma Pass when booking. You do not need to have actually purchased the Roma Pass at the time that you make your reservation. Also, this place is pretty difficult to find. Via IV Novembre is located just off Piazza Venezia near the Vittorio Emmanuel II Monument and Trajan's Column. If you are struggling to find it, it is right next to the Hop On, Hop Off bus stop, near a large toy store.

Wowed me with special effects. I found this activity online after deciding that the Timeline activities were a little too campy for us, with two teens ages 16 and 18. I was knocked over by the whole experience. Really gave you a feel for what was there, and how archeologists found it and worked out what it was. Well worth the time and price. Caveat - the experience is 1 1/2 hours and you stand for all but about 10 minutes. It can be hard after a long day of sight-seeing. There were some elderly women in our group who had a hard time standing that long. I recommend this for ages 13 and up.

Don't Miss This One. Recently discovered, Domus Romane unearths the former household of a very wealthy ancient Roman family. Who the family actually was is not as important as what you'll discover here and how much amazingly remained intact thousands of years later.You'll walk on thick Plexiglas floors over the ruins which gives you the sensation of stepping out of time machine and into this house. The guided tour then uses an amazing mix of light and sound to recreate the home as you stand in the various rooms. It is an amazing experience and you will really appreciate the many other ancient finds in The Eternal City.

Highlight of our trip. We went here on our last day and we were so happy we did. It is such a fantastic museum. We were simply amazed at what archaeologists had discovered! It was simply amazing getting such a rare insight into the lives of the ancient Romans. Highly highly recommended.

Extraordinary. I have read in Tripadvisor about this attraction and I was amazed to have read it is one of the best in Rome. So I went there to check out and I found it really wonderful. The work done by the archeologists mixed with multi media technology take you back in time to the era of Roman Empire and the life style of the wealthy people. You can not miss it. Must see.

Expect the unexpected. Don't forget to book this tour in advance. There are only a few slots per day, especially if you choose the English tour. We booked this a few days before the tour itself and got the last 2 seats... We also had to change our itinerary twice, because the first 2 dates we preferred on going were already full. Tough luck.Anyway, this tour was awesome! What makes it different is that it's out of the ordinary -- the floors were made of glass! This is such because everything you had to see was right below your feet! It was a bit scary at first because you could see what was under it, but you'll get the hang of it in a while. You could see what's left of the houses, floors, walls, and décor before through the glass floors and projectors also help recreate everything else through 3D animation which was pretty cool. There was a video presentation succeeding the "floor tour," as well.

Has the real WOW factor. Loved the experience of seeing the historical house come to life with the inclusion of Virtual Reality.Bit concerned at first of walking on glass floor but soon got used to it.
best museum in rome. This is amazing. incredible insight to life in ancient rome. you walk above ruins with life projected below. highly recommend.
Wow!. Went to "Domus Romane" on our last day, and it put it all into perspective! Well worth the price, and recommend making a reservation to get the ENGLISH tour.

Very unhelpful staff, didn't get to see the Domus at all!. This attraction was high on out must-do list during a weekend in Rome. Arrived at the Domus on Saturday morning to be told all English language tours were full but could book by phone or internet for the next day. Despite multiple attempts to do both we were unable to get anywhere. Went back to Domus on Sunday to be told the booking phone lines are closed on weekends and I should've booked online. Despite repeated explanation of our problems trying to do just that, the staff were offhand and very unhelpful. Since this is a relatively new attraction, I am surprised at the staff attitude. Disappointing....

Too recent for the guidebooks. The books we took to Rome didn't mention Palazzo Valentini at all. But, based on the recommendation of friends we began our month-long stay in Rome with this attraction. It really set the stage for an understanding of what Rome was about and gives a sense of what lies buried beneath much of the city. By all means, include this on your visit, even if you only have two days to "do Rome."

The Domus under the Palace of the Province. A very good virtual and vocal reconstruction of the villa of a senator; the area dating to 5th AD. had precious mosaics, marbles, statues, garden, niches, baths. You'll understand how the master of that house used to live even through the remains of dinner and lunch! Booking is recommended

Stunning. Had read the reviews on TA and made it a priority to visit. It far exceeded my expectations and for both my husband and myself, this was the highlight of our trip to Rome. Walking on a glass floor over the excavations was a little disconcerting at first, but when we got used to it, this was an amazing experience. The art historians and archaeologists who worked together to bring this building back to life have done a superb job. You start off looking at just the stones, which is fascinating on its own. But then during the commentary a part of the room lights up, a floor, a ceiling, a staircase, a mosaic, a thermal bath. Onto it is projected light, colour and pattern to show what it would have looked like in its full glory. There's also sound so that that you can imagine yourself right back there with the Patrician family whose home this was.For anyone with an interest in Roman history this is a truly fascinating visit and one I can't recommend highly enough.

A great little surprise!. Before arriving in Rome I had no idea of this brilliant attraction. It was recommended to us by the owner of our B&B however I would say its a MUST for anyone visiting Rome. Its also completely under cover so good to do on a rainy day!You basically spend the entire time walking on a glass floor suspended over amazing excavated ruins of what was once a wealthy house.The history about the building itself extends into the history of the city and the way the tour is conducted really brings everything to life.It uses a number of clever projections, light shows, presentations, sound effects - all sorts - to give you a real insight in the culture and how the building and life within the city has changed over time. Our B&B owner booked this for us however I think different language tours run at different times (eg. I think the English one was about 2:30pm).Its not a well known attraction like the Colosseum, the Pantheon, the Sistine Chapel or St. Peters - but this is the one I was certain I needed to review when I got home to ensure other people don't miss out on this little gem.
magnificent. It was just breathtaking - you can feel the history. You will not forget it.... I had a wonderful time.
Incredible. No one should leave Rome without coming here to see history almost in the making and they make it come alive
Beautiful interactive learning. Located in the basement of Palazzo Valentini, the domus are made to go with a play of light and shadow that enhances ..
A MUST SEE. A unique blend of ancient and modern multimedia. The way that the information was presented really made you feel that you were a part of the ancient experience.

a new take on museums. This is a wonderful place to learn about Roman life of 2000 years ago. The modern 3d effects are quite useful. My only complaint is that walking around glass floors in the semi dark can be a bit dis-equilibrilizing---not for the faint hearted. Also there should be a small booklet of explanation for the cost of this museum

Must See if you are in Rome. This was the highlight of our Rome trip - better even than the Colosseum. Amazing recreation - based on beautifully restored noble house from 400 AD, right under the streets and buildings in middle of Rome - complete with multimedia presentations.
Gives a real look into life as a rich roman family. A MUST see!

Ancient history made easy. This site is a great visit and I would recommend it to any traveler to Rome. This is perfect for young people. It makes learning a bit of ancient Roman history very accessible and fun. It is well organized, fun and dramatic.
Go see the Domus Valentini if you find yourself in Rome. It's worth it.

Amazing tour. This was a hidden gem amongst the obvious sights across Rome and hidden underground below a large building. The excavations found were amazing and extremely well brought to life by clever lighting and story telling. A must see!

Layers of History. This attraction was suggested to me for my 6 year old on the Roma Card. It requires a booking but we turned up in morning snd managed a mid afternoon booking in English.Tour goes for 1 1/2 hours. My daughter was a bit bored as commentary was not appropriate for her, but I found the tour fascinating and it provided greater appreciation for Ancient Rome and the ruins we see today. Mist interesting is appreciating, liberally, the layers if history buried beneath the streets of modern Rome. Its worthwhile, relevant and brings the past to life.

exciting and unique. unique museum and very exciting and interesting method that i never experienced before. There is an english and italian tour at different times of day. Amazing technology and information any age or educational backround you have. Tour guide and the whole exhibition is under your feet while fully lit and under glass you are standing on. loved it .

Great way to understand the layers of Rome. Went here based on other reviews - as others have said, it's a mystery why it's not in guide books. A couple of notes: it's very dark inside, and the tour moves quickly. It's 90% from a recorded voice, so there is no chance to ask questions. I would have appreciated a slightly slower pace. I think the main value is that you're given the opportunity to visualize what the ruins would have looked like, and their original structure is outlined in lights or lasers. Subsequent visits to Ostia Antica and the Forum helped with the big picture. The fact that this is underground below the municipal building is just amazing.

Multi-media Roman Remains. Multi-media assisted guide to an ancient Roman grand house. Fascinating, well worth a visit. The remains are below an existing building, and comprise a number of rooms, all with multi-media displays and lighting. There are English and Italian tours.

Best atraction in town. Important to book by telephone before or visit on day 1 to plan a visit. Only 15 people are allowed per 1/2 hour so hard to get in. Impressive way of presenting an old Roman house and its swimming pool.

Interesting site. Underneath Palazzo Valentini. Booking needed. Can book either by phone or in person. Went in on our way to Colosseum to find a slot. Luckily found a slot straight away. Few slots only in English. Great multimedia reconstruction of the Roman buildings underneath modern Rome.

At last I enjoy history!. Never been a lover of history until now. This place brings it to life, and amazing value at €27 for 2 people, for a 90 minute show.It's a recent discovery and what they have done with glass floors, projectors, light effects etc is surely the way all archeology exhibitions will be presented in future (Pompeii take note!). Added bonus, you finish with a ground level view of Trajan's Column, an angle rarely seen.Go here if, like me, your partner is enjoying ancient Rome and for you it's just not quite happening!

Wonderful 2nd visit. The first visit, 2 years ago, was the italian version, I was determined to 'do the English language tour to make sure I'd missed nothing.Well Worth Repeating!!! In fact it was not a repeat as a lot of the tour had changed. Fascinating use of technology to build on ancient remains & bring a way of life to us all. No photography allowed, & no souvenir book which is a shame.

A great new attraction that is really old!. Having visited Rome many, many times I was delighted to find a new attraction. Domus Romane is a top place to visit. It is a combination of an archaelogical site with modern lighting, lazers and other innovative ideas to enlighten and entertain the viewer. You will not just look at the ruins but learn about what life was like back then - you come away feeling really fulfilled (and pleased that you spent the money!)We booked on the website before we left Australia so that we would get an English speaking guided tour. This presentation is made even better by the recorded commentary that accompanies the guide and that is extremely easy to hear. It is only started once everyone is in the area.We were really impressed and fully recommend this old Roman villa with a new slant on tourism.

A Roman treasure. Very clever use of lighting and sound to help recreate what parts of these ancient Roman houses (now underground) would have been like in their time. Very interesting commentary to accompany the tour and a special view of a nearby monument also added to the experience. Tours go for about 1.5 hours and cost 13.50 Euro for adults (including the compulsory 1.5 Euro booking fee.) Places in each tour are limited (up to 15 people per tour) so it is best to book in advance if you definitely want to visit Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini. Tours are offered in Italian, English and French and occur at different times of the day. We reserved our tickets online for an English tour a fair few weeks before we left Australia for Rome. The website says to pick the tickets up from the booking office which in this case is the actual building where the tour takes place. The building is not too difficult to find however you may think you are in the wrong place. The entrance is actually in a courtyard of a government building where government officials often are guarding the entrance to. Just tell them you are there for the domus tour and they'll let you through.A very interesting and different attraction in Rome. A highlight of our trip to Rome. Would definitely recommend a visit here!

Innovative visit to an ancient and precious archeo site in Rome, off the beaten track.. If you are visiting Rome and love archeological sites you will certainly go to the Forum and the Colosseum but you must be aware of, and possibly make time in your tour for somenthing else nearby. Just as you turn the corner from piazza Venezia you find palazzo Valentini with its amazing archeo site underneath. It's a bewildering experience going below the Palazzo and discover this archeological jewel both for its beauty and for the way the tour is offered, a true and innovative fruition! Search 'palazzo Valentini' to make a reservation. You don't need a guide...but tours are guided....also in English. The curators of the tour and the archeologists/restorators are genius...

Amazing. This was one of our favourite attractions in Rome. Fairly new discovery and so well done - an unforgettable experience as you walk on see through panels throughout the excavations. Ten euros and an hour and a half very well spent.
Contact info!. hi I'm trying to get palazzo valentini email address so I czn find out dates/times of openings and English guides over xmas/new year period?

Very informative and enjoyable for those interested in ancient Rome. We booked in advance online. We deliberately chose a tour in Italian to fit in with other plans. When we got there, the helpful person at the desk said an extra English tour had been added at lunch time and arranged for us to swap. This proved a good move, the pre-recorded commentary was extensive and would have been difficult unless you were fluent or nearly fluent in Italian. There are no labels to read etc. In contrast to some other reviews, we found the staff helpful.The site itself was very interesting and I thought imaginatively presented. The numbers were limited- there were 9 people on ours and we all got a good look at the exhibits, the guide being careful to ensure this happened.Thought it a bit odd that the souvenir shop was half way round, but we were waiting for the group ahead to finish their tour.The film at the end describing in detail what the images on Trajan's column depict was fascinating. It wasn't overly long, nor boring as some reviews have suggested. I recommend this if you have any interest in ancient Rome. Make sure you identify the address before you set out, it isn't well signposted until you are inside the courtyard entrance.

Amazing! Great stop for your first visit to Rome.. This is well worth the money, but you will need a reservation. I have been to Rome 8 times and this is one of the highlights. Basically they take you through a old Roman home and utilizes digital technology to show how each room looked. The explanation of Trajan's column at the end was also great. If you have never been to Rome, make this one of your early tours. It will make everything else you see more meaningful.

Good but can be improved. This is an interesting concept and the tour lasted about 1.5 hours. You go through different sections of an excavated home of a supposedly wealthy person. Using clever lighting and sound effects, they explain what the excavated items are and what the home would have looked liked in its heyday. Some areas of the home are quite small and only a few people can enjoy it if the group is not asked to move along and give others a chance to view them. Unfortunately, this is what happened in the group I was in. Our group totalled 16 persons, 10 of whom were teenage foreign students who selfishly monopolised most of the attractions, leaving the rest of us unable to view them. The guide that was with us, could have done more to move the group along so that each person has a fair chance to look at the exhibits, but she was rather indifferent and did nothing. What they could do is to limit the number of persons in each tour group to 10 persons so that everyone can have a fair chance to look at the exhibits, and for sections where only 2 or 3 persons can view the exhibits at a time, for the guide to get people to move along. Also, a stop at the gift shop comes halfway through the tour. It should have been at the end of the tour so that those of us who are not interested in buying anything can leave, instead of standing around for 15 minutes waiting for those to finish buying their souvenirs, before the tour continues.

You've done the Colosseum, Vatican & Pantheon - this is something else!. This mulit-media experience of ancient Rome is unlike any other. The remains of two remarkable Roman Domus' are brought to life with the aid of engaging light, sound and projection accompanied by a narrative. Throughout the experience you are gliding across a suspended glass surface which gives you the sense of truly visiting the Domus. I look forward to seeing more of the Forum come alive through modern technology.

Domus Palazzo Valentini is the BEST TOUR in all of Rome!. I LOVE ROME!!! I love to explore the ruins of the ancient Roman Forum and the Colosseum, for example, but like I always say “You need a whole lot of imagination..…” to really understand and appreciate what you are seeing. I wish all of the architectural exhibits in Rome were like Domus Palazzo Valentini. No other tour in Rome will show you exactly what a REAL Roman house from the 2nd century looks like – you are THERE! This tour makes it all so easy to understand -- Finally. Talk about Visualizing! You’ll see excavations of these two 2nd century houses and then, our 21st century modern technology completes the scene with lights and video! This technology “fills in the blanks” by giving you the Before-and-After views. It’s very cool. The whole tour is so well done. This relatively new exhibit takes you on a walk – yes, actually walking on Plexiglas floors to see these houses which are UNDER a 16th century palazzo. The Plexiglas takes a little getting used to, but the kids love it! Obviously, these houses were owned by powerful Roman families. You will see various rooms including the kitchen and a very impressive private “Roman” bath with a balcony. You’ll see beautifully decorated walls and structural walls made of huge travertine blocks. The mosaics are so stunning and intricate, as are the tile floors. It’s amazing to realize that you are actually viewing ancient Roman houses from when Hadrian ruled! Check out the website: palazzovalentini.it The photos are fabulous but nothing compared to the seeing it in person! As they say on the website, “An unforgettable journey through time…..” and you’ll want to experience every minute of it!This tour is worth every “penny” of the 12 Euros entrance fee! But you must Book in Advance – and pay online or by phone – you CANNOT buy the tickets at the venue. They allow a maximum of only 15 people for the English-speaking tours – and there are only a few English-speaking tours every day. If you have a Roma Pass – call them to use it. (We had difficulty using the website – maybe it was our credit card – but our hotel concierge made the call for us.) Reminder – plan ahead as they are closed on Tuesday – and this is a very popular tour even though it’s not even in Rick Steves’ tour book yet! (How did that happen?)It’s located just around the corner from the “Wedding Cake” (Victor Emmanuel Monument) and Trajan’s Forum.This is an incredible look at ancient Rome that you won’t want to miss! I will see it every time I return to Rome!

Admin not so good. Be warned, only a few sessions not in Italian each day. English is at 4 & 4:30.Tried to book and was pushed to the only place which is the website, pressed the "English" button which is fine until you book and it converts back to Italian on the booking pages. Hence we booked an Italian session by accident not realizing the languages were different, as you can imagine the Romans on the front desk were very sympathetic when we showed up and they told us about the language ..... They almost laughed. Asked politely if we could change, no chance, non possibli. We went through it, looked ok, but just boring not understanding anything.

Great experience. Delving into the excavated ruin of long ago Rome was amazing - the tour was very well put together and the light show help us to imagine what life must have been like in ancient Rome living in the Domus Romane. It is well worth experience. The only thing that was a bit off putting was the ticket booking process - we could not book directly at the venue, but had to call and pay by credit card over the phone. Very strange as there were three people sitting at the venue dealing with same day ticketing.

What a find!. This is a fairly new attraction so it may not be in guide books but it's a must see. You do need to book ahead as only about 10 people are let in every hour. It's a excavation of a Roman Villa that you view through a glass florr using a guide and the lates technology to see how life was back in time and what was found, etc. It's a fabulous look at ancient Rome!

Wonderful use of sound, light and glass floors!. Just to agree with all the excellent ratings from other reviewers. But book your visit. We went in quiet October and were lucky they had laid on three additional English language tours.Tip for Roma Antiquities: learn from this venue when you finally have to protect the Forum or make that area easier to decipher.

different experience. It is certainly worth the time (1.5 hrs) if you have 3 days or more in Rome. If you have Roma Pass, the cost is free or 50% off, but you have to call to make the reservation; or you can purchase full price ticket and make reservation altogether online. We called in the early morning and got a reservation at 1:30pm. Our trip was at the beginning of Oct. My 5 year old daughter liked it, she called it a "cave", actually that was the only thing she remembered from Rome. Ticket for kids under 6 years old is free, and a reservation is also required.Trajan's Forum, Monument Vittorio Emanuele II, Capitoline Hill are nearby.

Unless you are fixed on a date, don't buy tickets for this or other event through Ticketone.it. Recently, I purchased two tickets for this wonderful place through Ticketone.it. To accommodate friends, a few weeks before the ticketed day I wanted to move the date ahead by one day and add two people. Their email response was as follows:"We are sorry but after the payment is made it will not be possible to cancel the purchase.Tickets are valid only for the chosen day and the time slot.No cancellation, no refunds, no changes are allowed under any circumstance, once the transaction is made."Please note they sell tickets for events all over Italy. Their position seems to be the same for all events. To be evenhanded, the website does indicate this policy but only in the "Help and FAQ"section. This policy is very heavy handed. It is true that I bear the responsibility for not digging deeper on their website. But it also would be helpful if they made this policy clearer in the beginning. I am writing this to alert others so they won't make the same mistake I did. Caveat Emptor!

EXCELLENT AND NOVEL PRESENTATION. I echo the observations made by other reviewers.  This was a skilfully managed exhibition imaginatively portraying the physical and intellectual process of an archaeological dig exposing the layers of the palimpsest that is Rome.  I was in a group of about a dozen people for my tour (at 3.00pm on a Saturday). Accordingly there was ample space to see the exhibits. I particularly enjoyed the audiovisual information provided about Trajan's Column which was followed by the short opportunity to see the Column from ground level.  I consider my experience would have been improved in 3 ways but I don't consider that the attraction is responsible for the first 2 lapses. As for the third, I humbly recognise my failure to fully understand the italian language. Firstly, I felt unable to book a tour myself since it appeared to me that I had to telephone to do so.
