Happily my hotel did it for me. I found myself on an english tour at a time when my earlier perusal of the web page suggested to me that no such tour was being offered. Secondly, it was unfortunate that despite this site being so popular among tripadvisor users, it did not appear on the various free Tourist Maps I picked up in Rome. My Hotel were slightly hampered in being able to mark precisely where I could find it. I therefore took longer finding its precise location than anticipated and accordingly was rather disappointed to have missed the very beginning of my tour. Thirdly, there were some items that had been recovered in the dig and were on display. I would have been very grateful had the information posted describing such been available in English

A real eye-opener!!. One of the most professionally organized tours with a full audio- visual presentation explaining the site (check the language for individual tours if you only speak English). Glass floors allow you to see the spot-lit points of interest. Small groups. A true glimpse of how people lived and an archaeological masterpiece. The best history lesson I have ever had!!!

Wow - a new Rome must-do. This is a really interesting new take on presenting excavated ruins. The excavation is of one of the most lavish and large private residences of Ancient Rome ever uncovered, but the way it is presented is very, very impressive, educational and entertaining.You walk over glass most of the time and imaginative use of lighting and audio-visual brings everything to life. Especially suitable for any members of your party who have trouble visualising what ruins might once have looked like, or people new to archaeological excavation exhibits.Tip: Put your camera away, no photos or video allowed, but just accept that this is part of the magic that they're trying to weave you into - cameras would ruin that. You wouldn't have time anyway, it's a relatively fast-paced 90 minutes, with no dawdling. You are moved through as a group with a guide.

Unmissable. Don't miss this when you're in Rome. Book your tour as they take tours by language and so have specific. The tour takes you below ground level to the excavations of the original building built on the site. You walk on a thick glass floor and the commentary in your language is set for each area. You are escorted from room to room. What happens is you can see what's left and with lights they show you the outline of the complete room and then fill in the missing bits to give a complete picture of how it was originally. Brilliant.

Absolutely fantastic- Go there !. This amazing underground museum has to be one of the most fascinating places I have visited in the last 20 years of travelling.its not really advertised in tourist books and guides yet, it's not been going very long.You have to book your slot in the language you want. There were 3 English sessions on the day went.Each session only has 16 people so it becomes a wonderfully personal experience.We walked right past the building initially as we didn't realise that it is part of the town hall, the Pallazzo Valentina.the tour lasts 90 minutes. Prepare to be amazed.

more than five stars, the perfect way to visit all these excavations for those who are not superspecialists. In this beautiful palace the past is relived with the aid of every technique our world knows, from augmented reality to storytelling, so that one never gets bored longer than a few minutes.
Domus visit. Fantastic look at life of a well-to-do family in ancient Rome. One of our favorite Rome attractions.

Amazing historic experience. This place was unlike anything we had been in. The home sits on top of history so to speak and the tour takes you down under street level to see the layers of Roman life as it was. The tour takes you over thick glass floors from which you can look down and see the original tiles, Roman baths, walls. Spot lights light up various focal points while a canned narration takes place in flawless English through speakers. The tour guide merely escorts you from one room to the next. Because you are walking on glass over things perhaps 10 feet under it, in the semi-dark it is a weird feeling and if you fear heights this tour probably isn't for you. It took some getting used to for me.To begin the tour you will have to wait in the courtyard until the appointed time which we were told was two minutes before the start. There is nowhere to sit. There is a little cafe next door so buy some ice cream and sit on their chairs. There is also a restroom beyond that.

If you'll be in Rome, you have to be there.. Once you will be there, you'll be able to move to the old days of great Rome. You'll get a great history lesson given quite differently than in the traditional museum. It is really worth to be there, great professionally prepared "show".

Wonderful Blend of Ancient and High Tech!. Imagine the ruins of an ancient domus discovered underground. (Seriously, much of Ancient Rome IS underground....still) Then imagine it come to life before your eyes! The colors, the atmosphere, the feel of traveling back in time. It's all here. And for EU 10 each, the best bargain in Rome! The whole city should have exhibits like this one. Multi media presentations throughout leave one stunned upon leaving.....Leaves you wanting to go back again --just to experience what it was like to live in such a place. Well done!!

Great experience. Nice to see such an interesting historical siteMost of the site is under a glass protected walkway but what's neat is the reconstructions of the ruins done with projected light show: so you see what remains of early roman house and then a virtual reconstruction happens in each room so you can see how the place could have looked when occupied. Be sure to Reserve your tour time for the language that you speak as the presentation is automated: one negative was that a live tour guide ushers you from room to room and does not give you time to linger in any one place one the particular presentation is done ( there is also a museum area with artifacts found at the site but you don't get much time to view these either ( they of course. Give you lots of time in gift shop)

Fabulous tour of Roman ruins!. This is a palazzo that was built upon Roman ruins. The excavation that was done to reveal the ancient ruins used modern technology. The tour allows you to walk on a glass floor looking down into the restored ruins. Also, 3D technology is used to create images of what the villa looked like so many years ago. A spectacular tour.

Excellent and interesting tour.. This is the first time we saw this palace but it was terrific. Very interesting tour and guide had many details to explain each part of the site. The lucite floors and the way that the ruins were displayed was excellent. A little hard to find the building since it was housed with some other building. Tip is to buy tickets in advance and to get there early so you ensure you'll find it. We got there very early and were able to be included in an earlier tour as space was available.
Great experience. You walk on glass floor and below you is a 4th BC palace! With the multi media effects you can really feel like you are a princess from the 4th century, walking in your palace...

Do this first. This tour will really help anyone visiting other a Roman sites visualise what they may have looked like in their heyday. We found it engrossing and entertaining once we had got used to walking on a plexiglass floor (don't do it if you have bad vertigo). We have been to Rome dozens of times and this is our favourite tour so far. We thought it was easy to find, directly opposite the wax museum. A bonus is the snack bar for the government staff where we got two coffees for only 1.50. When you' em finished here cross the road to Galleria Colonna. Another stunning site.

Don't miss this fantastic attraction!!. This Excavated Roman Villa was probably the highlight of our stay in Rome. Not only did we see the ruins of a villa of a very prosperous Roman Family, but the presentation of the site was excellently done. Because of the computer generated effects used, we were able to see how the Villa would have actually looked at the time. We came away with a much better understanding of life in ancient times. Not to be missed, the archeologists have done an amazing job here.

Peeking into Living History. Only a small amount of people can fit into the tours of this museum, so make a reservation well ahead. The museum tour takes the viewers through the ruins of an opulent townhouse, whose features are brought to life with projections and other media tools. The marriage of ancient and modern works very well. There is also a film about the Trajan Column at the end of the tour.Note: the staff are surprisingly not that fluent with English. We made our ticket reservations and made sure about the correct time both in English and in Italian – we were careful to do so, as there seemed to be problems with the orders of a couple of previous visitors. Still somehow they managed to book us to a different tour. Happily there was not a problem, but it ruined my mood a bit, as it was perhaps made to look like our fault. So when you receive your ticket, remember to check that the time matches the one you ordered.

Never Seen Anything Like This. This was our third time to Rome so I was looking for something else to do and found this museum. I wouldn't say this should be on the top of your list with so many sights to see in Rome, but if you've been to Rome before and are looking for something else to do this is an excellent museum/archaeological site. You stand on glass floors looking in to three different remains of homes from the first, second and third century. It's amazing to see how well they have been preserved and with the use of digital technology they fill in the missing pieces to give you a realistic look at how the homes looked thousands of years ago.

Absolutely fascinating. If it wasn't for tripadvisor I would have missed this one..and that would have been a big shame. Other contributors had warned of the essential pre-booking which i was very grateful for. I made my booking and I thoroughly enjoyed every minute of our tour. I have never been to another exhibition so well executed, it was a treat for the senses. I was definitely a MUST DO for me! My only regret there are no photographs allowed to be taken.

One of a kind Tour!!. I've been to so many museums and archaelogical sites through my travels and this has been my absolute favorite tour. They really really bring their story to life using lights, sounds, and lasers and this is one of the only places that really helps the visitor envision what life may have been like at the time of the site. If you only do ONE thing in Rome, I promise you, you should go here. You will NOT be disappointed.

Domus Romane very well done. We hadn't made reservations for the Domus Romane before leaving for Rome, but we stopped in around 1:00 p.m. and got reservations for later that afternoon. I'm so glad we made time for the Domus Romane. It was fascinating. Through modern technology the ancient Roman home comes to us in all its glory. It is a very well thought out attraction and I'll be going back one day to see it again.

Realistic Intro to an archaelogical site. Palazzo Valentini tour exposed the excavations with a multi media projection - showing what we can see and what we should imagine - going back to the times of glory. You walk over hardened glass - and see the excavations below. Initial steps were nervous but we became comfortable. The guide was great in explaining the parts of the palace - heating techniques / sauna/ swimming pool including the baby pool, grandness of halls and decorations in Marble...Dont miss. All of us loved it. The tour ended with the explanation of Trajans column and view. This is very close to the Piazza Venezia, just around the corner, and close to Colosseo/Fora. We did book ahead before the trip. Covered by Roma pass - but we didnt use Roma Pass.
love this place. wonderful museum with great historical facts presented. Required to visit. impossible to make photos

Don't miss it!. We just spent 12 days in Rome. On the way back to our hotel one night, I noticed the sign advertising this site outside of Palazzo Valentini. I was curious and inquired inside. It was quite late and my fiancée's feet rebelled at another 90 minutes doing anything. Our subsequent days were full and it was only on our last day, in mid-afternoon, that I inquired again. We had only one option: 6:30 p.m. that night; she was mightily reluctant but I had looked up Tripadvisor and reassured her. Five minutes into the tour, she was won over and at tour's end pronounced it one of the best sites in Rome and the best introduction to the ancient city. What made it so compelling? It is the extent of the archeology, the stunning and remarkable finds, the scintillating presentation, the excellent audio, and the impressive use of lighting and modern imaging techniques to transform the various rooms into a picture of life 2,000 years ago. We have travelled a fair bit and cannot think of another site anywhere that combines archeology and technology in such a dramatic, cogent, and educational form. We both wished that we had seen it on our first day! It should not be missed. My only cavil - the ticket staff and guide accompanying the audio-visual tour seemed bored to the point of indifference. And, incidentally, they take about a maximum of 20 on the tours so it is comfortable without any crowding or rushing.
Don't miss it!. Virtual recreations of this 3rd century Roman home makes the past vivid! Do it!!! Small groups are walked through subterranean spaces as the archaeology is explained.

Made ruins come alive. My husband & I visited here near the end of our Rome vacation & we really wished we would have done it earlier on. I think other ruin sites would have made more sense if we had seen this first. The tour is excellently done with lights, lasers, and commentary so you know exactly what you are seeing. I would say this is a must do in Rome!

Well Worth the Time. This attraction is a bit hard to find, but well worth the effort. This is the best archeological experience we've ever had. The arrangement of glassed over digs appearing below you as you go through this ancient luxury home is breathtaking. Rather than a schmaltzy presentation, you feel that the archeologists are showing you their reconstructions in a most professional way. The size and quality of this place is astounding. Don't miss this one.

Hidden Rome, away from the crowds. This was a fascinating find. You must book in advance, you cannot get a ticket at the door! The tours are limited to small groups due to the small rooms. This intimate tour of a Roman villa buried under Palazzo Valentini is very special. Lighting effects allow you to experience the villa as it was originally. There's also a special photo opportunity at the end of the tour....but you'll have to go on the tour to find that out. I would not recommend this tour for small children.

worth seeking out. This place is a little difficult to find and get in to. It is inside a courtyard with a security guard at the entrance, so looks like a government office or official building.You have to get on a tour for your language - we arrived at 10.00 am and got on a tour at 16.00 that day - prebooking over the internet seemed complicated by the language issue, so we did not do that. The gap between making the booking and the time of our tour was not a problem as it is easy to get to and near lots of other attractions nearby.The experience takes 90 minutes, and is fully guided, so you can not do this in a spare half hour!Having got over these hurdles... is it worth it... Absolutely!What you get is a really well concieved light and sound show that takes the reasonably substantial remains beneath your feet and brings them to life by guiding you through what is there and recreating what is missing. There is a lot to it - several times we thought we were getting to the end and found ourselves in another section of the maze of rooms.I would say this is not for very young kids - the commentary is a bit wordy and you do need to understand what is being said to get the full effect. Otherwise a must do.

Make sure that this is at the top of your list of things to do. We went with our 2 teenaged boys. We all really enjoyed the experience. It brought ancient roman times to life and was easy to understand.

A must see.. The domus was recommended by our B&B and was one of highlights of our time in Rome. You need to book in advance for a timed small group tour in your language. The Palazzo Valentini is now the HQ ot the province of Rome, and you need to go through the entrance into the courtyard to find the domus ticket desk through a door on the left. There are toilets and a cafe in the courtyard.The tour takes just over an hour and there are other reviews which go into some detail about the content. I would just emphasise how well it brings to life the way an affluent Roman family lived in ancient Rome. From one of the windows in the basement there is wonderful view of Trajan's column, and at the end of the tour a short film describing the carvings and the story of his campaigns. It adds an historical context to the domestic life of the family of the house, as well as providing a welcome sit down.A lot of the tour is in semi darkness and on glass floors so be prepared to tread gingerly at first until you get used to the sensation. It is a welcome change to the crowds at a lot of tourist sites in Rome and it was the attraction we most liked on our visit. With the other pre-booked tour of the coliseum which included the underground section and the top tier, it gave a real impression of life in Rome and the amazing achievements of the Romans. Don't miss it.

Brilliant once you get over the grumpy staff. Le Domus Romane is extremely well done. From reading their own website and Tripadvisor reports, we weren't entirely sure what to expect. There is a medieval house built on the ruins of a grand Roman house which has been excavated (leaving the house above intact). There is a quite a bit of archaeology to see, including parts of the baths, but the clever bit is the way they use special visual effects to recreate how the underground ruins might have looked in their heyday. The tour is pre-recorded and explains the site very well. At the end there is a very good movie which explains Trajan's Column very well. All in all the tour takes 90 minutes. One comment - we wondered why the staff were so different from normal tour guides - the reason - they are employed by the state - so not career guides - and for what-ever reason are off-hand (border-line rude) with visitors and definitely grumpy. At €13.50 each we (4 of us) reckoned it was good value for money.

Great exhibit. I found this in Trip Advisor attractions and I'm happy I did!We were looking for something different and this filled the bill. It is a beautifully designed multi media exhibit that was incredibly informative. Highly recommended!
Great way to learn and visualize ancient Rome. It is a bit corny, but definitely cool to watch the ruins come to life through projections. And you learn so much with a cool show. Definitely worth it.

Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini. Wow! Not to be missed! Excellent multimedia experience that captivates the imagination. Highlight of our trip to Rome. Group is small so probably recommended to book tickets in advance in your choice of language. Booked mine online and then just picked mine up at the door just before the show.

WOW!!. Loved this experience so much- words won't do it justice, just go and do it. Trust me. I have to write 50 words here, so I'm really just typing in the rest of this to satisfy the requirement, but seriously, if I wasn't writing this at 2am I would go into more detail- it's honestly great though. :)

Superb and not to be missed. This was an exceptionally well presented English tour underneath the Palazzo Valentini, paring away centuries and layers of Roman history to display the spectacular remains of a wealthy Roman villa of enormous dimensions. The 3D used to clarify and extrapolate allows the visitor to appreciate what this stunning villa would have looked like. This was one of the most impressive ancient sites and absolutely worth the visit. It is located just near Piazza Venezia, so is easy to find. We pre-booked over the internet.

Well worth a visit. This is definitely worth the visit. Takes about 1 hour but very interesting. You get to see how the wealthy Romans lived, life included underfloor heating, and indoor swimming pools with a kids paddling pool attached...kind of like an Ancient Rome "Cribs" trip. Great insight into the how advanced they really were, 2000 years ago

Ancient History meets 3D Special Effects Technology - Extraordinary. Whilst Rome is steeped in history Domus Romane is unique in the way that it makes the Ancient History of Rome so accessible to those that aren't so scholarly inclined (not to mean that it isn't also fascinating for those that are very scholarly inclined). The site is the archaeological remains of an ancient Roman Villa situated beneath the (relatively) more modern Palazzo Valentini. Discovered by archaeologists in 2007, it only opened to the public about three years ago after significant work by a team of art historians, archaeologists and architects. Sophisticated computer aided design tools and light shows (and voiceover commentary) bring to light how the Villa looked 2000 years ago. Because a Renaissance Palazzo was built over the top of the Roman Villa in the 16th Century, the ancient Roman Villa is well preserved. You can still see mosaics, inlaid marble floors and other treasures. You gradually progress through a series of rooms over the course of one hour. You walk over clear plate glass and the villa is beneath you. It is hard to describe how much the effects bring the history to life here. At first I was thinking that it was a little too "Disney" for such a historical discovery but throughout the course of the walk through the project I became convinced at how wonderful it was to see such a coordinated effort to bring the history of Rome to life so effectively. Because you are situated right beside Trajan's column, there is a fascinating movie at the end of the viewing outlining the story of the column, including an explanation of all the art work on the column and the history behind it. Some might find it a bit long, particularly if you arrive here after walking all day (and you are on your feet for an hour here during the sound and light show). You do get to sit down for the feature about Trajan's column though. Entry is 12 Euro for adults. There are only limited tours in English and because they only allow groups of limited numbers in at a time, you must book tickets in advance to get in at a pre-booked time session. We had about 15 in our group. You can book tickets directly on their website (www.palazzovalentini.it) but it is in Italian. I found it easier to book through Select Italy, an online company in Chicago we have used many times for all our Italian museum and theatre bookings. They only release the tickets about one month in advance though. Closed on Tuesdays. There were a number of kids in our group and they seemed to really appreciate the experience (they were between 10 -13). If you are thinking of bringing very young children please be aware that the rooms are very dark during some of the lighting shows and it takes at least one hour on your feet. When trying to locate the entrance, don't look for a sign to Domus Romane because you won't find it. Whilst you are viewing the Ancient Domus Romane, the site entrance you need to look for on the street is the 16th Century Palazzo Valentini which is not far from Piazza Venenzia and also right near Trajan's Column. I found this to be a highlight on this trip to Rome.

Amazing. A must see! Nice to go early in your trip as it is so informative! Me and my family were impressed and so was my 15 year old nephew! You can really picture Roma as it once was after this... And makes you wander to what else is hiding underneath the streets you walk today! Love the history of this place.

The best thing to see in Rome. This was mine and my girlfriends favourite thing to see in Rome.You have to book tickets before hand,just as a quick warning. But it was incredible seeing all the remains of the house, it even explained about Trojans column situated outside the venue.With the use of projectors it managed to set the scene and complete parts lost due to damage and really make you feel as if you were sat in the times.You will not regret this experience!!!!

MUST DO!. I have lived in rome for a few years now and only just discovered this? No idea why I hadnt heard of it earlier. If you are coming to rome! Put this on your to-do list! A great way to experience old rome, and see it be brought back to life in front of your eyes, using lights, lasers and sound effects. You can really get an understanding of how it must have been. So many of the things you see in rome, I find hard to imagine what it was really like, but this does it for you. I found this to be one of the most interesting things I have done here!

A Fascinating look into the past. Located near the Colosseum and the Roman Forum. The walk down the glass steps in the beginning is unnerving but ok after they dim the lights. Recommended by our Italian relatives because I don't know that I would have found it. It was discovered less than 10 years ago and according to the relatives they are still excavating. I was told there was a bunker in the front during WWII. Rome is a city that kept building each city on top of the other. When visiting the Roman Forum one has to imagine what is looked like. Here it is reconstructed through projected computer images. I agree lecture at the end is long but it is still informative. It is a great experience for teenagers as it will inspire them to appreciate history. One of the best stops in Rome. Not sure about wheelchair access.

If you miss this you missed best Rome has to offer. Probably the most captivating attraction in Rome by far, the best way in which history and culture of Rome can be explained and summarised without even one second of loosing concentration. Never seen anything like this when you stand on glass piece above such priceless archeological site.

A must see. This was one of the best exhibits in Rome. It allows one to see the actual ruins from a variety of perspectives. The 3D overlay makes each room more real. A must see if planning on visiting other ruins.

Great visit. We highly recommend this tour , ancient history is brought back to life. After we saw the Coliseum and the Dungeons it has been worth to to visit the Roman houses . If you come to Rome do not miss them!

Fantastic insight into whats under Rome!. We were planning our time in rome and saw this on trip advisor, the reviews were all very good and it looked really interesting. Alot of the reviews seem to be from familys, but we were a couple on a tour full of adults, it is definately suitable for all ages!I was a little worried at the lack of pictures, but they ask that you dont take pictures on the tour, this is understandable when you are there.We chose the english speaking tour, it was a good size group of just 12 i think, This made everything very personable.The whole tour was great, very well executed, they provide you with some really interesting insight into the ruins, and the projections/interactive element brings everything to life!We highly recommend you do this when visiting Rome!

Nice multimedia experience. NIce multimedia visualization in support to the visit of the ancient palace in the basement of the contemporary Palazzo Valentini.Both the kid and the young adult daughter enjoyed the visit a lot, it's a good way to experience history.

Be aware if you have mobility difficulties. I travelled to this attraction in September with my two sons.The eldest has mobility problems and uses crutches to get around.As far as I can see on the attraction website, there is nowhere that states the attraction is not suitable for those with disabilities.In fact it gives free admission to those with disabilities.The reason it,s not suitable is that there are two flights of stairs to get down before the tour even starts.There are other stairs/steps as well throughout the tour.Also, I wasn't,t aware that the whole "show" apart from the film at the end, is done standing.This proved very difficult for my son as there were no chairs to rest for a few minutes.If a wheelchair is used, there is no way at all you will be able to access the attraction, unless there is a secret lift that nobody offered to us or told us about despite them seeing my son struggle.The attraction itself- well, to be honest I found much better attractions in Rome, the Collosseum beats this hands down, you can also see lots of similar Roman remains at most museums in the UK so I wasn't particularly impressed by it.The technology used was ok.I thought the best bit was the film, simply as it told the story of the Trajun column, you can then go around the back of the building and see the real thing.All in all, think twice about visiting if you have mobility problems and don't consider at all if you rely on a wheelchair.I could spend two hours better at other attractions in Rome.Would be ok if it was raining.

Excellent. Don't pass it up.. If you are at all interested in the archaeological history of this amazing city, don't miss this. It is a presentation of an amazing find that is unlike any other. Be aware that it is quite long and involves walking in dark areas on glass floors. This may be an issue for some people.My only complaint, though, is that the guide we had was, well, kind of rude. She seemed bored and in a hurry. My think is that she really does not like her job.

Amazing way to envision an ancient Roman home!. This tour of a newly uncovered (2005) Roman domus is excellent in the way they use modern technology to recreate the house along with the ruins. My only complaint was the film at the end which covered Trajan's column was a little too long and anticlimactic after the tour of the house. Otherwise, if you are interested in ancient Rome, I highly recommend it.

4d illusion, but too crowded. Our guide suggested us to see this attraction, and my nephew was very excited at the end of the visit. You have the chance to see a couple of ancient roman houses rebuilt with the help of the technology, with a show of lights and sound.It would be a 5 stars attraction, but the question is that the rooms are too small for 15 people all together. Sometimes breathing is difficult too. 12 would be the right number.

A must not miss!. We found this gem through its website and booked a guided tour before we went to Rome. It is truly a wonderful place to visit, brought to life with genuine remains beneath your feet, while you walk on a glass floor, together with video and 3D imagery and laser work that really bring the whole place alive. A wonderful way to spend 2 hours!!

Educational but fun. Really interesting interpretation of life as a wealthy Roman in ancient times using archeological materials and modern technology to bring it to life. Like "Time Team" to the power of 10! It is slightly disconcerting walking over the glass floors protecting the ancient finds particularly in the dark but the soundtrack is informative and lively once you get over the fact that the commentator for the English version sounds like Comic Book Guy from the Simpsons. Good value for the 90 minutes and well worth going. I learned a lot. It is also beautifully cool after a morning spent walking through Rome.

Ancient Rome in a time machine. Oh this is such an excellent place to visit. It's only been open a couple of years. Even if you aren't that into ancient Rome and piles of bricks and columns etc this is a terrific visit - 2 Imperial palazzi have been restored, and you walk through these accopanied by the most interesting and innovative 3D son et lumiere - crowd scenes, what would've been outside the windows in ancient times, lightshows that throw up pictures onto the walls so you can see what it all would have looked like way back when .. . It only takes an hour and you have to book - but do so. If you go in the afternoon a neat thing to do is go on down to the Coliseum and do an evening underground tour there too. The palazzo is a cool thing to do and it isn't the least bit theme parky. It's ultra clever and uber-smart use of technology to inform and delight and create.

A must see!. We heard about this attraction through trip advisor and we were completely thrilled after visiting this site. We are a family of four and our two teenagers enjoyed the two and a half hour virtual tour that kept us entertained and more importantly allowed us to see a part of history that was unearthed in 2006. The archeological site held five centuries of information and it is a MUST see. We highly recommend this tour which can be booked online prior to your arrival in Rome. This tour may not be suitable for younger children because it is packed with information that they may absorb. We will definitely re-vist this attraction on our next trip to Rome.

Engaging and fascinating. We had three days in Rome with our kids - 13 & 10 - and this was a great two hours away from the hustle, bustle and heat. You are transported, with great effect, into a Roman House with a clever combination of genuine remains and 3D imagery. We were completely engaged throughout the whole tour. It is important to reserve your tour place beforehand to avoid disappointment.

Perfect for people with no knowledge of archaeology . It's an amazing experience to visit this place. Everything is perfectly explained, and lights and sounds make you get a clear idea of what life in ancient Rome would be like, for a wealthy family. In that sense, it's much better than a regular archaeology museum, because sometimes it's difficult to imagine the whole historical context if you're only staring at a column. So don't miss this experience. It's also great for kids.
Best museum in Rome. We brought our 11 year old girls and they found the ruins fascinating. This is a must-see attraction in Rome.

If you do one thing, do this. Wow. This this the best underground roman museum (and there are a few). It really gave an amazing understanding of the ruins we were standing it. The use if light and reproductions were brilliant. If you find yourself wandering around these ruins think "what the heck is that? Another small wall?" this is the place for you. If you have a short time in Rome, or even longer, make sure this is in your itinerary. BUT make sure you book in advance.

Not as good as expected.... We do not agree with all the high recommendations for Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini. After making reservations by phone, we were told to arrive early. We did and were able to purchase our tickets right away, but there was no good place to wait for the tour to begin. They instructed us to go outside in the rain. Looking for a dry place to sit down, we found some covered stairs but were soon chased away. Once again we were standing outside in the rain! It was not the Roman hospitality that we expected.It was interesting to see the ruins with the projections of how they once looked, but at times it was confusing. While standing in one place, they showed us a variety of projections without a clear explanation; and sometimes it was difficult to know whether we were looking at a projection or what was really there. At the end they showed a video about Trajan's Column. It was interesting at first but much too long and detailed. The concept for this tour is wonderful, but they need to make improvements.

Makes Archaeology and ruins fun for everyone. I booked this tour for myself and my family after reading about it on TripAdvisor and I must say it was much better than I expected. The tour was limited to about 15 people so it was quite intimate.With the use special lighting, lasers and projections the true feeling of the ruins are brought to life in a way I have never experienced before. I was very impressed.As a trained Archaeologist I am often dragging my family to ruins where ever we go. This was one of the few times that I could see the same sense if excitement in the eyes of my children that I always have. As an added bonus there was a film and explanation of the story depicted on Trajan's Column (which stands right behind Palazzo Valentini)Bravo Pallo Valentini for a really fabulous and memorable experience.

Very informative tour. I saw this on Trip Advisor, and thought it sounded interesting. Fortunately, I wasn't let down. It's very educational. They basically preserved an archeological site (a Villa belonging to an obviously wealthy owner. A senator perhaps.) under glass floors so you get a unique perspective of life in ancient Rome. Some of the walls and floors are in remarkable shape. They also use computer images to model what they think it may have looked like. It's amazing to think that back then they had running water, heated baths and floors, etc. Of course, this was someone of incredible means, but still...We also got a glimpse of an enormous ancient column and some history behind Trajan's column. If you have time and have seen the major sites, this is a nice tour to fit in.

A great and unexpected find. Didnt know about this until found it on tripadvisor. Really brought ancient Rome to life through creative combination of actual archaeological remains and sophisticated lighting and sound effects. Really two attractions in one - the villa itself and then a detailed explanation of trajan's column.Perhaps a little long at 90 mins, even then at times we were being rushed through when we could have lingered. Booking was easy for us though other reviewers have complained - even though website showed fully booked for the day we turned up in person at 2pm and were able to buy tickets for a 4pm English language tour not actually listed online.Well worth the experience - for our kids anyway it was more fun than wandering around the foro, comparable to the colliseum.Looks like they could make more of it,not least the gift shop which is rudimentary.

A Peep Into The Past. This is a unique attraction in Rome. It literally illuminates the lives and society of ancient Rome. Walking on a glass floor is eerie and scary at first but then you are so engrossed in the narration that you almost forget.Its not for those with mobility issues since you descend two floors of steps. Also its very important to book in advance for the language of your choice since numbers are very limited in each tour.I would specially recommend this tour for families with children over 7-8 years of age. it is a wonderful mix of history, archaeology, sociology and multimedia!

Most Effective Way to Learn about Ancient Rome Housing. We ordered our 1:30 pm guided tour tickets at 11:00 am for 28 euro (1 adult + 2 teens) at the reception desk. Maximum 15 visitors can join the 90 minutes tour. The first half of the tour consists of walking over different areas in- and outside an Ancient Rome Family House. The methods used to let you observe and to inform you are very effective: a narrator voice, glass floors, lighting, laser projections, sounds: all perfectly organized and synchronized to get a very good understanding of how (wealthy) families lived in the Ancient Rome and how their houses (incl. baths, sauna, ...) were constructed.The second half of the tour consists of a detailed explanation of Trajan's Column where you can sit down and watch a large screen. Very interesting and at times amusing stories.Highly recommended.

A step back in time, with a difference.. This tour takes you underground to stand over the very house that once stood there in Ancient Rome. You walk on glass floors and the lighting, computer aided visuals and lasers bring to life what was once there. There is even sound to give you a real feel of what it was like to be in this grand house, with swimming pool, sauna, library, great rooms, etc. Most educational and in a clever way. Hard to believe you are in the very centre of Rome itself with the traffic and tourists outside when you are down here doing this archaeological experience. Well worth it, especially if you are a history buff.

Do not miss it.. The hotel concierge told us about this place or we would have probably not gone or allocated time from other major spots. We would have missed so much. I understand this is one of the latest excavations so the tour is fresh and new. The forum did not give us the idea of life in Ancient Rome as this place did. Loved it!
Dont Miss in Rome. Absolutely different then any other mueasum ever seen, If you miss this you will always regret. Wonderful projection with laser lights and awesome reconstruction of old times.
Step back in Time. Other than the collesium, this was our next favourite place to visit, brilliantly recreated with lights and glass floors, and very interesting historic commentary.

Very well done, informative, but probably too much for younger children. Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini is a gem of an attraction, definitely worth the entry fee. Like the city itself, the site has multiple layers of historical significance (ancient, medieval, and contemporary), each of which is to some extent explored in the presentation and guide. It wasn't discovered until 2006 when digging began for a parking lot, so the site is still very much a work in progress in terms of excavation, and the ticket price is no doubt subsidizing some of that. The multimedia overlay (aural and visual) vivify the the ruins, and, as others point out here, help the untrained person appreciate what to look for when exploring other ruins. I did not find the effects Disney-esque and instead found them informative (that is--effects weren't primarily for show; they're trying to help visitors access a related experience). In my haste to prepare our itinerary, I somehow missed the fact that the tour includes extensive information about the Trajan Column, and, indeed, after you finish with the palace, you move to an area for another full presentation on this other marvel, and then you get to look at the column from its base giving you a perspective no other tourist is able to have. I visited with my very smart but impatient 10 year old son. He really enjoyed the palace tour and was attentive throughout (though the British-hybrid accent was sometimes difficult for him to understand--it is pre-recorded), and that part was just the right length for him. The Trajan Column presentation happened in what was "overtime" for his attention span, and frankly, I similarly found it hard to take in much more information at that point. That's unfortunate, because the concept of the Trajan Column presentation, which is not as sophisticated or creative as the palace presentation, is a good one--it tries to teach visitors how to read the story of the column and to imagine the motivations for creating it and what its significance might have been for its earliest visitors. It takes a little advance planning to work this into a busy schedule, but it is worth it. There are very few available seats for each tour and only a few English tours each day. Reserve in advance, and enjoy.
Excellent experience . Organized and clean, relaxing and enlighting, not tiring and easy to reach. Maybe overrated but still great!!! Go and enjoy.
totally unexpected. Very clever idea of using CG to enhance the imagination to visualise what ancient Rome was like. Wonderfully done
Extremely well presented - what a find!. Excellent experience discovering how people used to live in Rome. Impressive use of technology to re-create the houses.

Absolutely brilliant, do not miss!. Ruins discovered as part of Le Domus Romane Palazzo Velentini. Fortuitous discovery supported by excellent timeline story and video. I have seen Rome before but hadn't seen this and was most happy I did, the family loved it. The tour provided an insight into what life may have been like in ancient times. Ensure you pre book in your preferred language or you will struggle to get in. These are guided tours and only a small limited number can be included in each group (you'll see why when you attend) with sessions lasting 90 mins.
Not to miss. A fabuoluse journey through history. Order guided visits online, and preferably weeks before your visit. It will be worth it.

Something Different. Well this was a fantastic experience. Your children will love it too. It is all about how Roman nobility lived with the aid of interactive displays. To say more would give the game away.Make sure you book on line or you will not get in.

Do NOT Miss. Ruins discovered beneath Municipal Offices in Rome...gives one a sense of life in Ancient Rome. But be sure to book tickets in advance (can be done online) as the site is always sold out.
one of the best things in rome!!!. if you really want to understand how aancient romans lived :) go and visit this wonderful ancient roman villa with his interactive spots!!! is incredible!!!

Think before you go. If you have an archeological, historical, or engineering interest, parts of this will be of interest to you. Otherwise, it's 90 minutes that goes on forever. If you have small children, don't. If you are a larger group, costly. At about 14 euros, I didn't mind. But I would have been choked to pay for a family of four. Some interesting stuff, but a lot of assumptions in what they're telling you (a number of times, the guide said "this was probably...". Some of it was difficult to see. A great explanation of the tower, a while ago now, I think Trajans Tower. And the staff? A bunch of used car salesman. Go a minute early. A young woman asked to use the bathroom first, and they said no. They're on a clock.

Museum was great- Tour guide was AWFUL.. Let me start the review by saying the museum itself is fantastic, however the supposedly English speaking guide was the worst guide ever. We went on our last day in Rome (made reservations for 6 online- carefully noting the English speaking tour). A TripAdvisor Reviewer had warned the people at the museum were not friendly or helpful so we expected this. We arrived a few minutes early- there were 12 of us on tour and all were completely excited about visiting this museum. What we weren't prepared for was our English speaking guide could only moan "this way..." and clearly could not speak English. She would not allow for ANYONE to look at the items on display that had been mentioned in the prerecorded tour. She rushed past display after display... full of fascinating artifacts! All 12 of us wanted to stop and inspect- but were rudely scolded in Italian if we didn't proceed at her very hurried pace. This happened more than once! Everyone on the tour was thinking surely we will get to go back and see the displays after the tour. When she marched us past the giftshop, we were certain we would get to come back by. What tourist site doesn't want you to spend money in the shop?? Not this one or maybe not this guide. The poor excuse for a guide could have completely ruined the tour- however, what has been excavated here is well beyond her rudeness or lack of interest in her job. The museum truly is remarkable. It's worth going, but be warned about the guides. Because of this, I have to rank as poor.

Wonderful multi media experience. I enjoyed this attraction so much that a took a friend there on my next visit. It is certainly a 21 Century approach to Ancient Rome and really bought everything to life. Unlike other significant attractions in Rome, which were public building, this is a private villa and shows the life of a wealthy family in colour and movement. Loved it.

Ancient Roman life. We visited Le Domus Romane and thoroughly enjoyed the 2 hour tour. If this is one of your first trips to Rome then definitely I would focus on the big sights and save this for another time. The tour is sheds light on ancient Roman life as it reconstructs the ruins of an old palace using lights and computer generated images. Reservations are a must and can be done online. Short video at end of tour explaining Trajan column interesting.

So Interesting. We used our Roma pass and paid 8 euros. The problem was to book I had to phone Rome. However it was worth doing as the house is fasinating and as we were going to Pompeii the next day it helped us understand Pompeii better.

Fasicinating glimpse of ancient Roman home. We visited this unusual museum because it was so highly rated in Trip Advisor, and we weren't disappointed. It was a fascinating look at the ruins of an ancient Roman home that were buried beneath a Renaissance villa. The tour shed light on daily life in ancient Rome, as well as the techniques the archeologists used to discern this. While I may not rate it quite as highly as others (it was #3 out of 8000 attractions), it is well worth a visit. And after all the BIG sites of Rome (St. Peter's, Colosseum, etc.), it was nice to have a glimpse into something small and get more of a view of how ancient Romans lived.

Not a top 3 attraction but worth a stop if time. This was a neat experience but I would not rank it in the top 3 things to do in Rome (go to the colosseum and Vatican first!). The tour is about 1.5 hours and it goes through the ruins of an old palace using lights and computer generated images to show reconstruction. The best part for me was the 10-15 minute video explaining the depictions on the colonna traiana at the end of the tour. Staff were not overly friendly but the tour itself is a voice recording, they just lead you from room to room. You do need to book in advance but I was able to do so the night before without trouble!

The ruins explained. I traveled to Rome with my 10 year old son and 7 year old daughter and we all really enjoyed this experience. Beautiful explanations of the archaeological remains and a great place to get out of the summer heat.
Unmissable. Very well organised, enlightening virtual tour. Much better than a normal guide. It should be better advertised.

Brought the Roman ruins to life . We visited here off the back of the great reviews on TripAdvisor. You must book in advance for this attraction and ensure you know how to get there before booking. The best way is to find it first and book at the entrance. The tour combines lighting effects and the Roman ruins to paint a really vivid image of how they used to look. After visiting the Roman Forum and Pompei, this museum really helped to complete the picture of Roman life. Excellent.

Really enjoyed this tour. There were several things we liked about this tour. Being able to walk above the ruins was a neat experience but seeing the projections of what it would have looked like intact and with it's original painted walls and decorations was a chance to step back in time and really get a sense of what living there was like. Having looked at a lot of ruins, for me they really came to life here. And it is inside and cool. The film on Trajan was also quite interesting and gave us a chance to sit down and enjoy.

Roman ruins in a new light. This was my last stop on my 2 day trip to Rome. The glass floors, projections, History-like commentary and virtual reconstruction made the 'Domus' come alive and truly stimulates your imagination as to what life was like back then. For anyone who wants a new and engaging way to interact with the beautiful ruins of Rome, I highly recommend this tour. The breakdown of the story behind the magnificent Tragan column at the end was also a really enjoyable part of the overall experience.It's a real shame not enough people know about this cool place, but I'm sure the rave reviews on TripAdvisor are certainly helping to change that!I would suggest going slightly earlier in the day to not only find the place, which is hidden away one of the corners of a courtyard once you enter an official looking building, but also to book a ticket for a tour (different languages have different time slots) to avoid disappointment as they warned that tours were strictly limited to 15 people max.

One of my favorite tours in Rome. This tour was absolutely amazing. The staff and the guide were not the friendliest people in the world, but it hardly mattered. These ruins we saw were so well preserved, and the house was so large with so many different rooms, it was incredible. They use lights, sounds, animations, and voice overs to explain what you are seeing in thorough detail. It was easy to imagine what it looked like thousands of years ago. A must see.

Good for history and archaeology fans. We were a little surprised this is the #3 attraction for Rome. I think you shouldn't miss it if you're really into (Roman) archaeology and history -- and if you're not already totally exhausted from walking and standing on your feet. As it was, the best thing about it for us was getting out of the sun for a couple hours in the middle of the day. But even later that day, someone we met at another museum recommended this exhibit to us, so clearly it has a great deal of appeal for another audience.You do need reservations in advance, and be sure to buy the right time slot for your language.

Ruins explained!. This museum was very inovative in the way they presented the ruins and explained what was there and also around it. I wish others would do this, as sometimes it is not easy to imagine how the place would have looked back in the day!We also enjoyed the second part of the visit, with the Trajan Column explained, it was a great story, very informative and interesting.We were glad we did this visit, and are totally recommending it. We did not book in advance, as I was a bit lost by the web site asking for a 'Financial code'(?), but we went to the Palazzo Valentini anyway and they had tickets for the next tour, when the web site said they didn't.So if you don't find tickets online, it seems that they are keeping a small amount of tickets to sell at the entrance, it's worthwhile to check if you're in the area.

Ruins brought to life. I was never able to make much sense of ruins. A visit to the Palazzo Valentini changed this. Thanks to the multi media show you can really imagine what happened under this palazzo at Roman times. A great museum for kids and everybody else.

A must when in Rome. This was a very pleasant experience. I must say that for my two teens this was the highlight of their trip to Rome. For those like me who can't easily imagine the original place from ruins, here you won't find any problem at all. With the help of modern technology, the ruins in each room are transformed in what the place used to be. The commentary was so in detailed that one could easily be transported in that era!!!

Worthwhile visit. We visited this exhibit after reading Tripadvisor reviews, and were really pleased we did.The exhibit is an interactive experience, showcasing the remains of a Roman house. It is slightly Disney-esque, but this is easy to forgive as the beauty of the house comes to life.Rome is a wonderful city, but especially after the Roman Forum, it can be hard to visualise exactly what the city looked like. This exhibit helps those of us who struggle with visualisation to imagine how it looked.It's best to book in advance, and check out exactly where it is, as it is slightly strangely situated, just behind Trajan's Column. The only drawback is the staff could have been friendlier and a little more helpful, but I would certainly recommend a visit.

Amazing attraction, but not #3. this is a very interesting way to visualize how a rich families mansion looked in Roman times. Using modern technology to complete the ruins a unique perspective is given. Additionally at the end of the tour their is a documentary and a view of Trajan's Column. Not suited for very young kids. Overall, Highly recommended, but shouldn't make the top 5 sites in Rome

EXCELLENT!. I loved it and my 8 year old loved it - what else is there to say - we will go back.It was extremely interesting and educational in that they have skillfully digitally recreated the house and you walk on glass over the ruins- a definite highlight of our trip !!! Be warned though you need to book several weeks in advance - as the groups are very small and there are only a few English sessions per day. Also leave extra time to find it - hidden in the middle of civic buildings. A definite must in Rome!!!

Brings ruins to life!. Decided to visit on basis of other Trip Advisor reviews - and weren't disappointed! Even the two teenage girls in our family group stayed interested throughout the tour. You could actually imagine life in Roman times as the recorded commentary perfectly complimented the lighting 'projections' on the floor & walls, and because you were only in a small group you never felt the pressure of the crowds at other archeological sites. We had pre-booked and I would suggest this is probably essential as people were being turned away on the door. Definitely not to be missed!

Staff could be more friendlier, however, the exhibition was fantastic.. Very well presented with latest 3D recreation technology for the ruins. The place was too dark for little children (maybe not recommended), my kids found it interesting (age 14,12 and 10).Learned about Trajan's Column in detail which was a bit long.Nevertheless, we recommend to go as it was interesting and educational and best of all it's all in the air-conditioned area.
Roman Ruins Come to Life!. I always wonder what the ruins looked like in all of their splendor and full glory...at Domus Romane you don't have to wonder. Just make sure you book your tour in English!

The best archeological presentation I have ever seen. This presentation was one of the highlights of our trip. Yes, it is a little Disney-esque but, especially with teens, it truly brings Roman ruins to life. I have no idea why this place appears in no guidebooks at all, but it really should be considered a must see in Rome.

The best interpreted archaeological site in Rome, and quite possibly anywhere. Having studied Roman Archeaology at University, I have always been disappointed by how many sites leave TOO much to the imagination, preventing people from fully appreciating an archaeological site. This is particularly true about many sites in Rome and Italy (e.g. sadly, even the forum.)Palazzo Valentine is an AMAZING exception. It is a perfect example of how EVERY archaeological site should be present to the public (if the resources were available.) Through the use of lighting, video, reconstructions, etc. they walk the visitors through ever aspect of the remains of a few amazing houses and their context to the adjacent Forum of Trajan. It enables visitors to clear see how an archaeologist interprets a site and reconstructs what the ancient buildings must have looked like. Whether a curious novice, or a professional archaeologist, this tour was an ABSOLUTE TREAT. To quote my friend who visited with us: "They don't charge enough." I would encourage visitors to go here FIRST, and then to the forum, and elsewhere.If only some of the more significant archaeological sites in Rome had half this much effort in interpretation! p.s. The staff was also very helpful and considerate to my wife, who felt ill partly through the tour.

A real surprise. When we arrived, my family were sure that I had got the wrong place! I heard mutterings about 'it's just Government offices' and 'what are all the police here for?' It was the right place but unfortunately we hadn't booked in advance so had to tag along onto a French tour. As all the narration is digital along with the visual display, we did not get as much out of it as we would have done if it had been in English. But the visuals were good and from what I understood from school girl french from 30 something years ago, I learned a lot! Very interesting and I would like to return and enjoy the English tour.

Informative visit- great for teens. You do need to book ahead and make sure you get the correct language group. The reception is not especially helpful or friendly.The tour guide takes you from room to room and then pushes a button for the presentation to begin. The guide had probably done it hundreds of times and it showed on his face!Our group of one adult, 11,13 & 17 year old found this highly informative and engaging.The only negative is the presentation is a bit over the top & 'Disney' at times.The darkness and loud special effects may be too much for very young children ( under 5).

Fantastic surprise!. This tour was recommended to us by relatives in Rome and it was by far the best experience on this trip. It was fascinating to learn about the archaeological findings and explanation of life in Ancient Rome. We also learned about the story behind Trajan's column. Multimedia experience, calm pace, small groups, incredible journey back in time. Bravo!!

Archealogical tour. They only take small groups and the tour each tour is language-specific. It is a well-presented depiction of Roman life when Rome was still in power. The dig has uncovered a Roman bath and an adjacent villa. It takes about 1.5 hours and is moderately priced.Much of the tour is in very dim light. Good sense of balance recommended. Not a good venue for children.

Not to be missed!. This is an amazing exhibit. Everyone in my group enjoyed this experience. After spending 4 hours with a guide exploring the Colosseum, the forum and the Palatine Hill, this multimedia experience really put the ruins into perspective. Wow! Ages 12 - 56 loved this. I received unsolicited thanks for booking this tour.

A multimedia historical experience. Le Domus Romane was a great, multimedia experience. Although you visit it as a guided group, it is a much more personal experience than most historical sites. Group size is limited and is language specific, so you need to book online well in advance to get the date you want. The audio and lighting are well-coordinated- it reminded me of a very good Disney attraction. Tour lasts about 90 minutes, and much of it is fairly dark. Probably not great for younger children, but it could be fascinating for older ones

Completely different from any other museum!. In this museum, you stay as a group and move through Roman ruins with a recorded audio track and a computer/light show that really brings the ruins to life. The tour shows you what the rooms would have looked like in their day by projecting images. For me, the highlight was the video that showed sections of Trajan's column and explained the story that the spiral column told. It kept my almost-ten year old son's interest throughout. You move from room to room. Our guide acted like he did not want to be there, but his job is just moving us from room to room for the presentation.You are walking on a clear floor for much of the tour -- that was hard to do at first. It helps if you don't look down when you are walking.This was a great museum to see. Very unique presentation. It runs about 2 hours.

Le Domus Romane. Would absolutley make the time to visit this museum while in Roman. It was truly different from any other experience on our trip. Everyone in our group ages 50-19 loved it. Be sure to go!

One of the best attractions. We really didn't know what to expect. A mixture of museum, archeology and multi-media in one. It gave us the opportunity to see how people lived in Ancient Rome through the use of a glass floor and a light show. We loved it! Highly interesting! Because places are limited, I would suggest booking the tickets online.

Do not miss!!!. I read about this place on Trip Advisor but was not really sure what it was. I decided to give it a try and was really surprised. It was one of the best things that we did. It is really hard to explain, but you walk underground and see ruins from Rome that have been excavated. Okay, that really does not explain how this exhibits works. You walk on glass the whole time and underneath you, you can see the ruins. Now that might sounds boring, but it is NOT. The whole thing is narrated (make sure to get reservation in advance an in English-only about 15 people at a time and there is only certain times in English) and very interesting in that lights will appear on the parts that the narrator is talking about. Amazing and air conditioned, which was a plus. I highly recommend coming here.

Absolutely must see!. Located only steps away from Trajan's Column, this museum displays one of the most unbelievable exhibits we have ever seen. The Domus Romane was discovered beneath a government building, along with centuries of history set out in front of you to explore. From a technical standpoint, this museum sets a new standard in achievement, as you are actually shown projected images of what things used to be like in the ancient times blended with the real setting where they were. As if the Roman house were not enough, the visitor can see relics from the middle ages as well and compare life as the different layers of history are peeled back in front of your eyes. Perhaps the most important discovery is shown at the last of the tour - a section of a column recently uncovered that may well be the largest ever found and thought to be a possible relic of the lost Trajan Temple.If you are visiting Rome for the first time or even the 10th time, you must see this amazing exhibit!

Interesting multimedia presentation. Having been in Rome a few times, we were looking for something different. Domus Romane certainly fit the bill! It is a fascinating excavation which has been turned into an audio-visual feat, giving you a virtual view of what ancient Roman life was like. There are tours in many languages so be sure to book your ticket for English, French or Italian online before you go. One caveat: You actually walk on glass flooring right over the site, which could, if one is squeamish, be disconcerting. I hung onto my husband!

It Should be on your list, when visiting Rome. Completely different experience from any other museum. It was extremely enjoyable and gives you a rare insight on how life in Rome was so long long long ago! If I knew what I know now, I would skip the Vatican tour and go there, but that's just me. We booked it in advance. They have different language tours at different times, so check the website for that info. The groups, I beleive, are limited to 10 or 12 people( may be less) because of the space issue.The museum is located inside the courtyard of some oficial building with the guard standing outside at the gates. There is a sign for the museum, but you can easily miss it, if you are looking for a "museum". So climb those few steps and go inside courtyard and it will be on your left. The tour is about 2-2.5 hrs, packed with information, which I found absolutely fascinating.
Very interesting but all in Italian. Ruins and presentation were very interesting but without a private guide it would be hard to follow. Its all in Italian

Fascinating Trip into the Past. When visiting Rome you are immediately feel the history in the city, but it can be quite overwhelming and I found myself inundated with information. This tour is very informative and does a fantastic job laying out the history of some of the ruins in the city, and it does this in a very engaging and entertaining way. The tour itself is of an excavation site of a Roman Domus (or house) and uses visuals (lights, lasers) to bring the excavations back to life. You are standing for the first part of the tour, so comfortable shoes are recommended. Also, I highly recommend booking this tour online as it does get sold out very quickly, as there is limited spots for each tour.

Fabulous concept. Good use of lights and sound to deliver a historic escavation of the past. Do book online. Pricey but good. Get a good map or download directions as we searched around quite a bit. Teenage kids lost their attention after 20 min - there is a lot of narration and one should be really interested in archeo ,history and escavation. No photography permitted. A very novel idea!!

Fabulous use of lights to reconstruct the past. Helped inform our other tours of ancient ruins. Good small group size. although the guides English was difficult to understand he was very knowledgable and eager to explain everything.

Really worth making a visit.. Really informative and interesting tour. Its great that the tours are limited spaces after the hustle of the city streets - lets everyone see everything. The tour guide doesn't say much, its mostly pre recorded but all the visuals and the ruins themselves are amazing. We booked online in advance. We did find it a bit difficult to locate as the building itself doesnt look like a typcial tourist destination and there was nothing to say that you need to walk through to the courtyard - had to log in to tripadvisor reviews to find out!

Captivating. I had read some reviews online regarding the Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini and thought I'd give it a go. I booked the tour online. It was better than what I had expected. The tour is of excavations of a Roman Domus. It's very intriguing and with the use of special effects and lighting the Domus comes to life. The tour is very explanatory on Trajan's reign and you get to see a close up view of Trajan's column.This is not possible without the tour. The tour is worth it just for this. I would definitely recommend this tour. Informative for the time spent.

A unique view of ancient Rome. I wasn't expecting the full-on virtual nature of the tour, but it was fascinating. The floors are glass, so you can see the ruins of the Roman house on all sides of you. The guides do little except move you into the right area of the room (the tours, which are available in different languages at different times, are fully automated--there is a recorded track and spotlighting of/projection onto specific areas is timed out.) Seeing the mosaic floors in situ, as well as the Roman road; wondering what is beneath the immoveable walls of the current structure--it made for a romantic experience. As a former student of archaeology, I freaked right out when presented with the remains of a massive column from what had to be Trajan's temple. I had no idea why this Trajan's column stuff was coming in, all of a sudden, but there was a nice little surprise at the end that explained it. The odd bit is that you go through the gift shop in the middle of the tour, between the Domus and the Trajan part, and it seems like they let you move on when somebody cracks and buys something. It's a totally passive experience, which was wonderful after a full day of actively touring about and looking at maps, but that's the best way to schedule it. It's great for kids, as well--I highly recommend it. The story arc is pretty compelling.

Not so special. We made a special effort to get to this because of the glowing reviews on TripAdvisor. My family was fairly disappointed. It was interesting, but not nearly as interesting as all of the other things we saw in Rome.

Unmissable attraction in Rome. First time I have visited the Domus Romane and I am recommending them to everyone. They have opened just a few years ago after the recent excavations have unveiled this jewel of the Roman times, just near the Fori Imperiali. Compared to other attractions you can visit in Italy, these Domus are extremely well explained thanks to the use of technology. The visit is amazing but you have to book your ticket in advance. Highly recommended!
Totally unique. Use of technology to enhance the tour was excellent, we wish more tours in rome were set up this way. Don't miss this one.

The best attraction in Rome. As mentioned by other TA readers, it is a bit difficult to get ticket as there limited space in the attraction. We went there early morning and where lucky to get tickets for the afternoon tour. It is important to attend a guided tour where there is an language that you understand, as there is a lot of excellent information during the tour. It is amassing to see how technology combined with the excavations gives you a completely different perspective. If you at all get the chance to see this, then it is a must see

The place, where you can feel the connection with time. Thanks to Tripadvisor we booked this tour and didn't regret about it. The tour is very spectacular and glass floor creates very special experience. The most valuable for me was the feeling of the connection of the different generations in Rome. It was incredible to understand that at this place, where I walked, thousands years ago lived, loved, enjoyed people.
A look at the past. Fascinating archaeological find and they have done a wonderful job of bringing the time period to life.....computer graphics were fantastic. This is a must-see in Rome.

Just Amazing!. Please dont miss this amazingly curated excavation of an ancient Roman home. You walk on glass floors over the ruins, and you really see how Rome was built on top of a well preserved ancient city

Fantastic tour. This is one of the best tours in Rome. We looked online and it was completely booked in English, so we went to the museum and no problem we were able to do a tour. It's and hour and a half walking tour over glass covered ruins. You have a guide but they do not explain the rooms. That is done by taped information and videos. Excellent. I highly recommend it and it is very reasonably priced.

Couldn't get a reservation. Don't expect to walk to the location and have helpful people assist you with a reservation or to help you call their reservation line, you are on your own. We never got a reservation as all the English tours sold out well in advance (we tried to book a Wednesday on a Tuesday. The next available was for Sunday) and the call center said it would not be worth it unless you could understand the tour. That being said, if you speak French or Italian they had same day or next day space available. Wish we could have gone so book in advance and don't make the same mistake we did!

Unusual Archeoligical Exhibit- Don't Miss. An excellent informative exhibit of a recent excavation. Brilliantly displayed & organized. The typical tourist will miss this. Just when you think you've seen enough...the exhibition has laid glass on top of the ruins. You walk on the glass from darken room to darken room looking down at the ruins while a voice informs & lights & graphics highlight the different aspects of this recently discover Domus -house. Timed entry, English or Italian. Small groups. No large crowds. Catch the 4:30pm entry after spending the morning & mid day at the Colosseum & Roman Forman. A wonderful surprise. Excellent & Outstanding Exhibit.

Great site, really bad staff. Beware! We booked online in advance and somehow my husband booked the Italian tour by accident. Once we got to the site early, the woman at the desk checking people in made no comment even though it was clear we spoke no Italian. We waited and when the tour guide arrived, she tried to tell the woman at the desk that this was a problem but the woman didn't care and would not do anything for us. We went on the tour but have absolutely no idea if the actual tour guide was any good. What I can say is that the Domus is worth seeing. It is somewhat crowded and if you have problems with traversing uneven floors in the dark (the floors are transparent too) you will have problems with this tour. Everything that's most interesting is below you as you are walking through the Domus.

stunning! stunning!. The Genius of Man - the Romans who built this 4th century villa - recenlty uncoverd and explored, and the modern day archaeologists and multi media creators who have made it into a fabulous visit and learnning experience. You MUST book beforehand - either go there, or else do it online.A unique visit

Wonderful..prebook though!. A team of art historians, archaeologists and architects have uncovered and 'brought to life' these archaeological excavations of a couple of 'well to do' ancient Roman homes They are beneath the Palazzo Valentini, and wonderful to see. The mosaics are beautiful. They use light and 3D to show how these residences would have looked back in the day. You walk above the ruins on a plexiglass floor(which takes a few minutes to get used to). Tours are small in size and the guides are knowledgeable, although most information is coming from sound systems. Very, very interesting. Book online from home, then pick up your tickets a few minutes ahead at the Provincia di Roma complex on Via IV Novembre, which is where the tour is.

Well Worth The Time. Great tour. Really got the feel of how the wealthy ancient Romans lived. The plexi glass floor was a little intimidating and you had a feeling if you stepped off the supports you'd fall thru. Tour group is relatively small, so you have an opportunity to ask questions.

Walking through history. The place may not be that crowded like the other places in the country but what makes it difficult to access is the fact that the tour is conducted in seven different languages and various set of time so if you need to be at the right time and with the right language slot then the tickets had to pre booked and also to avoid a rude front desk altogether. Nevertheless no matter how hard you have to make it to the place, it is totally worth the experience. It is not your usual museum but an amazing walk through the ruins of an actual roman house from old times set In the underground of Domus Romane. The tour is actually like an aerial view of an ancient house while walking through the glass floors. I did had to get accustomed to walking on this glass with comfort and not losing focus. The display and visual guides are amazing and you get to live the roman era out of the pages of the history books.

Impressive interactive tour. On our Top 10 memorable sights in Rome. The multimedia presentation of the history of the Roman House and the civilization at the time are outstanding. The computer controlled projections and audio-visual effects recreating how the home and opulent surroundings looked thousands of years ago are breathtaking. The ruins and artifacts are extremely interesting, and the close up private view of Trajan's Column was a real treat. Highly recommended tour -- you must make reservations!

PREBOOK !. Great idea and fascinating and one of the best things we saw in Rome - proper insight into the past. Definitely need to prebook - won't go into too much detail so not to spoil the surprise but for 12 Euro's, extremely good value for money. GO!

One of the best attraction in Rome!. This is truly a must see attraction! There is a glass floor on top of what used to be the a roman house. You will walk through the house and while you go through it, they will show projections that will allow you to see how wealthy romans used to live!Book you tickets online!

Don't miss this while in Rome. This was amazing. To see the mosaic floors in such good condition and they uncovered a huge column. You look down on all these rooms. It takes a while to get use to walking on the glass floor. It's very dark during parts of the tour. They project on the walls how the villa might of looked. Very educational! Book in advance. They take you in small groups.
