Nice visual presentation. Really enjoyed the presentation, the down side is one must plan and book in advance because it is given in different languages at different times, but otherwise very informative, good visuals - definitely recommended

Interesting Site. The Palazzo Valentini is a very interesting archaeological site located under the Provincia di Roma complex on Via IV Novembre in Rome. It was fascinating to see the amount of space in the ancient home that was devoted to fitness and exercise. Buy your tickets online before you leave the US for your preferred time and language.

A Must See!. I'm so glad that we went on this tour! Essentially it's an underground tour of ancient Roman houses. They use technology to augment the experience. I've never seen anything like it before and this was one of the best things that I saw in Rome! I read that you need to book online well in advance and you should probably do the same. It's really cheap (approx 10-12 Euros per person) and the tour groups are really small => no crowds. It's short too, approx 1.5 hours.Don't miss this!

A must see!. We saw this on tripadvisor and we glad we saw it! This side was not mentioned in our guidebooks!All the good things said about Domus Romane is true! It is a walk through ancient time and after your visit you can imagine how it was in ancient time.We visited it with our children (age 9 and 11). Be aware that the tours are only in Italian, French or English. The English you hear is very fast (It was a challenge to translate this for our children) but even if you cannot translate everything, your visit is very worthfull because of all the things they let you see with the modern techniques.During the period we were in Rome it was very busy and the tour was sold out during the day we went. We were glad we had made an online booking. If you book online then at the end you can choose how you would like to receive your tickets. The 'Pick-up at the Venue Box Office' option is free of charge and means you can pick up your tickets at the entrance of Domus Romane.Be aware that the entrance is on the courtyard (so not the first office you see while entering this Palazzo). On the courtyard there are toilets.The tour lasts 1 1/2 hour.Price adults: 11,50 euroPrice children: 9,50 (6-25 years)Booking online: 1,50 euro extra per ticket

unpleasant personnel. I had really looked forward to seeing the Domus Romane but we were told at the entrance that we Had to go with a tour and No, they didn't sell reserved tickets there. For reserved tickets we had to go 'someplace' else in the city. They Might be able to squeeze us into an English tour that day. We were very surprised at the brusqueness of the people at the desk as everyone else had been so pleasant and helpful. It may be a wonderful site but is not set up for people to easily visit it and the staff's customer service attitude definitely needs to be reviewed.
Best museum experience. I recommend this museum to everyone. Best use of light, music and visuals. A total museum experience

Book in advance to avoid disappointment. Book in advance to avoid disappointment.
We popped in when we were passing and bought our tickets.
Roma card got discount.
Good experience a very well managed attraction.
Have recommended to all friends visiting rome since

Very Well Presented. I booked a few days ahead via Internet. This is essential because only a limited number of people are allowed on each tour.I found the place very easily, it's opposite the wax museum, in the municipal building. Look for the flags, and there is a huge poster outside! Enter the building and the entrance is on the left. Tip: If you are early, don't sit on the round tub in the entrance. It may look like a seat but you will get told off for sitting there, because it's an artifact from bygone days.Inside you walk above the villa on glass, often in low light levels. This is somewhat disconcerting but you get used to it.. As you tour the villa, the audio visual presentation is wonderful. This is surely the most complete Roman villa that I have seen.. Your tour ends with a short video about Trajans Column., and you get to see it close up, albeit through a grating. The whole tour takes abut 90 minutes, with a break of a few minutes. If you are interested in Roman history, this is a must. It may not have much appeal for children though.

Not to be missed ancient Rome. I visited this 'museum' 2 weeks ago while on vacation, that was recommended to me by my landlady. She insisted I go and called to make a reservation for me which is the first thing I suggest you do, as they can only let so many people in at a time and of course there are only 8 hours its open.What an incredible surprise this was, I cant thank Natalia enough for telling me about this.Your tour takes you below street level (where much of ancient Rome is) to an excavated area that has revealed a grand house, baths, and courtyard from the time of Emperors Hadrian and Trajan. the tour takes you through a series of rooms with clear floors through which to see the ruins, a recording explains the room you are in, what was found and what the room may have looked like, then slowly to pleasant music, video laser type technology build the room around and below you to what it would have looked like in its day, truly amazing. The tour takes about and hour and a half or so and gives excellent info and stories. I'll not say too much more so that you have the pleasure of the experience yourself. I am a history fanatic and the older the better for me so this was wonderful. If you are in Rome for a few days and enjoy this also go to Basilica of St Clement as there are underground ruins you can tour there also, its only 5 euro and you get to descend into the 1st century of the original buildings, more rooms are still being discovered and much of ancient Rome remains buried for future generations to discover, your imagination will run wild, enjoy!

A different museum-experience!. Don't miss this interesting museum when in Rome. This is how a museum should be like. Unfortunately the max amount of visitors at a time (15) is far to much. We missed out on a lot of interesting info when people stood in the way. Try to stand as close as possible to the guide at all times is my tip. Book in advance!

Great view of ancient Rome. A real gem of a tour. The very high tech tour showed how an ancient Roman family lived. It was a great way to see how people lived a LONG time ago! Really fun and instructive.

Okay experience. This attraction has amazing TripAdvisor reviews so I booked the tickets months in advance and paid more for the shipping than for the tickets themselves! From this I was really expecting something breathtaking.The attraction is easy to find- just find the Trajan column and walk alongside the building directly in front- you will see a wax museum on the other side of the road in front of you- the entrance is opposite to this. There is a large sign for the attraction outside the doors. Through the doors is a small square with the attraction entrance on the left, the next left contains public toilets.This tour was okay- you enter and stand on glass flooring with ancient ruins below. There is not much to see- but a recorded voice explains the ruins with the help of lights. This tour includes a fair bit of walking in the dark as the guide does not turn the narration (and therefore lights) on until everyone is in place. The narration is mostly speculation as there are many uncertainties presented by these ruins.Halfway through the tour you are taken into a giftshop which was a bit awkward as no one appeared very interested in purchasing anything. There was a substantial kid's section, and a fair amount of books to purchase.Nothing is added to this tour by being led along by a guide- this site would be as effective if people were just allowed to walk around by themselves. It is for this reason that I am hesitant to recommend this attraction to anyone who is not deeply interested in Ancient Roman house ruins- but has little specialised knowledge. The narrator's comments were largely simple observations- whereas I longed for a real insight into the context, desires and mysteries behind the construction of the building. This tour lasted around 1.5 hours- the first and last 10 minutes were best.#There is no water or refreshments available at this attaction. One of the tour group members had to leave the attraction and miss out on some of the tour to get water.

Best kept secret. This is an amazing site, a preserved Roman house that uses state of the art digital technology to recreate the space. The tour ends with a presentation on the Column of Trajan that is also excellent, and the museum presents additional archaeological finds almost as soon as they occur.

A must-see in Rome. An amazing and innovative archeology interpretation, unlike anything else in Rome. Pass up the Forum, impossible to interpret, in favor of this. Reservations absolutely required, and there are several guided tours in English each day (depending in season). Reserve via the web site which has all up to date info. An exclusive opportunity to see Roman life you cannot get anywhere else.

Amazing Eperience. What a great way to experience and see how a real domus from the first century looked. Fun and exciting multi media recreations. Great for the kids. Interesting facts about Trajan's conquest and column. A fun and way to learn. Highly recommend it.
do not miss it. if you have to visit just one place in rome this is it. a wonderful trip in ancient rome with the help of technology(do not miss it) p.s. you have to book in advance

Goosebumps from the back of my neck down to my toes. I actually felt myself having goosebumps running down the bacck of my neck to my toes. Never before has that happened to me. #1 says it all doesnt it.

Forget the Colosseum- go here instead.. After 11 visits to Rome I can confidently say this is the best sight they have. Simply amazing to behold. The film afterwards about Hadrien's column can (and should) be skipped as it takes away from the wonderful experience you have just had.

Worth seeing. Other than Turkey there are not many sites to see how the Romans lived. Privileged Romans no doubt. But here is their homes and their lives to see. You have to book to see it and it is a guided tour using new generation techniques of audio and video to highlight what you are witnessing.

The ancient meets the new age. This tour was great. I am not going to describe what's happening because I think the element of surprise should be present when the door is opened and you enter the site. The tour is very informative and cool. Our family consisted of me and my husband in our late 40s, our daughter age 25, and our 14 year old son. Every one of us was fascinated with the presentation. It ends with the story of Trajan Column - very interesting. The tour is not very long - about 1.5 hrs,, more standing than walking, definitely not for little kids. Just do it!

Must do. This was by far the best tour we did in Rome, the location is very easy to find (entrance in on main st via municipal building and has a huge sign with the site name on it). Do book in advance and enjoy a bit of time travel courtesy of archaeology and technology. Loved the explanation of Trajans column.... Cannot recommend highly enough

incredible. I visited for the first time 3 years ago. My cousin who lives in Rome took us. It is absolutely breathtaking. It gives you a real feeling of being there. Be sure you book yourself on the english tour and be ready to step back into roman history.

Highlight of trip. This was so interesting. It mixes archeology with projections and animation and allows you to really picture life in those times. My girlfriend who is less into tech and history than me also enjoyed it and considered it one of the best things we did

This site is not to be missed.. We learned about this fascinating archaeological site after we arrived in Rome. None of our travel guides had mentioned it. You need a reservation, and you need to book your visit at least a week in advance. Not only is the entire tour amazing, but there is a surprise at the end.

Hard to find, not tourist-friendly AT ALL. My friend and I got this sight recommended by our host and we couldn't find it that day at all! It is not signposted and you would never guess that it is inside that official palace building (opposite the wax museum). So we passed it several times and finally gave up. The next time I came to Rome, I found it, but I was told in an annoyed voice that there was only one tour in Italian and one in English offered. They seem to offer very few tours only. What I didn't know in the first place was that you can't visit the place without that guided tour. Information is so poor, you really feel left alone. And the two guys at the 'reception desk' were anything but friendly or helpful. Why being friendly to tourists, they can't resist flooding to Rome anyway!

Good attraction, interesting. Rude Staff. We didn't realise you had to book onto a tour, so when we got there in the afternoon the next available tour wasn't until 5pm so we bought a ticket and came back. Id definitely book online before.The tour is very interesting, it was very strange to walk on glass over a Roman house at first but once you're used to it its ok. The tour uses lights and image projection to walk you through the house, the attention to detail is fantastic and its very good for children. The only downside is the staff. Unfortunately, the staff on the reception are rude and the guy who was showing us round was very rude, and was on his phone constantly. when going into another part of the house he would shout 'move' 'come on' 'over here' you could just tell he just didn't want to be there. He really let it down.

Ancient Rome up close and personal. Only giving this a 4 as we could not get on an English speaking tour. But this was our fault for not booking before we left home. We took the tour in Italian. You walk on glass over a Roman house. Dont let the glass put you off you soon forget. Amazing how complete it is and interactive displays bring even further to life. Good for children of all ages. Dont miss this.

Very interesting trip.. A very interesting tour that came to life with the technology. A large area of excavation that is clearly explained, giving a fascinating insight into Roman dwellings. Highly recommended.

Highly recommend! Visit before you go to Roman Forum.. My teenage daughter and I visited this site and both enjoyed it immensely. The extent of the excavation under this office building is incredible! The tour walks you through the ancient home of a wealthy Roman, using lights and projection images to help you focus on particulars and visual what this home would have looked and felt like in ancient Rome. We learned much about life in ancient Rome and seeing this early in our trip helped when we were standing in the middle of the Roman Forum trying to imagine it in its heyday. We also enjoyed the extensive info on the Emperor Trajan/Trajan's column at the end. Our tour was a tad bit crowded, making viewing a little awkward at times but otherwise it was excellent. Not to be missed.

Exciting look into an ancient everyday life. I visited this place 2 years ago for the first time. Now, I took there my friends who had not been there before, and I found it exciting just as the first time. Highly recommended.Olga

Most interesting site in Rome. You would never expect to find a roman villa underneath this Palazzo. Guided tours (only) take you through this magnificent site, which, coupled with many little films and realistic video recurring reconstructions give you a unique idea what a stunning roman villa looked like. Highly recommended!

Tour ancient roman house overlaid with digital recreations helps visualize how it once appeared. Great tour of the remains of roman house, with digital and light show helping you visualize the ruins as they once appeared. Terrific effects bring it to life. Small museum lets you see small artifacts. Great surprise ending! A nice afternoon. Highly recommended!

Magnificent and mysterious.. Magnificent and mysterious.Highly recommended!All those graphics will bring you back to the ancient Rome and give you a view how the people use to live on that time.And all those stories from Traian column!!!Can't wait to bring my family over there to see it.The tours should be pre-booked. There is no walking by yourself. Groups are not large so do the reservations in advance.

Very worth to visit!. I reserved tickets for this attraction following the recommendations of so many people here in TripAdvisor, and it was a great decision!Its a very complete visit to ancient Roma, you can see the ruins and the recreation of two roman houses or "domus", roman therms/baths and a part of a street, and an interpretation about the story present in the Trajan Column. The ruins are beautiful but just normal, but the recreation they do about the place by using the lights and sounds is awesome, and its very explanatory. At the beginning I thought the ticket was quite expensive, but when the visit ended I didn't think it any more! You have to reserve it by internet, and the webpage works perfectly. It was a little bit difficult to find the museum for us, because the indications are not very good, but just look for the Trajan Column and a kind of door that is placed around it, and that's a "window" of the Palazzo Valentini :) You have to enter through a courtyard, and with arriving there about 10-15 min before the visit it is enough.

You shouldnt leave rome without seeing it!. Amazing experience! One of the most interesting places we have been after a 4days trip in rome! You shouldnt miss it! We had the english guide at 1630. We did not manage to call them to book, so we just dropped by and got tickets for the same day.

Very interesting exhibit. This exhibit was a great insight into how the wealthy Romans lived, and used lighting and projection to reinforce the story. Really informative and inspiring!Bare in mind, this is a guided tour, so you have to book either online or at the place earlier in the day.

History come to life.. This is a most interesting experience. You no longer have to imagine how things were or might have been in a Roman house just from the remains that were found. The missing pieces are projected onto walls & floors etc and along with the commentary it gives an excellent insight into Roman life. Highly recommended.

Best museum in Rome. It is as wonderful as everyone has already said. My only criticism is that it is so badly run. The two women who stand at the entrance desk are the most sour faced people I have met. There are only 2 English tours a day. We therefore asked to join a French tour and although I understood very little the light display communicated enough for me to be suitably impressed. It also made me understand the significance of the practically unexplained collums outside the house.

particularly interesting. I was in this church the first time I came to Rome with friends. The goal was not planned, and was the result of a metro-wandering. Unexpected interiors, really interesting especially the aisles and the rich mosaics.

Highly recommended tour. It is a 1.30 hours underground tour. The use of multimedia to tell the story is very clever and make the tour very interesting. A lot of the ruins were in amazing conditions and it was almost like you actually went back in time to the ancient Rome. The story of Trajan column at the end was also very interesting. Highly recommend everyone to go visit.

Really great, original.. We found it by tripadvisor, because it isn't mentioned in our travelguides. One of a kind. With light and film they make a real Roman house come alive, also the story of the column of Traianus come to life. Reservation needed, only 14 people in our group.

special site, giving you a good idea how the old Rome could have been. This is a grat place to get an impression, how the old rome might hve been, how bulidings look in the past, what happend to them and how parts of old building were reused for building new ones. Very good implementation of electronical visualization techniques to complement missing parts of the finds to give you the whole view.
Must see. This is the experience that Rome has lacked, historical and educational yet captivating and exciting. You will not be dissappointed

It deserves its place as number 1. Prior reservation required!. First of all don't forget to book your visit in advance, one or two weeks prior to your visit. Visit palazzovalentini.it or call +39 06 32810, the tour in English is at 13:30. They'll give you a number and ask of you to arrive 30 minutes prior to your booking. It's the building behind Trajan's column.Tip: If you buy the Roma card 34 euros at present times, you have 3 days of free transportation(A daily transportation ticket costs 6 euro per person) and the first 2 of the following museums for free:1)you skip the lines at the Coloseum and get in for free at the Coloseum and Roman Forum and Palatine Hill -12 euros normal price2)if you book ahead for the Galleria Borghese call the same number 11 euros normal ticket priceor 3)the Domus Romane 10 euros normal price.If you buy your tickets ahead online, you'll pay 2 extra Euros per person for each site.On the subject, I'm really passionate about ancient history and I read a lot, and I explain most of it to my wife, but after this multimedia experience, she said she finally understood what I was talking about all that time.It explains how a magistrate roman Villa is decorated, its outline, its content, its walls, water supply, its own private pool and bath and it shows you how it was supposed to be like in those ancient times, that plus a neighbouring house that is near the aforementioned one. You'll see the level of the road and housing in those days and see how the foundation of a Renaissance palace slices through a 100 meter roman mosaic.Great blend of technology and history, it highlights what it explains, go see it prior to visiting other sights, you'll see them with different eyes.I'm Romanian so as a bonus we got ourselves the explanation of Trajan's column as well and a multimedia representation of the layout and how Trajan's forum looked like in the glory days and in the same excavation sight they discovered columns twice as thick as those in the present day Pantheon. Imagine that prior to beeing Trajan's forum it was a hill as high as the present day column! Nota bene, What it doesn't say is that Trajan was the first provincial emperor, he was Spanish, Provincia Iberia and he had to be twice as competent as a Roman native to become emperor so his forum and first shopping Mall were dazzling it trumped in size the adiacent Caesar and Nerva Forums, and it was covered in Gold from the new acquired Dacia.Do yourself a favour and go chek it out.

Cool merger of history & technology. Unbelievably not in my guidebook, I booked this for my husband and myself based on the tripadvisor reviews. It is a cool sound and light show augmented by computer technology in the excavated remains of two Roman houses. Descend below a government office building in a renaissance palazzo and find mosaic floors, bed rooms, saunas, hot baths of a top-tier Roman family circa the third century whose lavish home looked out upon the Roman forum and Trajan's column. If you find yourself hard-pressed to conjure the Roman forum in all its splendor from a couple of lingering columns, come here. Let technology do the work, and suddenly the room you are standing in has resplendently painted walls; the fragmentary floor is a complete mosaic; the bathing pool sloshes with water. The segment on the column of Trajan gives a terrific account of his on-again-off-again battle against the Dacians. Highly recommend.

Awesome!!!. So interactive and instructive. Much more eloquent than just stones... You can really imagine how it was in the past. I think it's particularly interesting for children who can be a bit bored sometimes just watching old ruins... Lot's of explanation and it's in your language (French for me)You have to see it!

A must when you visit Rome but be sure to book it in English. We pre-booked it online prior to our visit. When we were about to start the tour the tour guide told us its going to be in Italian. Alright then but can you be helpful enough to move us to the english-speaking tour? Both the tour guide and receptionist said they we would need to pay again which was real inconsiderate. I mean the tour is about to start and were only given a minute of choice to pay again or be stuck in an italian tour- we decided to just go for it in a foreign language. Anyway good thing my partner knows abit of latin so we were able to understand a bit of it. The tour is wonderful. Its a ruin but you will be standing on a thick glass on top it. You get to appreciate it because they give you a visualisation of what it looks like during its time. Taking out the unhelpful staff experience, I think anyone visiting Rome should consider booking a tour and I recommend that you make sure you are booking it in english. No cameras allowed btw.

Excellent - dont miss it !!!!. Thank you all the travelers who reviewed this. Without it I would probably missed it.It is not visited by the hords of tourists but it is so educative and interesting. Unfortunately we are from Croatia. Tour was possible on one of the most spoken languages so didn't understand all like I would understand if it was on Croatian but it was enough to have the idea.Don't have to mention that my daughter was very impressed and asked if there was maybe another historical site explained in that way.Really good job they done.Bravo !!!!

Great for kids. Off the beaten tourist path, my three boys (14, 12, 10) said this was the highlight of our trip. It ties in with what they have learned about Roman life in Latin, History and RE at school. Book online as the tour numbers are limited. Booking can be slightly confusing but persevere.

Wonderful way to visualize ruins brought to life!. What a unique way to help visualize actual ruins found recently electronically assembled together into a lifelike building. All 6 of us truly enjoyed this experience.

One of the most informative historical sites ever!. It's amazing what happens when archaeology is combined with state of the art audiovisual technology! We were a bit skeptical about this site, having seen how audiovisual technology can be used to oversimplify and romanticize what ancient Rome must've been like. However, we were pleasantly surprised by the quality of the presentation and the historical accuracy of the descriptions. The tour was very informative yet entertaining. The designers of this exhibit did a terrific job making the archaeological findings accessible, both physically and intellectually. Highly recommended!

Most enlightening museum. After discovering this on trip advisor the first time, we were unable to visit while in Rome due to being booked! The second time we booked our tickets well in advanced, which was well worth it. It was extremely interesting how modern day technology can be used with ruins to create a virtual experience, while wandering around Rome it is hard to get the impression of what it once looked like, this museum certainly answered this question in regards to this very impressive house! Couldn't recommend it more, not so much for children though as its a strict itinerary and quite dark! For the price, you can't ask for more..

Wow - Somebody Finally Explained It!. For years I have been staring at the remnants of foundations of ancient buildings wondering what they must have looked like and the function the rooms played. In 1.5 hours, using existing archaeological digs and computer animation someone finally explained the mystery. You walk down under the existing ground level to the level of the ancient city of Rome where you visit a Villa (think rich people's house) that has been flattened. Through the use of computer generation this Villa is brought back to life with walls and ceilings recreated with computers while you stand in the middle of the room. Now for a few tips. Buy your ticket early - small groups only. It is dark and underground for you folks that might have the claustrophobia gene. Get close to the guide as the animated narrator does not allow sufficient time for the back of the group to enter the next chamber before the narration begins. There is little or no time for questions. I really don't think the guide could answer any complex question as the narration is pre-recorded. This may not be the best venue for children under age 9 or so - it just won't interest them and they have no place to go once the tour startes

The best archaeological exhibition in Rome - I think!. The site is very interesting with several houses, temple building and a private bath. The interactive models tells stories about the surrounding building of the Column of Trajan - something which was completely new to me and put the whole archaeological area in perspective. The visit starts in the private bath of the Roman house and continues - over as I must say, as you walk on a glass floor covering the ruins - several rooms into the dining room. "This is my favourite room", the guide whispered to me. And it is truly beautiful - with remains of marble decorations, mosaics and painting. The guide is not talking, he is only leading you through the rooms and starts the multimedia show. The show is impressive and informative - and makes it possible to recognise the structures more clearly. In the end there is a very nice film about Trajan's Column and you will be able to catch a glimpse of the column form Roman ground level - several meters under the modern street level.All in all the most exiting exhibition to seen if you are interested in Rome's history.

Book a tour in your language. A fantastic experience, but be wary if you are fazed by walking on glass above the floor. It's a great way to see the remains but some of our group missed the first part of the experience as they were still edging their way across the floor. Don't miss this if you love history. We booked before leaving uk and collected the tickets at the venue

Fascinating. This is a wonderful multi-media experience of some recently excavated ruins. There's under a government office building and it's necessary to book in advance. You can choose time with a presentation in English. You see some excellently preserved remains of a lavish villa. One note, much of the tour involves walking on plexi-glass floors to see what's under your feet. This might be a bit disturbing for those who suffer from vertigo.

Very good audio/video presentation. The Domus, a home for a Roman nobleman, was only excavated in the last decade under the 16th century building that now houses the Roman Municipal offices. The tours are limited to small groups, so reserve ahead on their website. What makes this tour so special is the use of computer projections onto the ruins below your feet ( or over your head) to fill in with light and color what you are looking at. Very interesting set of swimming pools/hot tubs. Some of the mosaic floors are intact, which is great to see. At the end, there is a very nice film that talks all about the battle for Dacia that is commemorated on Trajan's column just outside, decyphering the scenes on the column.

Ground-breaking archaelogical presentation. Other reviewers have described this very well. We booked in advance on-line from England, as they can only accommodate a small number of people on each tour and it is necessary to book for a tour in English. Very worthwhile and excellent value for money, must be government subsidised I think, as it is under government buildings. Very effective presentation making excellent use of modern special effects whilst still being very interesting and informative, quite a few "wow" moments, took about an hour and a half and ended with very good presentation about Trajan's column. Fab.

archaeologists using technology to explain. When digging an underground carpark under the provincial government building they found these remains, and someone has had the flair and insight to set up this multimedia experience to try to make sense of it all, succeeding brilliantly. Check on the website beforehand which tours are to be in your language, because obviously that is essential. You are also well-advised to book on the site. It is much better to be there with a small group, as inevitably you get in each other's way as you look through the glass floors, and strangers don't squeeze up together in the dark. As a way of explaining an archeological site this is really impressive. You get a genuine sense of the reality of ancient Roman life. At the end of the tour is a colossal broken column, which is presumed to be from the (lost) Temple of Trajan, and so they have a little video explaining Trajan's Column, which you then see from a door at the end of a passage, just to emphasise that the house really was at the centre of things.The entrance is on the left in the central courtyard of the palazzo, but the guard outside will direct you. There are lavatories in the courtyard.

Fantastic Experience. I am so glad we booked this. Through the lighting and multimedia effects, we were thrown back into living in an Ancient Rome Domus. I won't spoil it with more details but I highly recommend if you can afford 90mins to venture through this during your stay in Rome!

An archeological treasure. What a wonderful way to spend an hour and a half in the middle of "Ancient Rome". This multimedia visit to the ruins of a once glorious Roman home which was built over during the past many centuries is being uncovered painstakingly and presented in a most entertaining and comprehensible way. Much of the tour is prerecorded in beautiful English but a guide is there to direct you and answer questions at the end. Towards the end you are given a fascinating explanation of Trajans Column and then one looks outside and sees the actual column which has just been brought to life. One has a new appreciation of ancient Roman history after this presentation and for all the ruins lying right outside the door. A tip for those challenged by walking over glass floors: don't look down! There will be plenty of time to look down once you have stopped at the next point in the tour. Walk with your eyes straight ahead as if you were walking across a normal floor and it will be much easier.

Interesting. This is a new, and ever reoccurring, secret of Rome yet exposed. Don't go if you are acrophobic. Or rather I suspect that your doctor would rather that you did go. You walk over glass panels with history lit far beneath you. It is terrfifying. But you learn something. If you ever what to be again a child on a rolling coaster terrified as an adult I recommend this. It will not be a waste of your time.

Try to visit both the Domus Romane under Palazzo Valentini and the Case Romane del Celio.. As each tour fills up quickly, we reserved our tickets online well in advance. It's a very unique and interesting guided tour and we learned a lot not only about the city, but what every day life was like as well. There's also a very interesting video on Trajan's Column towards the end. We liked the unique and clever design of having us walk on glass floors with the ruins beneath us. Not only was the information in the tour interesting, but the use of lighting effects to guide us though each detail kept it captivating throughout.Ordering tickets was easy and the entrance is to the left of the inner courtyard of the building. There's also a photo opportunity for Trajan's Column. My husband and I absolutely recommend taking this tour and also adding in visiting the Case Romane del Celio, which is less known than the Domus Romane, but allows you to walk within the ancient rooms of the dwelling at your own pace.

An absolute must.. We had been in Rome for a few days and visited many of the major sites when we found ourselves with a few hours to spare. I googled attractions within walking distance and this popped up so we walked in expecting to spend a few hours examining the ruins.Little did we know that they had booked tours only and they were sold out.Fortunately for us a lecturer who was taking a visiting US student group through had two spare tickets so we were able to join their group. On of the students grinned at us and said it was Disneyland for archaeologists.And it was.As you walk through the underground ruins on glass floors, projectors are used to 'paint' the ruins and recreate what the the original buildings would have looked like.In our touring around of Europe I have never seen such a fantastic use of technology to bring the story of the past to life.Palazzo Valentini is a must see on any visit to Rome and on par with any of the better known attractions.Make sure you book a tour and do not miss this. You will not be disappointed.

very interesting tour under Palazzo Valentini. Add this tour to your visit to Rome. It's interesting and well organized. It is a little difficult to find, as it is underneath the Palazzo Valentini. You have to go inside the building, through the hallway to the courtyard. Turn left, it's right there. We went in January, so we could still book a tour on the same day. However, I recommend booking in advance. Our hotel booked our tickets for us. There is a nice coffee shop an restrooms at the entrance. It reminded me of the underground ruins in Bath, England, but this tour is guided, and of course in your language. Imagine what else is under your feet as you walk around Rome!

Not to be missed. This site consists of a visit to a Roman dwelling found underneath a Renaissance palace. The audio-visual projections onto the original ruins recreate the original home in its full color, and give insight into the lifestyle of the family who occupied it. It really brought the past to life!

Brings history to life. We booked on line and we were so glad that we did.This tour offers a really different insight into ancient Roman life.It never gets boring and the use of lighting to highlight areas ensures the tour remains interesting until the end.We were a group of 18 people and I think having a small group is a big plus.Quite easy to find, 10 minutes walk or less from the Trevi Fountain.

Do not miss out. I was born and raised in Rome. I love my town and know it pretty well, despite it's so rich in cultural heritage that there is always more to know, learn and yet to discover.I work abroad and go home only once a year, YET since the Domus' opening, there has not been 1 year I don't go and visit...for the great pleasure of diving into the ancient history of my culture...and always hoping archeologist discovered more! This happened a while ago, when a new breathtaking discovery was done and a new section about Traiano's column was added.The tour is well structured and you will literally walk in the Domus, living them through centuries in an amazing time machine game of lights, 3D reconstructions, video projections and unimaginable archeological treasures and repertory.Rome is my hometown and the work made at the Domus makes me feel proud of it...In only wish we could invest and do more to discover and preserve our cultural heritage!I encourage all archeology / history interested tourists and Romans to visit! :)Tours are run every day from 9h30 - 17h30, in Italian and English.Adult tkt is 10 euros.6-25 years old or over 65 is 8Primary & secondary schools 6.Booking is possible on spot as well as online.More info on their website.To anyone who reads me, Enjoy Rome and this journey through history!

Unbelievable and Haunting. This newly opened museum, that is rather hard to find, is one of the highlights of our visit to Rome. It is located in a commercial building and was uncovered when a garage was being excavated. Visitors walk above a glass floor with ingenious special effects that reveal what was an ancient Roman palace. Visitors are directed by a guide to various uncovered ruins. The entire tour lasts 1.5 hours and was at the top of our list of highlights of our vacation. Don't miss this--you need to make advance reservations.

One of the best things to see in Rome. Wow! this was the first time that I felt they truly made the best of their historical heritage in Rome! A definite must see if you care for history and would like to truly dive into how it used to be in this place! Don't forget to ask about the times for the English-speaking tours in advance!

A true view of ancient Roman living.. This is very well organized. We went on a guided tour in english, and the guide was excellent. The ruins have been done in such a way as to recreate an idea of their daily activities. The transparent floor over some of the rooms is dizzying, but really amazing, for every age!

Top museum experience. This is not your average museum or archeological site. Sitting below a govt. office, these are underground excavations of a "domus" or wealthy roman home. Using sound and image projections, the visiting group travels around the underground archelogical site that comprises several ancient rooms including thermal baths. Surprising finale.Do not miss it! the experience is very unique.To avoid disappointment, book in advance (i.e. before your trip); the tours are guided (this is not optional) and the groups are small - and there are not too many tours per day.

Technology brings history to life. One of the best attractions i've ever been too, worth fitting into your trip but book in advance!. Such a nice change from just walking around a museum. On the day we went a couple of the projectors in the small rooms were not working but someone was working on it as we went around so didn't complain but thankfully didn't affect the tour too much.

Great for kids. I read the reviews and thought this might help fill in context for my 9.5 year old son while we were in Rome. It ended up being something we all enjoyed, but particularly my son. It is a great way to help the history come alive a bit and give an idea of how to train one's imagination to work as you see so many ruins while in Rome. Worth the time.

Don't miss!. This was one of my favourite things that I did in Rome. You have to reserve a time in advance either online, on the phone or in person (although you may only be able to book in person for that day).You walk on glass panels directly above the ruins and so can look down and see everything beneath your feet. Everything that you are seeing is explained to you in great detail and special lights and effects make it clear where and what everything is...for example by outlining the traces of steps . There are videos that demonstrate what each room probably looked line in Roman times whilst you are standing in that room. Its fantastic because it can be so hard to visualise and appreciate what all the Roman ruins would have looked like, whereas this brings them to life. The tour lasts about 1.5 hours and I cannot recommend this enough.

Hard to find, but worth it! A different experience in Rome.. This place is hidden past the inner courtyard of a government building. It's rather hard to find, but if you go left from where Del Corso meets Piazza Venezia and look for a door in what looks to be a solid brick fortress with a coat of arms hanging on top, that should be it. Go through the dark corridor, past the little open-air area in the middle of the building, and left once more into this entirely innocent looking doorway and you'll find yourself at the entrance to the Domus.At this point you pay a small fee (5 Euros for us since we were a group of students, more for adults and singles of course) and then a guide will lead you inside. I don't want to say more as it will spoil the experience but suffice to say it's different. And after ruins after ruins after ruins full of hawkers and pickpockets and noisy crowds, different is good. If you have kids, they will love it for sure!

a bit disappointed. This was highly recommended by friends but we were a bit disappointed. It was far too hokey for us. The concept is good but the execution was a bit silly at times. With that said, the movie that they show explaining the carving on the column was great.

Definitely Worth Seeing. This is a uniquely displayed Roman house that is well worth the time and effort it takes to see. We were able to get in the day after arriving in Rome thanks to our hotel front desk to made arrangements for us when we checked in. This is probably not possible in high season. The glass floors that enable you to look down inside the house can be a little dizzying, but you get used to it. It's a fantastic tour.

Surprisingly innovative. We've been visiting the remaining a of this Senator Villa after having read some review in internet and honestly not caring too much about all details but only wishing to visit a nice Roma ruin in a perfect location. The surprise was huge. The entertaining guiding voice make you feel as in a film. The fantastic lights and 3D reconstructions of the interiors are cutting edge technology. The final guided 3D tour around the Colonna Traiana bassorilievi is absolutely revealing. A last surprise will let your mouths open and your imagination fly over 2000 years old imperial feeling. You'll think Rome is really magic after this visit. The price is absolutely cheap compared with the amount of emotions and work behind this visit. A must.

Needs preparation. Well I was not able to visit this supposedly wonderful place, but I am writing the review to place some tips that may help others "not miss it"Very difficult to find, maps are not accurate and entrance is through a couryard off the main street. There is a Cosmpolitan hotel on the block behind it, but I think you need to ask around for exact location.No walk ins; you have to make earlier reservation through a call center, and entrance is limited, I think to 20 per group.The visit is conducted using different languages at diffent times, so if you need to listen to the guide you need to pick the suitable visitBest of luck.

Unique Experience. I booked over the internet from home before we left for Rome, very easy, and we are so glad we took Trip Advisors advice and visited this historic exhibit. If you are keen to see some history while in Rome, then this is great, an excavated Villa, you travel about 10-15 metres underground and discover a little how life was 2000 years ago. The lasers and projectors are great, in reproducing artefacts as if they were new again, I have not seen them used this way before. Highly recommend to see when in Rome.
ruins illustrated. exhibits with taped tour brought this palazzo alive, but our guide's English was not too good.well worth the tome and money

An Interesting tour, different than any other of ruins. An excellent interpretation of a typical noble household and the 'light's' depiction helps to recreate the space much better than simple pictures would. The tour is clever and informative. A must do. FYI- this tour is quite new, but you still need to book in advance. The tour is located in a palazzo that also houses other events, so it can be a bit confusing when you walk in. Stay left.

Better The Second Time. This was my second visit to the Domus Romane; the first was in May 2012. Through the wonders of modern technology, a "light show" fills in what's missing from the houses of ancient Roman aristocrats. Booking ahead is required. In addition to the Patrician Roman House, the tour now includes an explanation of the story depicted on Trajan's Column and reconstruction of Trajan's Forum, which are adjacent to the Roman House. You are also able to look out a "back door" to see Trajan's Column. If you cannot get a ticket before leaving for Rome, ask your hotelier to check for you. It's worth the effort. A small cafe and bathrooms are in the couryard next to the museum entrance.

History alive. A fantastic interpretation of the home a Roman nobleman - from the ruins under a 16thC palazzo another entire story can be read. Using modern techniques the ruin is brought to life and then incorporated into the external forum - a great presentation, not to be missed.
Excellent way to view history. I thought this was a really clever attraction, showing you the way an old building would have looked and giving you a real insight into the life of romans.

History brought to life! A highlight of our Rome visit. I had no idea what to expect when taken to this museum by my wife but was very pleasantly surprised. The audio visual is brilliantly superimposed onto the the actual archaeology making it far easier to understand the story of the ancient building. Our children ( 9 and 12yo) had struggled during visits to the Forum and some other Roman monuments. They were both completely engaged during this museum visit. Remember to book online.

Best if you want to know how they lived. Tour which takes you underground of Rome. It was really interesting and you learn a lot about angient life in Rome. Preporder is a must only 15 people per group so order early!

Fasinating experience. I really didn't know what to expect from the reviews and the website. What you are doing is going into a palace, where the first floor has been removed and replaced with plexiglass and you walk over ancient ruins. These are lit and have audio commentary to help you understand what it might have been like 2000 years ago. A truly interesting experience, well worth the entry fee. Book the English tour.

Little known attraction but a MUST SEE!. My daughter and I stumbled upon this by accident. While standing in line to inquire about the tour, another tourist standing behind us said this was rated as one of the top attractions to see in Rome. On her advice, we decided to do the only remaining tour of the day. So glad we did! It was one of the highlights of our trip!So cool to see the ruins come to life beneath your feet and be transported back to ancient Rome!I would recommend making reservations ahead. We had dumb luck on our side and got in the same day, barely.

Better than expected. This venue was recommended to us by the proprietor of the B&B Residenza Arco dei Tolomei (a great place to stay) and it turned out to be a very interesting and worthwhile experience. You literally walk on top of the excavations on plexiglass while listening to a description (in English) of what you are seeing; as the narration goes on different parts of the excavation are lit up or they show projections of what the house would have looked like when it was actually occupied. Reservations are needed because the English tours are only given at certain times but we had no trouble getting reservations even calling for them just one day in advance. Note, though, that we were in Rome in November, not at the height of tourist season so if you're planning on going at a busier time, make your reservations earlier.

Undiscovered gem,thanks Tripadvisor!. Went there following this site's recommendation and was well worth it.Most people don't know of its existence,and even outside the building,you are not aware of it being there.We learnt so much about the owner and the times of the Domus,in such a fun way,and I received congrats from my friends for my insistence in seeing it.

First Century Meets 21st.. A great use of technology to bring ancient history to life. Initially, walking on the pexiglass floor is a bit creepy, but the substance of the tour makes it possible to quickly overcome any discomfort. Films and projected images help to depict the runs as they may have been when constructed and occupied. A particularly good thing to do on Mondays, when so many other places are closed, or on a rainy down, although it can be damp and chilly in the underground setting.

Fantastic, A Must Do. We loved this. A must see, must do, gives you more of an idea of the possibilities of early Roman life in a whole new techno fun way. I would strongly recommend booking ahead online and be on time for your booking. It will be getting busier and busier.

This was amazing. What a great idea: installing see-through floors over Roman ruins. Once I made it down the first few steps (I have a depth perception problem and the darkness combined with the glass floors to some adjusting on my part) it was an amazing tour. Please note that if you have the Roma Pass, the tour is covered and free, but you must still make a reservation. The English tour was at 1:30 p.m. and although the woman checking us in at 1 p.m. was less than welcoming (I think she resented our Roma pass as she tried to charge us 10 Euros, but I had the Rome pass book with me, and had mentioned it when making the reservation) the tour proper was really informative and so well done.People with problems standing for long periods should know that there is no sitting down until the very end. There was a pause in a gift shop. Just as you exit the gift shop there were two benches. Once people started sitting down (no one was buying souvenirs), the tour progressed. Coincidence? Not sure.I would absolutely recommend taking the 1.5 hours to do this tour.

One of the Best Museums I have visited!. This destination in Rome is was just amazing. We have spent their 1.5 hours in the underground but it was so attractive, interesting and interactive that we even didn't feel how the time passed. I felt the environment of ancient Rome and it was a great experience.

What an awesome place to see. Make a reservation for this, you will enjoy it.Takes you through ruins below a villa in Rome with a visual recreation. Exceptionally well done and not to be missed. A nice break from museums. Tour was about 1.5 hours and was very good. Location is a bit hard to find on their website but if you are standing in front of the big while Victor Emanuel Monument (big white monument), with your back to the monument, go to Main Street in front of the monument, turn right and it is about 1 block down on the right.

A brilliant recent addition to Roman archaeology.. A great diversion from the tumult of Rome's main attractions. Only small groups and feels very intimate. But no photography allowed :-(Cool lighting effects and sometimes overly dramatic audio track: 'One can almost imagine the sound of children running up the stairs'. Cue loud children laughing and running. A writer once told me to 'Show OR Tell'. Don't do both. It's a bit like trying to explain the punchline of a joke, it's just not a success if you have to explain everything. Some advice to Palazzo Valentini if they ever re-record the audio - don't patronise your audience.

This is a TOP TEN. While this museum doesn't catch a lot of first time to Rome visitors it definitely should. It is an amazing archeological site that combines the artifacts found with a multimedia presentation tying in what is there now with what was there in the distant past. It is the best example of how a influential Roman lived in the early centuries that I have seen in Rome, and truly an innovative and fascinating museum.

A MUST when visiting rome. My husband and I made reservations in advance and came with high expectations. The tour exceeded our expectations. I can rank this place as one of my favorite things we did in Rome. If you like archeology this is the place for you. Not only you can see the most beautiful excavations but they also combine amazing video projections to help you visualize how they lived in Roman times.

Worth a Visit. We thought we had seen just about everything in Rome during our many visits and this was a worthy addition.A very good way to spend a couple of hours in ancient Rome. The excavations began about 2000 and are presented in a very educationable fashion. The ruins are brought to life with an audio feature and an impressive 3D overlay showing how it may have looked in it's time.

Unique experience. There is not another museum in Rome quite like this. Basically you get to tour rooms of two Imperial-era villas that were found located beneath a 16th century Palazzo. There are gorgeous inlaid marble floors and mosaics. You basically walk over the rooms on glass floors and look down into them as they are now. Then a lighting show recreates the room to show what it looked like in antiquity. It's a good attempt to help us all "see" beyond the ruins.

A "must do" if you are into the Roman underground. We used this as a visit on the Roma pass and I think it was my husbands favorite attraction. He was at one point an art history major and he had always heard of Rome being build upon layers and layers of history. The glass floor and illumination show really shows how the ancient roman house would have looked back in the day. There is also a movie at the end that tells the full story of Trajan's column that we would have never learned about otherwise. It is truly a very hidden gem and one that should not be missed! A small note for allergy sufferers...I did not find it moldy like some others without the glass like San Clemente.

Unique & Fun. Agreed with all previous reviews, this is a one-of-its-kind museum in Rome. Opened only in 2010, it is indoor, air-conditioned, and well designed to give visitors a tour of an ancient Roman villa. Many parts were presented in the dark with lighting and videos. Therefore, it was hard to showcase this unique visit in pictures. Nonetheless, it was worth the visit!

Book ahead of time for English!. Unfortunately we could not book ahead for an English tour (if you go in the morning, it's possible to get an afternoon one), so we went on the Italian tour.Unfortunately we don't speak much Italian, but we were able to enjoy most of it! The staff was nice and accommodating, and the exhibit itself was impressive! It's definitely amazing to see how these bits and pieces of ruins and pottery actually looked in their prime!We really enjoyed it and I'm sure it'd be even better if we could have understood!Note - there are stairs as you go throughout the exhibit so those with difficulty walking may need assistance. We also had to leave our stroller upstairs.

Dark but fun and informative. We didn't allow ourselves enough time to get to this tour so we arrived a few minutes late. Because the ticket attendant wanted us to get in as much of the tour as possible he walked us very rapidly to where the tour group was assembled. It's a bit disconcerting walking over the transparent floor in the dark-especially when you see stairs and feel like you should be stepping down! We didn't miss much of this tour and we really enjoyed it. The best part however may have been the explanation of Trajan's column. Fascinating! There is so much to see and do in Rome but I would probably want to do this tour again. It's reasonably priced and there's a lot to absorb. Just be sure you book in advance as only a limited amount of people are allowed in at one time, and there are different times for different languages.

Brings Ancient Rome to Life. We booked two weeks in advance for an English tour. This really is a very engaging and clever archeological attraction. My 9 year old daughter thought it was wonderful even after being worn down by a day at Pompeii and the Roman Forum. This is a example of how to bring something to life in a spectacular way.

Virtual Reality. For once History got to me! Following up the archeological excavations with virtual reality was a hit! My 10 yrs old granddaughter said: –This is like a lesson of history! and she meant it in a good way.

Worth the visit. I tried to book this in advance for Monday, 30 Sept, but all English tours were reserved. Never did see a window for booking in early October. While walking around on Monday morning,we "stumbled" upon the place and inquired about ticket availability. Luckily, we were able to get tickets for an afternoon tour. Well run tour with excellent descriptions of how Rome changed from the Roman through Renaissance eras in this one location.

What a marvel!. If you really want to understand the development of Rome go here now! This is a spectacular exhibit of the layers underneath Rome. As the number of people are limited, only 15 per hour, you can really enjoy and absorb the information. The ruins are complex and beautifully explained. The digital animation, in the most affective way I have seen, clearly demonstrates the glory of the excavated palace. Go buy your tickets now!

interesting but you MUST book. If you want to better understand how the Romans once lived, this is a great insight into decoding the ruins. The graphics and lighting effects recreate what this villa would have looked like. It's rather tucked away, neither our map, nor phone app could find it. Happily a local hotel concierge was obliging. Numbers for the tour are limited so you must book in advance. Our concierge did it for us (the website is not straightforward) but we couldn't get in for a couple of days. Well worth the effort though.

Interesting!. I enjoyed this exhibit and would recommend it. As has already been said, it is basically a tour through an archeological dig of an old mansion underneath a government building. Totally worth the 12 euro or whatever it was I paid. The website completely sucks and doesn't work at all. Just call the number and sign up that way. I had my hotel call, no problem; just have your credit card ready. There are only a couple of English tours per day around 1:30pm. The tour is automated by a voice speaking in English and a person who works there helps to guide you from room to room. She forgot about us a couple of times and it was a tiny bit confusing to me, but overall a good experience.

Most interesting. We took the Italian tour as the English tour wasn't until the afternoon and we had other plans. The tour guide was very kind to point out things in English for us. It was really cool to see the ruins and then get to see how it might have been in it's glory. The glass floors made me feel a little dizzy at first.

Palazzo Valentini. An excellent new addition to the Archeological sites of Rome. The use of new technology to show you how it looked really works, your imagination can only stretch so far!Well worth a visit

Cliff notes version of ruins of ancient Roman homes. If you have a couple of hours this an inexpensive way to get a quick and sometimes interesting view of how a ver rich person lived in Ancient Rome. We had been to Pompeii and Ephesus on this trip and as such it was not as revealing with new insights.

Amazing Rome / Amazing Italy. I love history, archeology, etc., and time in Rome is very precious, vibrant competition between unique attractions...Well, every second was worth it and you'll never look at ruins in the same way you did before. Stones speak to us, and what they have to say is very often astonishing.
Relive the past. This is definitely a must see. Going back and visualizing through great graphics how Roman homes were like is just fascinating.

Le Domus Romane is worth the visit. It is an interesting place. The multimedia presentation is quite nice, however I am bit surprised that the place has been rated so high. I would give it one star on the Rick Steve's grading scale if you know what I mean. Visit it if you have time.

Gives a deeper understanding of ancient Rome. We found this place via TripAdvisor, which is truly fortunate. We had passed by this place several times and never had noticed it. None of the major maps mark it and we had never heard of it. As you go through the tour (which you can book in English, Italian or French), lighting effects highlight what the ruins show about Rome circa 100-500 AD. Additionally, they demonstrate what the villa might have looked like back then. We had previously taken a bike tour in which our guide gave us great historical information about the ruins around the city. We found that Le Domus Romane gave a deeper understanding of what life would have been like during the highlight of Imperial Rome.This is definitely a must-see (especially for those who are not well-studied on the time periods of Roman History).

A bit Disney-ish but informative. I would have never expected an almost theme park like experience but that's what it felt like most of the time. It was unusual to say the least and more engaging than your average archeological site would be especially for kids. I would encourage you to go as it is a really good example of how a wealthy family lived back when the Colosseum was used for entertainment and the ruler was an emperor! You must reserve ahead of time because their English tours are limited and your Roma Pass will be accepted if you go in person. The little electric bus bus 117 passes right in front of it so if you are on your way to the Colosseum, just stop there first to get your tickets.

A hidden gem. Like most of the other reviews have noted, this place is a hidden gem. I had never heard of it until my friend found it on Tripadvisor. we were not disappointed. We arrived early, hoping to get on the first visit for the day, but it was booked out, so I would suggested booking on line. The multi-media presentation is well done and the partial reconstruction of parts of it gives you a good insight in to how the other half lived. Easy to walk to from Termini or from Vittore Emmanuale. Highly recommended.

A must visit... This particular attraction is virtually on no map, has little signage and no lineups. However, it is one of the best places to check out while in Rome.As other reviewers have mentioned, it basically walks you through a couple ancient houses and uses computers to show you what it would look it. It sounds kind of cheesy but is really cool. It really helps you visualize what the buildings looked like back then and helps you understand many of the other popular sites where the buildings are basically ruins.You need reservations to visit and you can buy them online at their website. As others have mentioned, it appears as though if you show up you can usually buy tickets for the next guided tour (you can only go as a guided tour). The price (around 10 euros) is an excellent deal considering you get a tour with it. The Roma pass does work here, but you cannot book online and have to call them to book manually if you wish to use the pass.As a tip, the washrooms here at clean, free and without lineups. If you are in the city center you can use the facilities here. When you enter the building, go straight past the first few offices until you reach the courtyard. The office to buy tickets is the first door on your left and the washrooms are the second on your left.

A real masterpiece. This is the best place to get a clear picture and understanding of what a Roman house - of a rich Roman- might have looked like! little difficult to find but we were amazed! watch Rome come to life beneath your feet and all around you. Glass floors cover ruins that come to life during the show. Really excellent experience that you should not miss. It is also the best deal in town at the price. We are so glad we found this hidden gem on this site.

One of the best attractions in Rome!. They did an amazing job putting this attraction together. In a city full of ruins , this is the best place to get a clear picture and understanding of what a roman house - of a rich roman- might have looked and felt like. I strongly suggest to make a reservation. There are only 2 tours in english and I believe it is max 20 spots per presentation.

it's holodeck!. A great exhibition. Fascinating to see how the upper class lived in 400 ad. they used projections to give you an idea of how it may have looked at the time. My husband, a verteran Star Trek fan, felt like he was walking trough a holodeck suite. an added plus was the description of the column' 'next door' describing the excavation work necessary to put it there, and then a close and detailed description of the story depicted on the column. It's done with a guided tour and you need to reserve up front. don't forget to mention that you have a Roma Pass ( if you have one) and it's one of the only attractions open on Monday in Rome!

Best keep secret. This is a new attraction and they only allow a small number of people in per tour. It is a guided tour with lots of steps. It was fabulous unlike anything I have ever seen, well done taking you back in time with graphics. Book early but a must see.
Marvellous. Use guide , then you will have a perfect experiense. Use good shoes, because you will walk a little bitt.
Fantastic. Brings history to life fantastic place to visit a great way to spend a couple of hours, but remember to book in advance

Just Fantastic!. It's in a government building on Via Novembre 4 aboveTrajan's Column. An imperial villa you walk on glass floors that peer down into the rooms and then they superimpose modern imaging over them to recreate what they looked like. They finish with an In depth review of Trajan's Column where they match commentary with the columns images/sculptures. Takes about 1.5 hours. Reservations necessary as viewing is by small groups arranged linguistically.

A must do.... ... if your into roman ruins and also have trouble imagining all the splendour.We've been to Pompeii and the Archaeological Museum in Naples a couple of days earlier and although the remains are truly impressive, we found it often difficult to imagine what the ensemlbe looked like. At first, we were sceptical of these ruins due to the "multimedia" aspect. But it is soooo well made with the glass floors and the light projections and everything. We were in a group of only 12 which made the experience amazing. Visitor info: French tours run only once a day. We got tickets for our English tour on the spot, 20 minutes earlier. We saw no signs and got no info that the museum would close due to works as indicated by an earlier reviewer (we were there on Oct 11th).And DO have an espresso at the bar along with the governmental workers :)

A hidden gem. This was the highlight to a recent week spent in Rome. It's a hidden gem and glad we found it. Make sure you book in advance though as numbers are limited. It was really fascinating to see a roman villa come to life. It's an attraction quite like any other.

Well worth the effort. We started our visit here, then went to the Forum and Coloseum. It worked for us though the limited times for tours may not work for all. It's really well done. Do your homework on its location; there are no crowds, touts or big signs to help you.

highlight of our trip. We really enjoyed the visit to the Palazzo Valentini - it had what other attractions were missing in that it bought the ruins to life and really allowed you to understand how magnificent these buildings must have been in there time.We hadn't booked in advance and on the website the English tours had sold out but we went along when it opened on the morning we wanted to visit and managed to get tickets for later that day.

remarkable luxury. Fascinating look into a super luxurious villa from Romans times.The use of modern technology to demonstrate how it would have looked originally was fantastic.Informative and insightful

A different and intimate look at Ancient Roman life.. Tucked away inside a government building, this museum is everything most tourist sites in Rome are not: intimate (only guided visits in small groups), modern (lasers and special effects enhance the views of the domus under the reinforced glass under your feet), uncrowded and unrushed. The presentation on Trajan's Column sheds new light on a structure most tourists snap a quick shot of before moving on, never understanding the story it tells. Visit included in Roma Pass. Recommended.

Mesmerizing. After seeing all the great reviews we had to go see it. It is very well done and quite instructive. There is an incredible film at the end concerning the Trojan Colonne, so make sure to go see it before doing this tour.

This attraction will be closed from October10th for building renovations.. Just a tip for anyone like myself who was really looking forwards to seeing Le Domus Romane.On the TA Rome forum the news is that building works are starting October 11th and will be quite lengthy.It is very disappointing to say the least.
Incredible. Two adults and two children (age 10) were mesmerised. The tour was very well done, as close as I have ever felt to stepping back in time.

A must see for everyone. This was one of the few tours we took as my fellow travellers were not much for museums however they absolutely loved this one. It was fascinating to actually see how the ancient romans lived. The way they recreated the visuals brought everything to life. You were not left imagining what that broken piece artifact once looked like, they actually gave you the visual which ws wonderful. They also provided you with a history of the city of Rome which was well worth while. It would be a good idea to go to Le Domas first before you start to tour around Rome as it will provide some perspective to the city

Our favorite attraction in Rome. A friend and I, both 30, spent the better part of four days in Rome. Hands down, this was the most amazing attraction we visited - Galleria Borghese was second. Two or three stories underground, beneath the 16th century palace, are the ruins of an incredibly well-preserved 4th century high-class home. For an hour and a half (during which time you never glance at your watch) you walk over glass floors looking down into the various rooms as very exact/high tech colored lasers and other effects illuminate several sections of the ruins so you can tell exactly what you are seeing. All this while a well written narrative is broadcast in the darkness around you. It's like being in the middle of the most well produced history channel program but being able to witness the CGI recreation with your own eyes. We did not find it difficult to locate. Once you see Trajan's column, you're a block away. It's a yellow multi-story building w/ flags out front and a red sign bearing the website's logo. They have limited English tours each day (that frequently sell out) and they require a reservation with an early arrival time to pick up your tickets. We had purchased the Roma Pass and were able to get the discounted price. Tip: I had trouble booking the tickets with my Google translate on, once I flipped it back to Italian it worked no problem - just in case anyone else runs into that issue.

Truely wonderful experience. A little gem from ancient Rome hidden beneath a renaissance palazzo that is now a government building. The armed guard at the main entrance was very friendly and directed us to the entrance on the left hand side of the inner courtyard.We were lead as part of a small group, down several flights of steps which ran down into the basement. Our guide revealed an archaeological site laid out beneath a reinforced glass floor. We were encouraged to walk out onto the floor and explore the room. And then the show started.Over the next 90 mins we walked in wonder from one room to another as a narrative explained the remains of the roman villa and bath house and a digital light show brought the villa and the family that lived there to life.Best 10 Euros we spent that weekend.

finally we could picture how Romans lived. If you have a hard time imagining real life just by looking at archaeological sites, this tour is a revelation.We absolutely loved it and so did all the other people when we visited.Note: you must book in advance or rely on luck. Only guided tours are allowed in. Their web site may tell you that the English tours are booked days in advance, but that is not always accurate. Drop in if you are in the area - it's right beside Trajan's column

A must. Its a journey to undergound city. This museum bring you back to Roman times. I mean its really bring u back there. They bring u to deep underground where they found the ancient city of Rome beneath the ground level of today city. And the way they educate us what the city is like in the past is truly fantastic. With modern technology of presentation and the real excavation. This is only guided tour. You have to check timing in your language. The length is 2 hours. It worth every minute there.

A great experience..... This is truly a wonderful insight into the buildings beneath Rome. It has only been open since 2010 so is quite an amazing experience brought to life with some great technology. The ruins were discovered when the area was being excavated for a car park!!! The tour takes you underground and you are walking over the top of the ruins via a glass walkway, some great lighting and commentary guides you so centuries long lost....book in advance so as not to be disappointed as there are only about a dozen per tour. It lasts for about an hour.

Really interesting, but only if you are REALLY into archeology and history.. This was a beautiful exhibit. It was very interesting as well. However, the tour was rather ling and drawn out and somewhat repetitive. It lasts about 2 hours but could be condensed into about 40 minutes. My husband and I grew a bit bored and anxious; children would not suffer through this well

Fantastic tour!. Planning a trip, especially to the city such as Rome, takes some planning ahead. Andthat’s exactly what you should do with Domus Romane: book your tickets ahead and prevent missing to see this marvelous place. We were lucky to have a wonderful host/hotel owner, who recommended us this place, which we would otherwise miss and it would be such a loss… The groups are limited (when you see the place, you will find out why), so I think that you shloud book at least one week earlier. If possible, plan your visit to Domus prior to other archeologicalattractions (Colosseum, Forum…), because you will learn a lot about Romans and theirconcept of leaving, building…You will understand much better all those other (more famous) attractions afterwards.We come from a country which was in the Roman period under their rule and have seen many relicts, tombs, remains of palaces, etc. But in spite of that, stepping into the Domus’ underground and seeing how the old Romans actually lived, was a miraculousexperience. Although being slightly claustrophobic, I didn’t feel any anxiety, because the visual and sound impressions were so captivating, that I didn't have the time to think about anything else. The whole project has been excellently planned and executed; you will experiencehow the old and modern cooperate in the best possible way. The use of modern computer technologies to recreate and visualise the relicts found here trully contributes to the overall experience, which for us, was like travelling through time and coming into 3-4 century A.D. At moments, I felt like I was disturbing the people who lived here and whose presence can be felt even nowadays. The oral part is also very, very good. I got the impression that the team of best archeologists, art historians and writers was gathered to write the story which leads you from one room to another. All in all, fabulos experience and a highly recommended tour!

Walking over & into the past. What a strange sensation at first to be walking over the excavated ruins of a wealth Roman home! With the help of graphics and lasers, the ancient ruins come to life. We walked thru the house, including the bathrooms and swimming pools. No pictures are allowed, but there is too much to see anyway and the walk, though not rushed, is kept moving.

Wonderful visit !. This is by far the best experience I have had with Roman ruins.
