Though I am a big fan of the Roman period, visualising ruins often proofs difficult, especially when there is little left. However, at Le Domus Romane a digital simulation guides you through the house of a wealthy Roman family. This nifty piece of technology highlights - quite literally - the important bits and 3D reconstructions help you picture what it may have looked like.The simulation lasts for a while and is therefore worth the money spent. If you're under 25, bring along some form of ID with your birth date on it to get a discount. There are only a few English tours, so book in advance. There are ones in French, and of course, in Italian. Le Domus is very close to Piazza Venezia, so ideal for when you're around Trajan's Column and the Altare della Patria. It's even within walking distance of the Colosseum and the Forum

Make the time for this tour of Le Domus Romane. Excellent, well run and informative tour. Amazing special effects bring the ruins (which are lighted below a glass floor) to their original look and design, such as the simulation of "blue water" in a pool or fountain and painted frescoes on the walls of rooms... Make the time for this exhibit--well worth it.
gem of a find. first rate place to visit. the tour is very informative and imaginativley put together and executed. Place is a little hard to find but well worth the effort

Glad We Went. It took us over an hour to find this place, and it turns out it is inside city hall, or rather under. The views of the excavated home under meters of Rome were enhanced by projections which brought it to life, or as it was when it was used 2000 years ago. The tour audio is recorded and video/pictures are computer driven too, so everyone gets the same info which was quite interesting. It's a bit impersonal, but given the slackness and apparent disinterest of the staff, that was fine. I'd recommend that you do go..and be sure to get tickets on-line in advance as English language tours are few, and each tour takes only about 25 people.

This place is so great!. Watch Rome come to life beneath your feet and all around you. Glass floors cover ruins that come to life during the show. Really excellent experience that you should not miss. If you are traveling with bored teens who are rolling their eyes at you because they don't get it, this computer assisted, multi media tour with a wonderful surprise at the end will capture their attention. It is also the best deal in town at the price. We are so glad we found this hidden gem on this site.

Amazing!. The sensation of walking on glass floors was a bit strange at first, but very quickly forgotten as you became absorbed in the discoveries of the excavations. Excellent presentation and great use of technology to bring the finds alive. The explanation and 3D presentation of the obelisk was exceptional.

So glad we visited. We'd arrived here on our next to last day to find that all the tours were booked up, so we decided to book for the next day. Having read the great reviews, we weren't disappointed either. A fantastic experience, the way in which they show you the excavated remains then recreate the entire room and house around you is both clever and interesting.

Presentation presentation.. Wow what a way to present a ruin or excavation. This is definitely the future of presenting ruins or excavations sites. I don't like to spoil the fun by telling it all here but here's the clue. Pretend that you are in the movie while it is being shot on location. And it is real. This domus weaved its history with the solitary Trajan column so be prepared for a good close up.

Amazing. If you have time this is not frequently visited. It an underground view of an actual ancient Roman home. The tour is worth a visit. Make a reservation. Tours are limited and in different languages.

Amazing time travel tour. Beautifully done. While it first only looks like your going to stand on a glass floor above some ruins, it then turns into a real renovated Roman house with the help of visual affects. The tour isn't given by the guide who takes you from room to room but is a very informative recording. perfectly timed with the visual affects. The tour even seems interactive (you can touch the warm walls of the sauna) and you can finally imagine how such a house might have looked like back then. In comparison to other entrance fees this was a very fair price. If you still have a bus or metro bus ticket from that day, you even get a discount.This and the Palazzo Doria-Pamphilj were the highlights of our trip. Also great for kids, I'm sure.

diffferent sight to see. we really enjoyed visiting Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini. You have a guide so make sure you book a tour in your language. You see the ruins of a villa but what makes it different is that they have discovered the ruins and then covered the floors in glass so you walk through the rooms looking down, they then use, commentary spotlights and projectors to tell the history of the villa, it really is a different place to visit

Fantastic. Not to be missed, extraordinary place, fabulous guided tours (you can't wander round separately) every multi media modern skill is used to evoke the past without ever verging on the Disney-esque or cutsie. Heavily booked, we were lucky to grab the last two places on the English speaking tour yesterday. Perfect also for a wet day as it's all inside. Do go!

Antiquity Meets Technology. This is by far the best experience I have had with Roman ruins. Though I am a big fan of the Roman period, visualising ruins often proofs difficult, especially when there is little left. However, at Le Domus Romane a digital simulation guides you through the house of a wealthy Roman family. This nifty piece of technology highlights - quite literally - the important bits and 3D reconstructions help you picture what it may have looked like.The simulation lasts for a while and is therefore worth the money spent. If you're under 25, bring along some form of ID with your birth date on it to get a discount. There are only a few English tours, so book in advance. There are ones in French, and of course, in Italian. Le Domus is very close to Piazza Venezia, so ideal for when you're around Trajan's Column and the Altare della Patria. It's even within walking distance of the Colosseum and the Forum.

Fabulous!. I never write reviews on trip advisor but this is a truly fabulous attraction, ridiculously good value (approx 11 euros each) and well worth checking out. Make sure that you book well in advance (its easy to book online) as there are only a couple of English language sessions each day and only about 12 people are admitted on each tour. You spend one and a half hours exploring an excavated Roman house. Lighting and commentary are used to bring the house back to life and to reveal the many layers of history in the house. As well as exploring life in a Roman house this tour also includes an in depth video on Trajan's Column as well as a close up view of Trajan's Column at the end. The tour is a bit long and dark for very young children, pushchairs are not allowed but it doesn't make this clear on the website. This is a real experience, definitely book it, you wont be disappointed.

Must see.. I did not know what to expect from this, but must say I was pleasantly surprised. Never before has history been (so) interesting and engaging. The tour was 1.5 hour in total, so I recommend visiting the bathroom before and bringing a bottle of water :) The entrance fee of only 10€ seems incredibly cheap for something like this!

Bound to become very popular. This relatively new attraction/exhibit is excellent and bound to become a "must" of on anyone's Rome itinerary. Blending a wonderful archeological site of wealthy Roman's domus, with a high-tech overlay that brings the site to vivid life (to a degree we've never seen before). The close-up view of Trajan's column at the tour's end is an added bonus. We went with two kids - 8 and 10 - while the 10 year-old really enjoyed it, the 8 year old was bored/tired half way through.

Interesting and different way to spend an hour or so.. I was pleasantly surprised by this attraction and if you are at all interested in Roman history you should visit this place. You effectively spend 1-1.5 hours touring a part excavated Roman house which is brought to life through the use of lighting and commentary. The price is very reasonable (< 10 euros each) and we arrived on the day and booked a tour which started 2 hours after.

interesting twist to the ancient rome attractions. after reading all the reviews, I tried booking this place last October when I first went to Rome, but it was too late! all the English tours were booked out for the days that I was there so couldn't go. this year, I booked a month early and got spots for the English tour in August! it was a really interesting tour and definitely has a different twist to your usual ancient ruins attraction sites. it uses technology to bring the old to light of what it would of been back then. so if you want to visit this place, make reservations online early! I had to use google translate to book it because the site in "English" version wasn't really translating properly.
Worth a visit. Was quite interesting and well worth a visit. I wouldn't recommend brining small children as it's pretty dark and spooky in some parts.

modern multi-media presentation of a Roman house. The excavations here are presented using various multi-media tools to help the visitor understand and reconstruct what they are seeing. It is important to reserve tickets online in advance as visitor numbers are limited. For anyone who struggles with seeing too many bits of ancient rock this is a good way to bring ruins to life. It is also an interesting contrast to combine this with a visit to the roman houses under Santi Giovanni e Paolo (the other side of the Colosseum) which are presented in a more traditional way. The visit here lasts about 90 minutes.

Educational, creative use of lighting. I loved the unusual way the lights and projections were used to enhance our understanding of the archaeological discoveries of parts of the 1st and4th century houses here. My wife felt a bit uncomfortable walking over the reinforced glass which covered the flooring tho
A new treat. What a delightful surprise, a very well presented and interesting look at life in early Rome with a good commentary

domus romane di palazzo Valentini. great interesting visit .Very well organized.It lasts 1hour and 15 minutes approximately. I feel finally proud of my Rome, of the clever way to show our treasuries to tourists. really proud this time!

A surprise highlight of our trip to Rome. Having read the reviews on tripadvisor, I booked our visit in advance.Pleased this is rated so highly on Tripadvisor, otherwise we may have overlooked it!The ruins are amazing, and the tour has been put together so well - lighting is used to recreate what the building would have looked like. All modern exhibitions should be like this.

Do not miss!. This tour was the highlight of our holiday and seems to be a littel known gem! Tricky to find I can uinderstand why. Its about 100yards from the Trajan monument and the entrance is on the Via Novembre. The tour takes you through a journey of what it was like to live in a Roman house. Tastefully done, it uses technology to enhance the experience as you hover over the ruins on a glass floor. In parts it is genuinely quite moving. I absolutely loved it.

Wow!. This was really a great way to see and learn about ancient Rome. Very tastefully done. Definitely recommended. I would not, however recommend it for small children who are easily scared of the dark or eerie music. My 7 year old would have run out immediately.

Insight into life in priveledged families houses nearly 2000 years ago. This was a good recorded tour that gradually built our understanding of life in priveledged families houses nearly 2000 years ago.Interesting that pools, saunas etc existed but the engineering and mechanics and labour involved was so different. It is not easy as an English speaking person to use the website to pre purchase tickets. Also be ready to feel a little uncertain at the beginning and end of the your about what to do. The communication on the way in and out was not good and when the av connection and lights went out no one explained anything or apologised. Still glad we did it though.
Awesome. Awesome.... Free as part of the Roma Pass but you need to call to make a booking. Really enjoyed the explanantions and light and visual effects show.
nice visit. beautiful architecture and a great place to people watch. We visited this on our segaway tour, which is a great way to visit many sights that you normally wouldn't be able to by foot.

Impressive tour. It is not the most popular museum in Rome, yet the tour / visit is impressive. The experience of going back in the ancient days in the tour is amazing. Without booking in advance, we arrived there at around 11:30am. We were suggested to take the Eng tour at 1:30pm. So we bought the tickets and we walked around the area where we could easily spend the 2 hours. The tour was in a group of 15 persons and it finished at around 3pm.

Toppissim. Should you really want to be educated just go there. Discover only in 2005, the excavation, and the presentation is really very well done. 11 euro entrance for a 2 hours experience of anciant rome. Super

Very original, fascinating museum. We planned to visit this museum some time in advance and stayed in a hotel just across the street (Hotel Mancino 12). It is definitely worth seeing. It is a rather long guided tour with plenty of useful information and well conceived multimedia presentations. Our ten years old son enjoyed it very much, but it might be a bit too demanding to follow for very young children. Trajan's column is just behind the museum...do not miss it!

off the charts. get tickets now. you won't be disappointed. a thoughtful and enlightening presentation, the tour group number is kept low, so you can see and hear everything very well. beware those of you who get nervous standing on glass or grates - you are walking over an archaeological dig so keep that in mind!

Le Domus Romane should not be missed!. This was well worth seeing. It gave my family and I such a wonderful glimpse into the life of wealthy Romans in ancient times. My teenagers like it, too, and that is saying a lot.

Unmissable.. This is one not to miss! Well worth seeking it out as it's so original and interesting. We went on a Tuesday to find it closed but made the effort to go back on a different day and so glad we did - loved it!

Must see attraction. Don't miss this hidden attraction, just behind the Trajan's Column. This must be seen, it's difficult to explain by words. The tour is worth the money, it uncovers the wonders of architecture of a traditional "roman domus" during several periods of time, by using multimedia effects added to actual ruins from beneath the building.

A fantastic trip back in time!. Having lived in Rome for many years I was surprised to have discovered this fantastic museum. You must book online for this museum experience. They have tours in different languages and they last an hour and a half each. A maximum of 15 people are allowed on each tour. It's quite near Piazza Venezia, and a quite look on google maps shows exactly where the museum is located. It has big signs outside the museum so it is quite hard to miss. We arrived 20 minutes before the tour started and waited in the courtyard before it begun. At first it seemed a little confusing as you are walking on glass above the ruins. The tour is by an audio/video recordings. So there are no problems understanding what is being said as the recordings are of a high quality. I would definitely recommend this tour. I learned so much about life in Ancient Rome. I particularly liked the explanation of Trajans column.

A must see. This place was quite hard to find, enter through the courtyard of Provinci di Roma on Via IV Novembre and there’s a doorway on the left. Great attraction, which I found very useful to visit before heading to the Roman Forum, as lights and video is overlayed onto the excavated ruins to give you a virtual picture of how the ruins may have looked in Roman times. You walk around on a glass floor over the excavations – first in a gym/bath-house and the second main room is a house. Although mainly rocky ruins, they have managed to salvage mosaic floors and roman roads, ceramics and other bits and pieces and it is truly amazing to think there is plenty more of this under your feet as you walk around Rome. The multimedia tour helps to bring the ruins to life.An unexpected treat at the end is about Trajan's Column, which gives a virtual reconstruction of the column in colour (as they believe it once was) and talks through what each of the scenes carved into the marble represents. The conquest of Dacia, present day Romania. It’s one of those many structures in Rome where you can’t help but wonder how the Romans managed to make it!The entry fee is a bargain for what you get, you must book in advance (we bought our ticket online) for a set time – and make sure you select the tour in your own language! There are limited tours a day so you should book as far in advance as you can. Our group was ever so slightly on the large side (it can make it hard to properly see down below the glass with a larger group) so I hope when you visit you get a smal group – but visit you absolutely must!

Conceptually Excellent. A fascinating concept tour of a palace in Ancient Rome technologically enabled with 21st century techniques. You definitely need reservations because the tour group # is limited. This tour will give you an amazing insight into the archeological challenges of excavating a city that lives below a modern city. The audio, video, laser and visual techniques are outstanding. Walking around on glass floors viewing what's beneath you is cool and unique. The only issue with this museum is sadly the human element - how sad for all the enormous effort and expense the curators put into every other aspect of the museum. The tour guide was about as engaged and interesting as the third shift barroom attendant at McDonalds. They were rude, unfriendly and downright dismissive - what a shame because this place is really spectacular otherwise!

AmAzInG!!!. This was one of the coolest museums I have ever been to in my entire life. It's a must see in Rome! It is a little tricky to find though because its located through one building and off the courtyard. Also you have to book your tour in advance. They have specific times and languages available but it is not a museum you can just walk in and pay for. You have to purchase tickets online only. The museum walks you through history and digitally recreates the buildings for you. It's all underground so it's cooler if you visit in the summer (it was 97 degrees today but WAY cooler down in the museum).You can't take any photos or videos so you feel really engaged and captivated. I highly reccemmend this museum!

Amazing experience. The museum lets you travel through an excavation site underneath the street with multimedia presentations guiding you through in each room, the tour is 1.5 hours and really helps your imagination work on other excavation sites. Photographs aren't allowed in this museum.

A hidden gem. My sister told me about this and it really is a hidden gem as been to rome before and never heard of it. You walk around the ruins and they get reconstructed around you. I would advise you to book in advance as they only have one or two english tours a day and aren't open on some days. deff worth the trip, should be on everyone's plans

A Virtual Walk Through the Past--Don't Miss It. This tour is for all ages. There is one set of stairs and the rest of the tour is flat walking on a glass floor through which you can see the ruins of a very wealthy and recently excavated Roman home. It is amazing as so much is in tact. Lights illuminate sections of the home's excavation and an audio narration explains what you are looking at. These narrations are in a variety of languages, so ask for your language when you book your tour. This tour visually brings the site to life through computer overlays and enhancements so that you can "see" what your brain is trying to imagine a place once looked like. It surrounds you so that you are part of the home as it was. I loved it! It is by far the most unique way of viewing an ancient archeological site. The tour lasts about 1 1/2 hours. There is a very small (one room) museum of some of the artifacts discovered in the excavation; however, many of the artifacts lay as they were found in the site. The museum is part of the tour and it is small; you will see it quickly and the kids won't have time to be bored. There is a small gift shop also a few minute stop on the tour, and a documentary film about the excavation going on outside the Roman house you are touring. You will have time to look at it after the film viewing, but since that site is outside and open, you can view it after the tour at your leisure. This is by far the most unique way to view a site and become part of its history. Book in advance and don't miss it. You will be so glad you saw it and viewed it both in its natural and enhanced state. So unique, so well done, and so worth it.

Do not miss!. Amazing! Even our 13 year old grandson said it was one of the coolest things he did in Rome. They have tours in different languages that you can sign up for. We got there a bit early so had lunch across the street in an A/C trattoria. Glad we did as tour 1 1/2 hours long. Spectacular - check out its website. Don't want to tell you too much as might spoil it for you!

Amazing show. This museum is the last museum we went to in Rome. It was the most magnificent, original and interesting museum tour we’ve been too. You have to book in advance first because there are shows that are in different languages. Inside, the floor is glass and beneath it are the artifacts that they show while an audio is being played to guide you. There are various types of rooms that show you different artifacts and there is a gift shop where you can purchase souvenirs. At the end they sit you down and they play a clip about how the Romans lived in the past.

It's a Must - New Antiques in Rome. After visiting Rome for so many times, I found a new attraction thanks to "Tripadvisor". You can't take photos inside, so you have to believe me, this place is great!!! You must book tickets in advance, if you want an English tour. A lot of money was invested at this site, and you'll appreciate every penny of it.

Disappointing. My husband and I booked this excursion in advance and were looking forward to it. Sadly, we did not like it much. We had a guide who was only interested in finishing the tour as fast as possible. All he was doing, was pushing the buttons for the interactive presentations in the rooms. Since I expected an old-fashioned way of things being presented (when a person actually -guides- one through the facility), I was disappointed. Maybe we just had bad luck with the guide? I would, however, recommend the tour to people with children, since there are some entertaining elements and effects, which makes the whole enterprise more or less exciting.

Remarkable. Affordable. Bookable.. Unique and a brilliant introduction to Roman life. The restoration and computer graphics give a life like view of the life of the rich and famous in Ancient Rome. Can be booked on line and at €12 is a steal. Is located very close to the wedding cake so an easy trip. Takes about 90 minutes from start to finish and in part, is air conditioned. Opened in 2010 after a 4 year project and for me, just plain brilliant.

Hidden Gem. This was one of the highlights to our visit to Rome. We booked by phone from our accommodation. I would agree with the other favorable comments made. You feel like you are in an actual Roman House. Fantastic value and nice small groups. The place is a little hard to find so do your homework and take a map. Don't miss it!!!

CALL AHEAD FOR RESERVATION.. We came here around 4:00pm and the people at the front desk told us we had to call and make reservation because you have to take a tour. The odd thing was is that when I looked at their flyer it said nothing about reservations. I think the people just didn't want to give us a tour because it was only the 2 of us and they were closing soon. They told us there was a possibility of getting a tour if we came back at 5, we waited until 5 to only be disappointed, they then offered us an Italian tour at 5:30 of course we didn't take it.

Fun and helps you imagine ancient Rome. You have to reserve your place in advance - I did this online at: http://www.palazzovalentini.it/index.php?lang=eng (click the link 'booking your visit' at the bottom right). Tickets are 11.50eur or 8eur reduced. There are a few different tours per day in English, Italian and French, and the attraction is closed on a Monday.On to the actual attraction - it is so unique! And difficult to describe. You will go underground and be walking over glass floors. Beneath the floors you will see the extensive remains and ruins of a Roman House. These are brought to life with lights and animation effects. It really does help you to envision life at the time and how the houses look, rather than just appreciating how old a ruin is. Tour groups are small (15 people) and you are led partially by a member of staff, and partially by the multimedia experience. The voice descriptions can be a bit cheesy, but it is all in the fun. It lasted about 1.5 hours total, including a video you watch at the end.I recommend visiting just after midday in the summer times as it is a cool distraction from the high temperatures.

START your trip here. This place gives you an excellent overview of life in ancient Rome and helps your imagination transform all the ruins you are about to see into their original and beautiful splendor, which can be the toughest part of being here (at least it is for me) - but this exhibit really helps you get a grasp on the amazingness of Roman civilization (as well as its bad points.) 4 adults, 1 5 year old. suitable for little ones, and GREAT for ones a little older.

Spectacular Roman Ruins. The Palazzo Valentini is a real treasure that recently opened. The tour is fantastic - small groups in English or Italian - reservations are necessary. The Palazzo was built on top of these Roman ruins - now uncovered and restored. The amazing part of the visit is that you walk above the ruins on a glass floor so that you see how the ancient Roman Villa was laid out and how people lived in it. And today's technology adds to the tour - 3D pictures are viewed on the walls to so that you can visualize how it looked in Roman times. It is remarkable!

A great surprise. A friend of mine suggested me to visit this ancient house in the heart of Rome and this was really a great value!Tourists must book their visit in advance. They can book tickets directly at Palazzo Valentini where the Province of Rome has its headquarters or at the bookstore Feltrinelli (there are many of them in Rome, the closest is in Largo Argentina) or online/on the phone with a credit card.If you buy Roma Pass the visit is included.The tour lasts almost 2 hours. It's a modern way to visit the house of a noble family in the ancient Rome because tourists walk on a glass floor that allows them to see everything under their feet. Walls, steps and everything is lighted up as the story goes on. The story teller is a famous Italian presenter of science/culture and scientific TV programm. At the end of the vist there's a part dedicated to the Traiano's column.Everything is so well explained that it's really exciting! Certainly you shouldn't miss this visit! Personally I do think it is even better than visiting Colosseum or Fori Imperiali. At Domus Romane you really understand what was going on back then and you can see videos of realistic reconstructions of the rooms.

Unbelieveable Tour of a House in Acient Rome. We couldn't believe how exciting and informative this attraction was. This "multimedia museum where antiquity meets innovation" is really just that. It totally demonstrated how life in ancient Rome was lived by the upper class. They mentioned it is currently the 3rd most popular attraction in Rome...well it just may be the best in our opinion! Bravo!

Be sure to enjoy the tour in YOUR language!. Well, that was MY fault as we took the tour with the guide speaking Italian and we speak English. Their website had been down and I'd been trying to make reservations to tour but couldn't. When it finally came back on, I forgot to check that it was an English tour. It wasn't and you'd think we wouldn't have gotten much out of it but we DID. The acrylic floor is such a different perspective and fascinating to be able to see so much while "over" an active excavation site. The hologram lights "filled in" where your imagination might have needed help. We found the time there to be well worth the money even though it was in a language we didn't understand. It's quite an extensive site and we'd recommend it to anyone. Very strange walking over a room and looking down into it!

Great Museum to see Roman Ruins Come to Life. This was an amazing museum. Located below a 16th century Palazzo and only recently "rediscovered" the ruins of two Roman villas have been unearthed and exposed for contemporary visitors. Walking over the ruins on glass floors is a bit disconcerting at first, but you do get used to it. The multimedia presentation makes the villa come to life with the recreation of the villas' walls, artwork, etc.. It's true that the tour guide is just a guide who facilitates where the group needs to move to next, but the taped tour is very informative and interesting. You should try to reserve in advance as there's only one tour a day in English. Kids really enjoy this tour. It brings ancient Rome to life in a way that they can truly relate to. Another plus is that it's indoors and cool on a hot day in Rome!

Best museum in Rome. I learned a lot from this place. It's worth it for €10. Really enjoyed it. This is an underground museum that is combined with lighting technology to represent the actual image of the ruins and gives you an idea of how a rich roman house looks like. Hard to explain but if you do go, you'll understand why I spent time writing here and recommending this place.

Unbelievable visualization of history; our favorite attraction in Rome. It can be hard to visualize ancient Roman history - where they lived, how they lived, etc. The Palazzo Valentini achieves perfect visualization through very-modern technology. The house/ancient ruins have been turned into a choreographed light and sound show, showing how they lived by highlighting areas below your feet (on a glass floor), and even using modern technology to fill in the gaps and use details to show exactly how the house would have looked like. The value is incredible, especially since it's included with Roma Pass. Just make sure you book in advance - we arrived at 2 and were able to make it into the last tour of the day.
Must see. My daughter enjoyed this very much. Worth the walk to it. Definitively one you want to add to your list.

overated. we were looking very forward to this having read the reviews and having been to rome several times before it was exciting to experience something new. the building was extremely hard to find, the tour started 20 minutes late as extra people were allowed to join and the tour guide and door person disagreed about this. the structure itself is interesting but the guide really just does direction. one fellow tour person, a very large man in size and girth, generally stood closest to highlighted areas blocking views of the others, including 3 children who were part of the group. the guide did not intervene. we ending up leaving early. way better stuff to see in rome-most of it free.

Great family experience. Fantastic experience walking above an old roman villa. Very little walking and extremely engaging with great use of audio / video to make visiting ruins exciting to all generations. Highly recommended!
An amazing look at how wealthy Romans lived and played.. Combines classical archaeology with modern technology to provide great insight into the Rome that was. Don't miss it.

excellent presentation of Roman villa and Trajan's column. This is the only modern, multi-media presentation of its kind in Rome. It does require an hour and half of time, and you must reserve in advance (by phone is the easiest). I would not recommend it for a first-time visitor who is in Rome for only a few days. For the second or third time visitor, I would rate is as a "must see." It's worth it.

Unforgettable journey. This is a tour not to be missed of the myriad of things to see in Rome. 3rd century Rome is brought to life with 3D technology and a holographic light show. You basically walk over glass floors as an interesting audio narrative takes you over the remains of this magnificent residence of a well connected Roman. Also great explanation of the scenes on the frieze the spirals across the magnificent Trajan's column. Essential to book ahead.
Must see. The tour takes hour and a half, but is very well organized. Practically you are walking on a glass ceiling and you could see how the Romans used to live.

Great visual and educational experience. We went to this museum based on the fabulous TA reviews and were not disappointed.The combination of modern technology and ancient history is a huge success. We went to a 3pm tour and were quite tired after 2 days of walking around Rome, but my 2 teenage children were kept interested throughout( no easy feat). My son commented at the conclusion of the tour that it was a really cool way to make history interesting! Make sure you book they were turning people away for our session.

A Must-See!. For around euro15, this museum is worth the time and money for any visitor to Rome. It features the ruins of a roman home presented in 21st century comfort and sensibilities. Really nicely done!!!!

Amazing experience. Truly amazing educational experience. So many wonders in Rome and Palazzo Valentini's narrated tour with a sort of hologramic light show to help fill in the banks where ruins have missing peices. Really well done! Would definitely reccomend this to any visitor who has at least 4 days in Rome. Takes you a day to do all the main sites like colosseum, spanish steps etc, then another half day or so for the Vatican and its museums, then another day for perhaps the catacombs etc and then this. If you have the time, do it! Book ahead on-line thought.
Excellent tour!. This is a fairly new tour in Rome and I would HIGHLY recommend it. Best to book tickets in advance because space is limited if I remember correctly.

Glad we saw this. We really enjoyed this tour and are so glad we booked it after reading the reviews on trip advisor .
The tour groups are small so you do need to book in advance . This villa is just amazing and the video footage really brings it to life . Well worth the visit .

BBC Time Team on speed. You know those 3d recreation animations they do on TV??? This is the same thing but projected on real ruins, while you're walking over them.
What everyone else said - helps to put it in persoective abd appreciate how ancient Romans lived... Well, the wealthy ones at least!

Didn't disappoint. Loved that the tour size is so limited. Means everyone actually gets a good vantage point throughout the tour. When dim people shuffle forward and stand in the view of everybody else, as is apt to happen on guided tours, the tour guides gently guide them back out of the way. I really appreciated that. The tour itself is fantastically orchestrated and contains fascinating, captivating information. Both my husband and I really enjoyed it.

Best archeological site seen!. You have to book a little ahead to go to this tour, and it takes a full hour-and-a-half, but it is extremely good. You walk on glass above the excavations, and it's pretty high-tech automated tour (with a guide who doesn't have to do a great deal - most of it is completely automated). Hard to explain, but it's fantastic: way better than even an experienced guide could manage: projections on the walls, animations, visual re-constructions, quasi-holographic virtual reality reconstructions, and up-close with some amazing artefacts.

Interesting, but rather too rushed and crowded. We might have been unlucky, but we felt we were being rushed through our visit to Le Domus Romane. Perhaps it was because there were 16 people in our group (I think a better maximum number would be around 12), but we found that the recorded descriptions and highlighting of the different sections had often started before all the group had assembled or even before everyone was in the room. In addition, we were quite crowded around some of the sections, making it difficult to see and appreciate what we were supposed to be looking at. This spoiled our experience of what I think could have been very interesting. A lot of work had obviously gone into the design, lighting, projections and recorded descriptions, to make it easy to imagine life for the residents and slaves in the Domus, so it was a shame that we could not take full advantage. All in all, this was probably a worthwhile visit, but I wouldn't put it above many of the other attractions of Rome, especially if you are in a large group of visitors

Great for Kids!. I found this museum as part of a family Rome tour book. It was a suggestion on how to help children envision how the Romans lived. My 8 year old daughter loved this tour. It is an active excavation site that is enhanced by lights, movies and 3D technology. The tour is very well layed out, the technology is amazing, and they limit the tour to 15 people. The tours times are scattered throughout the day because they can only have one tour in one language at one time. You can call for tour times or schedule on line. I showed up at the building at 1:30 but the first available English tour was 4:30pm. We killed sometime and went back for the tour and I am so glad we did. A highlight of Rome!!

Really glad we decided to go. Went here on the basis of TA reviews (didn't know about it previously). Thoroughly enjoyed the visit which lasted an hour and a half in total. The tour was cleverly put together, entertaining, interesting, educational, and cool in the summer heat. The staff were friendly and helpful.Worth booking as we turned up at 1pm and next available tour in English was at 5pm. As we had valid transport tickets for Rome that day we received a 2 Euro discount on each ticket (didn't expect this when we turned up!), reducing the cost to 8 Euros each.

ruins of wealthy home. Booked in advance as suggested by Trip Advisor. Lots of fun walking over and learning about what might have been in the past; the superimpositions via virtual media was excellent; the tour was abour 1 1\2 hours.

Unique Experience. Found this attraction on Trip Advisor. Having been to Rome in 2011, we hit most of the big sights and we were looking for something a little different. This hit the mark. A unique, very well done multimedia experience highliting a roman ruin beneath the city streets.The tour was offered in english and it was very well done. Walking on glass floor above the actual ruins was a unique experience and provided an opportunity to see something new for us. Would recommend if you are looking for something to do outside of the major attractions in Rome, but wouldnt prioritize it for a first time visit.

Almost missed this gem!. We initially did not plan to visit Le Domus Romane but we are so glad that we did! This is the way that all Archeological sites should be operated and it gave us fantastic insight into what life at the height of the Roman Empire must have been like. Can be a bit hard to find as it is situated inside a courtyard so make sure you have clear directions as well as the address. Well worth the euros - you won't be dissappointed!!

History comes to life. This is so worth a visit - we loved it. It brought history to life with a respectful reconstruction of a senator's house, complete with guided tour that used modern day technology to fill in the gaps and show the house as it would have been in its heyday. You do have to book in advance - our concierge said you didn't and we almost missed out as a result.

Book if you can. Well worth the visit!. Fascinating journey through history. An archeological dig brought to life in a multimedia display. You learn a lot about the site. We twinned the visit with lunch at the state-owned (?) restaurant at the bottom of the hill which serves fresh regional produce. Recommended.

A different kind of museum. This was a little difficult to find as it is located in with government offices. The tour took 90 minutes, most of that spent walking through the various rooms. You are walking on glass above the ruins and a light show depicts how the rooms would have looked. It was very interesting and I would recommend a visit.

Living ancient Rome. This was the second time I-ve seen this Domus Romano. This time I brought my sister and brother-in-law who were visiting from the U.S. They loved it. They raved about it when they got home. Why? Because it is hard to actually visualize how Romans lived. Yes, you can visit the Terme di Caracalla, The Forum, the many churches and piazzas in Rome, museums etc, etc., But this exhibition brings ancient Rome alive; you can actually see the rooms, the baths, the floors, the steps, the outdoor road, the middle age walls over the Roman domus. You can see the rain on the floor in the garden. Outstanding exhibition: a multimedia masterpiece. This year they even include a film on the Colonna di Traiano. Wow! You can actually see and UNDERSTAND the history carved on the column. All tourists should make a point of booking a guided tour. As in my title of this review, you get a chance to actually LIVE ancient Rome. A shame there aren-t more of these multimedia exhibits.

Very good. We added this to our trip after reading reviews about it on trip advisor. It was really cool to see the ruins of this house and imagine what it had looked like thousands of years ago. The lights, laser effects and narration were very good. The only think I will say is that they did have a tour guide who tried to explain things to us and he didn't speak english very well (to be the tour guide for the English tour group). That was just a minor thing as most of the tour was prerecorded. Overall the tour was excellent and I would recommend it!
Interesting. You get to see how an upper class family lived many years ago. The lights illuminate the areas the narrator is talking about.

Great find!. My wife and I are professors, and just finished teaching a semester in Rome. Unfortunately, we discovered this place after the students had already left! This would have been a superb way to explain what ancient Roman life was like, and how it became buried under the present city! Next time, this will be the first thing the students see! Glass floors throughout, plus computer graphic projections do an excellent job of recreating the ancient house. Very small, so reservations are required. Absolutely fascinating, but very new, so not many people know about it!

3D-Archeology. This is another "must see" if you are interested in ancient history and archeology. The best presentation (on this subject) i have ever seen in my life. Considering my hometown i have some museum experience..The staff is also very nice people (young ones at the desk and the staff inside). Maybe the call center wont pick up your phone for reservation. but dont give up. go there and make your reservation. it is very close to that Venezia Palace. so it is easy to stop for 5 minutes. it worths beleive me! Wonderful museum.There was a stone in front of the door. An old lady was tired and sit on it. A manager woman (i guess) shouted her in Italian. Old lady was afraid and went somewhere else to rest. It was very rude. i couldnt beleive my eyes. I am sending my regards to that woman (supervisor maybe?). if that stone is that much precious, please place it to an appropriate place.

Magically informative... A treat for the intellect and imagination!. I travel to many places and I found this to be one of my favorite experiences in Rome. The brilliant showcasing of actual ruins beneath you set to a reconstruction through visual projection is fabulous. There is an incredible amount of information conveyed in this hour and a half tour. This period in history comes alive and I am now much more able to visualize the past glory contained in other ruins.

Exciting way to learn about ancient history. We went with our chidren (8 and 10) who loved it because it helps them to visualise how Rome must have looked in Roman times. There's a lot to see, and i really thought it a bargain for such a show. Since you can only visit in small groups, you need to book. There's also an excellent movie on the column of Trajan, which explains it really well. We all loved it. Probably better than visiting the forum romanum with a guide!

A fantastic history lesson!. Make sure you book a tour here! The see through floor allows you to see the actual archeology and how they have used the information to piece together the story of this site. Well worth the money.

Wonderful site, but some things you should know in advance. What a creative way of displaying ruins. You move throughout the villa foundations, following an audio-visual presentation that shows you how the villa would have appeared in its heyday. It's really fantastic!If you are new to Roman ruins, this site is probably one of the most informative, and I would suggest it as a first stop to help you understand what you might see at Ostia Antica or Pompeii for example. If you've seen lots of Roman ruins, this one is the most uniquely presented. Please note: The site is not a Disney experience (i.e. suitable for all ages and physical abilities). The site could be improved with web bookings and more helpful front desk staff.I would highly recommend this site for the vast majority of travellers, but there are some things that others might benefit from knowing:1) The tour itself is underground in an, at times, dimly lit, ancient ruin. Anyone with compromised mobility or eyesight might find this a real difficulty. 2) Many of the floors are glass (which gives and excellent view of what's below). Some people might find this disorienting to walk on.3) The audio acompaniment is informative, clear and easy to follow (I did my tour in Italian, so I am assuming the English version is of the same quality). However, the guide would collect the group and give little chats, often in cramped viewing platforms. Unless you were at the very front of the group, it was impossible to hear what the guide was saying.4) If you have a Roma Pass: Although this site is included in the pass, you still have to book it in advance. This is easy to do over the phone and can be done well in advance. There are tours in various languages, and the English ones appear to sell out the most quickly. The phone staff (very helpful) will ask for credit card payment, so be sure to say you have a Roma pass. I agree with other reviewers that the desk staff are unhelpful and borderline rude (even if you deal with them completely in Italian). 5) The place you pick up tickets is tucked inside in the courtyard of the main building, so give yourself time to find it. After reading this on previous reviews, we decided to drop by the day before to find the site and to to confirm our booking.6) It's sort of a one-way tour, so some parents may want to encourage kids to use the bathroom before heading into the underground. Some younger children might find it a bit loud and dark (i.e. scary)7) Some people might find it clautrophobic, but on the other hand, you are in a small group and there is plenty of space away from the viewing platforms.I think most travellers would have an awesome experience, especially a first-time visitor to Rome. Highly recommended!

Add it to your list.... These ruins were beautifully displayed in a museum quality atmosphere. It was a pleasure to be on the tour as it was a small group. Don't go if you are clautrophophic....it takes a minute to get used to the sensation of walking on see through floors.
Gem. All we can say is the facts speak for themselves. This is an extremely informative tour of what did happen and just as interesting, what may have happened. Don't miss it

cool, calm, collected and most instructive. This is a very interesting visit well presented with a group of 15 persons maximum. The black mark is the need to reserve solely by phone (the tours are often sold out in advance).No online bookings,and the people at reception are of no help.That said once in there it is 1h30 of agreeable time travel back in ancient Rome (with air conditioning ). One of our more pleasant souvenirs of Rome

Great multimedia display, book ahead. Serves as a great intro to Rome - we were glad that we did it toward the beginning of trip as it provided some very useful background information, and we were definitely more tuned to the architectural details of the ruins we visited later. The segment on Trajan's column was also very good.They do either one or two English tours per day, limited to about 20 people per tour. So make sure you book ahead. My children (7 and 9) enjoyed it very much, although younger children may find it a little scary as the tour was conducted in the dark with very dim lights most of the time.

palazzo valentini. Excellent , had read about this on Tripadvisor and pre booked as advised, could have sold our tickets 3 times over such was the demand, so glad we didn't, walking on the glass floor is a bit strange but worth it, 3D show was clever and explained so much giving an insight into other ruins such as the Forum, Ostia Antica , Pompeii and a very good explanation to Trajan's Column (in colour too!!).

Overrated by some on here. Decided to try the Domus Romane only due to its high TripAdvisor rating and the very good reviews some people were giving it. Didn’t want to miss something special. In our opinion though, it wasn’t worth doing after all. What you see is not anything out of the ordinary in a city littered with Roman remains. The recreations they display isn’t anything you haven’t seen on any roman drama on television and they the last half hour is a dissecting of the tale told on the relief of Trajans column, which any decent guidebook or internet site on the subject would do nearly as much. The 90 minute tour and the time getting there and waiting around could have been spent much better doing something else in Rome. I personally found it annoying that some people on the tour were talking continuously throughout it. Obviously people who didn’t understand English and only booked the English tour because there wasn’t one in their language. You’d think they’d have the manners to respect that others can understand English and are trying to listen to the tour audio.

worth seeing. If you are freaked out by walking on clear glass, don't go - it takes a bit of getting used to for some, and the guide was unsympathetic, to put it mildly. The effects are maybe a little too clever - the site is fascinating in its own right. The video at the end unpicking the meaning of the images on Trajan's column was fascinating. Allow 1.5 hours and book ahead.

do not miss this. I visited Le domus Romane in January so i didn't need to book. This is how touristic tour must look like in 21 century! Absolutely perfect! They put allot of effort to make everyone feel for a second like he arrived in history! There are amazing special effects that together with old ruins bring you special experience and only in this way one is really able to imagine how old Rome looked like! I suggest it to every tourist like one of best Rome sight!

Interesting. We booked this in advance...english tour...I think we were the only two that spoke english...the guide probably answered more questions in Italian which took away from our experience...his English was adequate at best...the audio taped portion was excellent...the video at the end about Trajans column was outstanding...this could have been our AHA moment in Rome if we were in an all English group...6 or 7 people joimed the group at the last second (Italians) which is why we didn't get the full effect...after all said, this very easily would have been 5 stars...I would recommend this, only if they promise you what you paid for.

Bringing the past to life. An excellent tour of the remains of old roman mansions, while walking on glass floors that are a little distance above the ancient floors. If only we could have those mosaics and spa facilities in our own house! After seeing the foro romanum this exhibition is more gratifying because it uses modern technologies (lighting, sound and digital effects) to recreate how the rooms looked like when they were still lived in. When we visited in April 2013 all the technical problems reported by other travelers seemed to be resolved.Just keep in mind that tours need to be booked well in advance, as they only allow 20 persons at a time. If you can't cope with standing for a long time, this may not be for you. The visit lasts for a good 1,5 hours and there's not many chances to sit and have a break. Well, not until you get to the second part of the tour: the movie analyzing the story depicted on Trajan's column, a great complement and very well explained. Afterwards you will see the column from a different point of view!

would be great with kids. Good tour of the remains of a Roman 1st century house beneath a Renaissance palazzo. With the use of computers and projectors they reconstruct the house as it might have been

Excellent place. The best in rome if you want to really understand and see how a roman house was. Brillant idea with light reconstruction of building. It's better than anything else! a must see you cannot miss! especially for young people. if you visit this first you may undestand better the forum and other historical sites in rome.

The Surprise Site. I found this on trip advisor and decided to put it on our schedule as a surprise for my husband, daughter and son-in-law. I booked the English Speaking tour and kept it a secret until time for the tour. You will need to prebook and purchase your tickets prior to arrival. I checked the site before we left and there had been some concerns that the projections in some of the rooms were having technical difficulty but when we arrived, it was working perfectly and our guide guided us to the exact spots that we should be standing in order to enjoy the site to the fullest. We had a small group as 4 people that had booked did not show up, but it starts right on time. Do not be late. We enjoyed this and my family is still talking about it. It is wonderful and very well done. Congratulations to all who worked on this presentation.

Wow - do not miss this, it is a must visit. This is the best, the very best. ,and a booking as the tour groups are very small and you need the English tour or you will miss so much of the detail. Exceptional ruins under a 16th century palazzo, with the detail brought to life with light, commentary and recreations. Very very clever and very special. The glass floors are a little disconcerting at first but worth the effort.
Cool. Interesting visual effects helping reconstructing those days, where ancient Romans use to have fun and live. Worth it!

Not impressed. After having read all the amazing reviews about this place my expectations were high. Maybe too high, and maybe that was the problem. I was a little disappointed and thought that I could have spent my money some place else. The tour is ok. We walked around the basement of the building , looking through the glass floors under which are the ruins of an old roman house of almost 2000 years ago. With some projections of lights and colors they try to recreate the house the way they think it was, based on evidence they found, and at the same time they give us a lot of information about their history.I guess if you have plenty of time in Rome you can spare a couple of hours on this place. But if you are on tight schedule - we were there for 4 full days - I would suggest other amazing places.

Brings Ancient Rome To Life. Visited this site due to trip advisor reviews and booked tickets well in advance. Really difficult to find. We walked round for an age and when we asked a bar owner near Trajan's Column, he pointed down! We were standing on top of it. To find the entrance, you need to go to round to the other side of this building, there you see a courtyard , guarded by security. On showing them details of the attraction, we were let through. There is a small coffee shop here too which we were told was for the local police, but tourists are allowed to use it too. Really cheap coffee and a great stop before and after the tour. Probably the cheapest refreshments in town but probably not accessible due to security for non users of the tour. There is also a toilet next door, with no queue! Worth keeping in mind for emergencies as Rome is notorious for its lack of public toilet facilities!You begin the tour by going down a glass ramp over the original staircase. A really strange sensation, but you soon get used to it. You then pass from room to room , standing all the time on a glass floor and looking down as various areas that light up and on occasions an animation also takes place, bringing the room back to life.  Our two children, both 8-9 were kept engaged in a concept that is difficult to excite the young, especially when they saw children's images and their voices recreated. Lots of details were given that gave areal flavour for life in Rome during the period of Empire and the lighting effects were very clever. English actor narrates which helps - the tour is classy and put together xyremely well. Earlier reviewers mentioned a video about Trajan's column, this was not available to us, but we did see the base of the column using a tunnel from WW2. We almost missed this part though as the tour guide led us into the shop and we presumed this was the end. A great tour and definitely worth doing if you want to discover what life was like for the wealthy roman urbanite (the sophistication and quality of life for the wealthy is jaw dropping) but for us this attraction loses a point as we were denied the Trajen video which would have topped off the tour as this was virtually next door to the ancient house and an important view for the residents of the time.

Great experience. Great experience but not the best attraction in Rome. I think in my opinion the best thing to do in Rome is just like going around the city with a bicycle. Rome is an open-pit museum itself.

Very annoying experience. First of all, for non Italilian speaker, this place sits inside the building of "Provincia Di Roma", i passed and missed this multiple times before finding it! secondly, you meed to make a reservation as each group can only consist 15 person (+39 0632810), thirdly they are closed on Tuesday.

dont miss it. its something different , Went there without booking . It was easy to get inside although the comments I ve read about pre booking .Its all about a villa discovered and brought to life using technology

A fascinating and informative tour. I found this tour both interesting and informative and was particularily impressed by it's audio visual presentation on the story of Trajan's column. You must pre book the tours in advance online to ensure that you secure a place.

Definitely worth it!!. This is a must see! Great historical perspective to show you how Rome was during it's glory. The "ruins" are brought to life by great lighting displays. You can really not just imagine it but actually see it!The price for this over one hour tour is unbeatable! They only take small groups at a time which is great. I imagine it is also nice and cool during the summer to get away from the heat.The entire ruins were not open during our visit due to technical issues, but I would definitely go back to visit again!There is a good amount of walking on glass as you walk above the ruins, but they keep the rooms dark because of the lighting which helps not feeling like you are going to fall! Just one glass staircase at the beginning, then it's all pretty much on the same level.

It was OK..... I was pretty excited to see this from previous reviews. It was certainly a unique and informative experience presented in a very cool way, and we DID enjoy it...however...it was just too long. We did not stay for the last section as our feet were very sore and lower back pain from walking and standing on hard surfaces (you will understand after walking around Rome for 3-4 days). When we asked to exit early the tour host seemed somewhat miffed....but oh well. It was worth it, but I would recommend they cut it shorter by 20 min....

Must see.. This is one of those must see tours. Don't want to spoil it by giving too much away but if you are really into Rome history you won't be sorry you carved out the time. No walks ups must buy on line and in advance. Limited to small group and limited showings. ( language presentation) A lot of high tech support so if you are going just make sure everything is working as apparently it has had a malfunction recently. (Not on our watch)That aside it would still have been an interesting tour and for the value can't be beat.

Mar13. Quite difficult to find, but worth the visit. Bit strange at first walking on glass, but interesting and worth the visit. You are walking over the ruins of a home and graphics help to show what it would have looked like

Interesting display of the layers of history. I learned about the Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini on TripAdvisor and decided to go there our first day in Rome - it seemed like a great way to ease into our vacation, taking into account jet-lag, etc. I highly recommend this tour, though the day we went there were technical difficulties with one of the tapes so we were escorted to a separate room while they rebooted the tape. After the problem was corrected we went back (adding disjointed down time to the tour). The guide did his best to fix the issues, and all was resolved in due time. Our guide, while quite pleasant, did not have good command of the English language (there are several English language tours a day, and we supposedly were on one). He tried his best to convey the information - but I think the experience would have been 5 star if we had a guide that was more fluent. The Domus itself is quite interesting, and the original walls, floors, etc, are displayed in a unique fashion using plexiglass (see-through) floors, etc, so that you can see the layers of history under your feet. It can be a bit dizzying to walk up and down the plexiglass stairs, so someone that has balance issues might find it challenging.I would definitely recommend this site, but hope they will hire tour guides with better English language skills for the English Language Tours.

Very Interesting. We went to this place due to all the good reviews in Trip Advisor and it didn't disapoint. you do need to book in advance as it's quite popular. The experience of walking over so much history is quite exciting and amazing, the audio comentary explains quite well what your looking at. On a down side I felt that our guide rushed the first part of the tour and didn't explain wha we were looking at but the Audio comentary did cover what he flew through. I don't want to say to much so as not to spoil the experience but its a wonderful way to help show what the runins your looking at might have looked like. Defo worth a visit.If you have a Roma Pass you can use it for this attraction so if its your first/2nd use of your card its free.

Did I expect too much??. I guess Domus Romane is ok for a visit. If I hadn't read all the raving reviews on tripadvisosr, I would probably have expected less and possibly been more impressed with this place. Our 'English speaking' guide didn't speak much English and there were times during the tour that he was supposed to tell us things, but the recorded information that was played during the tour was good, clear, and loud, and we probably learned enough from it. Walking on a transparent floor is a unique experience! Took me a while to trust that I wouldn't fall to the floor below! Walking on it confronted me with angst at first, and continued to amuse me! I'm probably a little jaundiced in feeling that if you've seen one ruin, you've seen them all. What you see in Domus Romane is remarkable, but what do you see in Rome that isn't remarkable? I'm not unhappy I went, but I wouldn't go a second time. Would I recommend it? I'm not sure. But I wouldn't try to discourage you from going if you told me you were going.On the other hand, I really liked the short film at the end about Trajan's Column!If you decide to go to Domus Romane, here's how to get there...THE FIRST WAY TO GET THERE - If you go to Trajan's Column (which is across the street from the huge, white Victor Emanuel monument), you will be right across the smaller street from a grey building with the word "PREFECTURE" over the door. That's the building, and this is the 'back door'. Go in this door, and go straight ahead through the next door. Keep going and you will find yourself in a small, nondescript courtyard. Cross the courtyard, keep going and you will end up in a big, real courtyard. The Domus Romane office is all the way down on the right.THE SECOND WAY TO GET THERE - The main entrance to the building faces Quatro de Novembre street, and is immediately across the street from MUSEO della CERE (The Wax Museum, in English.) and that name is emblazoned across a very visible yellow background and stretches along the top of the ground floor above the door to the Museo della Cere. Go into the big courtyard of the "PREFECTURE" building and the Domus Romane office is the first one on the left.Tours are limited to about 15 people. We went in mid March and our English tour was full. There are two English tours a day.There is a very small, limited service cafe next door. It has a few cold sandwiches in a glass case, and various drinks. The toilets for the courtyard offices ares next to the cafe.Spirit

Very Cool. Going into this my husband swore this was going to suck because it wasn't in his tour guide. Coming out he was blown away. It is a hidden gem and a great value compared to other sights in the city. I loved the light shows and the intimacy of the "museum-y" sections of the tour. We booked an English tour and while we didn't have any trouble understanding our guide, one of the families had trouble understanding him. It probably helped this was the third set of baths we had toured so we knew exactly what he meant when he was explaining the rooms. The main focus of the tour is a mansion, probably belonging to a senator, but at the end you get to see a couple giant columns from the nearing forgotten Temple of Trajan that stood near his Column. At the very end he showed us a passage that was part of an wary 20th century bunker that comes out near the foot of the Column it was an unbelievable view.

Unforgettable!. This was a stunning, educational, and visually delightful experience. We were unaware that one should have reservations, but we were lucky enough to find availability on the next tour conducted in Italian. We know just enough Italian to have had no problems understanding the tour, but if you do not speak some Italian it is better to book the English tour. The tour lasted a little over an hour and was fascinating from start to finish. It was wonderful to watch how the Italians of all ages in our group delighted in this multimedia glimpse into an ancient Roman home. There is nothing phoney or overly animated about this tour as you are in the underground ruins of a real Roman villa. Before Nero's Domus Aurus was closed to the public we had the chance to tour it and we agree that Le Domus Romane was a better experience.

Great Presentation. After seeing countless ruins throughout Rome and Ostia, we really appreciated the videos and graphic displays recreating this site. From the remaining mosaics, art work and marble the excavators were able to present what is probably a fairly accurate depiction of a wealthy life style at the peak of Rome's power. Judging by the lavishness of the home and the prime location next to Tajan's column, I would guess this was the home of a very wealthy Roman, perhaps a senator or general. The videos brought the ruins to life and gave me a greater appreciation of other sites in the city that have been scavenged of their precious materials. The video explanation of Trajan's column was very informative and entertaining.Our guides english was adequate and answered my questions to my satisfaction.

Fantastic. After reviewing the good recommendations from Trip Advisors, we decided to see this museum. The exhibition is interesting. The only thing I want to mention is buying tickets. We read from Palazzo Valentini’s own website that the admission is 10 Euro and the booking fee is an addition of 1.5 Euro per person. Since we have a group of 10 people, we thought we would buy the tickets when we get there and will only pay 10 Euro each person. No, No. They do not sell tickets at the entrance. All visitors need to either book the tickets on line or by telephone, in another word, the 1.5 Euro per person booking fee is to be paid one way or another. We end up booking the tickets on line and going back the next day.

Interesting but not all rooms working. The exhibition was interesting especially in some of the projections we were shown to help better visualise what the house would have looked like when it was being used. Unfortunately many of the rooms were not working with the sound and light projection system so we had to rely on a guide to point things out to us. Our guide did not seem to speak very good english so we did not get much out of most of the rooms. (Note that we joined the english tour so we did expect decent english). Perhaps when/if it gets fixed this will be more worthwhile to visit, however as i saw it I would not recommend this.

Insight into living in Ancient Rome. This a very interesting tour showing the remains of a Roman Mansion and also a virtual presentation of how it might have looked when occupied in the 2nd century. Our tour guide had adequate rather than fluent English which made some of the details less than clear, and deterred one from asking any questions, but the audio commentary was in clear English. It is advisable to book ahead as the tour groups are small.

Interesting but...... We had great expectations, after reading the Tripadvisor comments and after twice failing to get in (it is not clear how to get tickets - finally one of the guards / policemen that stands outside the Palazzo (government office) said to call the telephone number). After sorting out booking the tickets (by telephone - i must say it was one of the best automatic telephone queuing services i have used) we did enjoy the tour of the excavation. Standing directly above the ruins, on a glass floor, was disorientating. Our main complaint was that we did not have enough time in each section. Lights went on and off and if you were not in the right position you missed the object being talked about. An extra 5 minutes in each room with all the lights on would have made the experience complete for us. It is an interesting tour. They deserve recognition for the way the ruins are preserved and creating an innovative tour but we do not think it deserves the hype.
Fantastic tour. After seeing this being posted as the #3 thing to do in Rome we decide to check it out and only 10 euros we didnt expect what we saw. It was an incredible tour! Highly recommend it!!

Average experience, over rated.. I visited the Domus on March 11th. We were looking forward to being able to see the ruins, find out the history behind them and see the much talked about 'bringing to life', whilst we did experience this and what we did see was informative the whole experience could have been much better and definitely did not live up to the hype created on trip advisor. We bought our tickets online the day before, this sells fast so book early if you do want to experience it, they were 10 each plus 1.50 processing fee, you can also buy them from the bookstore in largo Argentina. You pick the physical ticket up on the day at the office.Upon entering you are led down some stairs to the first room, be warned the majority of the experience is walking upon glass floors! Which does take a little getting used to! The experience started off well and the narration explains the ruins below whilst brining them to life using very modern technology, which in fairness was very impressive and a great way of getting you to imagine the ruins, and see exactly what part of the ruins is what. You also see some videos of what the room may have looked like and are asked to imagine what the house was like.After the first room, the whole experience on this occassion went downhill. The second and third narrated parts were not working, nor were the multimedia effects. We pretty much skipped them as the guide didnt give too much information, whilst he probably was knowledgable there may have been a language barrier. We then browsed artifacts, before having to rush back to the next room as the show had stared and no one had told us!The experience continues and you learn more about the house, the next two areas were fully immersive with the multimedia effects, I wont explain what you learn as you'll find out when your there! Part way through our guide changed to a young gent who's english wasn't great, the next room was skipped for some reason, i'm not sure if many of the group noticed it, but there was a whole area skipped before walking out to the part way through gift shop... the reason was probably that the voice and effects were broken. We learned nothing here, and were led to a waiting area for five minutes.The end gives you an insight into the Trajan Column outside, which was interesting, you sit and watch a video and then are led to see the column. The experience should take 1hr and 30 minutes, we were definitley not in there for that long because of the broken narration and effects.We found the whole experience unorganised and average as we missed out on three parts due to the difficulties. If you like history and want to learn more then go for it, we found some parts very interesting but the whole experience was disappointing.
Fantastic Experience. This amazing exhibit allows the visitor to immediately and clearly imagine the everyday life in ancient Rome. Make it a must on your visit.

Extremely overrated. When I saw it on #1st place from all Rome attraction I expected much more.First we watched movie about Trajan column - which was quite interesting - but be honest - better one are viewed on Discovery ChannelThen we wander around the house - domus - The guide almost didn`t speak english. fortunately there was english lector. telling about history, domus and describing showing laser and holographic images.We weren`t amused.All what I was thinking about was to get the hell out of there . The lecture was boring - the laser and holographic projections were not very good nor interesting. IT was ruin of house - you can see all those mosaics, floors baths and marbles in different parts of Rome without need of multimedial help. You couldn`t even ask guide about anything - he speaks almost no english - all he did was getting us from place to place without any further explanation - we could only hear for english reader during the projections.Please be aware of its high rating - for me it is terribly overrated - we had much more fun in Leonardo Da vinci genius museum where were interactive replicas of his machines..

A unique exhibit. The exhibit is 'brought to life' by little bits of CGI. At the beginning ancient Rome was reconstructed, then throughout the tour walls and mosaics were 'rebuilt' inside the villa. Towards the end there was a really interesting explanation of the Trajan Column. We felt this was worth booking tickets for.

Overrated. I went here on my last day in Rome and wish I had spent my time differently. It is midly interesting but not for the price and does not compare to Rome's many other attractions. This would be an entertaining options for people to choose if they have children but otherwise I would suggest giving it a miss and spending your time elsewhere.
Great great. Great great place to visit. Uses lasers, 3D tech, and old ruins to show you what the old mansion used to look like. Unbelievable experience. Very highly recommended.

Wonderful 'new' find. Very interesting guided tour with great audio visual effects, which brings the place to life as there are only fragments of the domus uncovered. It is a bit scary walking over the glass floors viewing the rooms below! We did not book in advance, but called in and bought our tickets, which were timed, so we returned an hour or so later (Villa Borghese has a similar system). We loved the story of Trajan's Column which showed in detail on screen the wonderful carvings on the marble column, which you couldn't see with the naked eye as the column is so high. This is well worth a visit.

Amazing. It is a hidden gem!! It really is! There aren't many advertisements regarding this place as it is hidden and relatively new. Opening its door in 2010; and to say the least well presented, very good graphics and extremely good for all the tourists who have had to bare the "italian accent" as this is all recorded from an english professional. It really gives u an insight to what Rome was and how things were built, i'm not going to ruin your amazement as you'll pleasantly surprised.For tourist information: you need to book one day in advance online so you assure your ticket especially during tourist seasons (summer).From your roman born adviser!

"Rome. A lifetime is not enough". I don't know where this place was on my 6 previous trips, but I'm glad it came to my attention this time. Starts slow but builds, with an excellent ending video on Trajan's Column. Not for those with equilibrium difficulties or a fear of the dark. The sensation of walking on plexigalss (or whatever) takes a little getting used to. I don't see it as a #1 attraction, but it can certainly make a top 20 list. I booked the "English" tour on line with no difficulty. If you happen to be a grandparent, it happens to be a two minute walk from "Little Big Town", Rome's new, largest in country (4 story), excellent toy store ( and "yes" grandma, they'll ship ).
Very interesting. It relates the history of a domus and the story engrave on the "colonna di traiano".The visit is a little too short.

Evocative multimedia visit. Walking on a glass floor on top of the archaeological finds, you get a true idea of the ancient Roman villas/palaces discovered here, with virtual reconstructions, sound, light, explanations... You walk through the villas and baths, as it were. Very well done !
