Absolutely worth the visit, but don't expect to walk in.. Visiting this combination of ruins and technology was very interesting. You really get a feel for how the people here lived, and I'm unaware of anything else like it in Rome.The tour is a multimedia experience overlayed on actual ruins of a palatial home that gives you a feel of how life was for the occupants of this manse.You have got to plan ahead for this, however, since the tickets are limited and take a couple days (and weeks ahead is much better) advance planning to acquire. Highly recommended.

Bringing history to life.. This is an amazing place to visit. You have to book in advance and be part of a guided tour. If you aren't really interested in history it may not be to your taste but we loved it. You are taken downstairs, under the Palazzo, where you walk on glass floors. Lights are switched on to show the house remains under your feet and projections on the walls give a real feeling of how it used to be. The tour lasts one and a half hours.

Interesting Use of Technology. In the same way a planetarium projects on the ceiling constellations and sparks your imagination, they've done it with archaeology and made ancient history much more relatable. I don't think people know of the Roman's love affair with color, and they use projectors to show designs and patterns of long gone frescoes over the plain brick wall.In order to preserve the excavation work, they have you walk a few feet above it on glass floors. It sort of, heightens your experience; it's interesting to see the structures light up beneath you, but I felt a little nervous at first!You also get a neat presentation of Trajan's Column.I hope to see more archaeological sites presented this way in the future.

Our favorite place in Rome!. After seeing all the usual cathedral and Ancient ruins this place is my favorite as its really very interesting as described by many trip advisors travelers.You won't be bored as there are special effects and introduction so you could visualize what the ruins were like before as you are not simply staring at a pile of rubbles,concretes etc without a clue.

Bringing a slice of Ancient Rome to life... After seeing hundreds of statues of gods and emperors and dozens of impressive ruin sites this place offers something more: computer-generated effects help us to visualise exactly how an opulent bath house and villa appeared in the days of the Roman Empire, alongside a fascinating commentary about the property and of Trajan's Column. My boyfriend and I thoroughly enjoyed this attraction and would recommend it to people of all ages (with the exception of the very young).
Exceptional interest and value. An amazing hour and a half review of this particular historic house which is very well presented. Book in advance if possible.

A great display well worth a visit. Its a great place. A 15th century grand house built over the top of a 1st century grand house. You go underground to see the ancent ruins. They use projectors to show you the ruins as they once stood. You learn a lot here. Well worth a visit

Very interesting, but crowded!. This was a complete surprise! They have used cutting-edge projector technology to recreate a typical Italian Domus. They used sounds, narration, plexiglass floors and projection technology to show us how the ruins we see one meter below our feet actually looked like, on the ruins themselves! One bad thing is the fact that the group size is too big (15 - 20 people) for such small environments, so sometimes people would simply miss the fast projections and would not be able to move from point A to B in time, while things were lit up. They should really consider limiting the number of people to 10 - 12 (max) at a time. Also, they were out of water when I went, so the café and bathrooms were not working properly.

Ancient Rome comes alive. The one and a half hour tour gives a very good idea of some aspects of how a 2nd or 3rd century AD wealthy Roman household might have lived. The remains of the two homes and the private baths come alive with the coloured projections used to evoke the past grandeur. You still need to use your imagination, but it is easier than with just bricks to look at. The second part of the tour focuses on other structures that were found during the archeological dig. It is all so well presented that I was left with a feeling of wonder and a desire to go on the tour again.
The best Rome can offer. Our favorite attraction in Rome, hands down. If you have an explorer personality, and a fan of ancient relics, this secret palace is the right place for you.

#2 attraction in Rome, REALLY?. Maybe interesting for multiple time visitors of Rome... unless you're really into history and archeology, don't waste your precious time here. It was a beautiful day outside and I wish I had spent my last 2 hour in Rome elsewhere. Even just strolling around the city or sitting at the sidewalk cafe and watching people go by would have been more worthwhile.

interesting trip back in roman ages. reserved one day before bec there were a couple of holes, enjoyed every single moment of this experience back in a roman ancient house, and helped a lot by modern technology, amusement meets understanding how a really existing roman domus can be explained today, and multimedia helps a lot. definitely to recommend!
surprise. A great surprise!!! and very interesting...Great effects. When I'll come back in Rome i would like to visit Le Domus again
Very well done archeology. It added life to the archeology. We had visited the Forum the day before, and, while that was good, this added the humanity to the site.

Extraordinary voyage into ancient Rome. The site is built on 2 roman villas found under the Provincia Palace. The 3D multimedial reconstruction is accurate and sophisticated. The voice comment is well done. It's a must for tourists coming to Rome, as it combines real walls, floors, ruins with images and special effects. It's like being in a Universal attraction but in the real Rome!The new part with close view of Colonna Traiana is excellent. Congratulations to the project organizers. Cons: at the beginning it is difficult to get use to darkness and stairs

Excellent tour in English. We had been here several years ago and the tour we took was in Italian, which we neither speak nor understand. This time we were able to book a tour in English. Of the 15 members in the group, we were the only English speakers. The number of tours is limited so I guess people book tours in whatever language is available.The tour was narrated and evrything was explained as you walked through the underground house. There were lots of video enhancements to help you visualize how the house actually was. The tour was very informative and interesting. I highly recommend it and suggest you buy tickets ahead of time, since it sells out in all languages.

Amazing production value, this was fascinating.. High quality ruins that are still being worked, and you walk over the actual sites on a glass floor. The laser light and sound show goes on and on, and the final film that 'unwinds' the story told on Tajan's column just outside was fascinating. What a find- this was in none of our guide books as it is so new. Be sure to book in advance, as there were only 2 english tours per day of only about 20 people. The costof 12 Euro was so low for the 90 minutes of great education/entertainment. Bonus- great coffee shop next door inside the courtyard, must be for the employees of the building, as the 1 Euro cappucino was top notch.
A great surprise and very interesting. A great surprise and very interesting, booked it on line as we wanted to be sure we did the English tour. Great visual effects.

Educational and interesting. Le Domus was the perfect way to learn more about the history of Rome and its buildings. The multimedia presentations and the immersive nature of the experience mean that Roman history really comes to life. The tour would be great either at the beginning of your trip (to give you the background on some of the monuments you will be visiting) or at the end (to fill in the blanks about the monuments you have seen throughout your stay). Either way works. Do make sure you book in advance as even in January, the tours fill up.

Great display. This is a very professional presentation. One walks on glass floors (unsettling to me) and graphics are projected on the archeological remains below. There is also a wonderful film on the Column of Trajan which is just outside the building.
Fabulous. Two recently discovered ancient Roman patrician houses; fabulously presented - full laser illumination, done with tremendous good taste and discretion.

Fantastic!. This is an amazing excavation of a villa from imperial rome which is under an existing government building . We did the English tour . The way the tour is done with projections onto the excavation as you walk above it on a glass floor is excellent . We gained a clear idea of the way the building would have been at the time . I booked the tour some weeks before and found the online site very difficult to book through . In the end I rang directly through and booked very easily over the phone . Our three teenagers enjoyed this site , and I would recommend this for any families.

Must See but Reserve Early. Quite well done - ancient ruins uncovered in the basement are pretty much a dime a dozen in Rome but this tour uses some virtual technologies to help almost anyone see what the archaeologists see. Not as mind-blowing as the necropolis under St Peter's but very good and easier to get tickets.
Nice experience in Rome. Very interesting visit, a modern and new way to find out about the past. Highly recommended for children also.

This was a totally rewarding experience.. It's true that one has to follow the instructions for booking, but it wasn't as difficult as some reviews have made it seem. There were also some crazy rules about where to enter the piazza that contains the entrance, but the hassles were well worth the experience. This was so worthwhile for the lessons in Roman living and the views of what this villa actually looked liked. A very very worthwhile experience. There were steps and some crowded areas and the attraction is underground, so it is best to be aware if these things are a problem for you or anyone in your party.

Wonderful mix of----. archeology, history, science, entertainment and multi media! Even if you were not interested, at all, in archiac construction, you will be fascinated by the multi media imposition on the structures which make the rooms "come alive" to appear as they were originally. These rooms were clearly not the domain of the lower class, nor even the equestrian, so we gain access to a building that had to have been very exclusive in its interiors when it was occupied by its owners. This is a wonderful two hours or so and well worthy of the ten euros and your time.

Best way to see the "layers" of Rome. This was a great example of the underground discoveries of Rome. We had just arrived that day and after the long overnight flight, we were exhausted. I would have loved it even more if I had been more awake. Good way to start off a trip to really appreciate the ruins you will be seeing.

Wander through history ,thanks to modern technology. A real insight into life in Rome through the ages,our kids enjoyed it considering a lot of stuff has been "boring" for the 12 year old.technology allows a real concept of living spaces in ancient wealthy Rome ,the tour in English is good,just make sure you book in advance.Two landmarks nearby (or 3 if you count Palazzo Vittorio Emanuele II just around the corner) are the waxworks diagonally opposite and the Little Bigtown Toystore next door on the downside of the hill.

History comes to life!. Most visitors to Rome are surely 'into' history. It surrounds you on every side, nowhere moreso than in this totally immersive multimedia experience of domestic life in Ancient Rome. My husband and I have both studied this period, taught history and visited many museums, but this display took our breath away. Be prepared - you must book (small groups are taken through the site separately), and be up for the nearly two hours' presentation. There is a lovely voila moment near the end! It is altogether an emotional and vivid experience.

A very different but no less interesting experience of Ancient Rome. This is definitely one to see when you have seen the other important sites in Rome and are looking for something a little different. It can be a little difficult to find as the Palazzo is a government building and you have to go in past the police guard and it might seem like the wrong place at first. Make sure you book in advance as we had to take the tour in Italian due to no space on the English one. Once that is done, though you will love the experience. You step across glass floors - a little disconcerting at first in the dark- but specific areas are lit against the dark backdrop under your feet in time with the commentary and reveal interesting and beautiful architectural features. You can clearly see how Rome is layered century upon century and the tour recreates in 3D projections directly on to the ruins just how it would have appeared in its time. It is also a much more serene experience than the more famous attractions being mostly underground and guided tour only. We loved it and will go again.

Very Interesting but a little boring. If you really are into history then you will love this. Whilst it was very interesting and it was presented in a very professional manner, it was a tad boring and it did feel like I was 14 again and on a school field trip.

An absolute MUST. Having read reviews on Tripadvisor, this looked like a high priority visit and we weren't disappointed. Make sure you book in advance as there are only 2 English tours per day and only 16 people are allowed on each tour. The tour, conducted in excellent English takes you to the uncovered remains of the palace of a very rich Roman. Boring, you may say? Not so! You walk over glass walkways and each interesting item is illuminated as the commentary tells you about it. The genius, however, is what happens then. Using brilliant CGI graphics, the mosaic floor is completed in front of your eyes, the walls rise up and are decorated and you see how it would have looked in its heyday. There is a separate, and equally brilliant, CGI presentation about Trajan's Column. The tour lasts about 90 mins and is right for children as well as adults. By a country mile it is the best 90 mins you will spend in Rome

must do activity. If u have seen all imp sites in Rome, finish off with this one n you ll feel complete . this place is very well presented n is about 1.5 hours long. Its got a great detail of information of how archaeologist s findings etc, movies . this is definetly a must do. Book a day in advance n u should be sweet.

Good summary of archeology.. I found this on the internet and booked before arriving in Rome. The group I was in was just the right size; amything more than a dozen and it would be crowded. The overlay projections worked quite well, and as we have already just seen most of Rome's ancient sites, it all made so much more sense.

History and technology a highlight in Rome. You cannot miss this amazing place... the ticket office may not be exceptionally friendly but the tour is fantastic! Its a unique opportunity to gain more insight into ancient Rome and the incredible architecture and lifestyle! Dont miss it!

Best archeological exhibit I've visited in Rome. This subterranean visit to the remains of two private houses from the imperial age of ancient Rome is spectacular. The exhibit structure, the narrative and explanations and overall multimedia visit were just top-notch. My 14-year-old daughter and I loved it. It's the most professional archeological exhibit I've visited in Rome. (Complimenti al Fondazione Roma and its partner organizers.) The multimedia explanation of Trajan's column was excellent and the next surprise was the perfect end to the visit. I only wished that we had had a little more time to view some of the ruins and ask questions of the guide. Also, the lighting in the first rooms could have lasted longer so that visitors could take more in. Make reservations well in advance.

Felt like we had gone back in time.. I stumbled upon this attraction while looking for things to do on our vacation, follow the advice, book in advance, it pays off, small groups only for this. This is one of those places that with a little help from technology can actually transport you back in time to the lives of the aristocracy in ancient Rome.

The best tour we took in Rome. Makes the 5th century life in Rome come alive.At first walking on glass floors is a bit disconcerting but you quickly get used to it. I do wish they would slow the progression from room to room down but they're packing in the tours.

Perfect blend of technology and archaelogy. The presentation takes one through a detailed but simple explanation of how a centuries old building looked like, using excavations and projections. This museum sets a yardstick for other museums in the world to follow. Worth every penny and more!

an interesting journey in a Roman senator's house. Palazzo Valentini has been reshaped several times during the last centuries. Its today's look is from the 19th century. During one of the works, at the underbasement level, with no surprise since we are in Rome, many mosaic floors appeared, suggesting the prior existance of an important house in the area. Fortunately, a sound task was undertaken and now it is possible to visit all the remains of what came out to be the house of a senator of ancient Rome. The house had two ploors, many patios, a thermal spa (with both frigidariun and tepidarium)The man was living a pleasnt life. Much of this is now exposed at your convenience and for your curiosity. A path, walking on glasses, with lights, music, and slides, make the experience an absolut must
Amazing. Not to be missed. One of the most interesting exhibits we visited in Rome. Good restaurant across the street. Be sure to prebook - not all tours are in English.

This is just the BEST!!!!. It is a new area found within the last 5-6 years..and they have found a true treasure...not only do you see the original home levels/items/etc. but then they re-create what it looked liked when it was 'whole" and create a video experience to let you see what it looked liked...if you do NOTHING else in Rome ...pls. do this...they have 2 times a day with English so be sure you pre book or get there early to get the right tour..if you are English speaking...I have been to Rome 3X now ...and the BEST ever!!! Pls GO!!!

Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini comes to life!. So you have seen some of the amazing sights of the Roman ruins, now you have to visit this attraction to bring it all to life. This is possibly one of the best value for money tours you could take. Sadly no photography is allowed in this place, this disappointed me greatly, but the experience was vivid enough to imprint itself on the memory. The visitor is guided through a series of chambers built over an actual Roman palazzo, excavated underneath civic buildings. One walks over a glass floor which is suspended only a foot or two above the original floor below. This can be a tad unsettling at first, but as the incredible scene of this excavation appears before you, any anxiety fades quickly. Any difficulty you would have in visualising life 'back in the day' is taken of through very creative use of overlaid projection. Nothing is left to the imagination as a narrator brings it all into sharp relief. We had no problem booking this tour online and picked up our tickets at the venue an hour before the scheduled start. Drinks and food are available in a cafe/ canteen area right next door to this attraction, which is in the square of this government building.
excellent experience. brilliant presentation, video, also tragens column. Inside is magic. combination of lighting and amazing remains

Interested in Ancient Rome? This Experience is a Must!. If you are interested in exploring Ancient Rome but need help visualizing how buildings appeared thousands of years ago this is the experience for you! Through multi-media technology you will feel like you are standing in a beautiful palazzo. I thought this presentation/tour was extremely well done.One word of caution...you will be standing in a very dark room on a glass floor viewing what is beneath you. At first it is a bit disorientening but after several minutes I adjusted.

A look at ancient Rome through modern technology. The Domus is a very different experience of Rome compared to everything else. The guided tour takes you through a series of chambers under a government building where you walk on glass over the excavated remains of ancient Roman baths, houses, and ruins.The use of multimedia helps one to better understand how the ruins used to look and functioned, which can really brings them to life. Some of the ruins are very well preserved and really make you gape in wonder. The tour takes about an hour and a half and we highly recommend it. It's good value and the groups are quite controlled so you get a chance to look at the ruins, although in some of the smaller chambers you sometimes have to peer through people and their legs to get a better view.We recommend booking online at least a week in advance. The booking website can be quite confusing. It rejected our application a few times saying we had missed certain boxes even though we had already filled them in. We had to try a few times for it to finally work, so keep trying!

Go here first!. my wife say this single attraction opened her eyes to the joys of Imperial Rome. We've been to the city twice in 4 years and I've been boring her for years with my interest in Roman history. This attraction suddenly made it all go 'click' for her. Its superbly presented, and real value for money....the graphic projections to fill in the renaining ruins are a triumph of technology. It is a guided tour, presented at different times in various languages so you MUST book in advance . I cant recommend it highly enough

Best 10 Euros Spent. We couldn't book on web via smartphone but turned up and were able to get into 1:35 English (30 Nov) same day. However strongly recommend booking well in advance if u plan to visit in summer. It is a 'long tour' at 1.5 hrs, but I was entranced the whole time. I enjoyed the multimedia presentation as it brought the house to life ie watching mosaic floors complete. I wish ALL ruins were presented this way. Note: the first stairs r clear perspex and yes it's quite disorienting but u soon acclimate. And def if u have limited mobility then this prob isn't for you.

Very nice. A nice way to explore Roman history using Multimedia, Optical and 3D technique. They rebuild the structure from ruins using the modern day technique to give us the better idea. We liked it.

Informative and entertaining way to experience Roman ruins. This was one of my husband's and my favorite experiences in Rome! It's difficult to describe, but the technology and media make the ruins come to life in an interesting, informative way. Highly recommended. Book an English tour in advance.

Amazing high tech presentation of new archeological finds. After getting recommendation from friends, we bought tickets 2 weeks before our trip to Rome. This was a fantastic experience. And a great way to see how the current modern city is built upon multiple layers of the past. In many ways it's like visiting well done carnival fun-house. We really enjoyed it. Make sure to prebook an English tour and show up 15 minutes early for your scheduled time. It's a timed tour, and they won't hold the rest of group for you.

A must see when you are in rome.. I am glad that I went to see this. Many of the people in Rome is not aware of this attraction but I think you must see this in order to really appreciate what Rome was in the past. Makes you realize how the cities of Ancient Rome is a reflection of modern city planning and layout. After attending this attraction, you get to realize how little has changed and how ingenious and advanced people were 2000 years ago. I had difficulty trying to book the ticket through the internet but calling made the booking made very simple.
A must. Went here on day 2 a must if you want the full rome experience. Went for the sunday service and was bleesed by the pope what more can you ask for

The secret treasure of Rome. I did not hear about it before, but my hosts in Rome invited me to see Le Domus Romane. It was a very nice surprise, as it is perfectly designed, showing both context and details, giving a full picture of the history of the area. Roman riuns meet 21th century multimedia - and the result is phantastic! Entry is 10 EUR, certainly worth it!

Fusing the old with the new. The archeological remains of Rome's ancient baths and houses have been uncovered below street level, this place once belonged to the great "domus" of ancient Rome. What is different about this place from all the other ruins in Rome is they managed to integrate modern technology by presenting virtual reconstructions through graphics and videos -- you can literally picture yourself as if you were taken back in imperial Rome. Walls, rooms, kitchens, decorations are seen in pure form and living color. All through the 1+ hour tour, I kept saying, "how did they do that?!"The Palazzo is still fully operational and has government offices that surrounds the archeological museum. There are guards standing at the entrance that will question you, just tell them that you're here to buy tickets or that you are taking the tour. We tried buying tickets online but their website isn't very user friendly and very slow. A very interesting history lesson for 9.50 euro/person and kept us dry from the unpredictable weather! the only sad thing is, taking photos are not allowed inside.

Very interesting- but not good if you are claustrophobic. The media show is very well done and the location is fascinating. Only issue was that the rooms are very dark when you are going from one room to the next, so some group members took so long to creep their way along, that you missed out on the intro in the next room. The room with the 3D display at the end is tiny, so if you don't like enclosed spaces you might like to skip this.You definitely have to reserve well in advance, as only small groups are allowed. The website for ticket reservations doesn't seem to work well, so call to reserve.

Unusual and enjoyable tour. Never heard of this place until I loaded the Trip Advisor app. We had to fight our way around police road blocks (there was an anti-austerity protest on) to get there but it was worth the effort. A very enjoyable visit though not my personal favourite in Rome. Particularly enjoyed the film at the end explaining Trajans column. Remember you have to book in advance.

Do not miss this fabulous archaeological wonder!!!!. Embedded in the fondations of the Palazzo Valentini, they have unearthed the home of a Roman nobility. They not only show you the magnificent unearthed ruins, but through a multimedia miracle, they brought these ruins back to life. A magnificent example of history not to be missed. We were so awed by this that we encouraged our limo driver to take his family and shared it with many others we met durning our visit in Rome. Now I tell you.......do not miss this one. It is only an hour and a half, and you can't believe how they did it. You too with be amazed how the artistic heritage of antiquity can be brought back to life through technologies!!! You need to call for reservations and it is only 10euro, or 8 if over 65.

Really brings history to life, an enriching experience!. Strangely we went to two very similar museums on the same day, both affording a chance to explore the hidden history of Rome beneath it's modern foundations.Early in the day we went to Balbi Crypt, which to be honest was poor, there isn't much to see, and you are simply led from room to room downstairs, looking at walls of rubble and vaguely realising they are part of some sort of old plumbing system/water tank system. The slightly offish lady doesn't make any effort to explain anything to you, and there are no explanatory signs. One of our party asked her a question which she answered with some depth of understanding, so if she's going to the effort of taking us round the tour, surely tell us what we're looking at.Afterwards we looked on Tripadvisor and saw this as the top-rated place to go, so went along and booked a place for the English-speaking tour in the afternoon. Again you are led under the city, through different rooms and areas. What an incredible difference though, the guide is organised and informative, computer graphics are used to superimpose onto the remains  how it would have looked in Ancient times. It was revelatory, seeing history come to life under your feet! The mosaics are stunning, the fallen tower amazing, and emerging into an alcove to see the Trajan's Column a great finale.I would greatly recommend this tour, I started the day thinking Rome was a bit boring and ended it amazing and enthused!

one of the best stops in Italy. Unimaginable job by the folks who excavated and display this amazing site. Tour guide is part of the deal and is knowledgeable (not too good in English). We were doubtful it deserved TripAdvisor #1 rating but we were proved (delightfully) wrong!

Wouldn't call it a "must-see". I'm a bit ho hum about this. Probably put off by walking on see-through floors and occasionally having to feel your way round a room in darkness, as well as finding it difficult to see round people. We had a 5 day visit in Rome and in retrospect I would have left it for another longer visit. I went with 2 other people, one of whom found it very interesting and the other who would have prefered to have his nose pressed up against the window of a high end clothes shop. I did like the little film on Trajan's column shown at the end of the visit .

We loved it and learned so much. I called to reserve tickets and had excellent service in English. Much more than we expected...so glad we had a chance to see it. A bit of a struggle to find but the back of the building faced Tajan's column

Unbelievable!. I had high expectations for this tour, and was not disappointed. I loved the recorded audio presentation because it was in clear English and thorough. Usually at this kind of tour, I want it to hurry up and finish, but this one was a perfect pace, I loved the recreation of what the palace might have looked like, because my imagination is just not that good when it comes to looking at ruins. It was not only exceptionally interesting, but it was informative as well. The very last part was incredibly powerful. We were a group of four, and none of my travel companions knew where we were going or what we were going to see, and they were all thrilled with the experience. Getting reservations online did not work for me, so I finally called them from Canada and had no problem making the reservations. Another neat thing about this sight, is that it is open on Monday and closed on Tuesday, the reverse of most museums and sights in Rome.

Stepping back in time - amazing view of Roman life. You need to book a specific tour time and it is well worth it. As you step onto a plexi-glass floor, you see the remains of several centuries of villas and streets below you. The multi-media show describes how the ruins were found, what each section is, and what life would have been like. An added bonus is the view of Trajan's Column at the end of the tour. The villa is neaer Trajan's Market and the Forum so it's easy to include it in your "ancient Rome" tour day.

Not To Be Missed!!!!. Being a new attraction in Rome, open only a year or so we did not know what to expect at all. I must say this was well worth the visit!! Very easy to find, a short walk towards the Victor Emanuel monument then a fast left before you enter the Piazza, up about a block or two and opposite the Wax Musuem in a rather mundane goverment building. Enter the building through the front arch and ask for the Domus Valentini and it is to your left once you enter the courtyard. The tickets need to be purchased online, as there are a limited number of tours, in English each day, and a very small group is allowed in at one time. We did this on our recent trip and had no problems finding the attraction or with the tour.The tour takes you down into the cellar of this building where upon excavating for a carpark, a Roman villa was discovered. This tour is an audio/visual wonder above the villa looking down into the rooms of the villa guided by the audio and visually by the enhanced lighting used to illuminate the areas under discussion, truely striking indeed. The tour runs about 11/2 hours and I would do it again and again on my trips to Rome, it was so interesting.One warning I would have is that the tour guide was of little value, other than to be sure folks moved from room to room, and you have a very odd feeling in the dark walking on glass above the villa. It takes abit of getting used to and older folks may want to be aware that your depth preception is thrown off abit by the dark, and the sheer glass that you are walking on and the small rooms, so give yourself a bit of time to adjust.

We couldn't get in!. This may be one of TripAdvisor's top-rated attractions in Rome, but we couldn't get tickets. We went to buy them almost a week in advance, but had a hard time finding the place, because the street address does not seem to exist. However, if you stand at the far side of Piazza Venezia facing away from the Victor Emanuel monument, it's just a block or so on your right.We went into the museum, though,we were told they did not sell tickets there; we'd have to go to a book store five or six blocks away. When we finally found this store and its ticket office, the clerk said they no longer sold tickets for tours in English. I find this hard to believe, but we left empty-handed. So, a word of advice. Try to find out well in advance where you can get tickets and if they still have them for tours in English.

Wonderful and to add to other reviews…. I found this place on Trip Advisor and I am really glad we were able to see the site. To add to other reviews here, you must book online or over the phone. We made the mistake of trekking it all the way over there thinking you could make a reservation in person and that is not the case. I had a hard time making a reservation online via my iPad, so, we had our hotel receptionist make one for us over the phone. I couldn’t get us in to an English showing so I signed us up for the French one thinking that my husband could just translate as he speaks French fluently. After going I can say that it would have been way too hard for him as it is an ongoing presentation via multimedia technology. To our good fortune, he was the only person in the group of 6 that spoke French. The others were Italian and since we all understood English, and since they have a lot of Italian tours, they played it in English. I can’t say enough how grateful I was for that. I consider myself pretty well versed in ancient Roman history, but I still learned a lot about the life and times of Romans and we also learned a lot about the area surrounding the excavation site. This is a must see in my opinion.

A little unexpected. Went to this gallery which was off the beaten path and really enjoyed the tour. We went on a recommendation from a friend, I was very tired the day we went but the tour was not overwhelming like some others and was just right and appropriate and I learned a lot about Trajan's Column here.

One of the most thoroughly done tours in Europe!. You honestly will not see any tour done so thoroughly and with such high degree of quality that it feels like a Hollywood production. Lighting up old ruins is also something unique I have not seen elsewhere in Europe either, and effectively conveys life in Roman aristocracy.Purchase your ticket online for 13 euro, or at the desk a few days ahead of time for 10 euro (I am not exactly sure of the price but am sure it's quite a bit cheaper to buy in person). Note that this attraction is not as simple to find as you would think, go ahead of time and ask around.Side note: no photos allowed, don't bother bringing your camera

Not Numero Uno. It's definitely a good tour. For EVERYBODY. Go there if you have extra time in Rome and you've already been to Rome's best attractions. Don't cry if you miss it. Missing Vatican City is something to cry about! In HIGH SEASON it will be booked out. To assure getting tickets you need to start watching their web-site for the release of tickets (for sale) for the days you will be in Rome. Start watching around 90 days out. They'll release at any ungiven time a 2 month block of tickets. And in HIGH SEASON they go fast. I can't understand the bad votes this tour gets on account of people could not get tickets. Most reviews clearly cover the fact that this tour will sell-out.

A good spin on looking at Roman ruins.. Basically a palace that has been built on Roman ruins which have recently been excavated. There is a glass floor over the ruins that you walk around above the Domus Romane ( the Roman town house) as modern technology lights and projections fill in the gaps to allow you to see how the house was originally The tour lasts about 21/2 hours and also covers the history of Trajans column.The tour needs to be booked in advance as only around 16 people at one time are on the tour.It is also quite difficuilt to locate you are looking for the "Pallazzo valentini" (vallentini palace) which has the remains in.

Poor Service. We never got in which has prompted this review.It is more a tip than a review of the attractionWe had the ROMA PASS which does include this attraction but tickets and visit times need to be booked in advance, you cannot turn up and expect to wander round like many Museums. This needs to be clarified as it can and it was, a waste of time for us. The staff were neither sympathetic nor helpful

Like stepping inside a History Channel episode. i visited Le Domus Romane on a suggestion from a friend, and after seeing its high billing on TripAdvisor, I figured I shouldn't miss it. I am definitely glad I went - this was such a treat. Le Domus Romane is an excavated set of ancient Roman houses beneath Palazzo Valentini. The museum is special because it uses media and technology to tell the history of the structures and the process of their discovery. For example, you walk into a dim room with a glass floor, the ruins visible beneath your feet. A narrator guides you through the room, a light shines on areas of the ruins, one at a time, as they are explained. A broken floor mosaic is shown, and images are projected on its missing portions to show you what it would look like, new and whole.It's a creative and well done museum!

Not the best attraction in Rome. This place is a well-done, informative explanation of archeological ruins, but it is far from being the number one thing to do in Rome : if you're hesitating between doing this or the Colosseum, the Forum, the Vatican, St Peters Basilica...don't...Domus Romane is a nice thing to do if you have time left over

Deserving of the #1 ranking - well worth the time. The combination of the virtual reality technology, the real archeological digs and the suspended glass floors makes the history of this beautiful home come alive. We attended with our 2 sons (ages 10 and 12) and they were engaged the whole time - which is not always true of our visits to historical sites! As other commenters have mentioned, the presentation of the story carved into Trajan's column dramatically illustrates the history of his conquests and shows the artistic detail of the column in a way that can't be experienced by merely looking at it from street level. Very impressive all the way around.

Really well done. We particularly liked the video that explains the drawings on Trajan's column. In pictorial form, details of daily life as a Roman soldier were described. The story told of food, living arrangements, and building infrastructure to support war. Part of the exhibit is in a fortified bunker built by Mussolini. Our hotel secured reservations for us. Reservations are required and the groups are small to allow all to view the full exhibit.

Worth a visit if its raining. We went here after reading the reviews and it was quite good, especially as it was pouring with rain outside. Booking seemed easy enough and we didn't encounter any problems unlike some reviewers.The staff on reception were not the most friendly but that seems to be the italian way.Once inside, it was very dark till you got accustomed to it.The tour was interesting but there were too many people, and sometimes it was impossible to see what the recorded voice guide was talking about, maybe thats just because i'm quite short but because the recorded voice and lighting effects don't pause you cant catch up when the group moves on because the spotlights have gone out. The best bit for me was the explanation of Trajans column at the end. On the whole it was ok but it lacked the human touch that a real guide would have given so you could ask questions.

Extraordinary experience. I was impressed by this domus. The archeologists had made a great job. It is a must see. The light show presents the house as it was in Antiquity and how it was supposedly used. There are still mosaics and marble on floors, you can see the inner swimming pool, sauna and the system how it worked, stairs, outter wall with an antic road and much much more. Make sure to book your visit in advance.

Romus Domus. As advertised. Detailed, but accessible, if you are not an absolute history afficianodo. Tech and history combined. Really interesting, unique layout. My wife is claustrophobic and made it through, as it is well ventilated and fairly open. Some mildly tight areas. One of our Roman highlights

WORTHWHILE. As others have written: this is a 4th century Roman villa that has been uncovered in archaeological excavations and is now presented in a very accessible and interesting way. Our teenagers (who have patience neither for museums nor excavations) APPROVED. As far as finding it: It is located in the building that is just beyond Trajan's Column. So: find the column; walk into the courtyard of the building behind it, and look to your right for the sign. Also: Make sure to call or use the website to make reservations. If you didn't: stop by. When we were there, a couple were able to get reservations for two days later (despite the fact that, on the website, I hadn't been able to get tickets for that day!). Don't give up!

The past and the future. This is surely the future for museum and archaelogical displays. The intelligent use of audio visual graphics brought the past to life and made for a captivting 90 minute tour. Restricted numbers meant that there was a sense of tranquility - the very antithesis of the Vatican museums - allowing full consideration of life in ancient Rome, literally spreading below your feet as you walked over the acrylic covering. The guide was informative with excellent command of English and complemented very well the taped information. One of our party has spent her working life in secondary education and then in museums so is very well placed to judge the efficacy of the display. Like us, she was enormously impressed.

Very interesting presentation of ancient villas. We went here in March 2012; we were the only people on the tour. Ancient roman villas lie, quite literally, in the basement of a government building (Palazzo Valentini). These villas have been conserved and are now an archaeological site. The floor is covered with acrylic so you see ancient steps and floors under your feet. The site is interpreted with computer-generated graphics to show you what the buildings looked like in antiquity and what happened to them over time. Quite often in Rome, something that looks like a pile of rubble was once a beautiful building; this exhibit helps train your eye to look for clues as to what something once was. It also sheds light into the work of archaeologists digging through the layers and layers of time that is the Eternal City. We found this exhibit very worthwhile, and we're old hands at Rome!

Do Not Miss This Site. A visit to this site (domus) was one of the highlights of our visit to Rome. It was very educational and entertaining. The visual effects are professional and make the tour of the site so interesting. The tour is not too long. It's almost as if you are transported back to the time when this domus was alive with people. You can actually visualize participating in ancient Rome life at the top. The spa, the pool, the flooring, the water and sewer system, just everything about this place stands out. It is a little difficult to find the location for the beginning of the tour so allow yourself an extra 15 to 30 minutes to find it. The entrance is in the courtyard. We did have an issue with the tickets which I purchased by calling them four months before our trip from the US to Rome. Keep the number they give you if you call to make your reservation. By the way, when we were looking for this place, we asked a tourist office person it's location, and she said this site is known by all present day Romans and is considered one of their most important sites. She even wanted to know how I got the tickets since she said she's been wanting to go herself. It is slightly dark at times of the tour. Perhaps they need to add some minimal floor lighting. There were some glass steps to negotiate, but they were careful to point those out to you. I suspect someone may have fallen on them in the past. The group was a little larger than it should have been since there were some areas that were too small to accommodate more than just a few people. Yet our group was polite and shared space. I still think they should make the groups smaller though. Go and enjoy life of the ancient Roman elite.

Disorienting. I appreciate the glowing recommendation of others who have visited this place... but I disagree completely with their experience. You are expecting a roman ruin restored to its former glory and what you get is a disorienting,very underlit, overly dramatized view of an archaeological site that has been lit dramatically and then covered in a plexiglass floor. The result is that you stumble uneasily through dark spaces, usure of your footing and underwhelmed by the lit rocks below your feet. Think twice before bringing anyone aged over 70 as they will be dizzy and ready to leave the tour early as was my father aged 94...

“An Archeological Treasure”. I discovered this unique experience by chance as it is not well signposted nor known of the common roman hotel porter. In Palazzo Valentini one sees how the mansion of a very rich roman was transformed over the years into the government building that it is now. The archaeological remains are displayed under a glass floor, tinted and brought to life with a wonderful and original multimedia and light show. Mosaics, decorated walls, baths and furniture come to live. There is also a birds eye video of the area as it would have been in the days of ancient Rome. This truly is a wonderful example of how modern technology can revive the past.If you understand FRENCH, there is a visit at 9.30 without queue nor waiting list !

A must!!. I have to say that that there is a reason why this is the top thing to do in Rome. The presentation is top notched with pre recorded guide assisted by unique laser lights that bring the past to life. The floor is all plexiglass which allows you to see the entire excavation site. Buildings, floors and rooms come to life in a way you cannot imagine until you experience in person. Book it now if you intend on visiting Rome. You will not be disappointed. The last part of the tour is wild, you get to appreciate more than you think. Don't worry about where you sit during the video presentation, not a big deal if your sitting on the side or in the back. This tour is an absolute must!

My favourite attraction in Rome. I absolutely loved Palazzo Valentini. The creative use of technology to bring a historical site to life was captivating. I especially liked being able to imagine myself in the rooms at the times that the Romans had enjoyed the spaces. Being able to see the Palazzo from above through all glass floors being lit up with laser lights to outline important areas was mesmerizing. An absolutely brilliant sight to visit.

Excavations enriched with multimedia. Ancient ruins are brought to life through creative lighting and simulated images. An excellent site for those interested in archeology and history. The group of 15 people is too much in some of the rooms, especially if they are inconsiderate and slow-moving people like the ones in our group. This not the most suitable attraction for kids, because they will get bored.Our navigator did not know this site, we found it with the address only. We were lucky to get tickets for the 15:30 show on the same day. I'm glad we did it, but I can see it does not appeal to everyone.

Great Real and Simulated Perspective of a Roman House. I turned up at 9:30 on a Friday morning to be told by a slightly irate guard to come back at 9:30. My Italian didn't extend to being able to explain that it was already 9:30 and I was made to wait outside. FInally got let into the museum at 9:45 and booked an English tour for 1:30pm. Bear in mind this is a government administration building and they don't really tolerate tourists just mooching around the place which is why pre-booking is essential. They only discovered the ruin when they wanted to build an underground car-park for the government workers, so they are an accidental tourist sight and hence the outside staff seem to be reluctant participants. The staff in the museum were great though. Book this 2-3 days ahead - more in peak times. If you turn up at the right time with a ticket you will ushered through to then experience one of the best guided shows to Roman domestic building. You walk on a glass floor 3-4 feet above the ruin which is illuminated in sections and shows the basement gymnasium, spa and rooms of a grand Roman Domus. Lighting projections then show the pool filled with water and complete the missing mosaics etc to show how it really was. As the others say, best experience in Rome. Quite a few stairs for those with dodgy knees. Not a place for a stroller.

Wish we could have gotten tickets.. We learned the hard way how to get tickets to the Domus Romane, and we will tell you what we learned. Get tickets by calling +39 06.32810 or going on line to ticketone.it a few days before you want to go. Don't lose your patience but see the process through. Reading how hard it was to get tickets, we walked over there this morning hoping to get something for tomorrow or early the day after. We found Via IV Novembre but couldn't find no. 119. Eventually after asking around and being told how great the exhibit was, we did find it. [If you're facing the Vittorio Emanuele monumental building, it is somewhere to your left.] We entered and were "greeted" by annoyed guard who told us there were no tickets and we had to call or go on line. As we left, other tourists entered to the same greeting. We called immediately and actually reached someone who would have sold us tickets for two afternoons from now, unfortunately too late for us. It doesn't make sense to the American mindset to do things this way and we must have annoyed the guard by our reaction.

Ruins brought to life. Le Domus is a must do experienceIt is very difficult to find (so thank you trip advisor for all the info) and must be booked in advance.The tour begins at a very ordinary looking office building. The staff at the ticket desk are not very helpful but do not let that put you off, they do not actually deal with the bookings but will give you contact details. The English tour begins at 13.30 eery day (there is only 1) and the groups are small, due to the small spaces you will occupy.You travel under the building and over the ruins, which sit under glass floors below you, this does feel very strange at first. The whole building is brought to life with a series of images that are projected onto the walls and floors that shows you what the villa was like when it was built.It really is an amazing experience and I would recommend doing it before you visit other ruins as it will enhance these experiences for you by giving you a much better idea what you are looking at and helping you to fill in the many gaps.

Visually Creative Display. Expecting wet weather in Rome, we decided to try some indoor activities and were not disappointed by this venue. You need to book a tour ahead of time and we had no problems doing this. Don't expect to get in on the day you call to reserve. The tour started on time and there were approximately 15 people on the tour...space is an issue when walking through the displays. You basically walk on glass floors looking at what once was a home. Creative use of projectors and images create a visual of what this home may have looked like 2000 years ago. I really found this useful as I find it very hard to imagine what some of the ruins in Rome looked like in their day. Although I felt a bit rushed from room to room, I thoroughly enjoyed the visuals offered by this museum.

Fantastic Experience- Like Going Back in Time. Le Domus is a ruin which is brought to life in a very creative, 3 dimensional way which involves the use of lighting, films, sound effects, etc. You really get a sense of what the structure would have been like in it's day, and a glimpse into what life was like for the indiviuals fortunate enough to live in such a place. The location is good- easy to find and near other attractions- but you do need reservations and the website is tricky. We have been to a number of other well known ruins, but the way this was presented was so amazing and really served to transport you into the time and place. Highly recommend!

Very interesting. You will acquire a good understanding of how a wealthy, connected family lived in 4th-century Rome. We saw a lot during our time in Rome, and this was definitely one of our favorites.

Completely amazing-highlight of our trip. Le domus is a must! By far our highlight, it's outstanding what they have been able to do with an ancient roman excavation site and turn it into this fantastic tour and learning opportunity. Very well organised, selling itself far short with admission price of 10euros for a near 2 hour tour and definitely the best thing we did. Couldn't book online for the following day so we turned up to the address and managed to get tickets for that afternoon. Don't want to give too much away but it's simply incredible! Will change the way you look at Rome.

If you love history, this is a must see!. All I'm going to say (just like every other review) this place is awesome! If you want to get off the beaten tourist path, this place is for you. I would highly recommend getting your tickets ahead of time due to the limited English tours. Awe, if your hungry after your tour the little eatery on the corner has great food!

An Archeological Treasure. This is a museum of one of the most intact ruins of a Roman Villa found in Rome. The rooms are overlaid with digital projections of what the original structures may have looked like two thousand years ago. The tour handles groups of only 15 or less and must be booked in advance. Don't let the telephone messages discourage you. The notifications for "fully booked tours" are often for other museums. Persevere and you will get a reservation.

Fantastic experience!. We visited this site, which was literally 5 minutes from our hotel and adjacent to the Imperial Forum. It is incredible! We found out about it from Tripadvisor - it's not in any of the guide books that we have seen. We booked an english speaking tour and weren't sure what to expect. The multimedia presentation transported us through time and really brought the ruins and archaeology to life. Just when we thought it was finished there was a film describing the carved reliefs on the Trajan column, which ended with a closeup look at the column from the site. The tour lasted over an hour and a half and cost us only 10 euros each - less with a Roma card. Great value for money. Only difficulty was trying to book it - couldn't find a way to do it on the website (although it advised to ring a number, we were reluctant as our Italian is minimal), so we had to turn up on the morning and book for later in the day - probably not possible when busy, or if staying across town.

Thanks Trip Advisor. Without the app we would ever have found this gem. Does not appear in any guide books we have. If you have any interest in how the Romans lived them this is a must. For 10euros you get an innovative and informative trip through a roman villa found buried beneath a palace. Hour and a half well spent

Nothing like it. This is the first time I can SEE what these ruins once looked like! It really does a wonderful job of educating and visualizing what this roman residence looked like in its glory days. You learn so much, and you finally understand the whole process of how these once beautiful houses are now meters below the ground, completely forgotten

Time travelling in Rome. When touring archaeological ruins, have you ever wished you could visualize the site in its original glory? If so, Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini is the museum for you! We discovered this relatively new attraction thanks to its #1 rating on TripAdvisor, and it did not disappoint. It is the most effective use we've seen of modern multimedia to create a “time travel” experience. Advance reservations are normally required, since tours are limited to a small size and are presented in various languages throughout the day. However, we were walking by early in the morning and found that we could get in immediately if we wished to take the French tour (not our first language). We thoroughly enjoyed the experience and learned a lot despite perhaps missing a few linguistic nuances.As we were guided on plexiglass walkways over the ruins, audio explanations were complemented by computer graphics and laser lights that rebuilt the excavations before our eyes as they would have looked in their original splendor. Human guides are present throughout to answer questions. There are also transitional rooms where many of the original artifacts are displayed. At the end of the tour, we were ushered through a “secret passageway” out to the base of Trajan’s Column, the only place on this tour where photos are allowed.

new eyes. By going on this tour, I viewed other Roman ruins with new eyes. The tour gave so much background information and the ability to "see" how things once looked through the multi media presentation. When I went to other ruins, I would apply this new knowledge and recall the "visions" I had experienced at Le Domus. And the additional information about Trajan's Column was an unexpected pleasure. We walked by this column so many times while in Rome, and after this experience I had to stop and really stare each time we went by. Overall, an amazing visual experience, a fabulous teaching tool, and a great opportunity to really appreciate the history of the area. I highly recommend Le Domus. You will be so glad you went. Book early.
Fantastic experience. Wonderful multimedia museum that you should visit after you have already seen the basic sights in Rome.Small groups.Must book in advance.

Excellent attraction, beautifully presented.. I first read about this attraction on trip advisor and I can only say how very pleased I was I went. It is a stunningly good interactive experience and a must see for anyone. It is the architectural remains of the original Roman house (or Domus) on the site and is truly stunningly presented. It's a bit odd and very disorienting walking over glass floors, but well worth it. At the end of the tour there is an explanation of Trajans column as well, very interesting.The Palazzo is quite easy to find, go to the Victor Emmanuel monument, and across the road to Trajans column and walk down the alleyway leading on to the column, you will find a signpost there, when you reach the main street turn right as you are actually walking down the side of the Palazzo. Go in the main entrance, which will probably have a lot of police around as it appears to be a police headquarters. When we went there was some kind of function going on and it was not obvious where we should go. The entrance to the Domus Romane is in the ground floor courtyard. If taking the english language tour, it is essential to book as there are only 15 places and only one english language tour per day. I must say the people in the entrance area are not the friendliest, but the tour guide was very nice. There are quite a lot of stairs so not really suited to anyone with mobility difficulties.In the upstairs courtyard, there are loos and a cafe, we didn't eat there but it looked o.k.I honestly can't recommend this tour too highly.
very cool museum. very cool and suggestive i loved the atmosphere of domus valentini. loved so much the exibition... a bit difficult to find but worth every dollar.... (or euro!!)

Excellent tour!. This was a great exhibit, it was the only tour we went on that really tried to show context behind the ruins we see today. I would definitely recommend this tour to anyone visiting Rome

Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini. just visited this site yesterday, and can't agree more with most of the past reviews. Really brings things to life - helps me appreciate other excavation sitess even more. A great visit in Rome.

I would give it six stars. I discovered this unique experience by chance as it is not well signposted nor known of the common roman hotel porter. In Palazzo Valentini one sees how the mansion of a very rich roman was transformed over the years into the government building that it is now. The archaeological remains are displayed under a glass floor, tinted and brought to life with a wonderful and original multimedia and light show. Mosaics, decorated walls, baths and furniture come to live. There is also a birds eye video of the area as it would have been in the days of ancient Rome. This truly is a wonderful example of how modern technology can revive the past.If you understand FRENCH, there is a visit at 9.30 without queue nor waiting list !
Breathtaking. This is a very imaginative reconstruction of life in a Roman house. The visuals are striking. one can only admire the creative intelligence behind this project.

Excellent!!!! Don't miss! But, unfriendly and unhelpful staff.. Definitely book in advance. It's worth it. We saw people get turned away the day we were there. They tried to make reservations for later in the week, but they were full then too.I went to Rome with my retired parents, and this is one of the sites they enjoyed most. The audio visual effects are really fantastic! They really help you understand what Rome must have looked like in its prime. During the first part of the visit, you walk over a glass floor and see a house that has been excavated below you. Amazing!!! I had never experienced anything like it. They use visual effects to reconstruct parts of the house below you that don't exist anymore to show you what it must have looked like.Later in the visit, there is a room where you see an audio visual presentation of what the city of Rome looked like when it was most powerful. Also, this was really amazing.The only small problem I had was that the staff were quite unfriendly. When we checked in, they weren't very nice. One staff member leads you through the whole exhibit. He seemed irritated to answer questions and his demeanor was a bit off putting. After our tour, we bought a couple items in the gift shop and sat on some benches in a hall exiting the gift shop to look at our map and see where we were going next. We had only sat there about 2 minutes when the staff basically told us to leave. Other than the staff issues, we were happy. The attraction itself is fantastic!!!
Definitely not to be missed!. Really enjoyed this visual multi media experience. Really brought all the ancient sites we were seeing in Rome to life.

Great experience. This really brings to life how well off Romans lived. The use of technology to clothe the stones is imaginative, informative and shouldn't be missed.
Book ahead.
beautiful... worth seeing. Beautiful place, visit at a quiet time and if you admire lovely artwork and appreciate history its ideal for all

Amazing!. This was so much fun! I love ruins and have struggled to use my imagination to envision what it would have looked like. The multimedia effects were just the ticket. It sounds cheesy, but it's not. It's actually really well done and fascinating and made a big difference for me when visiting Pompeii and the ruins around Rome. They only take a small group of people on each tour (one English tour a day) so be sure to book in advance!

Well worth the journey. We only went to the Valentini Palazzo because other TA reviewers rated it so highly as it barely gets a mention in most guidebooks. Booking tickets in advance is pretty much essential as only about twenty people are allowed on the one English spoken visit at 1.30 p.m. each day. Don't be put off when you arrive in a pretty uninteresting Government office block as what you are going to see is underneath it. This is 21st Century technology meeting 1st Century reality and with fantastic results. You can't fail to enjoy it and thanks again to the other reviewers for putting it in first place. It was the best place we saw in Rome.
Fascinating and evocative.. Gave a real feeling of being there. The audiovisual effects were superb and we really enjoyed it. The ticketing arrangements were however a nightmare.
Fantastico.. Great place to visit. Liked everything. Lots of interesting people and shops. You need to see this place. You will enjoy t
astonishing!!. like all the tourist attractions in Rome , this one had the wow factor in volumes!!! it's all so unbeievable here! You can not deny that this is a spectacular place!!

Over-Rated on Tripadvisor. I usually trust Tripadvisor reviews as they generally always are on par with my own thoughts about a place. Here though I thought The reviews are over-rating this attraction! In my opinion it is at best 3.5 stars. The tour is about 75 minutes long and consists of looking down at the ruins of an roman hour while parts are highlighted with lights. A recorded VoiceOver explains what you are looking at. A lot of hard work obviously went into making this attraction. But for me it was definitely not the number 1 thing to see in Rome.

Overrated. I'm not going to lie-- I think its silly this is the #1 attraction in Rome. If you are a major history buff or an archaeologist, then by all means go. But only do this if you are in Rome more than 3 days or so. If I had done this as one of the "must dos" on a short trip to Rome my first time there, I would have been very disappoointed. It's way too long. Kids will get bored. Spend extra time and money on tours of the colosseum, pompeii, herculaneum in the sun, the forum-- don't spend it inside for 2 hours in the dark.

Indescribable. This museum was so unlike any others. Special effects on top of the ruins really give you a better picture of what a wealthy family living in a villa was like. It's a little difficult to find the place and be sure to make reservations using Internet explorer not anything else otherwise you'll get stuck at some point in the ordering process.

Rome meets Universal Studios. Excellent attraction. I think it was this way because they were able to combine technology and multimedia effectively to portray Rome's history at its pinnacle.We were also unknowingly lucky because I forgot that you have to reserve first. I totally forgot and went there at 4pm, and very fortunately they had tickets available!!Must see attraction... They changed the game altogether... You'll get a vivid feel of how life was 1,700 years ago....

Unique- best after you've been to other ruins.. This unique and inexpensive (11.5€ ) tour involves walking on glass above an incompletely dug site. Best visited after you've been to the usual ruins/sites, the novel feature here is that in addition to viewing the ruins themselves, a light and projector display will bring the original ruins to 'life', allowing you to better understand and see what the original was like. After having been to many archeological sites, we found this experience put all the previous ruins in a new light. There is only 1 (or 2) tour in english each day and they usually fill up, so walking in is unlikley to work, except for 1 or 2 people. Far better to get tickets ahead of time online or through a concierge. Total time of multimedia tour is just over 1 hour. Bathrooms are inside the courtyard and very good good just across the street.
lots of walking in rome. lots of walking inside go to the top and see rome and has a bus stop across the stree lots of stairs to clime but lots to see and enjoy
authentic - following archeological dig. loved it.Only deals with what was found. Leaves a lot to the imagination, but one can visualise the lifestyle of the very wealthy owner.

Excelente!. This is a must in Rome! the guide tour inside the domus is perfect, it makes you feel you are actually in the roman home or palace. we went in the italian tour no more then 15 people it keeps the magic!

Interesting, Informative and Fun. this is not the easiest museum to find. Luckily we used our Tripadvisor Rome at to locate it. it is definitely worth the great reviews. It is done sort of like a Disneyland attraction. It does keep your interest and let you see how Romans really did live.I would recommend this to anyone going to Rome.
Time well spent. Very unique exhibit. Small group with excellent guide supplementing outstanding visual and audio presentation. Was helpful in understanding the construction of the ancient city.

Fantastic!. We went here based on tripadvisor reviews, and it was certainly worthwhile. We did this early in our trip, and it helped put the rest of our stay in Rome in perspective. The presentation does a good job of reconstructing the ruins with really cool visual projections on the floor and walls along with good pre-recorded commentary. It explains what life for a wealthy Roman family would have been like, and it describes the excavation process. It was like being immersed in a really good History Channel documentary with lots of good computer animations. We would do it again. Definitely recommended.

Number 1 attraction to do in Rome ? Yes, it's true.. First, the people who don't find this museum need glasses or can't read a simple map. It's super easy to find. The visit is A-mazing. What a way to discover the Roman life and the Roman culture during Imperial Rome. It's a passage back in time but you are exploring with the tools of the 21st Century. I saw a lot of museums and exhibitions during my trip in Italie and this was the best. To avoid frustrations, book in advance online. The tour is mostly sold-out each day.
Wow. Incredible. Have to go see for yourself. I recommend every traveler to rome should book this tour. Won't be disappointed
very nice. They discovered this domus underground the Rome City Hall in 2004 ( when they are digging to make a park place). It worth a visit and the price is just 11 euros !!!

Fun activity!. This is a really great thing to do while in Rome but make sure to book ahead. We never managed to make a booking for an English tour while there's always lots of places left for the Italian ones. We decided to go for the Italian tour since I understand Italian quite well but it was not easy to understand everything while translating to my partner.

A nice surprise!. We decided to go to this place thanks to TripAdvisor. It's definetly worth a visit! You have to book it in advance, we didn't know that but we got a time two hours after visiting the place so we did some shopping and returned to Le Domus Romane for the tour.

Unexpected find. We checked this out based on the Trip Advisor reviews. You do need to make reservations, especially since the english tours are only once or twice a day. We were surprised to find ruins in such good condition in the basement of a public building. It was a bit disorienting to be walking on glass.

Fasinating. Dissagree that this was "Disney-like" we found it a fasinating visit and well worth the time spent. Gave a great insight into life in Roman times and a great presentation. But do suggest you book in advance as the English language tour is often over-subscribed. Another tip you can get an amazinly reasonable snack or lunch there.

Brilliant but get there early. A definite must see and really brings ancient Rome to life. Make sure you book in advance or get there at 9.30am to book. Tours are limited and only accomodate 15 people. Also has stairs so not suitable for wheelchair users

Great for kids.. No doubt the special effects are great and the presentation and ruins are amazing. A kind of " Disney oriented " show. However I disagree on the fact that this is #1 attraction in Rome. If you don't have enough time there are many other places to go, don't try to cover this one if you think you can miss the biggies. It needs advance reservations.
Book tickets online. A very interesting experience, and a demonstration of how technology can help imagine Rome in its glory days.

Surprising find. Would never have heard about this other than on tripadvisor, debated if my 11 and 15 year old could handle it, and decided to give it a go. You go downstairs and stand on a glass floor while a voiceover tells you about what you are looking at. Lights are used to point out individual elements and fill in how things must have looked - a bit like standing in the middle of a TV history documentary. The voiceover is engaging and builds to increasingly interesting finds as it moves along. Towards the end you get a fascinating video, and the chance to sit down for a bit, about the inscriptions on Trajan's Column and what they actually mean (and the artistry that went into them), and then you get the payoff of going down a corridor to see the actual Column just outside the building.At about 1.5 hours, most of it standing up, I was a bit concerned my 11 year old would get bored, especially as he had let me know exactly how tedious he had found the Pantheon and Vatican Museum, but he liked it.There was the added bonus that this tour was underground, early in the afternoon, when it was in the 90s outside. It therefore neatly gave us something interesting to do while staying out of the sun for a while.I didn't have a problem booking, but I would imagine it is best to book early as the tour groups are limited in size. Price is very reasonable.

Very interesting and informative.. We had read about this on tripadvisor and felt it was something we would enjoy seeing.It was a major pain in the backside trying to book this and took time and plenty of perseverance,but keep at it as it was worth the effort, there were people who just turned up on the day and were lucky enough to get a ticket, but as the amount of people is limited to around 16 you do take your chances.It was very interesting and gives a 4 dimensional view to an anotherwise inanimate object. It was great to see how the use of lasers and projectors could bring this house back to its original glory.When you look around the other Roman ruins this gives you a more detailed image of how glorius things must have been.Well worth the visit.

The best secret in Rome, not even the locals know about it.. This 3D, stereo, high tech, almost 2 hour tour blew our group away. You step onto plexiglass into the 16th century and really see how this Cardinal lived. From the steam room to the library, from the remains of an earthquake, to fires, the history is here. And you are smack in the middle of Rome. This is by far the best site I have visited in Rome.

Well worth a visit. Purchased tickets in advance after reading reports on TA. We enjoyed this a lot. Only complaint would be one tour a day in English and probably two or three people too many on the tour which meant certain exhibits were a bit of a squeeze. Fascinating though and well worth the entrance fee.

I keep going back. This is a well hidden treasure of Rome. the Guide in English is at 13.00 (I think) The tour lasts about one hour 20 and is so well done. Rome needs guided tours like this to bring its wonderful past back to life.
Amazing (must reserve in advance). This is a must-see while in Rome...You have to reserve in advance (we did it via internet). I never though it was going to be that nice.
I didnt go, but you should. We were unable to get tickets, because we didnt know about this until it was too late. It looks so interesting that you should check into it ahead of time.

Not sure why this is the top thing to do in Rome acccording to tripadvisor!. The only reason why we bought tickets to Palazzo Valentini is because it was rated the #1 attraction in Rome on this website. We were completely let down. The tour is 2.5 hours long (too long) & they only allow 10 people in each group (which is nice) but it is difficult to get tickets at high tourism times. The tour is all indoors with AC which was the only nice thing about this tour. The tour shows pieces of a mansion that used to stand where Palazzo Valentini is now. Trajan's column is right outside the back door (part of the tour). The tour is taped so a live person is not the moderator. The entire tour is just like a movie (but while walking room to room)& then at the end of the tour, they ask you to sit down & watch an actual movie. I fell asleep because it was so boring. Save your time and money ( I believe it costs about 36 euros for 2 people) and go see something more interesting in Rome -- there is so much to choose from!
An underground Rome adventure!. A recently excavated site near the historical center with one of the most interesting experiences of underground Rome.

Complements the Forum. Well organised and very interesting. In the heart of Rome. Easy to get to. You enter through a government building and go down beneath the Piazza Venezia near the Forum. Much of the time you are walking on plate glass looking down at the ruins of two houses. You have a guided tour in a relatively small group with recorded commentary and sound/lighting effects - well done. They try to bring it to life. The tour we went on was entirely in English - which puzzled a couple of Italians. We bought the tickets at the desk in the building in the morning for the afternoon.
very well done!. What a great way to understand the great history of this amazing city! 1.5 hours of interesting sights and sounds.....Well done!

A very worthwhile visit. This is a must to book in advance online before travelling. Make sure you book the English tour at 1.30pm. Actual tickets are sent express post within a few days.
