It was excellent, complete with music, atmoshere and lighting effects to create 3D perspective what was a very posh residence looked like in Roman times before an earthquake destroyed it. We saw what people looked like and behaved. We walked on glass flooring that enabled visitors to view all the marvellous finds below. You see all the rooms with parts of it still intact like the beautiful terrazza marble floors. A fantastic experience!
Fascinating. Definately worth it - our kids who had to suffer through numerous churches and villas really enjoyed it. Need a reservation.

Best (new) stop in Rome!. Having been to Rome a few times and seen the m"must see" attractions, we were really happy to have this small museum recommended to us by an Italian friend. We we were very lucky to get tickets only a few days before our trip. The same friend called on our behalf, as the website didn't seem to ever load properly to indicate whether tickets were actually available. We paid over the phone and arranged to pick up the tickets just before our scheduled time. The museum entrance itself is located within the courtyard of a municipal building of some sort - beautiful on it's own, although it took a few minutes to locate the correct set of doors leading to the Domus. They are on the left about midway back in the courtyard. The tour was limited to about 16 people (our party alone was 7) and was conducted in English. They seems to have spared no expense in this small but really interesting museum, which is broken into two distinct sections. The first, as other note, is the most compelling, showing in great detail the ruins of a wealthy Roman home at the height of the Empire. The wealth and technology of the time are really astounding, and computer graphics and lasers recreate the excavations to their original spender right before your eyes. The ruins themselves, mostly under glass floors, are impressive on their own, but the technology used to bring them to life was a real treat. The second part of the museum focuses on the nearby Trajan's column. As a history buff, I found the detailed description of the story told on the column's reliefs interesting, but I can see why some reviews find this to be a distraction from the earlier focus on the house itself. If nothing else, it gives the visitor a chance to sit down and reflect a bit longer on the whole scene. Le Domus Romane sets a new standard for bring the past to life, and will hopefully serve as a model for other museums in future.

This IS the best attraction in Rome.. I can not rate this attraction highly enough. What a superb idea -an excellently executed and very professionally presented tour. The tour is pre recorded but with added assistance from a member of staff who politely guides you through the surprisingly vast complex. The audio is very clear and interesting. The accompanying light show / projection lit reconstructions are brilliant and the music adds the correct level of drama. The bonus is the very welcome sit down and video presentation about Trajan's Column at the end of the tour. We did this tour as well as the much lauded Vatican Scavi Tour on our trip and - though it surprises me to admit - the Domus tour was SO much better! You need to book the Domus Romane tour in advance as only about twenty people are allowed in at a time and English language tours are limited to a handful per day. My advice is book online a couple of weeks before you go ( although it is not the easiest website to navigate and it does not like mobile / Android based devices at all).The Domus Romane has the air of being one of Romes best kept secrets. Fortunately it is not a suitable venue for those god awful group / coach tours who constantly block up the hallways in the Vatican and take the shine off that experience somewhat.Obviously - if you have no real interest in Roman life / Roman history then perhaps the Domus (and indeed Rome itself) will not seem so interesting. If you like Time Team then this tour is pitched at that sort of level. Kids will love the glass floors and lights but are likely to lack interest in the commentary. Very young children especially will probably suffer with the humidity and some may be a little afraid of the darkness, so think carefully before taking very young children on this tour.Adults / teenagers with an interest in Roman life / Archaeology etc will love it. If you go on the tour early during your visit, it will certainly help you visualise how the ruins in the Forum / Palatine etc would have looked originally.
As great as all the hype!. Went because of the trip adviosr reviews and was very pleased. Took three young kids (ages 3, 5 & 7), and the enjoyed too. Really puts things into perspective

Depends on the tour guide. Our tour guide was useless. Barely even showed us where to go, barely spoke. I think we would have enjoyed this much, much more with someone who actually enjoys their job and has a passion for it. He sure didn't!!

Lived up to expectations. Just wanted to add some information on wheelchair access.This trip is fully wheelchair accessible and the staff are extremely helpful.In our party of 7 was my 16 year old son who uses a wheelchair. Just let the staff at the reception desk (on the left hand side of the inner courtyard) know when you pick up the tickets. Whilst most of the party went with the rest of the tour, a member of staff showed my son and I to an internal lift, just in the offices on the right, as you enter the main building. We were then met at the lower floor and taken down a small lift to join the main tour. We then just followed the main tour. At one point there is a flight of steps which thens turns into a small lift. This is the first time I have seen this arrangement and it is a marvelous piece of engineering. At the end of the tour we just retraced the route to meet our party back in the inner courtyard. At all times the staff were extremely helpful and made sure that my son did not miss out on any aspect of this fantastic interpretation of the remains.

Incredible!. We learned about Palazzo Valentini online, it was not in any of our guide to Italy books. I think it is too new to be in the books. It is well worth seeing but you have to book ahead of time as they only allow a certain number of people in at a time. It is the remains of a Roman house which was discovered while excavating. They project what the house most likely looked like upon the ruins and it really brings the place back to life. It was a fantastic home of its time.

The air conditioning was nice. This attraction would be interesting for people who are interested in Roman history and ruins. The technology is great, but the subject matter was boring for me. This is a 6th century house that was built over a 1st century house. At some point, they found the ruins of the original house and its features. The tour leads through the different rooms, and through digital images and projections, shows what the house would have looked like in its heyday. The tour finishes with a twenty minute movie of the history and meaning of the oblesk v the square that the house overlooks. We both found the voiceover cheesy and overdramatic but it was a nice break from Romes summer heat.
Worth Booking!. Definately a highlight to our trip. The tour brought this old villa back to life! A very informative tour with many hidden surprises.
Fascinating Look at a Roman Villa. The tour was well-designed and interesting. The reservation system is abysmal and I would suggest checking for tickets in the morning at the site.

Fascinating but not for folks with walking issues. Amazing way to view the past from the present. Just be aware that it involves a lot of stairs as you are walking below the existing Renaissance Palazzo to reach the ruins (that's how far underground the ancient city of Rome lies) and there are no places to sit down. I did see some wheelchair signs but the guide said she didn't know of any wheelchair access. There is a basic tour which will show you all of the ruins (Riditto) and an extended tour (Intero) which adds another 30 minutes and presents an audio-visual history of Trajan's Market and Trajan's Column (to which the ruins are adjacent). I took the extended tour and it was interesting to learn about Trajan's Column but if you skip it and save the extra 2€ you won't be missing any of the ruins which is what the visit is really about. I took some photos using my "museum mode" and they came out pretty good which just the existing lighting.

Very strange. This sounded fantastic - see a villa enhanced to show how they really lived. It was disorganized. They really need to show you a map of the layout and give you some background first. They also desperately need to install benches around the walls. You stand for a full hour. I did not feel that this was virtually enhanced in the way it promised - it was very hard to understand what the rooms were or what might have been there. It ends with this weird info about nearby carved column that goes on and on.

Not to miss virtual reconstruction. Walking on a glass floor you see the actual archeological excavation of two ancient roman homes then a three dimensional virtual overlay that fills in the missing decorations. Incredible experience.
lovely. loved it . it was fabouls the museum was so pleasent i just loved it. didn't like the woman at the recption, she was a bit scary

Well worth it. Found out about this here and just got back from our trip. Just do it. But reserve early as there are very limited english tours. The group is only 15 and it takes about two hours to complete the tour. The whole show was great; combining fascinating ruins with a multimedia overlay. Was a very cool experience.

Beautiful place of worship. It is beautiful. Unfortunately no pictures great summary of history of roman Jews .souvenirs were nice purchased a few tour guide pleasant very lovely interior A mst to see

A Mobile iMax Movie. In the US, there are these huge theaters that bring you 3D experiences alla National Geographic type styling. I think that's what you find here. I reserved the English tour for a day in August several months in advance via the online site with no problem. (Though, to be fair, I've lived in Italy now and have figured out these things a little.) I picked up our tickets about an hour before the 1:30 tour and we waited in a shaded section of the courtyard until the tour began. It is all inside, which is nice in the heat of August, but even the best air conditioning can not fully battle the Roman heat at the heart of the day. As mentioned in many reviews, this experience uses glass floors to allow you to fully see ruins of this discovered palace. The lighting and video in here is top notch and allows you to see what the palace might have looked like back in the day. They'll move you around from room to room and the guide tries to help everyone fit appropriately so everyone can see. There were less than 15 in our group, which was good, because in some spaces, that's all that will fit. It is definitely worth a visit. Most kids will like it, but the younger ones won't understand everything and you stand the entire time until the last 10 minutes. This experience is really cool, and they could easily charge two or three times what they do...not that I want to give them any ideas.

Best kept secret in Rome.. Amazing use of modern techniques to reveal the home of a very wealthy Roman family. We required a booking to get in and had to return the next day, but it was well worth the trouble. Visit lasted about 90 mins in comfortable conditions away from the scorching summer heat.

I'm not into archeology, but this was an AMAZING experience!!. It was a tiring walk from our hotel to the museum, so it was a bit disappointing to know that we should wait two more hours for the tour. However, it is nicely organized allowing only 15 people at once so they can have a fuller experience. We saw the ruins of two old roman houses and using 3D technologies we pictured how the houses could have been at that time. Very interesting and informative, pleasurable for young and old. Recommended for everybody!

Absolutely Brilliant.... We thought this was one of the best places we have ever visited. So much more interesting than the forum, which is a whole lot of ruins but this Domus Romane brings you really back into ancient Rome. You will feel what it was like to be in a Roman House back in the day and this place is real, it is beautiful and yes, it is air conditioned. haha Thats for those of you visiting Rome in the summer coz that is huge. I was in awe the entire tour of this amazing building. Hard to get English speaking tours but we got ours a few days before our visit after being unable to for a month. Keep trying and have your hotel or b&b owner get you the reservations and ask them to keep trying.

It was different.. It was impressive, it was different, but it's not the number 1 attraction in rome. Its worth going to and some of the bits are really interesting and how new these baths in terms of when they came across them is amazing really. You walk on glass on top of ruins and old baths and saunas and you can see how they made it all work. Worth a visit! Book online!

Very informative and unique. The tour was excellent. You see a lot of ruins in Rome and after a while they all start looking the same. In Palazzo Valentini they make the ruins come to life by using projection on the floor, ceiling and the walls, as well as showing you computer generated images of what the houses used to look like. Toward the end of the tour they show a 20-minute documentary about Trajan's column and the story it tells about Trajan's conquest over the Dacia. After the movie they take you to one of the widows to see the column up close. They also talk about the theory of the existence of Trajan's temple and you can see the huge column laying under the glass floor which may prove that theory. The only negative thing is the booking process. The booking website was not working at all. I called the number on the screen and made reservations, but when we got to the museum it turned out the reservation had been made for a wrong museum. Luckily, there was another English tour a few hours later. It was definitely worth the money and the wait. By the way, you can get a reduced price ticket even by showing a current validated ATAC ticket. Full price is 10 euros, reduced is 8.

A little hard to find; fantastic trip back two thousand years!. A little hard to find, a little hard to book, however once you are there, you will find it is an hour and half well spent!What a find this one is! Thanks again to tripadvisor! From start to finish I found the tour fascinating. I'm not sure it would be great for pre-school aged children; however, I am almost glad our kids (teens) were not there, because we will definitely bring them back when we return to Rome. Don't want to spoil the visit by saying too much more, just go there!

Unmissable. If you are interested in subterranean Rome and the lives of the patrician class you can literally walk through 2000 years of history underground here, illuminated with sophisticated film and narration (done sensitively!) Book your slot on their website, you won't get a place by just turning up, there are specific language and tour times.

Great tour. This was one of my teens' favorite activities in Rome. The addition of the multi-media features showing more what it really looked like, and the unaccented English guide (pre-recorded) was very helpful to them to better envision what the home would have been like. Was also helpful for future ruins that we saw since they better understood about all the baths, etc. Very well done and worthwhile!

MUST DO. Only 15 visitors are allowed at a time - and book early. This is not to be missed. Gives you a terrific perspective of what a roman house really looked like (okay, a RICH roman's house). Kids will love it - but MUST book ahead. You will wall on glass floors in relatively low light conditions. The audio-visual aspect of this is EXTRAORDINARY - I've never understood ancient Roman life so well after this visit. You will come away really understanding how Romans lived, and how their houses evolved (this house was lived in for over 300 years - starting in 100-ish AD!). over centuries. This is a MUST DO. PS there is a "treat" for you at the end of the house component of the exhibit.

way overrated. I had an incredibly difficult time getting tickets to this museum (broken web links, bad phone numbers, put on hold for long periods of time, etc.), but persisted because the reviews were so glowing. I finally was able to find a way to buy tickets online after two hours of sleuthing. Not worth it. The museum itself is interesting enough, and I can see why people really like this place; it presents the information in a very Discovery Channel type way (i.e. you can just sit back an absorb information as you would while watching a television program), which might be a nice break for people who are tired of a more traditional museum education experience. What the museum does NOT deserve is the #1 Attraction in Rome status on TripAdvisor. Go if you can easily get tickets without pulling your hair out in frustration. But don't feel like you've missed anything special if it doesn't fit into your schedule.

AN ABSOLUTE MUST!. There is nothing in the world that captures the true spirit of Roma as this tour. Roma is a city below a current modern city. The entire Foro and ancient Domus Aura are below some extravagant and elegant Renaissance and other buildings. What you see is such a small portion of what is actually there. Poor Rome cannot even have an extensive underground transportation system because of all the antiquities below. This tour carries you through the Palazzo and then below to a stately residence of an important Roman citizen. The re-creation done with computers looks like HGTV but instead of modern day you are looking at a home from the Roman Empire. The parts of the floor one sees are beautiful and then the complete mosaic performed with the help of a computer is really worth seeing. It is a little over dramatic but I think the effect gives more impact to the experience. Warn little children that it gets dark but there is nothing scary. I loved the part of the tour which confirms the existence of the Temple to Traiano. The window view of the Colonna di Traiano is extra special. The entire description of the colonna reliefs is wonderful to anyone who cares about victories and battles. You need to book tickets to the event and make sure you sign up for the appropriate language. There is an inner courtyard that has a small bar where you can hang out if you have some extra time before or after your tour. I have been to Rome over 50 times and assure you that this is a must see. Rome is a city to be explored and the history of the place is everywhere you turn. Even in the basements.

Loved it!. I think it's amazing what lies under the modern city of Rome and if you can see this during your time there I highly suggest you do! I booked this tour because of its ranking on trip advisor, and it didn't disappoint! It's such a same so many people wrote negative reviews on trip advisor about this attraction simply because they couldn't book! I had no trouble at all booking online and I booked a couple of weeks in advance of my trip. When you go, the group is about 12 people, and there is an employee to guide you through, but most of the speaking is done by a recording. I didn't time how long it took, but it was about an hour. Most of what you'll see is underground so it is cool temperature wise. The multimedia helps bring to life what you are looking at which is great because essentially you are looking at ruins of an ancient house, but you are walking above it, looking down through a thick plexiglass floor. Maybe one day they can develop something like this when touring the roman forum!

should be the first tour on your Rome list!. I was very impressed by this museum -- I loved that they recreated the past through digital technology. The mosaics, decorated walls and beautiful floors are amazing. I highly recommend seeing this museum first before you see other ruins as it helps you visualize what was there long ago. Also, loved the air conditioning in the museum as Rome was on its 3rd heat wave while we were there!
wonnderful. I liked everything maybe the weather was a little hot but that didnt stop me from having a good time
Very interesting and well presented. Great tour of the rooms under the palace, kept interesting with the visual effects. A look into the future of how tours should be conducted!

Do not miss this exhibit.. It is a little difficult to get reservations (the ticketing website is tricky when booking from the US) but the hassle was absolutely worth it. There are limited tickets so you should probably book in advance, especially for the english tour. The tour takes you inside a Roman villa that is still an archeological dig. You walk on glass over the excavated portions and they use lasers and projected slide shows to show you what life was like. It is very well done and the script is excellent. Our entire family, including a teenager and a 10 year old truly enjoyed this.

Recreation of a Roman Villa. This digitally illuminated tour of the excavations of an Imperial Roman villa under the Palazzo Valentini provides an excellent introduction to the physical remains of ancient Rome. Allows tourists to visualize what is often a confusing jumble of stone. Ends with a great view of Trajan's column and nearby markets. Highly recommend.

Ancient Rome Gets the Disney Treatment. We had heard that touring Le Domus Romane would help put our subsequent visit to Pompeii in context. It would effectively make it easier to imagine what the ruins would have originally looked like. In retrospect, I don't think it enhanced my Pompeii experience in any measurable way. Our tour began with a seemingly bored young man leading us into a room with a glass floor. Aside from pointing out where we should stand, and turning lights on and off, the guides had no real purpose. The tour was "led" by an overly emotive voice over which can only be compared to Disney's Hall of Presidents and included more computer imagery than Avitar. While the ruins themselves were pretty amazing, the omnipresent "Imagine if you will..." pontificating was rather annoying. The tour concludes with a 20 minute video recounting the events depicted in each panel of the Trajan Column in great detail with, of course, CGI reenactments. The tour would be so much better if they did away with the voice overs and just had knowledgeable human guides walk you through.

Our favorite in Rome!. This ended up being the first real tour we did in Rome and it was wonderful! We took our 3 kids (ages 13, 11,9) and it really set the stage for all of the other activities we did like the colosseum, the forum and Osta Antica. The technology really enabled a step by step explanation and brought to life the ruins for our family. They only allow like 13 people for each tour so it wasn't too crowded but can probably make it hard to get tickets. We were able to walk up at 2:00 on a Friday and get tickets for that afternoon. I will definitely recommend this to any friends traveling to Rome!

a truly wonderful experience. only guided tours, so you need to sign up and wait your turn. the visuals, the lighting and the whole glass flooring makes for a really jaw-dropping experience of ancient villas beneath your feet.

This was FABULOUS!. We ordered our tickets online before we traveled- you have to watch the website closely because there is only 1-2 english tours a day and they sell out quickly- space is very limited! You get to travel down to a Roman house where you see it as it stands now in excavation and then how it looked under reconstruction with some very interesting technology. This is a great way to help people understand what they are looking at when they see ruins and if possible would suggest it be done at the beginning of your trip and it is perfect for kids as it really helps them see what they are looking at in context. It's near Trajan's Markets/Column of Trajan. There are restrooms next door but no place to get a drink. A definite must do!
Good Tour. We both enjoyed this tour as it expalined in great detail as we watched the house come to life in with great sound and lights and for the price it was very good value for money

Enjoyed LeDomus--but expected more. We were able to get tickets online--had to use internet explorer to use the Le Domus ticket website. My husband, myself, 2 daughters, 14 and 16 arrived early, got our tickets and got a bite to eat at a nearby bar--The Glass. Good house wine and decent lunch. The tour was very knowledgeable and helped fill in the holes of how ancient Romans lived, But I was disappointed with the film at the end. I thought they could have explored more about the inner workings of the house--the way it was upkept, the slave factor, cost of running household etc. If you have the time take a ride to Ostia and see the ruins they have--Rick Steves has a good audio tour you can download to your ipad/ipod. We enjoyed Le Domus overall, but not our most favorite Rome site.

Not a MUST -- But Very Good. I reserved an English tour a couple weeks before visiting Rome. Based on the reviews I was expecting quite an event. Basically it was interesting and I found the virtual imaging of the ruins helpful in visualizing life in Rome so long ago. But it was crowded and at times difficult to see the display. The crowd was shuffled into different rooms and sometimes you could not see what they were talking about. Plus when we entered one room, it switched to Italian - for a while - but it was corrected. A MUST is the Colosseum, the Forum, the Vatican, St. Peters. A MUST is San Giovanni, the Catacombs, the Pantheon. A MUST is the Trevi fountain, the Spanish Steps, the Borghese Gallery (Apollo and Daphne), A MUST is antipasto & wine while watching the sunset over Rome from the Pincio. This place is COOL and NEAT - but it is not a MUST. I enjoyed the narrative - honestly when they sat us in chairs to watch a video/movie and said we were half way thru the tour, I thought "only half way?!". However the video/movie was very educational and informative and I overall I am glade we went.

amazing experience. Myself, husband and 2 teenage sons took this trip. It was very well organised, very informative and reasonably priced, If wanting the English tour book well in advance. It was such a reprieve from the heat as temps were around 38degress outside. It is amazing what can be achieved with special effects!

Great experience if you can get tickets. This is located in a VERY nice building on a busy street. We tried for weeks to get tickets in advance; needed the English speaking tour. The website was NOT friendly and finally got tickets but only 2 on Sat and 2 on Sunday for our party of 4. Luckily we went on Sat for our 1:30 tour and they were able to book all 4 of us for Sunday as we stood there in person. It was a very well done presentation using all kinds of projection, lighting and overlays using computers to generate what the ruins must have looked like when occupied hundreds of years ago. It is worth going if you can get the website to work properly.

Contemporary entertainment on an ancient subject. We've been here on our last day in Rome and we don't regret it one bit! The museum can only be attended by getting a ticket for a tour in either English or Italian (they only provide the tour in these two languages, from the top of my head).So we picked the English 10.30am tour on a Sunday, we were with a small group of about eight. You are taken into the museum and are guided into several rooms. You are walking on glass so that the archeological digs below you are visible. Through the use of light, the separate digs light up and you are taken back in time by a voice-over who recounts what the probable use of the room et cetera was. A great insight into ancient life through the unique findings of the archeologists. Recommended for both adults, kids, families, friends and couples.

Really well done and educational. Really enjoyed Le Domus. Although trying to book the ticket for the English tour was a nightmare, the actual museum and tour is very well done and educational. Highly recommend it, don't get discouraged by the online registration and keep trying.

Great Use of Technology. As other reviewers have noted, this museum uses technolgy to bring an ancient Roman home to life. Where there is a partial mosaic floor, lights fill in the rest so that you can get a sense of its appearance when occupied by its inhabitants. The tour is narrated and highly informative; it provides a valuable perspective to help you view other excavations, such as Pompeii. Aside from the educational aspect, the museum is air-conditioned and provides a nice respite on a hot summer day. The sandwich shop next to the entrance is good and very reasonable.
incredible. they make the history come alive in fornt of your eyes. don't miss. we were very impressed.

Amazing exhibit of an archeological dig with ruins and multi media show.. My kids loved getting to see how archeological discoveries have led to a reconstruction of what private life was like in ancient Rome

Only thing i WHOLE HEARTEDLY recommend to do in ROME :). Rome beginning of summer was hot hot hot, it came as a relief both educationally as well as perspirationally. This tour is an absolute delight, the one english speaking tour guide is an absolute GEM with a passion for the job, answered all our questions! took my husband 2nd time - he was sick the first time - and we only got half the tour without an english speaking guide. Book via the phone line prior (i booked a couple of days inadvance when in Rome)! a must see!!
10+. perfectly preserved!! It's incredible that after 2000 years you can see such wonderful mosaics!! worth a visit (worth also to come back :) )

Insight into archeology. Thought that this site was a great use of multimedia. It was very interesting from a archeology standpoint how they managed to piece together all of the findings of the ruins. This would be a great tour for those with kids

When archeology meets technology.. If you go to Rome book this visit it is worth every penny. You will be able to see the rest of two Roman villas by walking on a glass. It feels like being suspended and it is really cool, felt almost dizzy in the beginning. Then lasers, lights and virtual reconstructions will help you to learn how these places were made and will enhance your experience. This is going to be enjoyed also by people that could find museums boring. If you decide to go book well in advance, especially the English tours cause they get full very quickly as they allow just few people at the time. It is really a modern response to how with the help of technology we can go back in time and feel what it was felt. A futuristic way to be in the past. enjoy!

Best tour EVER. The 'host' of the tour lead is on an interactive journey through the levels of the house and history. The 'host' was informative giving food the thought. We left wanting to learn more about the history and life of ancient Rome. I will recommend this tour to all who come to Rome.

We all loved this.. What a great way to learn about Romes past on an intimate small scale.The tour groups are around 15 people. The exhibition is an amazing way to step back into time and discover what life was once like.Make sure if you want an English tour that you book in advance.

Creative and fun way to show the history of Rome. The tour is an inventive window into archeology. The floor you walk on is thick plexiglass over a steel grid, which allows you to see the ancient structures below. A guide moves you from room to room and the tour is broadcast through speakers, giving details and other sounds to bring the space to life. Sections of floors and walls are highlighted; what isn't visible or clear is filled in using computer generated images, so you see how they may have looked originally, including colors and decorations. Because the villa is right door next to Trajan's Forum, there's a detailed explanation of the carvings on Trajan Tower after the villa tour. The tower is 13 stories high with images carved in marble that spiral upwards to recount Trajan's most impressive military battles. The villa owner must have been somebody very important or influential to have built his house in such a prime location.The number of people allowed on each tour is limited to about 12-15, so I recommend getting tickets well in advance. I booked on-line a few weeks before I planned to be in Rome and didn't have a problem getting a reservation. I think kids who are old enough to participate without getting antsy could enjoy this as much as adults. It's a nice way to personalize the ruins and respite from the sun if it's a hot day!

Worth your time!. I loved that they make sense of the ruins that you are seeing. You are standing on a glass floor with the ruins below you. Different aspects of the ruins are highlighted and somehow it all makes sense. They make the dirt and holes come alive and seem as though you are there in Roman times. I would highly recommend!

Palazzo. This is such a wonderful place to be, it is best beautiful museum of all. You might have read about it, well all that is written about it, is as it is. I took my son who wanted to see it, because he read about Rome and wanted to study architecture, now he is heading for the program and hoping to do some of his studies in Rome.

Inconvenient Ticketing. We arrived around 11 am, expecting to snag tickets for the next day. They had availability for the next day English tour. We had the Rome Pass, which should include this attraction. They told us they could not sell tickets for the next day, and told us to call a # to book the tickets. We have no phone where we're staying, and we couldn't get the payphone to work. Even though the "ticket" was included in the Rome Pass, the call center charges 1.5 euros booking fee. We could book online, we would still be charged a booking fee. These people are just unhelpful and lazy. They don't lift a finger to help you. They wouldn't even give us a "free" wifi login so we could book online. My advice: don't waste your time trying to get in this place.

Really, really interesting!. Other things were more "impressive" (who can not be impressed by the Colosseum?) but this was easily the most interesting museum experience I had in Rome. Fully recommendable. My kids really enjoyed it too. It lasts about 90 minutes. I can relate to the people who had problems booking the tour. It helps to have java turned on on your computer. The system wouldn't let me book our chosen date for ages and by the time I managed to get around to it (after the system had opened the dates) it was filling up fast. I hope that the people responsible can make it a bit easier. Ticketone is not good. A shame to turn people off such an excellent attraction.

Best site i've been to. This was an amazing experience and i would recommend it to anyone visiting Rome who want to get a feel for what life was like for wealthy Romans in the ancient past. The use of technology in recreating the palazzo was very good.

The Best. My husband and I have visited the sites of Rome previously. We travelled with our 3 children, ages between 4 and 7 years. This was the highlight of our trip to Rome. I'd read about it on TA and wasn't disappointed at all despite having high expectations. You must book ahead to visit this place, but it's worth it. It was fascinating. The kids wanted to do the tour again. It's a very well presented tour of a Roman Domus discovered when workers started excavating below in preparation for an underground carpark. They fill in the gaps with stories and special effect lighting so that you almost feel like it is new again. Can't recommend it enough.

not for height haters. The tour is very informative and well worth a visit. Be aware that the tour begins in the dark on a glass floor with ample space below to view ruins. It creates the illusion of being up high, so it takes time to adjust.

excellent!. Probably the best museum I've ever visited! This museum really brought the history of Rome and its past inhabitants to life. Do it before you visit any of the other sites and it will make better sense of the history.

So Innovative. This museum is the most innovative, technologically interesting museum we have ever visited. So beautifully done. We can't quite figure out how they could afford the expensive displays and effects when only 15 people can visit at a time.....

Excellent! Really makes sense of everything we saw in Rome and Pompeii!. After reading so many reviews about this not highly publicized attraction, we booked well ahead of time for our early July trip. We were travelling with our 8 year old son so we were really interested to see what he thought of it after reading reviews. DID NOT DISAPPOINT! We had already been to Pompeii the week before but he seemed 'amazed' at what he saw here. Not only are the excavations amazing but the multimedia presentation really makes it easy to seeand understand what we had been seeing for weeks (ruins). We especially enjoyed the film at the end about Trajan's column. We had been admiring it hours before the tour and then to end up learning all about it was a fantastic coincidence. Imaginative, ingenious and one of the most interesting sights during our week in Rome.

Well worth it. What an amazing place to visit. Was lucky enough to arrive 20 mins before an English speaking tour started and there were spaces.....best to book in advance though. Loved the technology to recreate a real roman house and you feel like you are actually standing in it. Found it a little hard to find as signage not huge.

Fascinating!. The Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini was the most interesting and different of all the sites we visited in Rome. We were so pleased that friends had alerted us to this new attraction. It seems the tour is being added to all the time, as new areas are unearthed and opened up - a man who was on our tour in May said that he had also done it the year before, and this year's version had lasted an extra half hour because of new sections added. The view of Trajan's Column at the end is breathtaking.
LIFE IN THE 4TH. CENTURY. Very interesting. Gives you a glimpse into life in a well to do Roman household in the fourth century.

good stop on a hot day. We went on Fri June 15, 2012 at about 9:30am and got reservations for the 2:30pm English tour.We used our Roma Pass. The multimedia presentation was very interesting and brought to lifethe lives of the roman people living at the site. We were mostly walking on glass floors over theruins which some people needed time to get adjust to. Nice visit on a hot day with a couple ofrest breaks during the 90 minute tour and a chance to sit down.
Worth a visit. A nice stop but it was hot and there was not a lot of ways to keep cool.

amazing... Took an English tour as suggested. Amazing technology used to reconstruct and explain the ruins found underneath the building using small small details. It was good and will recommend. Roma pass accepted. Book early as tour is done in small groups.

You will stay in a real anciemt Rome house. With the help of a sofisticate virtual reconstrction you will visit a real ancient roman house of a rich family that owned their personal gymnasium and SPA, with tepidarium, calidarium and frigidarium. You will also ear the voices of the virtual roman boys playing outside the house.
Don't miss to riserve on advance the english guide tour.

Best archaeological interpretation ever!. My husband and I are archaeologists and we were overwhelmed by the artistry and technology of this attraction. Via projection and animations, you are introduced to the complexities of the history of this huge Roman villa as you walk on glass floors over their bath romplex, the remains of an old Roman road, visualize their first floor rooms and staircase and you get to experience vicariously the earthquake and fire which destroyed the house. The connection with Trajan's column is a big surprise, so I won't spoil it. Some effects, such as the shadowy chariot and rider along the old road, filling in the mosaic floor with light effects and making it appear to rain are breathtaking. A lovely break from the searing heat of Rome when we were there! Truly a memorable site.

Amazing - don't miss it. This was the most worthwhile attraction we've seen other than the Colosseum and Vatican. I loved how the visual effects were used to recreate the scenes of what the ruins looked like when people were actually living there. The baths, houses, swimming pools. We really got a feel for life in years past. It's a strange sensation at first to walk on glass floors above the ruins, but as soon as the first lights illuminate each section, you will immediately be immersed in history.There was also a movie explaining the story told by the carvings on Trajan's column. It had so much information, I wish I could see it again. We were then taken to a window which gave the closest view of the column that I have seen.Don't miss out - buy your tickets online before going to Rome. All of agreed this was worth more than we had paid. We can't believe the technology involved.

Terrible experience trying to get in. This review is for the website, official office and tourist info which were / are deplorable. I am unable to comment on the attraction as sadly, I couldn't get in. First up I bought a Roma pass to use for entry. First problem, the web site won't let you book using the Roma pass, this must be fixed. I then thought I might book via a tourist info office. No good and the best they could offer was a cross on a poor map so we went off to book directly. After asking directions many times we finally stumbled across Le Domus. The web site and the official brochure do not have a map to the location. Of course it was fully booked but on trying to book in advance, the office couldn't do that or even tell us availability, very poor. They wrote the name of something on a piece of paper. To cut a long story short, after asking in several shops, police, etc, we discovered a small booking office inside a book shop inside a shopping centre ! After 2 hours since we started the exercise, we were told there was no availability for the 3 remaining days of our Rome stay.I hope those running the Domus read this review and make some urgent changes or a good attraction (apparently) will fall by the wayside due to poor management.

Don't miss it!. We have only visited this museum because it was the first on the Tripadvisor list. It was no mistake. It is a perfect example of how old artefacts and new technology can be combined to allow for an exceptionally engaging experience. Do not miss it!(Booking a visiting slot is a must, because only small groups are taken in, so do this at least a few days before arrival.)
Time machine. Like going back in time! In my opinion a must do, we had a guide from easitalytours, Nicole, who was great, I guess without a guide you miss a lot.

A must visit in Rome. If you are in Rome - you must visit Le Domus Romane. Not only is it an extraordinary site and a completely immersive experience - your knowledge of Ancient Rome and appreciation of the contemporary city will be enhanced 10 x fold. It's the best interpretation of a cultural heritage site I have ever had the privilege of experiencing.

More of an experience than a museum.... Domus Romane is fantastic. We were very lucky to be able to get last-minute tickets for the tour given in English. The group was about 15, with a very wide age range, but everyone seemed interested. The visual effects are spectacular, and our tour guide was also very knowledgeable. We asked him additional questions and he seemed more than happy to explain details. The lack of crowding is so nice after standing in lines at most other Rome attractions. Highly recommend trying to get tickets to Domus Romane! Very worth it.

Very informative-What you need to know.... This is a very cool attraction. I highly recommend it IF you can get tickets. Is it the #1 attraction in Rome - NO, but it is worth your time. What do you need to know? The site is basically a trip to an archaeological site under the streets of Rome. The modern city of Rome is built literally on top of the past. The further you dig below the streets, the further back in time you go. The tour is only about 15 people and 1.5 hours long. It is a set tour that has a narrator describe what you are seeing. The narrator is a very clear recorded voice. There is also a guide who directs you from room to room and does hit the button to start the narration until everyone is ready to begin. With the use of lights and some cool effects, you are kept focused on what they are talking about. It is informative, but not overwhelming. The site includes Ancient Rome (of course) and some Renaissance as well. Overall, IF you could plan ahead of time and IF you can get tickets (in which you should call well in advance-like 1 month) I would say go for it!
Amazing!. A great experience allowing you to be transported to ancient Rome and the very special quality of life led by the very rich of that time. Very well done!

Great Tour, but only saw 1/2. Because of the high tech equipment, something broke 1/2 way through our tour. We weren't given any further explanation and was sent away without any apology or concession. What we saw was pretty amazing though.

Breathtaking . . .. I've visited Rome many times over the past thirty years, and may safely say that this is by far the best museum - its more than a museum - in Rome. The entrance fee is derisory. I'd gladly have paid treble the price! A mixture of human guide, multimedia presentations, and stunning reconstructions make this a must-see on visiting Rome.

Interesting. This is an interesting and well done tour as well as a welcomed break from the heat outside. So often in Rome when you are looking at ruins, it is hard to imagine what things actually looked like in their original form and what life may have been like. This site does it for you using technology and it is very cool. That being said, I find it amazing that it is the #1 attraction in Rome when there are sights like the Colosseum, the Roman Forum, etc. The tickets for the once daily english tour are very hard to get, I checked the website daily for weeks so I didn't miss out when tickets became available. If you have several days to spend in Rome, put this on your list of things to do but if you are in Rome for just one or two days, I wouldn't miss out on any of the other incredible sights to see in Rome just to see this one.

Archealogical eye opener. So glad I took the advice of TripAdvisor's members and went to Domus Romane - It was interesting and well presented once you got over the odd feeling of walking on a glass floor. The excavation was explained and shown in some detail, but it was not too much for the curious visitor. The digital recreation of what the home might have once looked like were a great addition to the actual excavation. Booking in advance is best but we were able to get a ticket for an afternoon tour when they opened that morning. Definitely worth it. I did not notice whether or not there was an elevator. I suspect this might be difficult for people with mobility problems but contact the venue for info on that.

The perfect blend of ancient history and cutting-edge technology. I recently went to Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini and walked away sort of shaking my head in awe at what I'd just experienced. I was unable to book online so I called to book. Although I would have preferred English, only one tour a day seemed to be in English, so I gladly took the tour in Italian. (I guess I'm lucky I understand it well enough). The tour started promptly and in a heartbeat you're standing on a see-through floor, in the dark! I admit, it took my legs a few moments to adjust. I took some pretty tepid steps at first, convinced I would somehow fall through the floor. But you adjust pretty soon, both to the floor and to the dark. The information provided on the tour is really comprehensive, and the actual site is amazing. The light display is cutting edge, or least I think it must be. This is a really excellent tour, and quite cheap I thought. The Italians are all over this, and they are definitely on the money. Do it!

Great Experience. From concept through execution to final product, this is one of the most intelligently curated historical sites I've ever visited. The "high tech" elements add greatly to the experience w/o it becoming about flashy technical delivery. I learned a lot.

Best thing we did in Rome. Great tour! The Domus is in unbelievable condition and with the help of lighting effects you really get a clear picture of what it would've looked like. Don't miss this and remember to book in advance! Website only offers one English tour a day but there is other times if you call the provided number.

An adventure right in the City!. This attraction is super cool and perhaps a preview of the future. The tour is automated as you decent from the busy piazza and street into a totally different world. There are illuminations on the ruins highlighting specific areas accompanied by a commentary showing what the areas would have looked like in antiquity. It feels like an exotic ancient adventure but then you come right back to the modern city. Outstanding! Enough trying to describe it, go see!

Excellent attraction, and probably the best value in Rome?. I booked tickets well in advance on the strength of reviews in TA, and we were so glad we went. It's not that easy to find, I reckon we walked past the entrance at least four times before we spotted it, but it's definitely worth seeking out. There is only one English tour per day so booking is pretty much essential. The tour lasts a good couple of hours so represents excellent value for money.Tip - there is a little cafe in the square behind, if you are early you can get a lovely coffee and snack at probably the best prices in Rome!

Brilliant 1,5h tour through the time. Brilliant site worth seeing. It is a 1,5h tour where you "move back in time". You walk on the top of two excavated Roman houses belonging to the Roman elite. Advanced multimedia technology simulates the old times and atmosphere. Fully recommended. It is 10 euro full ticket.
What a wonderful experience. It will tell us a lot about Rome.Here is well worth seeing many times. Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini is one of the best place for me in Rome

Well worth a stop!. If you like history, or if you need a better visual on all the partial ruins you will see around Rome, include this interesting museum in your travel plans. It is underground, and computer image technology is used to project what the rooms would have looked like based on what has been excavated under the glass floor. Great information, and helps put other sites in perspective. Cool video of Trajan's War at the end, where you get a chance to sit and relax for a bit...on a hot day of site-seeing, this is a welcome relief. Tour is concluded by an up-close look at Trajan's column, a wonder in itself. We have three sons aged 9, 12, and 15, and none of them were bored by this tour. Only caveat is locating it; there is a sign out front, but you have to go well into the Palazzo to get to the ticket office. This site takes Roma passes; tour times all have to be reserved in advance whether you have the Roma pass or not. Info is on their website, but I called directly, and found this less confusing than booking online.

Despite exhaustion it was worth it!. We enjoyed this "museum" despite the fact that we had just arrived in Rome after traveling for around 14 hours! Our guide seemed a bit disinterested in our group so we figured out how to push the English button. The mosaics on the floor that have been uncovered are beautiful and the massive columns on display give you a reference point for many features that we saw later.

Le Domus is outstanding. Wonderful site well worth seeing. They've done an outstanding job making this ancient home come alive, and the glass floor makes it possible to really "see" the home. My only complaint is that the size of the groups is too big. Whoever arrives at a new "room" first blocks the view during the narration, and those at the back have to trail along behind. Other than that, wonderful. A true "don't miss".

Wow!! Book as soon as you can. We waited and waited to be able to book this attraction as spaces are very limited. On the very day they went on sale they sold out and we were lucky to get the last 4.What an amazing place, everything was so professionally done and absolutely fascinating.I went with high expectations and was not disappointed. I could not get over the value for money.I am petrified of heights and while I made a bit of a fool of myself with a couple of yelps at the high glass floors that you look through, even I got used to it in the end.Fantastico!

Another secret but amazing site. This historic ruin hasn't apparently made it to my American guidebooks but it was fascinating. For 10 euros, you get an extraordinarily thorough tour of a 1st-3rd century AD Roman Beverly Hills mansion, with on-the-spot re-creations of what you might have been seeing two thousand years ago. It's like a giant now-and-then book with the overlays of what the site originally looked like and what Rome's archaeologists have currently excavated. If you are interested in archaeology and Roman history, this is an authentic place to visit, particularly if you have checked out Trajan's column and ruins first. If you have a choice, don't visit this the day you get off the plane, because large portions of this tour feature semi-darkness and you will think it's time to sleep. Another interesting feature of this site is that it is wheelchair accessible. On our tour, my husband and I were able to watch how they accomodated someone with stairs that turn into a ramp. I am also not sure how many and when their English-speaking tours are, but we got lucky--when we visited at 2pm on a Sunday, they sold us tickets for the 4pm tour, and we were happy to return, after checking out the Pantheon and the Torre Argentina (site of Julius Caesar's death).

Wow..something else.. This tour provides a magnificent mix of historical information using the latest technology to bring ancient Rome to life. Definitely book your tickets for this, if you are coming to Rome. My highlight amongst many, was the information regarding trajans column.

Captivating. Hidden under a government building is the amazing Domus Romanae. The use of computer projection and graphics places you in a luxurous roman villa at the beginning of the common era. This is a musem such as you have never sen before. You must book well in advance to get a ticket for the english tour which is held once a day, but if you are at all interested in the history of the Roman empire you will not regret it.
Really interesting. I enjoyed the talk and the tour of the building, but my daughter has bad eye sight and some of the dark rooms were disorientating for her.

Great unique museum. The problem with this museum was that, while they limited how many people could be in each tour group, 19 was about 5 too many. The guide did not provide instructions so people could be more aware of the best places to stand so everyone could see. Some of the small rooms could not fit everyone. Also, the souvenir shop was in the middle of the tour, so 16 of us waited for 3 people to shop...I would still recommend this and maybe the staff will start to make some changes.
Wow!. Spectacular! Highly recommend! So well done and interesting, truly a highlight of our trip. So glad I found this on tripnadvisor before our trip!
Great experience.. A must for everyone interested in ancient Rome. Internet reservations doesn't always works. It's better to make a reservation in person. A spontaneous visit is not recommended.

Unique Museum Experience. I've never been to a museum quite like Le Domus. It really stands out in comparison to the other museums and galleries in Rome as this museum utilizes technology to give visuals and explains the historical background of this Roman bath house. No need for imagination when you visit here!The tours last about 90 minutes and tour groups are very small. Book in advance!

Fantastic museum - brings the ancient ruins to life!. Previous reviewers have summarized the contents of this tour very well, so I won't repeat this here. It is really well-done, and it brings the ancient ruins to life in a way that makes them seem very real. I agree with the previous poster who says that it made his visit to Pompeii better - it's really neat to look at the ruins, and then have a picture of what they used to look like.I'll add my 2 cents about booking - you CAN book without buying a ticket, and without paying anything in advance, but I did it by calling them rather than over the internet. Call them at +39 06 32810, and wait for the prompt that gets you to an English-speaking operator. Tell them the date/time that you'd like to visit, and then tell them you're paying with the Roma Pass. They will book your time slot and give you a confirmation number for your reservation. We had already visited several other museums by the time we got to Domus Romane, so we paid the reduced ticket rate at the ticket office when we checked in for our tour.Note that the number above is useful for booking other sites as well; I also reserved a spot at the Borghese Gallery on the same call. Both reservations worked perfectly. I used Skype to call them, for a grand total of about 15 cents! If you book over the internet, you have to pay a surcharge of a few euros per ticket, so definitely call, and use Skype or another VOIP service; you'll save a few euros. As others have said though, booking is essential, because the tour only takes 15 people per visit, and there's only one tour per day in English.Others have mentioned the snack bar - I'll add that their prices are pretty cheap, compared to most tourist stops. An espresso and a bottle of sparkling water cost about 1.40€. I should have had some food there, too!

More Tours Open Up, Amazing Use of Technology to Bring History Alive, BUT Not for Little Kids Who Scare Easily & Hard to Find!!. Wow! Hard to describe how amazing this is! Fortunately they've opened new English language tours - there was one starting at 3 pm just as we finished our Sunday tour. Quite tricky to find, though - allow yourself extra time. My 10-year-old was enthralled as he finally understood the significance of Roman ruins. But my 6-year-old was frightened early on in the tour as the film shook to simulate an earthquake. He begged to leave the darkened room, and we just about had him calmed down when "fire" struck!! He did manage to make it through, but it was distracting for others. As he regularly plays with older boys, I thought he could handle the tour, but in hindsight I'd probably wait until a child was at least 8 or so before bringing him on the tour.

Le Domus Romane di Palazzo Valentini is great!. I booked this over the internet and was really glad I did or we would not have got a place. The tickets say 12.00 and 1.30 which sort of confused us but the English tour is at 1.30. You have to take a tour - you can't go in on your own. Go to the ticket desk and show your internet booking form and they will exchange it for tickets (I was not asked to show ID confirming I was the booker but bought the credit card I used to pay just in case). You will then wait in the courtyard until about 5 minutes before its time to go in. There is a cafe in the courtyard where you can get drinks and food if you arrive a little early. This attraction has a lot of standing so it is worth having a litle sit down before you go in. It takes about and hour from start to finish. The gift shop is in the middle and then you continue with the next part of the tour. Its lovely and cool inside as you are underground so a cardigan is useful. It's a bit difficult to find so worth going early. There is nothing like this in Rome and it was worth every penny. Its just fantastic. I booked through www.ticketone.it and the tickets were 10 Euros each and 1.50 Euros each service fee so 26 Euros for 2 adults. Pay no attention to the seat numbers on the order confirmation - the short bit of the tour where you sit in a small auditorium has free seating and all the seats are good.

Fascinating, Unique, A Bit Over-the-Top. Excellent tour of an underground, recently excavated Roman domus. Elevated glass floors and extensive use of lighting effects help to provide great insight into the structure and function of the homes, and we found that this tour really helped add a terrific amount of information that made our visit to Pompeii later in the week far better. The script and audio presentation is a bit overwrought in my opinion -- sort of like Disney Meets Discovery Channel -- but that's a fairly small quibble for such an otherwise interesting experience. As noted by others, access is very limited and tickets are often not available via phone or Internet sales until just before the beginning of the month (in our case tickets for June 2012 weren't available until the final week of May 2012) so be sure to check for availability frequently.

Indoor, underground your with added technology. Take a step back in time and under the city of Rome. Centuries of a city underground are pointd out through multiple useds of projectors, technology and multimedia as you walk along a glass floor to see the ruins. See the baths of a one time Roman Palace, along with ancient artifacts and ruins. This tour is done in small groups, so be sure you book ahead of time to get your desired language and time slot. Very neat tour and nice break from being out in the heat!
Book early. There is only one English tour a day at 12.30pm so book early for this new and unique experience. This has set a new standard for museums in Rome and should not be missed.

Palazzo Valentini Domus de Romane. We recently visited this site and it was great. I had booked just based on the Trip Advisor reviews because I didn't see it in any of the guide books. I promised that I would write a review because I didn't understand what this would be like based on the reviews before we went. However, I notice that several others have "filled in the pieces" of what this attraction is like--pun intended.But I thought I would add my bits and pieces as well....Palazzo Valentini is a government building with some sort of official function. However, at some point excavation of a typical Roman patrician home (or two) (thus the Domus de Romane-Home of a Roman) was done underneath the Palazzo. So a very great presentation of the excavation area was put together for daily tours. If you want the English tour you must take the 1:30 tour. Booking in advance is a good idea but very confusing. Do it if you can. However, if you book in advance they will not accept the Roma Pass.When you enter with a very small group-no more than twenty or so and that was probably 2-4 more than should have been in the group- you will go down a set of stairs to the excavated portion of the building. You walk on a clear plexiglass floor that is over the excavated area for the whole tour. You can see the entire excavation from a very close perspective. In each area you are treated to a media experience not a live tour guide. This is a plus not a negative. You will hear voice over script and see scenes projected on the excavated site that "fills in the gaps." For example, if a partial mosaic was found on the floor the multimedia projection will project what the completed floor will look like. In the swimming pool area, water and decorations are projected. I won't spoil it by giving you all the details. Near the end you will see where a large column was found during the excavation and you will get to see the Trajan column from the perspective of the excavation. This house was really near Trajan Column. Then you will see a film on the story that is carved on Trajan Column...very interesting and well done.I hope this explanation helps and is not a spoiler for those who would rather just be surprised! I would definitely recommend it. It is very interesting and well done. I would also consider doing this tour before the Forum if you could schedule it. It helps you fill the gaps in on all other ruins.

Fascinating experience. I had a little trouble booking this up; they don't seem to release tickets until about a week or so beforehand. So when I tried, at the middle of May, to book for June, I couldn't. However, I logged-on to the website at the end of May, and was able to select tickets for June. Very glad I did.Couldn't find the place at first, basically you go through the arches of the main building, walk into the courtyard and then the entrance is the first door on your left. There is a poster outside the main building, but its not that clear when you first enter. We would've given this 5 stars but, when we first arrived, we were told to wait outside in the courtyard. Someone came and checked our tickets, then went back inside. After 5 minutes, we noticed that the other group waiting inside had disappeared. We enquired and were told that that was our group! No one had told us, or the other people who we were waiting outisde with us. Anyway, we caught up with the group and didnt miss much in the end.The experience itself was really interesting. The glass floors and the recontructions via projection were fascinating, state-of-the-art stuff. Just gave you a real easy insight into how the Domus would've looked back then.The explanations of Trajan's Column at the end was really great too.Staff were friendly, well trained. Just a great experience for all ages.

Jewel in the Crown of our trip. I loved the historical aspect of this recent find under the Palazzo Valentini. Walking on glass floors above the original floor level is fantastic but it is the juxtaposition of the ancient site with modern technology of light projections and virtual reproductions that bring this attraction to life. The history of the 'houses' and that of Trajan's Column is amazing.

The Brilliant Palazzo Valentini Experience. Visited with 3 children (14,12,10) and all of us loved it. Brings to life the Roman lifestyle and ruined house of an important public figure and his family. In what was a huge house, in an incredible area right next to the Column of Trajan, the Palazzo Valentini is a unique and vivid experience. Each child was awestruck by the multi media presentation which also gave a great account of the story of the column. The approach here to History helped our children realise that the past is exciting and relevant even when the evidence we can actually see is scanty. Highly recommended for all.

Fascinating. Such value for money- this experience which included many ruins and artefacts, coupled with modern technology to recreate a Roman Villa, gave a brilliant insight as to how life might have been. Thoroughly recommended for all but young children. There were some children struggling to cope with all the walking about in semi darkness for almost 2 hours!
Well worth a visit. Got real lucky and got tickets for the tour on our last day of our trip to Rome. This turned out to be one of the highlights. Well worth visiting and recommend it.

Brings the history to life. I bought the tickets for this based on the reviews on trip advisor. This is the link for the tickets www.ticketone.it. It cost 23 euros for two people and the English version is only at 13.30 each day.The ticket shows 9.00 on it but that is confusing as that is the time it opens. To view these ruins you need to walk around on a glass floor which was really weird. Underneath the floors are the ruins and they use lights to make it look realistic and to try to capture the atmosphere of what it would have looked like in its time. You are walking around in the dark. There are short films as you walk around and the ruins are amazing. Well worth a visit if you can. It is behind the Forum. You probably will need to book in advance although they did let 4 people in who had not previously booked.

History, archaeology and modern technology - a great combination.. I will not repeat all that others have said, but this really is an excellent experience. It brings to life better than anything I have seen something of what the house must have looked like inside, and as importqant it puts in lots of details about how the conclusions were reached from the archaeological finds, and what must have happened (eg. earthquake, fire etc). It helps you to understand what you are seeing in an outstanding way: you almost forget that you are there and seeing this live as it is as technologically sophisticated as a television programme -- and then the special effects stop for a moment and you can look down and see the reality beneath you. We particularly enjoyed the gradual reconstruction of a mosaic, and the columned room with a girl walking towards you, then going into another room.And the new material on Trajans column is fascinating.... apart from giving the background, it takes you gradually up the column and the story it records (the Dacian wars), stopping to highlight and explain certain amazing scenes, using 3D effects and even colour as on the original. And then at the end you walk still underground a very short distance, look out of a grid door and find yourself just beside the base of the real column itself!This is a high tech site -- all glass, great sound, fabulous visuals! The tour is not totally perfect - not quite enough time to look at the static exhibits of finds in paces, it can get a bit cramped in some places (I think we had 18 on our tour), and folk with an aversion to walking on glass might initially be a bit uneasy (but its totally safe). The visit overall lasted about 1.5 hours. No photography is allowed.There seems to be only the one English tour a day, and booking well ahead is absolutely essential. It is not entirely easy to book, but everything went well after persevering. Unfortunately there is not (yet?) any booklet or even leaflet on the site. But there is a very nice small snack bar right next door (presumably really for staff working in the building over the excavations!).We were left thinking ... IF ONLY more of the sites in Rome had this sort of on-site presentation, but then this is totally underground still (which perversely is an advantage here, as you start in thr dark literally)!, and of course only a few can benefit on each trip.This really is a must-see!

Fill in Ancient Rome's Missing Pieces. The tour of the Roman Houses under Palazzo Valentini makes ancient ruins much easier to understand than does walking the Forum Romanum with guidebook in hand. Through the wonders of modern technology, a "light show" fills in what's missing from the houses of ancient Roman aristocrats. The floors are clear glass, so the visitor isn't walking on the ruins, but above them. Lighting completes areas missing from mosaic floors and wall frescoes, even adding water to the bath complexes. One English tour per day is offered, and booking ahead is required. If you cannot get a ticket before leaving for Rome, ask your hotelier to check for you. It's worth the effort. A small cafe and bathrooms are in the couryard next to the museum entrance.

Fascinating!. If you enjoy the historical aspect of ancient Rome you will really appreciate this tour. Book ahead! The website is a little confusing, the English speaking tour begins at 1:30 and only a handful of people can tour at a time. The location is definitely not easy to find and houses several other businesses. The ruins were found under a 15 century villa that has been restored into an office building. When you walk into the courtyard Le Domus will be on your left. Enjoy!

A must see. This is one of the most interesting and beautiful museums in Roma (and there are just too many). Here you can really experience and understand that Rome is cake of historic layers. You go into the underground of the Palazzo Valentini and end up in the house of a Roman nobel family. A sure sign of how rich this family was, is that they had their own spa. You walk over a glass floor over the excavations and a light- and multimedia show explains you where the pool was and how the hot water tubes ran. You see a fantastic Roman mosaic that has been partly destroyed by an earthquake and the missing parts are reconstructed by light. The whole visit is done by a voice.over of famous Italian historian Piero Angela. Another strong point is the simple fact that they are open on Mondays, when almost every other museum in Rome (and Europe) is closed.

Success! June 1 tickets now available. I finally just got 2 tickets for the English tour on Friday June 1. I called this morning at 5 am US time and the answer was still "They are not available yet. Maybe after lunch." I just called back (7:45 am east coast US time), and they were available. I am sorry I forgot to ask if the whole month is now available for purchase, for those who need later in the month.(I have been calling for over a month every couple days, and more frequently lately when they would say, "tomorrow")

well worth it !. I read of this attraction on TripAdvisor but, travelling without a local phone and limited internet it was not easy to book. I decided to call in as I was in the area and was told the English speaking tours were fully booked and that they could not take a booking for the following month when I returned to Rome ...very disappointing for an international tourist... BUT... A quick check of the numbers revealed that they COULD squeeze us in for the next tour.. in an hour! Wonderful service from the girls at the counter.. thank you !After walking the Palantine/Forum/Colosseum etc I had an appreciation for the amazing work the local archaeologists carry out but this experience really brought old Rome to life for me. The sound and light show was extremely well done and the final video on Trajan's Column was a fascinating history lesson in itself. This would be an ideal excursion on a rainy day but one I would recommend any day.The tour numbers are strictly limited and there is a good reason for this so do book ahead if you can... I was lucky but I am sure many others have missed out as word of mouth continues to spread about this state-of-the-art museum

Really interesting!. This is a really unique experience that uses technology to explore what used to be an ancient Roman house. The use of technology to give visuals of what the house was like at the time was very impressive! It is also really informative.You will need to make a reservation for the time slot you want. The price is reasonable for the experience.

A house of Romans, very near to Palazzo Ciancaleoni Domus. In Piazza Venezia, there is a new Museum. Palazzo Valentini where you can see how was a House of a Roman Family of the Roman Republic. I usually suggest that experience to the Guests of Palazzo Ciancaleoni.

Underground villa!. This museum is seen by walking on a glass floor, over the archaeological site of a villa. The technology is simply amazing. No words or images can explain the experience. Just go!!At the time of our visit, there was one english tour per day, at 1:15pm.

A Virtual Tour of Ancient Rome. Do not miss the chance to see this museum: glass walkways allow you to peer into the ruins of a storied ancient Roman house. The fabulous light show and graphics fill in staircases from a single step or complete a mosaic floor from just a few blotches of remaining tiles. Incredible!!

State of theart ancient Roman history. This is probably the most extraordinary high-tech "history facility" we have ever visited. As others have said, this Roman villa was destroyed by an earthquake and thereafter buried under a renaissance building and has recently been discovered. You go beneath the Renaissance Palazzo Valentini and are shown by the use of extraordinarily modern visual techniques, the way in which the house was designed and functioned for an extremely important Roman family living close to the centre of ancient Rome. Many of the original rooms and walls exist which makes the experience all the more interesting.The floors are suspended glass and the streets, buildings, walls etc are disclosed to you by clever lighting as well as the use of lasers and wall projections and a continuous commentary. There is also an exhibition of all the artefacts that have been discovered.On our tour, a woman and her mother arrived and seemed to be able to persuade the guides to sell her tickets there and then or at least use non allotted time slots. This was a mistake because it led to our tour being overbooked which means that towards the end of the tour when we were watching a film, three people had to stand for about 30 min and no additional chairs were provided.However, if the organisers limit the number of people to the right number (or increase the number of chairs) then all should be well.The tour is about 90 min The exhibition can only take a limited number of people. I think about approximately 20. You move as a group from room to room as if you were travelling through the house which is underneath and above you as you walk. Therefore, space is limited because it is within an enclosed area. The film towards the end of the tour takes you through the history of ancient Rome as shown onTrajan's Column. TIPS: It is absolutely essential to book and to do so well in advance. It is not suitable for people who cannot go up and down stairs or walk or stand for long periods of time. It is equally fascinating for adults and children. In fact, children will find it really thrilling way of learning about ancient Rome.Eating out: if you want to plan your trip around lunch, we strongly recommend a lovely restaurant nearby called Restorante Abruzzi-Via del Vaccaro good pasta, very reasonable prices with lovely surroundings and good service. See our review of it.This is a "do not miss attraction" but you must book early. There do appear to be some glitches on the website and in consequence, whilst it is not much of a comfort do persevere, it's worth it.
A hidden gem. Very informative, very interesting and well presented. Only difficulty is one tour per day in English and bookings can only be made online during the month of the visit.

Booking. Just passing on an FYI on the booking engine - I actually called the reservation line from Canada (the booking on-line system showed all the english seats were reserved already) - I had no problem getting a reservation today, for 31May12... The June calendar, though will not be available until 20May12. Hope this helps anyone trying to book - also you just reserve your spot & pay (or Roma Pass) when you get there.

Neat multimedia recreation of imperial Roman house. 90-minute or so tour of excavated Roman house with visual and sound effects. Entertaining and informative demonstration of how archaeologists peel back the layers and reconstruct the past, and how there remains much to be discovered.
