Groups are small, so book your tour well in advance. Only one English tour per day when we were there. Towards the end it did get a little repetitious (minus one star).

Just An Unbeleiveable Experience. The use of high-tech to recreate this incredible Roman home is startling, breathtaking, and really gives you a sense of our (wealthy) people lived. This is really a fascinating experience. Book your tickets ahead to make sure you get the English language tour -- groups are very restricted and the time slots sell out quickly.

If u can get in... Teach me how. Agreed with the great u can get in review. I had a roma pass which would allow me to enter this museum.However, there was no place for booking for Roma pass holders on the website. Calls to make bookings were not possible, I was put on hold on some voicemail. I went there 2x but all the english ones were sold out.Disappointing to say the least - but I am sure it is a good attraction judging by the reviews..

educational and entertaining. Fantastic and educational, using real archaelogical remains, lighting and graphics. Really helped us visualise parts of roman life and the technology they brought into wealthy homes in those times. Also fascinating, was the different levels of archaeology within and beneath the palace - where once was a road, was then a palace, which was then converted, by recycling anything to hand. Well worth a visit, and book online to guarantee a place.

Hopefully this will help you book this tour!. I had a heck of a time booking this tour. Would try with Mozilla Firefox browser and would get to "select" step but nothing would show up. Tried Internet Explorer and kept getting message that the site, ticketone, used JAVA. So went to JAVA site and downloaded JAVA for Firefox for free and then restarted the whole process and was able to book with no problem. I booked the last three English tickets left for May 24th. Hope this helps!Steph
Interesting Tour!. We stopped by early in the week and booked for the next day. Cool tour. Nothing else quite like it. Need to use your imagination. It's convenient to reach by many bus lines.
my kids just loved it.... what a way to spend an afternoon. all the ruins and 3D animations of the ancient mansion... I just felt like I traveled back in time. just wonderful experience

Great if you can get in :-(. There are set tour times and you have to join the tour to visit. There is one English tour at 1:15pm daily. On the Saturday we were told to return on Sunday. On Sunday we arrived 30 mins in advance but it was already sold out. You can't book in advance and can only pay on the day in person. Annoying. So get there really early and buy your tickets well in advance of the daily tour or risk disappointment.

Don't miss it!. Really an exiting experience, like visiting a house in the Roman era. Amazing what they did with the combination of the remains of old buildings together with modern technology. Reservations must be made.
Amazing. This was one of our highlites it gives you an amazing insight using lasers and light projection under the glass floors.This is a must do, you wont forget this visit.

Great Use of Technology. This was a unique and fascinating experience. The lighting and projections allow one to understand the site in a way that words alone cannot. Heed the advice to book this in advance. People who showed up at the last minute for the one daily English tour were turned away.
amazing site!. recreated with laser and projections, an ancient Roman villa discovered.

Great use of technology to bring the past to life. Many of Rome's most famous sites are visually inspiring on their own--the aqueducts, the Colosseum, the Pantheon, Michelangelo's dome at St. Peter's, etc.--but to really understand the evolution of Rome over 2,500 years, you have to go beneath the surface, and that is tough, because so much of what you see is decaying walls, broken remnants of pillars, foundations of buildings. It takes some imagination to process these ruins in the context of real people, real life. This exhibit does exactly that in perhaps the coolest application of modern visual technology that I've ever seen. Lasers and light projection "fill in the blanks" to show the hallways where the rubble of staircases led, extend the stubs of columns back to their full height and complete the pattern of remnants of mosaic tile floors. My 11-year-old loved it, and so did we. If you plan to go, you really need to book in advance, as most days, they only do one English tour and the group size is limited to maybe a couple dozen people. This might be the best 90-minute investment we made in our recent trip.

Great Introduction!. This site really helped us to understand what we were seeing when we went on to Pompeii and Herculaneum. The virtual reconstructions filled in the gaps in my understanding. Very worthwhile!

A great way to bring ancient Rome to life. This is a great place to visit, especially with children as it really helps to bring the ruins to life. It makes a nice change to be in a small group and to use modern technology. Some of the special effects were very good. There is also now an option to see a little more and to learn more about Trajans column - our 13 yr old was really impressed with this as it was one of the 1st things we discovered! This costs 4 Euros.
beautiful and a great sight in Rome. great place to add to your 'things to see' list. Nice area, beautiful sights and places to eat

Fantastic technology display. To be honest having read the reviews here we were slightly disappointed with our recent visit - I think we were expecting too much, or at least more. Having said that the presentation and use of modern technology to bring the place to life was excellent and I'd recommend it if you've never seen anything like it before.

Fascinating Insight into Roman Life. Make sure you book in advance, numbers are strictly limited and several disappointed families were turned away while we were there. The special effects are great, and give terrific insight into patrician life and the organisation of state. Palazzo Valentini is also the administrative headquarters of the Roman police and there is a handy (and cheap!) cafe for the workers in the courtyard next to the ticket office.
Newest Attraction. What a wonderful surprise! A must see in the heart of Rome. Need to get tickets before you go.

Very informative. One of the highlights of our trip in Rome, this visit makes you understand a lot more about the Antique Rome and how sophisticated was this civilization. Great display, with lights and interesting explanations. Good to visit the forum right after.

fantastically presented. I booked the Domus for my first full day in Rome in the hope that this tour would give me an insight into life in ancient Rome and I wasn't disappointed. The Domus is beautifully presented using modern technology to good effect. You walk on glass floors over the excavations in darkened rooms as the recorded commentary describes what you are looking at and lights pick out the area under the floor that is being referred to so even a novice can make out the baths etc. Images are also projected on to the walls showing what would have been the gardens and recreations of rooms etc. I also found the 'fly over' tour of ancient Rome very informative and enjoyable. All of this for 7.50 euros - excellent value and well worth a visit - make sure you book as there is only one english tour a day and it is fully booked most days.
Fantastic. This is well worth booking, amazing insight into Ancient Rome. You must book, only one English tour per day

Fascinating. What a treat, to be able to visualise what an entire mosaic floor would have looked like - this very clever exhibition makes the most of the unexpected find beneath the Palazzo Valentini - an intact and beautiful roman house.. The discovery is not tempered by the fact that the Palazzo Valentini was built right through the middle of it; rather, this adds to the intrigue and mystery, as you find yourself asking "did they see this and ignore it, or did they miss it altogether, and if that's the case, how? Like most attractions in Rome, very reasonably priced, and well worth the money.

Quite an experience!. Well done tour with up-to-date technology. Showed up on a Thursday without a reservation and was told we had to book in advance online. Then they took pity on us and we paid there for Monday's tour.

Multimedia path to a piece of ancient Rome. An interesting contrast between the old and new although by its nature ( the recorded English tour) it was a programmed ( somewhat hurried) trip though the site. It didn't allow enough time for all to see with the number of people on the tour. It seems most appropriate for teenagers _ those on the tour got a kick out of walking on the glass. To me its not the #1 attraction in Rome. Coop

A fantastic trip to the past of ancient Rome!!!. This is a visit you must not lose when in Rome... you can really go back to the past visiting the roman houses of powerful families during the empire. Technology has given a big help to reconstruct how those people (maybe rich families or senators) lived in these amazing houses (located underground) decorated with beautiful mosaic floors, baths, etc. The introduction and multimedia explanation along the visit will make you understand how was a daily life in these roman houses located in the heart of ancient Rome. You will learn a lot in less than one hour!!!

Best place to visit in Rome. My husband and I went to this place because it was part of the Roma Pass we purchased. We were completely wowed by this interactive museum. I loved walking on the glass floor looking at the different levels of different houses from 1st century to present time. It is amazing the way everything is presented to you. I also enjoyed watching videos and laser light presentations. The stories were very good too. Floor mosaic is so beautiful. This is a must see in Rome. It is nothing like I have seen before. So good!!! English tour was at 2 pm.
Relaxing. I loved this place, it is breathtaking and would be beautiful in warm weather. A really relaxing location to get away from the madness of the centre
A museum that tells the story!. Must see. Interactive multimedia presentation is amazing. You will remember this one.
A must. One of the top things to see in Rome. English tour only once a day at time we visited, so recommend booking well in Advance

Highly Recommended to Anyone Who Has An Interest In Ancient Rome!. Booked tickets online at ticketone.it. This was a really fantastic visit. The tour in English is at 1:15 and needs to be booked in advance. As a Lecturer in Roman History at a UK university I was not expecting to see anything new, but was really quite pleasantly surprised at how informative and interesting this visit was. It is exciting, not just for the new archaeological material that has been found at the site, but for just how clever the reconstructions could be. Book ahead and go - you won't regret it!
Worth being visited. This is a top attraction for every history lover. completely worthwhile on its own, its location affords an opportunity to kill two birds with one stone. please don't miss it.

Roma. Everybody who saw Rome know that he or she will want to return there… Modern Rome is lively city and has some excellent restaurants and nightlife. This is place incomparable to any other city on the planet. When you see The Mausoleum, The Colosseum and The Pantheon, you should also visit Vatican! Italian summer rain in this photo gallery is amazing:) http://www.jp2love.com/gallery,5,JP2-Places.html
Start here for a great overview. This tour helps make sense of the rest of the ruins you will be seeing.
see ancient rome. Really helps you understand ancient Rome's life. Very different from other scavi tours.

Fantastic display!. Such a well done exhibit -- very different than a museum. You can see below ground to the ruins, hear great narration, stunning special effects fill in parts of the ruins and mosaics, etc., that you would otherwise need to imagine. Very exciting way to see a rich Roman home at the height of the Empire.

Amazing new attraction!. We loved this 1 hour top notch experience. We took our children ages 10 and 6 and everyone agreed it was great. I bought our tickets online, since there are limited spaces available for an english tour (we went at 1:15). I think this attraction was so well done and would have paid a whole lot more.
Wondrous. All I'll say is thet this is an experience not to be missed. You will be awed!
GOOD NEW ATTRACTION. A good detailed look at recent excavations of a Roman House and how it would have looked.When we were there, in Feb, there was an English tour at 1.15

Finally interactive version of ancient Rome. The place is somewhat familiar, since it is inside an ancient building of Rome city centre.It is through the excavation made under it that they found what was there since Traian's period.The most amazing thing is the huge column laying down and the mosaics.The virtual reconstraction is something! you have to see it to appreciate the work made by archeologists and computer grafic designers! Available in most of the main languages and cheap! A new thing to see ancient monuments!

Its all true - including italian bureaucracy which is no different to any other bureaucracy. I turned up at the door on a Monday to make a booking at the office . The "helpful" provincial police officer standing outside in the snow stopped me from entering the building let alone getting to the booking office. He told me it was closed because of the snow. I told him I only wanted to make a booking. He went into the office and returned saying I had to do that by telephone. So remember to head straight through the entry portal until you reach the open quadrangle. The Domus office is well signed and obvious on the left but you do not see it until you are in the quadrangle.I phoned in my booking that night for 9.30 am the next morning. It is only 4 euros for old people but a 1.50 euro booking fee. The visit however is worth much more in anybody's money.At 9am the next morning I was told to wait. There is, just beside the Domus booking office a really good caffe (probably subsided for the staff) with an upstairs mezzanine where you can drink coffee and eat your cornetto and listen to the chiacchiera while you wait or following your visit. There is also a palatial toilet on the opposite side of the quadrangle to the Domus ( in the provincial office building itself) which you get to through the first imposing doorway you see on the right when you first emerge into the quadrangle. The toilets are down stairs - again to the right. Nice to know if you ever find yourself in a spot in Piazza Venezia! You might have to tell the policeman, if challenged, that you are visiting the domus and have been told the toilet is "in here."At 9.30 in the Domus office I was told I would have to come back at 1pm because they did not have the english guide. In fact the problem was I was the only person who had turned up for the tour and they could not be bothered. Eventually I was assigned a guide whose english was better than my italian but the diorama virtual experience speaks for itself in any language. Other reviewers have covered it well. You do have to watch your footing at first until you get used to the lighting and walking on thick see through glass over open space with the occassional unexpected step or ramp. A bit like skiing in a whiteout. Rome is better in winter than in summer if you have good gear and warm accommodation.
Excellent.. Must see. Spectacular. Especially mapping on the walls. Highly recommended.
This is a must see in Roma, must call for reservations and request tour in English. Mulit Media exhibition of an old Roman house, well worth the visit... must book in advance..

Well worth it!. Wonderful small tour in English with lights and sound and guide. Experience a roman home from the 2nd century. Entrance is a little tricky - look for the police station door and walk through the 2nd gate.
Great light show. Very well presented - tho less breath-taking than San Clemente which similarly has different levels/eras of building. Excellent presentation

Multimedia Museum. Le Domus Romane Di Palazzo Valentini is a good example of how the internet is changing the way we travel and the importance of current informational sites like TA. I checked TA before planning my 4 days in Rome and was very intrigued by this #1 attraction that was unheard of just a few years ago. It’s just across from the Colonna Palace which I had on my itinerary so as instructed by TA reviewers, (and I firmly agree), I booked a reservation on the internet. Their internet site is very easy to navigate and make reservations which are necessary, even when visiting Rome “off season” as I was. The attraction is a multimedia presentation of the archaeological remains of an important Roman house build around 1585. Rooms, mosaics, baths are reconstructed using images projected on the walls/floor/ceiling with explanations given in several languages (pick the language you want when you book your reservation) to give you a better idea of what the house looked like. They also use an large reconstructed model to demonstrate it’s appearance “back in the day”.I enjoyed it but I’m not quite as enthusiastic as most of the other TA reviewers and would not compare it to seeing Pompeii, Herculaneum or Ephesus. They do a very good job with the little actual ruins that they have and I especially enjoyed the reconstruction of the floor mosaic. But for me, the “star” is the multimedia presentation, not the actual ruins. Because of time constraints, it often felt like we were being herded from room to room by our logistics “guide” and there isn’t enough time to linger over the displays of antique artifacts. Thankfully the number of people is limited, as some rooms are small and at times it was difficult to see the visual reconstruction because of people blocking the view. But overall it’s well done and these are minor complaints. The presentation takes about 1 hour 30 minutes and includes a very interesting reconstruction of Rome, but grab a seat quickly as they didn’t have enough chairs for our group and by then you are ready to sit! Most of the presentation is done in the dark, walking over Plexiglas floors/steps which might be unsettling for some people, but that’s what the logistics “guide” was there for…moving the group through the presentation. No photographs are allowed during the presentation. Overall I give Palazzo Valentini high marks for its innovative, creative multimedia museum and it’s definitely worth seeing, but #1 in Rome…I’m not so sure! Enjoy!

Great visual experience. This was a great experience, it gives an idea about how an Ancient Roman family lived. Also this house was one of the most lavish Roman "Domus" houses. The visual effects are great. Yet it is a little weird at first to walk on Plexiglas in dark.If you are going to go, go on your first day because it tells a lot about Rome in general.Not the best attraction in Rome though, that was a little overrated.

Ancient Rome comes alive!. I expected this to be touristy and a bit cheesy, but it was great! By means of light projections, a villa of ancient Rome, really comes alive. You see the fragments, as they are, and the projections expand the room, or floor, or pool, to its full glory. Well worth a visit.

Excellent experience for kids and grownups. The multimedia reconstruction of the Roman House is very well done and the house comes back to life again. It mesmerized and entertained our kids (age 8 and 5) for almost two hours. This is very interesting if you are knowledgeable about Roman history and a must-do if you are a first timer. Don't miss the combo with "La colonna di Traiano", a shorter visit (about 30m) with a very good video in the same facility. Visits are available in English and we suggest to reserve in advance.

I would have paid double for this it is so good.... This is a pure delight and about the best thing to see in Rome. Absolutely amazing. A secret little gem!!!! A little difficult to find... The address is Palazzo Valentini but it is actually at the bottom of the hill Via IV Novembre. The English tour is once a day at 13.15. I would say booking is essential as it is a small tour. I can imagine that in summer you'll have to book well in advance. Bizarrely you cannot pre book at Domus Romane and we were sent to Torre Argentina to the large book shop where there is a booking agent 'booth'. Its only a short walk away and the bonus is that there are ruins there where Caesar was assassinated which is another little advertised thing to see. Yet another bonus for Cat / animal lovers is the cat sanctuary in the ruins which opens at 12.00 till 6.00. www.romancats.com Well worth a visit. Check out www.palazzovalentini.it for details of Domus Romane and telephone numbers / links to sales networks for bookings. Enjoy!!!!!!!

Don't miss this astonishing site.. We booked this after reading a trip report on Trip Advisor. The tour gave a comletely different perspective on ancient ruins and managed to bring the excavations to life. Excellent use of lighting and graphics to show what has been discovered and how archeologists fit all the puzzle pieces together. It feels a little odd walking on glass floors and viewing what is underneath but you soon become accustomed to it. Highly recommended tour.
Great high tech visit to ancient Roman home.. This is a very good attraction in Rome. Unique high tech tour of an ancient Roman villa. Interesting for everyone. One our favorite stops in Rome.

Make a reservation days ahead!!. Was turned away immediately. English tours are once per day at 1:15pm. Make your reservation a week ahead I'd say or more! The building is not so well known to locals, at least in my experience. It's near piazza venetia. Aka the wedding cake building. Go through the courtyard to the left.

UNICO! Sito da non mancare di vedere a Roma. Straordinario, eccellente presentazione, coinvolgente... finalmente qualcosa di moderno per far conoscere nel migliore dei modi i Fori Romani, la Domus Romana, casa di un'antica ricca famiglia della vecchia Roma. Uno dei migliori siti mai visitati finalmente a Roma! Congratulazioni agli ideatori, esecutori di questa magnifica visita, sperando che prendano spunti gli altri innumerevoli siti romani, per far si che questa città eterna diventi veramente una eterna città e non una città morta.Che idea di prendere Piero Angela e che idea di ricostruire attraverso la tecnologia delle luci, quel che manca del passato. Finalmente ho capito la dinamica dell declino di Roma, da grande città piena di monumenti, templi, palazzi marmorei... diventata un paesello di pecorai dentro lo Stato Pontificio. il degrado dei Fori Romani negli anni e' chiaramente visibile nella mostra... Grazie e ci sto portando tutti gli amici che vengono a Roma
Insightful Tour. Brilliantly done tour giving some insight into the Roman way of life hundreds of years ago. Clever use of lighting.

Great Way to see Ancient Rome and Really understand how a family lived. Great multimedia presentation over an excavated early Roman home. You walked above the excavation on plexiglass while various features are illuminated below. A very detailed narration goes along with the presentation and you move from room to room viewing the complex. Tours are available in English or Italian. We were not able to make it to the English tour and opted for the Italian one. Even though my Italian is very limited, I enjoyed it and followed what was being shown. My husband, whose command of Italian is better, compared notes with me afterwards and I really did get most of what was beeing shown. Tour groups are very small and you really get to see a lot. Located just off of Piazza Venezia. Entrance is on via IV Novembre.

A hidden gem!. We found out about this place on a TripAdvisor forum and are we glad we did! A museum like no other. The multimedia presentation is fascinating and gives you a true appreciation of life in ancient Rome. Another bonus is that it is one of the few museums that is open on Mondays.

Outstanding archaeological presentation. A very intimate and exciting guided tour to a set of recent excavations beneath the Palazzo Valentini, whose day job is to be the home of the regional government. Perhaps that explains something of the surely prodigious funding which has been applied to present and render immediately comprehensible a series of excavations. What may not be apparent from the website or the ticket agency is how small a group you are in - I counted 15 on a day during which the notices said all tours were sold out. If there is someone in your family who is studying Latin or Ancient History, this should be the first thing you book.

Excellent lively and well balanced presentation. make sure you book and have plenty of time to get there; a little hard to find in the building; ask for directions at the entrance- some italian is useful here; as others say, the presentation is superb and will flesh out sites like the palatine and the forum

Absolutely Outstanding Visit. We are unashamed lovers of Roman historical sites and quite capable of spending hours picking round the ruins but this place should be on everyone's must see list for Rome. It is simply a work of genius and imagination that brings the life of a wealthy Roman mansion of the 4th century to life using the original excavations wonderfully presented under glass floors together with state of the art graphics, lights and multi media effects. These special effects make the ruins completely understandable and enjoyable by everyone of all ages. Quite beautiful and fascinating - we were thrilled by the visit. It's an absolute bargain for the price and we only wish more of the archaeological sites could have the same treatment. Please please go and see this.
Outstanding -- Favorite Activity of our week in Rome. Very well done and a great value. Parents and kids (12 & 9) all enjoyed it. As noted, limited availability so book ahead.

Excellent Tour of the Excavations of an Imperial Era Patrician's Home. The one hour tour of the excavations of a patrician Imperial era home is the perfect introduction to seeing the ruins of Rome as they would have appeared. Technology is used to enhance the mosaic fragments, bath, and living quarters. It adds to your vision and imagination, doesn't over-whelm or move into a 'Disney' approach. Very well done. An English tour is offered only at 1:15pm on the days open (not daily), and there are limited slots, so you need to call in advance to reserve a space.

This was fabulous!. I've been visiting Rome for many years and was beginning to feel antiquitied out. However, this tour really revved up my interest in ancient Rome. We both thought (two adult family members) it was one of the best tours we had taken. Other reviewers below describe the tour very well but what struck us was the feeling that we were there in ancient Rome. The English - speaking tour of 15 people is now once a day at 1:15 and it sells out fast, we were told. We bought our tickets that morning but it was apparently a fluke that two tickets were available. As seniors, we paid 4 Euros and the tour was a little over an hour.Recommended for grammar school age children and all others.

Unforgettable journey into the Roman Empire. Difficult to review since any word would not recognize the magnificent experience. Been there twice and I will be back again.. and again!!! Highly reccomended.. and costs almost like a magazine!!!

Modern Media Meets Ancient Rome. The family agreed that this was one on the highlights of our trip to Rome. It was the best 6 euros ( each ) we spent. I had tried to reserve tickets ahead of time, but the booking site did not show August calendar before we left. We took a chance and showed up Tuesday Aug. 9, but it was closed. So we went back Wednesday when it opened and reserved tickets for that afternoon English tour at 1:30. It is in a government building, so there is security. Ask for the Domus Romane and they will point the way. Walking on a glass floor takes a little getting used to, but once the media show begins to tell the story, you forget about walking on glass ! It was a great presentation and made the ruins really come to life. We highly recommend it. PS Students under 25 got a 2 euro discount

Definitely Worth Seeing!. This was a favorite of my 15 year old son. The well preserved ruins mixed with the technology used to recreate the atmosphere of the palazzo gave an excellent feel of how the family would have lived at the time. We reserved the tickets for the English tour in advance. They did sell out, so I suggest advance purchase. Definitely worth visiting!

Another magnificent find in the heart of Rome. You can understand why Rome doesn't have an underground. Every time you lift a stone you find a new treasure.This is the latest addition to the collection. Hiding under the rennaissance Palazzo Valentini (today hosting the Government of the Province of Rome) this magnificent Roman Villa was discovered. The reconstruction not only reminds us of the advanced plumbing and heating techniques but also thanks to a mixed media show it gives us a feel for the internal decoration frescoes and mosaics. As a bonus, there are moments when rennaisance and antiquity pile up on top of each other giving insights into both.Very well presented tour. There is one a day in English so check first.great discovery
